description:
Wonderful food in a nice restaurant that serves tapas. Everything we ordered were delicious. The service was efficient. There were many food choices available. 

The standout dishes we tried were the stew, tripes, calamari in aioli and paella. 

Definitely a must come back again place.
author: Michael D.

description:
Walked out of this place really disappointed! I had really high expectations for this place because of the yelp reviews! I'm starting to not trust yelp with all these false high ratings for restaurants!!! 

We ended up getting vermicelli seafood with white wine, pork medallions, and the empanadas. Pork medallions tasted like it was microwaved and overcooked. There was really no flavor. The vermicelli seafood came with three or four mussels some calamari, small pieces of fish and shrimp. It was ok, something I could've made at home and I was very unimpressed. The empanadas... meh. It was Soggy and tasteless. 

Compared to other restaurants, I've had way better. I most likely wont be coming back here. Maybe our expectations were little too high.......
author: C O.

description:
This is a like a hidden gem in SF, I don't get why i didn't discover this place sooner.  My friend Adna Y. recommended this place, and you have to understand i had my doubts before i arrived.  Not because I don't trust her, well maybe not completely, but she does usually pick a place we don't all like.  But times have change and know i call her "Oh wise one".  This place was the jackpot 

We arrived fabulously late as our other friends were waiting.  The host wasn't going to seat us until the whole party arrived, which i understand.  Upon entering this dimly lit restaurant I notice there are different types of customers here.  You have families, couples, friends and people here on a first date. So far I'm loving the ambiance.  

We started out with two tapas 
Mejillones Al Azafran - which was the Mussels sauteed in white wine, garlic, tomatoes, onions & saffron.  This was cooked well, and the sauce went perfectly with the mussels, it didn't over power the flavor which was good. I actually don't even like mussels but this turned out to be well liked by all the people in m party. 

Calamares A La Plancha Con Aioli which was Grilled squid with aioli.   I really need to stop sharing food with my friends. It just breaks my heart to see such good food go into other people's stomach.  This was by far my favorite dish of the night.  The octopus and the squid went so well with a the Aioli sauce,   It was very creamy and a a perfect pinch of sweetness to it.  You can feel that it was cooked with love.  I fell in love with this dish.  

For my entree i got the 
Costillas Breseadas A La Cerveza which was the Short ribs braised with beer, onions, garlic and tomatoes .  This came with mashed potatoes, and the ribs was so tender I didn't even need a knife.    

you can also get the dish for couples, for the price of 36.00 it's not bad.  It's paella with mussels and calms.  

I would totally come back here, but i have to admit parking was hard.  I would recommend taking a Taxi here if you want to avoid trying to find parking.  You have to get the Sangria here no matter what. It was so good and its freshly made at their restaurant.  I'll be back!
author: Belinda C.

description: Love the personable service of this place! I finally had a chance to come here for dinner after bookmarking after seeing it on Check Please! years ago - but I heard it's closing very soon! Maybe it already closed? So sad. Loved the Spanish tapas and lovely selection of Spanish wines. I only went here once, but I'm going to miss knowing that it was always there. I'm sure lots of regulars over the years are really going to miss this charming place with wonderful food and service. All the best to you, Zarzuela!
author: Maile N.

description:
I love it when I find a great neighborhood Spanish tapas place.  This restaurant is nestled in the middle of Russian Hill (Union and Hyde) and just serves great tapas.

My friend and I ordered a couple of the specials (fried smelt and padron peppers) as well as the dates, shrimps, octopus, squid, paella and the crema catalana. In short, it was way too much food but we wanted to try everything (I ended up taking a doggy bag home).  Everything was on point. The octopus was the house specialty and I really enjoyed that. The paella was cooked perfectly (not sure if this is the best I've had but it's up there).  To me, the most special tapas was the fried smelt.  I wouldn't hesitate ordering the same items the next time I'm here. 

Everything here is nice and rustic.  The restaurant itself and the music they play literally makes you feel like you are in Spain (and I've been).  The service was nice and attentive. The above meal plus a glass of wine including tax and tip costs about $80 per person - it's about what you would expect to spend to eat a nice dinner in SF these days.   Highly recommended!!!
author: Andrew S.

description:
This quaint, small restaurant at the corner of hyde has the most attentive and friendliest service I've ever experienced. The entire meal from beginning to end was satisfying and we even got to witness a server sing a spanish song! 
For the hot tapas we ordered:
-Calamari with aioli sauce: Anything with aioli sauce is bound to taste awesome
-Chorizo in wine sauce: my favorite tapas of the night
-Empanada of the day: slightly different than most empanadas I've had before due to the thicker, crusty outer layer, but still good nevertheless.
All delicious and at the right portions to leave enough room for the paella valenciana! (cause what is a spanish meal without a paella?) 

For dessert we had the Crema Catalana which is pretty much a creme brûlée

Would highly recommend this place! The atmosphere is truly welcoming and I liked the fact that the restaurant wasn't too loud to carry out a conversation
author: Sui N.

description:
I convinced my coworkers to check out Zarzuela, which my fellow Yelpers helped me find as one of the best places in San Francisco to eat one of my all time favorite dishes: paella. Zarzuela didn't disappoint.

Upon ordering the paella (and reading the menu), you're warned the paella is made fresh, for you, and that it'll take 30 minutes to cook. Not a problem for me (I'll wait that long for some good food).  For starters, we dined on the complimentary bread and olive oil for a bit before ordering dates wrapped in pancetta (they are a definite must try here).

The paella was cooked to perfection!  The rice was moist and soft, yet not turned to mush.  The seafood mixed in was all tender (clams and shrimp tend to get rubbery when over cooked). The saffron was used to perfection: giving the rice it's golden yellow hue and slight floral like scent which came through the brine smell of the seafood.  It was a pleasure to devour. 

A warning: online, the paella is listed at $17.00.  That must be a lunch price or something, because when you're in the restaurant at dinner time, there is no other option than the $36.00, serves two, option.  

Ultimately, the food was amazing.  The service left a little to be desired (our waiter seemed a bit to pretentious for me, and hated the fact that our group wanted to split the check, and refused to split it more than four ways). When asked about some of the menu items, he seemed overly bothered that we didn't know about the dishes. So, four stars was almost three for that reason, yet might have been five if he was nicer.
author: Rafael A.

description:
Delicious Tapas, not Patas!

Give me a couple of glasses of good sangria and I confuse tapas with patas (legs) before you know it, but forget me! Zarzuela has been here for so many years and the place still buzzes come dinner time!

Every time I go there I tell myself I want to have their paella, which is made for two and takes 30 minutes to prepare, but then I start with their sangria and tapas and before you know I am too full to have anything more, not counting dessert of course! By the way, talking dessert, they serve one of the best flans I have ever had in the Bay Area!

As for the service, excellent! Most of the servers have been there for years and know the menu inside and out. They are very helpful if you have questions and are sure to get you exactly what your tummy desires in nice little delicious plates!
author: Afshin A.

description:
We come here every single time we are in the Bay Area. Zarzuela has become family to us, and it is no wonder, with a two decade history and the consistency throughout the last 20 years. 

On this recent visit, I took photos like I always do, and owner/maitre d' Andy came over and said "you must have 1000s of photos by now".

My son always gets the crab bisque, as he has done so for the last 15 years. The boquerones is my favorite, as are the gambas ajillo. We always order the jamon Iberico with pan tomate, as well as pulpo. 

We've since moved away from the paella Valenciana, and now order the soupy paella instead. 

Eating here is like coming home for a glorious home cooked meal.
author: Anita L.

description:
I had high hopes for Zarzuela given the amount of reviews, ratings, and people waiting outside on a chilly SF night for a table (!!), but I was not impressed. 

I took Momma Nguyen here and we ordered the pulpa a la gallega (poached octopus and potatoes) and a Paella a la Valencia to share. Wish we could have ordered more tapas, but the paella was already a huge portion just for two of us. The pulpa a la gallega was okay. Aside from the rice that was stuck on the bottom of the pan, the paella was flavorless and bland. 

Perhaps I would skip the paella and just go with the tapas next time.. IF I ever make it back here. Our neighboring table had some squid and shrimp which looked appetizing. 

Tons of people waiting outside, though. So either we don't get it or were just unlucky.
author: Laverne N.

description:
Super authentic Spanish food. The tapas were all amazing, especially the Serrano ham and croquettes! 

Definitely recommend if you're looking for some delicious tapas!
author: Monica L.

description:
They don't take reservations, but I came on a Saturday night and the wait was maybe ~30 min for a group of 4. 

This place is a very underrated place in SF and a very popular spot for locals. The menu is great/comprehensive and authentic Spanish and the staff is all really great. Loved the paella especially and would definitely come back!
author: Kimberly T.

description:
I had never eaten at a Spanish restaurant before coming to here, but if you would've asked me to describe one, my mind would've come up with Zarzuela. We had an excellent experience here, from the sangria to the snails to the 'zerts, and it'll be on my list if we return to the Bay Area. 

We were seated right away, but we had to go into the 'back room', which actually added the to charm and made me feel like I was in a real restaurant in Spain, having to follow a native Spaniard through arched doorways to reach our table. 

My wife got the sea bass, and I'm not sure what the sauce on it was, but it was amazing. I wasn't as hungry, so I did the snails. They come on a thin crispy bread and covered in a green sauce that was a perfect compliment to the mushroom-like taste and texture of the snails. 

The food was great, the service was excellent, the ambiance perfect, and I'm so glad we stumbled upon Zarzuela! Check it out!
author: Shane K.

description:
tl;dr - delicious tapas at an affordable price

Came here with 4 other friends on a Saturday night around 7 pm and was told the wait would be around 45 minutes for our group of 5. That was pretty accurate and we ended up getting seated a little before 8. In the process of waiting, I did notice all the smaller groups of 2-4 people got seated much more quickly, so I would recommend coming here with 4 or less people to get seated faster.

There is a main dining area where the tables are placed very close together and I can imagine would make for a loud dining experience, but luckily we were seated in the back where it was much quieter.

Two people in our group weren't too hungry so they did their own thing while the three of us split a couple tapas family style. We ordered;

Croquetas de jamon y pollo ($7.25) - ham and chicken croquettes. I love getting croquettes at tapas spots and these really hit the spot 

Gambas ajillo ($9.25) - shrimp sauteed in garlic and olive oil. The garlic flavor was strong so I'd recommend ordering this dish if you like the combination of shrimp and garlic

Pulpo a la gallega ($17.95) - poached octopus and potatoes. Zarzuela is known for this dish (there's even a framed SF Chronicle article about Zarzuela by Michael Bauer in the waiting area that specifically calls out this dish) so I definitely knew we had to order it. It did not disappoint as the octopus was some of the most tender I've ever had

Paella a la valenciana ($36) - Spanish rice cooked with seafood, chicken, and vegetables. Serves two according to the menu. I love paella, and after many disappointing encounters with paella dishes in the city, I am happy to report that the paella here is legit and has the saffron infused flavor I expect from this dish. There was a generous amount of seafood and chicken as well. By the end of the meal I was super stuffed but still coludn't help picking away at the rice in the paella because it was so good!!

I would be remiss to not mention the amazing service we received in my review. I forgot the name of our server, but he was very attentive and accommodated all of our requests with a smile on his face. He was very knowledgeable about the menu; almost everything we ordered was on his recommendation and none of the dishes disappointed. In addition my friend asked for a wine recommendation from him and loved the wine he selected, so he knows his wines as well.

Parking is all along the street, and on a busy Friday/Saturday night is hard to find. I ubered here but another friend drove and she was lucky enough to find a spot 2-3 blocks away.

After tax and tip I paid about $38 for my meal (including a sangria).
author: Dianna H.

description: 3.5 stars for this hole in the wall Tapas place. Went with high expectations. Sort of didn't live up to the ratings I felt. Service was good, the sherry was decent. But the tapas were ok at best. Had the sausage braised in wine and the pork medallions. Didn't wow me, but was decent in taste. Ah, I think Toro Bravo and Ataula have spoilt me too much!
author: Sudipto G.

description:
This was my first time trying out a tapas place and let's just say it's exceeded my expectations. I had the squid, octopus, shrimp, potatoes with tomato sauce, the bruschetta plate and some sausages (beat sausages I've had in my entire life). All the above seafood were cooked to perfection. The squid and October were perfectly tendered and the shrimp sauce was delicious, I've never had better tasting shrimp.  

Service was great. The servers continually came out to take our dishes away and gives us new ones. The food came out fast too. I also really liked that they poured the sangria for us and came back with a bucket of ice to refill our drinks. 

I came on a Friday night around 9 and we were quickly seated. The location is great, street parking may be hard to come by, but I noticed that both a bus and the cable car stopped right in front of the restaurant.
author: Ami S.

description:
Yeah feels authentic as F*#% in here. There's plates with nice patterns hanging on the walls and the tables have white table clothes. Basically Spain. Also a painting of a bull with a few arrows sticking out of it. TBH, bull fighting is more barbaric than most people think. First they tie the genitals of the bull and then stick with some colorful arrows. Next they release the bull into a ring with some colorfully dressed bro who waves a large cape at it. Sometimes the bull gets the guy which honestly is ok by me. They deserve it. But mostly the bulls runs around at the cape with a bunch of people screaming and yelling because it's a big deal. At the end, they kill the bull with a sword. Like I said, barbaric. Never really will understand bull fighting. Or the NFL for that matter.

Aside from that, this place is great. Highly recommend it. It's not too expensive (most plates are under $10). Also they do paella but you'll have to wait 30 minutes to eat. Have no time or patience for that. #personalgoals2018
author: Andrew C.

description:
Welcoming neighborhood restaurant!  Lively atmosphere!  Dim lighting!  Wonderful place to relax for hours sipping, nibbling and chatting!  

A nice wine list Z had, the choice of Deobriga, Tempranillo, Rioja 2011 went perfectly with their tapas and paella!

Exquisite were their tapas: 1) outstanding was their Grilled Squid with Aioli 2) oh so sweet and lovely was their Langoustine with Garlic, Olive Oil, and Lemon Sauce; 3) unique was their Braised Quail!

As for Z's Paella a la Valenciana:  delicious it was on its own with plenty of flavorful white rice and nicely prepared seafood and chicken;  yet, missing I was of the taste of saffron, chorizo sausages, bits crunchiness of rice for this classic Spanish dish!

All in all, a fun evening it was!  Without hesitation, I would consider dropping in for their tapas when I'm staying close by in San Francisco next!

Cheers!
author: Jennifer Y.

description:
Zarzuela is so lovely! Located on Hyde street, next to many Italian eateries and wine bars, this spot's cuisine and heart stand out.

We started with these tapas:
- Pimientos Asados (roasted peppers, sherry vinegar, x..v. olive oil & garlic)
- Banderillas De Solomillo Cordero (grilled pork tenders marinated in pimenton, garlic and oregano)
- Gambas Ajillo (shrimp sautéed in garlic and olive oil)
- Patatas Bravas (fried potatoes with spiced tomato sauce)

We ended with the grand Paella (shareable for 2).

We also shared 2 sherrys and one of the best bottle of Albariño I've ever had. Everything is completely authentic, and the service was outstanding. It was someone's birthday at the table next to ours, and he quieted the whole restaurant by singing an entire happy birthday song to him. They really go above and beyond, here.
author: Ally H.

description: The transitional Spanish rice with sea food and chicken is great. Good for two people. The sangria is amazing. The location of this place is very easy to find. I would definitely take my mom here.
author: Yifei W.

description:
I looove their Paella, they have one of the best ones in the bay. It's very authentic, and I have been lucky enough to have tried it in Spain. It has a good amount of seafood and chicken, and that's hard to find many places only give you a little bit. The flavor is delicious!!! 

The waiter was super friendly, and made us feel extremely welcome. Explaining some dishes we didn't know what they were. 

The place in general can be a bit crowded but that's common for a Spanish restaurant. If you love Spanish food this is the place to go!
author: Cynthia A.

description:
Zarzuela or you mean Rawrrrzuela because their dishes have a great kick and punch to them! And where do I even start with their sangria?

Don't get me wrong Spanish Tapas can be pricey for small portions, but Zarzuela has fairly priced portions if you're in a bigger group, it will screw you if it's 3 or less! Just getting staples like the patatas bravas, Serrano ham, or the mushrooms championes will hit the spot,  but add the paella and the callos a la madrilena (sautéed tripe) and the paella valenciana (mixed seafood and chicken paella) and those are true stars! 

The servers are really nice and they are very knowledgeable based on what you like. Told them we like very saucy and flavorful dishes and they hooked us up. I would highly suggest coming here with a party no more than 6 as they serve bigger parties a little slower.
author: Eric Joseph D.

description:
We were in San Francisco and wanted to try this place for their Paella. It was a bonus that it was walking distance to our hotel

It was full upon arrival but we only had to wait a few minutes for a table

We ordered the paella but were told it would take 30 min. So we also ordered the Banderillas De Solomillo Cordero as an appetizer and enjoyed the bread 

The appetizer arrived and wow..it was delicious. The pork was tender served with a sort of gravy sauce and mashed potatoes

Then the paella arrived and they served it onto our plates. It was amazing..very tasty..and paired well with the Sangria 

Overall an amazing time. Great food and service. Recommended
author: Timmy T.

description:
Zarzuela is great, the boisterous atmosphere reminds me of Spain! 

I was seated at the corner table with a friend. While maneuvering was tricky with nearby tables within an arms distance, it was by far the best table which overlooked the entire restaurant.

Squid - 5/5 - definitely order this!
Shrimp in garlic oil - 4/5 - tasty! Surplus of oil but the garlic and shrimp were good
Croquetas - 3/5 - crunchy texture and liked the taste of them but the meat to filling ratio was lacking
Mussels - 3/5 - mussels were ok, broth was good
Mushrooms - 2/5 - I love mushrooms but wasn't fond of this dish. Prepared sour or sour mushrooms...?
Tortilla - 1/5 - had high hopes for this but it was the cold variety with an assortment of cold veggies

Overall I liked this place but would definitely try other dishes like the paella

All of the above came out to ~60
author: Jasper L.

description:
3.5 stars. Can't compare to that of Spain where we went for our honeymoon. Party of four. Seated right away around 530pm when they opened their doors. The service is on par but not over the top amazing. The food did come out pretty fast and their sangaria was good. 

#Shrimp - a bit overcooked
#Chorizo - not bad but I've had better
#Mushroom - very good. 
#Octopus - cooked very well. one of the highlights of our meal 
#Mussels - good but not something I would remember
#Paella- didn't take as long as we thought, about 30 minutes. No crust just plain rice. Loaded with plenty of toppings. My husband has made paella a couple of times and I think his is on par with their paella. 

One uni-sex bathroom in the back. Street parking. No reservations. Your party has to be there when you get seated.
author: Sarah C.

description:
Solid 4 stars.

I came here with my boyfriend on Friday night. We were seated within about 10 minutes. There is a nice warm waiting area towards the back of the building, near the restrooms, which was great as it was freezing outside.

We ordered:
-Sangria: A little sweet for my taste and not as strong as I would have liked 3/5
- Malbec: Boyfriend really like this. 5/5
- Grilled Squid: This was very good, not chewy. The aioli was very flavorful. 5/5
- Poached Octopus: lacking a bit in flavor. Potato to octopus ratio was disappointing. 3/5
- Prosciutto wrapped Dates w/Almonds: I loved this dish, it gave our meal a nice sweet touch. The sauce they serve is sort of like a berry jam and is great. 5/5
- Baked Goat Cheese in Tomato Sauce: YUM! This was my favorite part of dinner. I just wish they gave more crackers to eat it with as four crackers is just not enough. 5/5
- Paella a la Valenciana: Meh- I've had better paella. The seafood was fresh, chicken was dry, and flavor wasn't as strong as I would have liked. It was missing something, but I can't put a finger on what it was. 3/5

Overall 4/5 stars is well deserved. I'll probably come back and try other tapas.
author: Amanda R.

description:
Eat, drink, and be merry!

The goods:
Patatas bravas: Fried, chunky potato topped with a mildly tangy orange sauce. Great texture when eaten hot!

Seasoned mushrooms: Thinly sliced, stir-fried portabello mushrooms likely made with some white wine but also some other sauces. Very flavorful.

Grilled calamari: Delicate pieces of octopus paired with an aioli sauce.

Paella valenciana: Deeply ingrained flavors of the sea (shrimp, fish, mussels) with each mouthful of rice.

The wait hasn't ever been horrendous. The service is quaint.
author: Cici T.

description: AMAZING. If you want some amazing and authentic Spanish tapas, this is your place. The dates on the appetizer menu I couldn't eaten as dessert they were so good. The chorizo was awesome, and the portions were perfect to share. We had amazing wine, and the owner made his way to every table to make sure everyone was enjoying their dining experience. Super amazing. Super authentic. GREAT FIND in San Fran. We will be back!
author: Laura Y.

description:
PAELLA ON THE BRAIN!!!

I came here for one reason and one reason only.... can you guess?? The Paella Valenciana was perfection! Granted I've never tasted real Paella from Espana (going in September though!) this tasted like a very authentic and unadulterated version and I appreciated that is was full of seafood and meats. 

The empanadas were also delicious! The vegetables were perfectly cooked and seasoned and it didn't feel heavy or weigh me down at all. Perfect precursor to the main dish.

I probably drank too much spanish vino that night but no regrets. Perfecto all around!
author: Connie M.

description:
I was really not impressed. After reading so many reviews that this food was authentic, I was shocked to find the food mediocre in quality, fair in preparation, and a really small selection overall, given the high prices. 

We went on a Tuesday night, so there were plenty of seats available. Wine was tasty but overpriced. The octopus was a bit tough, but the sauce was delicious. The pork was bland and dry. The shishito peppers were tasty. They were out of a couple of the ports we ordered.

Overall, wouldn't return.
author: SisterMable S.

description: Very friendly service here. Went on a Tuesday night and it was oddly dead. Food was definitely good but not really mind blowing for the price. Wine selection was good also.
author: Rob R.

description:
We've wanted to try this restaurant for a while.  Friends were visiting from out of town who love to eat like we do, so we grabbed the opportunity.  We arrived shortly after they opened on a Wednesday evening.  We were immediately seated, but it fills up quickly.  We started our feast with several tapas and a carafe of sangria.  Usually I'm not a big fan of sangria.  Either it is too sweet or too sour.  Often a way to dispose of bad wine.  Not at Zarzuela.  The wine was light and refreshing.  One secret ingredient I tasted was just a touch of honey.

We shared several wonderful tapas.  Serrano ham (yum),shishito peppers, a chorizo empanada, callos  a la madrilena (yum yum) and pulpo a la gallega (yum yum yum).  We followed that with their famous Paella a la Valenciana.  Our server suggested paella for three should suffice for the four of us after all the tapas.

For purists who expect a perfect memory of a restaurant experience somewhere else, you may need to open your mind a little.  The tapas here are not tiny plates but a large plate meant to be shared.  The Paella also was wonderful.  Great seafood, vegetables and very well flavored rice.  Other reviewers have complained that the paella lacked certain things.  That is what makes paella so wonderful.  Each chef makes it in their unique style.  My advice about Zarzuela; come here hungry with an open mind.  You will leave comfortably full and VERY satisfied.

Gracias Zarzuela.
author: Daniel S.

description: Popped in on a Saturday night around 9:30. Good thing they're open till 10:30. The waiter was very helpful and gave no sense of hurry. The staple dish is the paella that's made to order. It was outstanding along with the various tapas. Don't forget the sangria!
author: Dan C.

description:
Perfect everything. Took a couple of friends and they loved it.
We had sangria, paella, prawns and braised quails.
Yummy food.
Friendly staff.
Cozy atmosphere.
Feels like home.
Can walk n every time have an amazing meal and be happy.
author: Mary N.

description: Yum! The tapas and the staff earned rave reviews! The tortilla espanola is muy rico, as was everything else we tried. Had the pleasure of being introduced to the chef and family. What a great experience. We'll return when in San Francisco, for sure!!
author: Sheri S.

description: One of the most enjoyable meals I've ever had, even including international. Everything is fresh, authentic and amazingly delicious. They've been serving the Russian Hill area for 24 years and is a local gem. The snails were out of this world.
author: Danielle S.

description:
I came to Zarzuela a few years ago - the experience was amazing, great quality, tasty tapas, original Spanish flavours... I've been dying to come back again and oh dear, what a disappointment. 

I ordered several dishes and the quality had gone out of the window - the tortilla was so bland, I couldn't believe it - I used to say they had the best tortilla in town! the langostinos... let me tell you, are just big shrimps, not real langostinos, and the small portion for $16 will serve you just 4. 

The only dish that was worth it was the chicken and jamon croquetas. They were delicious with a soft bechamel. Other than that, save your money.
author: Carla P.

description: The entire meal was amazing, best we've had in SF and definitely one of our favorites anywhere. The baked snails dish goes down as one of our favorite menu items anywhere. The staff was very friendly, accommodating and made us feel very welcome. We will absolutely be dining here every time we visit the city.
author: Nick G.

description: They charged an extra 20% to my credit card with no explanation. We split the payment and left the right amount of tip (15 to 20%), but they decided to charge a 20% extra on my part.
author: Pau P.

description: Decided to stop in for dinner with my husband as we were walking by...loved it!! Ordered an assortment of tapas from the anchovies, baked feta cheese,pulpo, arroz nero, and a few others. We enjoyed all of them! Attentive service from both the server and busser. We will definitely return!! Thanks again!
author: Lisa B.

description: We Loved the food and also the atmosphere. It was filled with people even on a weeknight .Paella at its best and Sangria was very good . We just fell in love with this place .It was filled with people even on a weeknight . Awesome service . They serve an authentic Spanish food. I dined here with my husband last night on the occasion of my birthday . A nice place to dine for your special occasion and they do sing for you if it's your birthday which is a wonderful thing to make anyone s day more happy !!
author: Chaitra V.

description:
Great and superb customer service.
Tapas just like the ones back at home(Spain)
Paella was good, clams were not fresh at all!

Overall great place to eat with your family.
author: Diana V.

description:
Love  this place very cozy, ambience is good and most specially the food is awesome, I highly recommend the Paella, grilled squid, assorted mushrooms, fried smelt, bacalao and mussels
 
I think I should just say everything here is excellent
Customer service is amazing, Arturo not sure is he is the owner or the manager but he is super nice he makes my birthday dinner super special, we are very well served.

If every restaurant has Arturo with them regardless if the food is just alright for sure you will go back but this restaurant possesses both qualities, excellent food and excellent customer service.

It's a must to try !!!!
author: Marie R.

description:
Lacking zest in both food and service. 

We had the grilled squid and tripe apps. While the grilled squid was tasty, there were only four small bites. I know this is tapas, but pretty ridiculous. As for the tripe, it tasted like old stewed tripe. Nothing special. They could've at least put some fresh herbs in to brighten it up. 

For dinner, we had braised short ribs, which was served thinly sliced and oxtail that tasted like the tripe. Pretty boring.

For service, we waited for almost an hour while there were open tables. They're just not very efficient. I know they were setting up for a big party but the table that we ended up at was open for at least 20 minutes.
author: Peter T.

description:
I made a terrible decision to walk to Zarzuela from Montgomery, and I'll just say that the hill up to the restaurant is no joke. You'll find yourself in a quiet little neighborhood where Zarzuela's historic, worn look fits in perfectly. Inside, the tables are packed tightly; I was seated right next to the host podium. I arrived around 7 on a Friday and was seated immediately, but after another 15 minutes we noticed that more people started arriving and were given wait times of 30-45 minutes. 

We ordered the house sangria, seafood paella, which is supposed to feed a minimum of 2 people, and the chorizo (sausages in wine sauce). We were also given bread, olives, and dipping oil while we waited. The sangria was good, though I didn't think it was spectacular. Sausages were the same, although we had fun dipping our bread in the wine sauce after we were done with them. I mean, they're sausages, which are basically a level above hot dogs. How fancy can you get?

The paella is where these 4 stars come from. It was a steaming feast within a cast-iron pan. I turned the rice over, and it belched these huge puffs of steam. There was a riot of colors from the shrimp, clams, chicken, etc. And the best part is scraping the crunchier rice that sticks to the bottom of the pan. So good. Of course, ordering this means that I didn't really get the "tapas experience," but I feel like I got enough variety out of this single dish. I wouldn't have it any other way.
author: Sophie W.

description:
What can I say? We don't live in SF, but we absolutely try to make a stop here whenever we can. Always great, always entertaining. LOTS of tapas selections...here's what we had last time:

Cold tapas...

Grilled eggplant stuffed with goat cheese. The name alone. This is a fave (I think we order it every time!)  Highly recommended. 

Dates stuffed with almonds, wrapped in prosciutto. Insanely good!!

Hot tapas:

Steamed mussels. I love the Spanish influence on the traditional wine/garlic broth. 

Chorizo. (not the same as the Mexican kind). Right amount of heat, great sauce for the extra bread you'll probably ask for.

Lamb chops. Good, but could've had more assertive marinade or seasoning IMO. 

Sangria: order a carafe. Just do it 

Dessert: we shared arroz con leche. Damn good. 

Bill for two: about $85. You kidding me?!?!

It's great food, noisy, crazy busy, and totally fun. Right by the cable car stop if you're into that. Put down your phone and GO!
author: Mike D.

description: Delicious tapas!  Loved the empanadas, prosciutto wrapped dates, shrimp, pork tenders, and steak!  Wonderful service, too.
author: Catherine M.

description:
The place feels like your are in a cozy restaurant in Spain, really nice,  rustic and decorated with taurus posters. If you looking for good tapas you should go there. The croquetas, fried anchovies and poached octopus were excellent and by far my favorites. The paella was good but I would better recommend the tapas plates. Paella is hard to make like in Valencia, it should be crusty rice as they cook it in a single very thin layer in Spain. It was a good paella, with all the ingredients like seafood and chicken, sausage.

We had a great evening and our waiter was very nice. Make sure you check the bill at the end, it was probably an honest mistake, but we asked to split the bill and both guest were asked to pay full price each instead of half and half.
author: Claire M.

description: Best Spanish restaurant in SF. My usual is the jamon toast, tomato and goat cheese, paella, and poached pear.  Can't go wrong with anything on the menu-delicious!
author: J M.

description: Great food, great people! Try the octopus, lamb, and crema catalan!
author: Alec N.

description: A very Nice paella valenciana, tasty but basic. The service was excellent and  the ambiance was spNish enough.
author: Hanneke S.

description:
Best tapas outside Madrid. 

Excellent welcoming people, fast and spot on service, exacting adherence to the traditional taps dishes. A taste of home. And the sangria blend here is a wonderfully unique combination with a. Bit of cinnamon spice that delights. Feels like the small restaurants in space inside. Delicious. Don't wait.
author: Austin B.

description:
The service was a bit slow but very helpful, courteous, and friendly. We were sat immediately in the back over-flow room from the main dining room. This was very nice as the main dining room was so loud even our son said it was too loud. 

The food was hot and the delivery perfectly timed so that one dish never overlapped another ensuring each was hot and able to be enjoyed at its best. 

The goats cheese wrapped in eggplant was a standout and although I usually don't prefer the texture of soft foods it was so good it didn't bother me. As for the rest of the meal it was good but a little bland for what we expected and often fell a little flat. Had we not had better in the past we probably would not have tried tapas or even Spanish food again. That is not saying they were horrible, just that they did not live up to expectations from other tapas we have had before. 

Overall a very pleasant experience and would have given 5 stars if the food had just been a little more flavorful.
author: J C.

description: This place was pretty good. I loved their almond dates, but other than that it wasn't all that great. The staff was friendly though. Also their custard desserts were amazing!
author: Gina B.

description:
Great food and helpful staff. Had the mushroom hot tapas, squid, sausage, and empanadas.  All were amazing. Not to familiar with Spanish wines, recommendations were spot on. 
The conversations between tables took me back to our time in Europe. The folks next to us had the fish (salted cod) and raved about it. 
I will return here when I get back to Russian Hill.
author: Greg S.

description: This is probably my favorite Spanish restaurant in the city. The service is great and the food is amazing!!! I had a few of there famous tapas and an entry plate of there Alaskan Halibut. Everything was excellent, I highly recommend.
author: Omar G.

description: Amazing tapas bar. Staff friendly and efficient. Food was great. Paella worth it for sure. Will be back!
author: Anne R.

description: Amazing service, amazing food! I came back from Spain a few weeks ago and this restaurant took me back there all the way in SF, I know I will definitely be back! Every bite was filled with the perfect flavors! :)
author: Terilyn T.

description: Our favorite go to place for Spanish food. Customer service is excellent, priced right and never rushed even though it's a small place with a usual line of people waiting to come in. Reservations are not accepted, so arrive early. You'll definitely want to try this authentic Spanish restaurant. Parking can be tough, but they'll seat you while waiting for the driver to arrive.
author: Lissette I.

description: Very good food.  We had the pepper steak, mixed mushrooms, baked goat cheese, and white bean stew.  It was all very good.
author: Kelby V.

description:
A surprising delight.  We were headed to Street but they were closed on Friday after thanksgiving.  So we yelped and found this place with 4 stars.  Luckily we were able to get in.  Must be because of the thanksgiving weekend.  It lives up to the Yelp reviews. 

We over ordered since we were both hungry but everything was good.  We started with two glasses of sangria.  Even the bread was good. Fresh out of the oven. I LOVE warm crusty bread.  It came with olives and olive oil.  A great start. 

Then we started with 3 small plates
1. Grilled shishito peppers.  It was the special. Yum.  Got a few spicy ones. They were good too
2.  Got the romaine salad with tuna.  It didn't sound that great on the menu but I loved it. Very fresh. They followed my instructions and gave it to me light on the dressing.  
3. Hubby loves the potato Espinola as well. I though the veggie mix in the middle was a nice touch

Next we had the small plate of fish of the day - Mexican Seanad and small of the prawns with lemon and garlic.  They had different flavors but really good as well. Am impressed and plan to be back.
author: Lei H.

description:
OH MY STARS!! YES YES YES!

I have passed by this place so many times and its just a few steps from the fabulous Missing Sock laundry as well (great place for a bite while you are washing and drying!)

What a sparkling gem of a place this is--tapas at it's finest!

We sampled the pie of the day, warmed goat cheese and tomato sauce, prawns in garlic and lemon plus the waiter brought the most delightfully briny olives to the table with soft bread and I had initially written the bread off as lackluster--but it was the absolute best choice to enjoy the flavorful sauces from each selection. 

Let's talk pie for a moment. The filing of choice was warmed vegetables and while I felt I was playing roulette with something so broadly described, my dining companion and I chose to go for it. Rewarded we were!! A well orchestrated blend of eggplant, zucchini, onion and savory spice baked into a hearty-but not heavy-crust. 

The large, in shell prawns were brought out on a plate where they encircled roasted garlic green beans--an unexpected delight. I am not a person who normally goes out of my way for green beans...but these, I surely would!!

I could make a lovely, comfort food meal from the warmed goat cheese and the soft bread! FLAVOR FLAVOR FLAVOR. I was already a huge fan of goat cheese, this is Olympic class excellent!

The space is small and feels almost as if someone chose to invite people over and cobble together seating for a communal celebration--not a crowded restaurant. The conversations around were a low hum, in a pleasant and comforting way. The atmosphere is intimate and very personal, a bit magical. And then, the (presumably) owner drew our attention to three celebrations taking place in the room. A special birthday, a milestone even and a special guest--each presented with a dessert and then he broke into a cappella singing that was in a rich, well trained and confident tenor. While I am on the record of NOT being a fan of unaccompanied singing or of foreign music in general...I found myself hoping he'd sing a little longer in his native tongue when it ended. It truly was as if we'd stopped at a family estate for the harvest and were all being feted for the evening! 

The wonderful evening spent there made me wish for a night out with my actual family there to recreate even half of the delight I experienced!  I would rank this against any of the top restaurants in SF for an amazing experience. Cable car, bus, on foot or by car--many ways to get there ... just be sure you DO get there!
author: LA O.

description: Great Spanish tapas place in SF. Beer and wine only. Pulpo was almost as good as in Spain. Had the paela and it was very good too. Service was pretty efficient and they have a reasonable corkage fee if you want to bring your own wine.
author: Kelly G.

description: Average Spanish fare. Nothing unique though good tasting. Overpriced for similar Spanish tapas places in the area are cheaper offering same flavors and perceived quality. Would not visitagainwith so many more to try. Service was good.
author: Ruby V.

description:
Fabulous restaurant! The Spanish food is spectacular and paella is as good as you're going to get outside of Espana. The place doesn't take reservations so if you're going on a Friday/Saturday, make sure you get there before 7p.m. There is a section in the back, which was where we were seated as it was much more private and you're not sitting just one foot away from your neighbor. Sit in the back if you can. More room and more privacy. 

The staff was super attentive and the food came quickly. We order the coquettas, squid, empanada, and all came out super quick and was absolutely delicious! But the star is the seafood paella served for two. Of course it's not going to beat the paellas in Valencia but it is the best that I have tasted outside of Spain.

Don't skip dessert since the bread pudding is to die for! It was super fluffy and light which was totally surprising. The best part, with all that food, our meal was super affordable! For two people, with all the food we ordered (including tip) came to less than $50/person. That's super affordable for San Francisco. I would totally come back again for the spectacular food, service, and price!
author: Lanai L.

description:
Lets start with the best tapas-Octopus (Pulpo A La Gallega) which was my husbands favorite. I believe its one of their signature tapas. The grilled eggplant stuffed with goat cheese(Berenjena Con Queso Cabra) just didn't taste good together and I wouldn't recommend it. Favorite dish was the Patatas Bravas! The cubed potatoes came with an orange tomato sauce and it was great. Mediocre tapas- the braised quail (Codornices Estofada); was good but nothing to rave about.... 
We really came for the Arroz Caldoso A La Marinera paella but unfortunately it wasn't a hit at my table. It was just ok....
With all the great reviews, I thought I would love Zarzuela but instead we left the restaurant dissapointed.
author: Noor S.

description: Exceptional, friendly service. Everything we had was great. The grilled calamari was definitely the best I've ever had. It was so tender and flavorful it was more like eating a scallop than squid. 4 dishes and 4 glasses of wine for $75 and we left very satisfied.
author: Jasper P.

description:
I went there to have a fancy dinner to celebrate my and my friend's birthday and NO REGRET! The white wine I had was pretty good, I think I had Chardonnay and it was good. For food I had paella and el pescado del dia and dessert. It was actually too much portion for two girls though, I'm really happy having meal over there.

The workers there were really welcoming and kind as well. 

I'd love to come back there again to try different wines and some food.
author: Katie T.

description: I used to love this place. The last 2 times we have been there have been a disappointment and I hope it's just a phase. We ordered paella and the arroz with seafood on different occasions and we were not happy. The rice dish was flavorless, and the paella didn't have the crunchy rice and very little seafood. The shrimp in this dish and the garlic shrimp dish both tasted funky, metallic-like. The octopus was the only pleaser of the night. Sorry Zarzuela!
author: Elizabeth G.

description: Magnificent tapas restaurant with delicious Sangria and small plates to delight the adventurous palette. Enjoyed the meal immensely: with tasty croquetas, garlic-drenched portobellos, prosciutto that melts on your tongue, delicious heavenly goat cheese wrapped in eggplant, twin soup wonders in the gazpacho and the crab bisque, exquisite octopus steaks, dates with almonds wrapped in pancetta, and Creme Brûlée truly realized. The exceptional service was just the icing on the cake. Zarzuela is one of the best dining experiences in San Francisco.
author: E.R. B.

description: I'm just finishing some incredible tapas. I HIGHLY recommend the patatas bravas, jamon de Serrano, and barquones ( anchovies). My GF had the croquettes and shrimp which were quite tasty. Great service! Good crowd. Nice place!
author: Randy L.

description:
No pictures were taken because I was so hungry I forgot to pull out the phone and dug in instead!

Zarzuela is an intimate restaurant dishing out a variety of cold and hot tapas as well as entrees.  We went with a group of 6 and shared a bit of everything.  

The sangria is FANTASTIC!   It's a nice cold red sangria with a hint of sweetness to it.  The baked goat cheese with tomato sauce is to die for.  Such a simple dish was a hit at the table.  The creaminess of the cheese with the acidity of the tomatoes spread on toast or the bread at the table was so good.  

The black pepper ribeye was tender, melted in my mouth and tasted great.  The pork skewers were served with a nice sauce.  The short rib plate was decent but not as good as the ribeye.  The paella is what everyone was looking forward to and was probably the most disappointing of the meals.  It was missing the crispy bottom layer of rice and seemed to lack salt or spice but the chicken and vegetables were favorable and tender.  

To summarize, order a carafe of sangria, get the goat cheese with tomato sauce, order the ribeye and skip the paella.  The tapas were the hit of the night.
author: Tammie W.

description: My husband and I were celebrating our 22nd anniversary and live out of town. I can't say enough about this restaurant. The greeter (I believe his name was Mike,) was awesome. He took care of us!! Helped out with meal choices, gave us readers to see the menu, and retrieved the camera we left behind. The waiter was quick and we received great service. The paella was fantastic! This is a really small restaurant with grand hospitality and great Spanish food. Highly recommend it!!
author: Debbie P.

description: Nice tapas and paella. Staff is friendly and polite. Great atmosphere. Lots of people. Socializing. Very fun. Definitely will be come back again!
author: Alana B.

description: Came here for my birthday back in 2013 and was seranaded in Spanish by a man with an accordion :)
author: Audrey L.

description:
I was told that there's usually about a 30 minute wait for 2 on a weekend night, but my boyfriend and I walked in less than an hour before closing on a Friday night and were seated immediately.

First thing we noticed: Very warm, friendly service. The server took our drink order and asked if we were planning on ordering paella, so that he could put the order in for that first to make sure it would come out on time. He was very enthusiastic about explaining the difference between the two options for paella: One had only shellfish, in a more soupy, risotto-like style (though he offered to add chicken in too if we wanted), and the other was a more traditional style paella with crispy rice and both chicken and seafood. We went with the traditional.

What we ended up ordering:
- Complimentary olives and bread with olive oil: Probably the most olives I've received anywhere for free. If you love olives, this will be a huge plus. Bread wasn't warm, but still tasted fresh and was very good with the fragrant olive oil.
- Sangria: Loved this. Deceptively fruity, but we definitely felt the buzz after a while.
- Grilled squid with aioli: Super fresh, cooked well, and that garlic aioli was amazing. Once we finished the squid, we ended up soaking the bread in the sauce too.
- Patatas Bravas: Classic option and probably the least memorable, but still very good. Can't really go wrong with this.
- Paella a la Valenciana: Great flavors and plenty of chicken and seafood. Once we reached the bottom, we had trouble scraping off the crispy rice at the bottom of the pan (noobs), and the server was happy to help and scrape all of it onto our plates for us. We had enjoyed all of it already, but that crispy rice was the best part!
- Shrimp sautéed in garlic and olive oil: Very heavy on the garlic, in a great way. Another great hot tapas dish. We ordered this as the kitchen was closing, but they still made it for us. Greatly appreciated!

Overall, it was a great meal, with the enthusiastic and friendly service being a huge plus. Would definitely recommend for a good Spanish meal!
author: Sara L.

description:
My glass of house Sangria was filled to the brim! AmazeBALLS stars on that MFer.

Complimentary: Bread, olive oil, and olives lit city and had a double dose of that.
bread was hard like sourdough, but soft inside. not warm

Staff was chill however, this one buster/food runner dude in the yellow, homie needs to pick up  a lesson on patience or common restaurant etiquette. Well me and my party supposedly a group of 4 should have been all there on time, but at first it was just two of us and the other two joined us later. But this busser/food runner you could tell was not having it. I don't know if it was cuz we were young or he was just not having a good day. But i and my friend felt helluh rushed by this guy. He came to our table and mumbled, "the kitchen..." something unintelligible then walked off. He then would continuously gave us the stare-down even after me and my friend ordered our drinks, crab soup, an arroz seafood chicken platter (all very delicious). I just didn't feel like he wanted us there even though there were barely anybody in the restaurant and nobody waiting to be seated at all. It was very unpleasant which is why I took one star out of this review.

Everything else, the sangria, the food, the ambiance, the restroom, and other waiting staff were very cool people. I would definitely recommend this place to others, but just hope you have a better time than I had with all the staff team.

note: potatoes with tomato sauce helluh good
Thursday night: got here when it opened 5:30 3rd party in :D
author: Jray M.

description:
Ambiance: 5 stars
Service: 5 stars

So why the 3 star review? I was disappointed with Zarzuela. I heard rave reviews about this place and was genuinely excited to try it. I enjoy Spanish food and frequent Picaro/Esperpento often. It all boiled down to the taste and quality of ingredients. Unfortunately, neither of them lived up to this restaurant's reputation. I heard from a couple of my friends that their food is not as good as it used to be. This review isn't to nag or be negative...all I want to say is bring back that old Zarzuela - I know you still have it in you!
author: Tarun P.

description:
With Alegrias closed on a Tuesday (also a Monday) which just happened also to be our son's birthday we decided to try Zarzuela as it's the only one in SF of note from Yelp reviews.

We made it on good time after visiting my mother at her rehab facility & was fortunate to find rare parking (after circling round for four times) along Hyde as someone was leaving.  Only a block away to walk we entered the restaurant and was greeted by the owner who allowed us to choose any table that was free, and being a slightly slow Tuesday evening it wasn't difficult to choose.  Busboy set down welcomed glasses of ice water (SF was a sweltering 80 something in the evening and all).  Then we read the menus and decided on paella Valenciana, pulpo a la Gallega, the Zarzuela (seafood stew), gambas al aijillo,mejillones (mussels), and boquerones.  Also ordered a bottle of white wine from Galicia.

Well, the pulpo though pricey was very tender and tasty and were paired up with sliced potatoes.  We'd ordered a racion in Madrid of this same dish and it tasted basically the same.  The boquerones were served with a bit of baby greens which was great to break up the saltiness of the anchovies.  The mussels were disappointing:  Very small to tiny (read 'baby' sized which frankly should have been tossed and replaced). The zarzuela I expected more in quantity for the price charged ($21.50).  It was more like the Italian zuppa di pesce.  Very similar but it was quite tasty just not much seafood.  The gambas (shrimp) were pretty small sized, however, the sauce was fantastic & flavorful like the zarzuela.  The paella was just okay.  Again they don't use prawns but shrimp.  And there was hardly any chicken save a few tiny chunks; the mussels again were tiny and just so so.  

Desserts of arroz con leche & crema catalana were pretty good.

What was obtrusive & rude was the busboy who continually tried to hurry us.  He grabbed our son's saucer although he was still using it, he grabbed the olive oil although we were still using it for our bread, etc.  

But overall we prefer Alegrias for their paellas & also for the intimate type of atmosphere.
author: Luisa T.

description:
Holy seafood paella delicious goodness! For $36 you spilt a huge dish of fresh paella that has been marinating in the broth and is so tasteful in each bite! 

We also got a craft of Sangria for $20 that is enough for 4. 

But not let me forget you receive bread, olive oil, and olives to munch on before you even order! 

The customer service is FANTASTIC from the person who greeted us at the door, the two gentlemen that helped us at our table. We sat in the back room which we didn't mind because it was quieter (even though also full) and we were served faster. 

Russian Hill 
Hungry 
Spanish food 

Come here!
author: Yvette A.

description: Visited for the first time last Saturday with two friends born in Espana.  Saw the restaurants feature on Check Please Bay Area and it was on my list of places to try.  What a fun restaurant.  No reservations taken, so get there in time to get a nice table....sip on the house made sangria, which our friends said authentic and true.  So well price, so yummy.  We enjoyed the friend anchovies, the croquettes, the sausage bites, then the paella, the pork medallions and the sea food vermicelli.  We will definitely return.  The chef is a master and such a warm man.
author: Nancy M.

description:
An authentic Spaniard restaurant offering great tapas and paella. Sangris -smooth and refreshing. Staff is superb and very organized. Waiter even took the time to blend the rice in the paella to distribute the flavors, what a unique touch. 
You will fall in love with Zarzuela. Definitely a must if you're in SF.
author: Gaby M.

description:
Good tasting food.  Priced just right.  Service was exceptional.  We ate there last Jan. 28 n we will be back.   
Thank you "Check  Please"!!!
author: Manuel L.

description:
Got here around 6:45pm on a Saturday and they told us an hour wait, but we only waited about 40 minutes. It wasn't too bad, since there's a lot of room to sit and wait. We ordered their famous sangria and the waiter brought it directly to us in the waiting area. The carafe was only $20 and was enough for all four of us to have about 2 glasses worth. I'm not usually a sangria fan--in fact, I don't like. But upon drinking the sangria at Zarzuela, I'm a fan! I even had a couple glasses. It didn't taste too fake or too fruity. It tasted like how sangria should taste--the best I've ever had.

If you've never been to a tapas restaurant before, it's like family style small-plate Spanish food. This place is about as genuine as you're going to get. 

The food was either hit or miss, with only a couple of misses. The lobster brisk was a little too fishy, but palpable. But the seafood paella was definitely the worst dish. The clams were really sandy and extremely tide-pool-y. The rice was the best part of it, but when it's your signature dish, I expect it to taste signature--or at least good.

The highlights included the jamon serrano and the datiles rellenos--which was addicting, but definitely more of a dessert. I also liked the eggplant stuffed with goat cheese a lot, which may be too cheesy for those who don't typically like cheese. The calamari a la pancha was good, but don't be surprised if it's a little different than your traditional American calamari.

Most dishes were between $7 and $10, with the exception of the paella (worst dish) which was $17 per person! And although they don't all come with a ton of food, the quality is really good. I'd say, including drinks, you could comfortably leave there at around $25-$30 a person. Especially if you don't get the paella.

Service was very good as well. Our food came out promptly and the waiter was extremely personable and accommodating.

Zarzuela isn't the best tapas place that I've ever been to, but it's definitely excellent for the price. You just have to know what to order and what you're going to like! Would definitely go back.
author: Ashley F.

description:
Came here last night to celebrate Niket B.'s 30th birthday

Food (Tapas)
+ Complimentary cold bread and olive oil
+ Baked Goat Cheese- good for dunking above bread
+ Grilled Squid- it's as good as they say- i'm sure that aioli had everything to do with it
+ Chicken and Mushroom- tender, saucy, comfort goodness
+Flan- pretty basic
+Bread pudding- tons of textures, flavorful, recommend

Service
+They do sing Happy Birthday in Italian for you (turns into a bit of a long opera) but fine to hear it once in the night
+Friendly

Ambiance
+Cozy, but cold
author: Sangita A.

description:
Ordered a bunch of tapas & they were ALL delicious. We got the mussels, squid with aioli, tripe, goat cheese with eggplant, goat cheese with tomato sauce, potatoes, a bottle of the house wine & their complimentary bread. Our service was excellent as well!

We came here on a Saturday night & they open at 5:30pm. We got here around 5:25 & got seated right away. The restaurant filled up pretty quickly. Also note that they don't take any reservations. It's first come, first serve.

Try anything on their menu & nothing will disappoint!
author: Trisha G.

description: Wow Expensive, but totally worth it. A side of roasted peppers... some sweet and some spicy. The service was absolutely top notch. The side of bread was crusty goodness and was accompanied by olives and olive oil. The restaurant is still popular with out of towners and the older generation. I went here once and realized what was happening. The mood, the vibes, the ambiance, the welcoming, the service and the food are all great!
author: Jones B.

description:
My boyfriend and I are visiting and on vacation when we came across this place, we passed it by and we figured we will come here for dinner, I don't see a lot of Spanish style cooking/restaurant here in US, I got very excited to see one and made sure we come here tonight.  

I am very critical of this cuisine as I would always compare it to my grampa's good ol' cooking, and it didn't disappoint.  The food are great tasting, very flavorful and like what I remember it to be, the Pulpo A La Gallega (poached octopus) is very tender and fresh, so buttery just like I remember, the Mejillines Al Azafran (sautéed mussels in white wine & herbs) and Gambas Ajillo (sautéed shrimp in garlic & olive oil) is sooooo delicious, I also loved their Sangria and the Flan de Leche, I would have love to try their Paella but I was too full to eat anymore.  But I will definitely go back and try that and other dishes I couldn't fit anymore in my small sized digestive system.

I give it my seal of approval and worth writing a review seal.

In short - i lalalalalove it!!
author: Freida G.

description:
Their tapas were mediocre and not that all together, creative and snazzily tasty!

We ordered up their Poached Octopus and Potatoes and it came out cold/warm instead of what we expected to be, piping hot. 

Then, came the Seafood Paella that was well cooked, but not the best I have ever had!

Service was good, but not enough for me to return.

The decor was homely decked out and intimate, but the food doesn't justify it all on returning!
author: Tiffany D.

description:
GET THE OCTOPUS!
Perfectly tender poached octopus on a bed of flavorful potatoes. A little steep at $16, but TOTALLY worth it.

The Paella was delicious - tons of fresh seafood goodies (including large chunks of fish).
Pass on the sangria. Was a little too sweet and tasted watered down.

Came at 8:00 on the Wednesday and there was no wait!
author: Michelle L.

description: Tapas, tapas and more tapas! The Paella is good but I love the tapas more. No reservation needed but wait is not bad. Nice place!
author: Jami F.

description:
Wifey and I were on a paella fit.  We heard zarzuela was the best in the city.  So, we decided to make the trek over and give it a try.  

Like all other paella places, it does take awhile so be prepared.  

Cute little place.  Nice ambiance and great service.  The paella?  Meh...it was alright.  There was a decent amount of seafood but the rice was soggy.  There wasn't that crispy goodness on the bottom of the pan.  The seasoning was just slightly on the bland side.  

A little disappointed?  Yes.  3 stars.
author: Jen W.

description:
We went to Zarzuela to celebrate my mom's birthday and the drive up to San Francisco from San Jose was definitely worth it!  My parents can be picky and I was a little nervous that they wouldn't like the food here since it was our first time trying Spanish food, but they loved it!  We enjoyed sangria, paella, cordero and a variety of tapas.  The food was so good that my parents asked to come back!

The place is a little small and the service can be a little slow, but the staff is extremely friendly and helpful.  I really hope to come back soon!
author: Juan Jose R.

description: Wholly amazing!!!! Walked in on a Saturday night and was welcomed by an awesome staff. Food was wonderfully prepared. My wife and I absolutely loved this place!!
author: J W.

description: This is one of my fave places. Unassuming and romantic, affordable and delicious. They don't take reservations, but so few people know how good it is, so there's almost always a table available.
author: Naomi A.

description: I came to this restaurant and I thought the food was "okay" but they had good customer service
author: Jesse J.

description:
Very nice restaurant and very friendly. We had amazing services from the manager or owner of the restaurant that created us when we walked in to our super friendly and helpful server. We ordered a couple of tapas: roasted mushrooms, sausage, and croquettes. We also ordered a small plate of chicken and mashed potatoes. Everything tasted fresh and had a good flavor to it. We also tried the sangria, it was ok not the best I've had but not the worst either. 
The restaurant is very small and cozy, very true to Spaniard Tapas Restaurant. Overall recommend this restaurant!
author: Vanessa R.

description: As a person of spanish descent who recently moved to SF, I was quite disappointed with the restaurant options for spanish food in this city until I came accross Zarzuela. I was very impressed to find such a great selection of authentic spanish tapas for very a reasonable price. Food was fantastic (the paella, pulpo a la gallega, boquerones, gambas al ajillo and calamares al aioli are to die for!) and and the service was impeccable! The server even recommended a wine to pair with our paella, which couldn't have been more perfect. Can't wait to come here again!
author: Mónica S.

description:
We had one of the service ever. Our waiter Arturo was just amazing.  
Sangria is tasty.
Food affordable and delicious.
author: Scarleth I.

description:
This was my pre-birthday dinner when I arrived in SF. It was late but the place was still lively. The place was pretty small and the tables were close to one another as well. It might have looked smaller because they had a group of 15 right in the center. (So yes, good for groups!) We were greeted and seated right away. My friend insisted we get the sangria pitcher ($20) and begin celebrating my bday so I agreed. It was weak, warm, and not worth the $20--I told her a glass ($5) would have been fine! We shared the Gambas ajillo ($7.25) --shrimp sautéed in garlic and olive oil. They were delicious but tiny and non-shareable. We were starving that I think we finished all the bread! 

We decided to order the Paella A La Valenciana for 2-$32--I was in heaven. I highly recommend this dish. It was perfect. All the seafood, chicken, vegetables, all flavored with saffron. The waiter was super attentive throughout the entire night. I was worried that the plate wouldn't be enough to share but we ended up not finishing it because it was a lot.
author: Yeraldine S.

description:
Wow, wow, and WOW!

I came here with a Swiss friend who was visiting for a short time and we were debating which restaurant to try along Hyde Street on Russian Hill. Decided to give this place a try and we were blown away! We ordered 6 dishes: goat cheese stuffed eggplant, serrano ham, grilled calamari, mussels, beef with mashed potatoes, and patatas bravas. Everything was incredible! I haven't had such good Spanish food since I was in Spain and this meal actually reminded me of eating tapas out of my hands in Barcelona. The best food is the kind that brings back old memories and makes you want to create new ones. I'll definitely be taking more friends to Zarzuela.
author: Jenny T.

description:
The quaintest restaurant I've ever been in on a lively Friday evening. The staff treated their job with the seriousness/knowledge you'd find at 5 star restaurant. I felt very welcomed and well taken care of the entire time I was there. Even when it really began to pick up, the staff was calm and did not rush us through our meal. Between two, we ordered five tapas, sangria, and dessert and left happily satisfied. 

Sangria: not too sweet not strong but well balanced and tasty (its a challenge to order just one!)

Baked Goat cheese: if you even remotely like goat cheese, I 100% RECOMMEND this dish. Very creamy and comes with a tomato pairing that exposes the best flavors goat cheese has to offer.

Mussels: I wish I were a bigger fan of mussels. I mostly enjoyed the sauce. However, I thought it could be a little more potent.

Octopus: YUM YUM this redesigned my perspective of octopus. Normally I find it chewy and bland however this was neither. The meat was tender, succulent, and complimented well with the boiled potatoes flavored by a phenomenal sauce!

Figs: ORDER THIS. This was the table favorite! The figs were perfectly cooked with a thin layer of prosciutto and nuts in the middle. I will be back specifically for this dish!

Chorizo: Mmmm you can't go wrong. It was not the best chorizo I've ever had because I prefer it with more spice, however still tasty.

Marzipan cake: Almond, sugar, marzipan, and raspberry all spun together to make an incredible top off to an amazing meal
author: Lily W.

description:
Still the Duke and love being a returning customer 
Food, service, and company spectacular.
author: Ulysses D.

description: Excellent atmosphere, Great Food, Great Service. Always a fun time dining here. Zarzuela always makes us feel like family.
author: Alberto J.

description: Mediocre Spanish food. Tried the mussels, chorizo, eggplant, shrimp, and quail. Quail was the best one. Extra star for having great service and delicious sangria.
author: Kim M.

description: Overall, a very good experience. The food was very good (everything people are saying about the squid with aioli is true; however, I've had better paella). The service was VERY good. And the prices are amazing. I can't remember spending this little for so much good food at a SF restaurant. Ultimately, I would recommend this place to anyone.
author: Mark M.

description:
My dad says out of 5 - this is a ten. 
Service was fantastic, excellent food and great ambiance.
They don't take reservations - so plan on waiting or get there before 7 pm.
author: Nicole C.

description: Staff was great and the food was amazing, especially the eggplant and goat cheese.  Very glad I stumbled across this place - I will definitely be back!
author: Tyler T.

description:
Top 3 dishes to get when you get here:
1. Braised ox tail stew
2. Grilled shiso peppers
3. Braised white beans

All of the hot tapas were good, the sangria was deliciously sweet and the service was wonderful, especially Sr. Arturo. 

The only thing that was ok was the paella. Well it was not 100% good; more like 95%. The seafood only paella had fresh seafood...tender mussels and clams, flaky fish, and soft squid and plump shrimp. The rice was undercooked and still crunchy. 

Try to get a table in the back so that you can have a reasonable conversation otherwise the front is too loud.
author: Tinyee H.

description: This spot was highly reminiscent of being in Spain- and old school Spanish interior feel with the classic menu items prepared like at a spot in Spain- no frills or new takes- but hits the spot if seeking the traditional tortilla, papas bravas, jamón serrano ... y mas. Perfect with a carafe of sangria.
author: J K.

description:
Not bad. I definitely wouldn't say that it was fantastic by any means but it was good. We had the lobes yet bisque, pork skewers and the seafood paella. The Bowie was tasty. Pork skewers were nothing special at all. Way too over priced for two small seekers that weren't even impressive. The paella had good flavor but I've had better paella at a few other Spanish tapa places. It wasn't bad at all, in fact it was pretty tasty. I've just had some kick ass paella. 

Not bad.
author: Steve J.

description: Traditional Spanish...............done right and AMAZING. The birthday greetings were heartfelt....food was spot on.
author: Doug P.

description: I've never been to a tapas bar and I quickly realized what I've been missing out on. This restaurant was recommended to us by a local bar owner...for a good reason! We weren't sure what to order so the waiter helped us narrow it down. I will be telling all my friends to come here when they visit San Francisco. So happy we discovered it.
author: Mindy L.

description:
After circling around for parking about 15 times we finally found a spot several blocks up on horrendous SF hills... Guess it made for a good post dinner walk. 

We didn't have to wait more than 5 minutes which seems very lucky according to other reviews saying their waits were 30+ minutes.. Yeah no thanks.

We opted to get the chorizo dish, the potatoes in tomato sauce and a paella. 
Everything was very tasty and full of flavor. 

*** I would take a bit of caution if you're even the slightest allergic to seafood because I broke out in hives all over my face due to the seafood in the paella. I think it was just so much mixed in the rice, that it affected me pretty bad and I haven't had that problem in a long time. 

Other than that, the food was good but service was spotty.. It was hard to get my water refilled when I flagged down several guys and they weren't even THAT busy for that to happen.
author: Tiff C.

description:
First timer.  

We ordered two tapas to start: Muscovy duck with prunes (a special for the evening) and the mushrooms.  The duck was served with potatoes that perfectly complimented the tender meat.  The mushrooms were also very tender and featured a few different types. 

My date and I don't eat pork so we were pleasantly surprised to see the paella was pork-free. The seafood was not over cooked and the paella did not have an overpowering fishy taste. Our server, Arturo, even plated the dish for us; he ensured there was an equal division of deliciousness. 

Highly recommend the mango/coconut dessert. Imagine a piña colada with mango instead of coconut. It was served as slice of pie with a layer of cheesecake, then mango sorbet, topped with coconut cream and toasted coconut!  Amazing!

My only regret. I didn't take photos!  Will definitely be back to see Arturo and try lots of the tapas!
author: Risa G.

description:
This place is delicious... We ordered the calamari a la plancha con aioli (grilled squid), setas a la plancha (grilled mixed mushrooms), and short ribs.

It was a little loud in the restaurant, but a lively ambiance. It's a great spot for a special dinner!
author: Lauren D.

description: I came here with my couple friends before the place got packed for dinner.  The staff is super friendly and very attentive.  When it came to ordering, our server made some suggestions and we went with all of them.  Definitely order the octopus/squid.  I had ordered the soup and get this, it was a cold soup and I swear, it was delicious!!
author: Thuy V.

description:
Zarzuela serves traditional Spanish food in a low key setting. LOW KEY. NOTHING FANCY. The chef is actually from Madrid. It's a mom and pop business with no investors, no $15 cocktails, and no $30 ham plates. Just simple food like you'd get anywhere in Spain.

I can recommend everything we ordered: garlic shrimp, jamon iberico (NOT ON MENU, ask for it), pan con tomate, croquettes, tortilla, lamb chops (the tapas-sized order has 3 and we each had one) and the sangria. The flan and marzipan spongecake were amazing.

No reservations but on a Wednesday night at 8pm we were seated immediately. Service was attentive and friendly. Food comes out very quickly, a plus or minus depending on how you look at it.

If you want an "experience" then yes, you may want to go to Bellota or Coqueta. But if you're looking for good Spanish food, this is where you want to go.
author: Elisa C.

description: After a year, I returned to this wonderful restaurant in Nob Hill. So many delicious items on the menu. My faves are the pulpo a la gallega (grilled octopus on a bed of potatoes) and the grilled squid and aioli sauce. The sauce is mouthwatering. I could eat this dish for days. So convenient that the Hyde cable car drops you off right across the street.
author: Jessica B.

description:
Great authentic Spanish tapas. The prosciutto wrapped dates, the calamari with lemon aioli, the empanadas, and the baked snails (wow - surprise favorite there) were all excellent. The baked goat cheese was good, but it didn't wow me as many reviewers mentioned it. 

Portions are truly small, traditional tapas style, plan on ordering at least 2-3 items for each person in your party. The service was good, we arrived at opening time and there was no wait. Plates were times nicely.

I'd happily visit again. The dessert menu looked good, but we weren't tempted enough to try something at the time.
author: Mary Y.

description: everything tastes good here, you can never go wrong here. they don't take reservations and they have a limited space. you need to be strategic while planning to eat here
author: Guven K.

description:
I saw this restaurant on KQED "Check Please"and decided to give it a try. Our party of three got there around 7 pm. Parking is real problem on Russian Hill. I had to park 6 blocks away. Zarzuela does not take reservations but there were tables available right away. We asked our waiter for menu suggestions. We ordered the following dishes:

Serrano Ham                 5/5 stars the ham was terrific and not to salty, bread
                                                          with a tomato puree comes with it.
Chorizo wine sauce      4/5           sauce was good portions were small
Champinones Plancha 4/5         mixed sauteed mushrooms
Gambas Ajillo                 4/5          garlic sauteed shrimp
Calamares Aioli              5/5         Grilled squid with Aioli sauce very good small dish
Paella A la Valenciana   3/5         the flavor was bland, rice was slightly undercooked
Chocolate Sponge Cake 5/5      excellent best dish of the night
Flan                                      4/5      good creamy 

Service was OK, the restaurant got busier as the night went on. There is also a dinning area in the back. Zarzuela is only open in the evenings and does not take reservations. Parking is a problem since all of the residents of the neighborhood are home in the evenings. The tapas portions are small. Each table comes with marinated olives.
author: George F.

description:
This place brought me right back to that awesome evening by the water in Barcelona, enjoying paella with a nice glass of wine, not a care in the world. I digress.

I'd highly recommend the carafe of sangria ($20 for ~6 healthy glasses, such a steal), the seafood paella, and a bunch of small plates to share.

The prices are very reasonable for the portion size, the service is warm and welcoming, and the ambiance is right out of a local restaurant in Spain. Perfect for a casual get together or even a more adventurous date.
author: Linda X.

description:
