Overall, some pretty good dishes... but I think I'm spoiled by my new favorite spot in Santa Ana - Lola Gaspar. This place blows all the tapas places out of the water. 

For those of you familiar with So Cal... this place is VERY similar to Lizarran in Fullerton (sans the pixtos)
author: Swapna M.

description: Today we had an outstanding evening there. The server was amazing and made it even more special. Started with tapas, went for the Paella and had an awesome dessert. From beginning to the end it was amazing. We will be back for sure!
author: Manfred H.

description:
Quick Tip: This place gets really busy on weekends, so be sure to arrive early.

Zarzuela is a cute and tiny Spanish restaurant nestled in between Nob Hill and Russian Hill. This restaurant serves an array of Tapas dishes and has a notorious reputation for serving amazing Sangria. I highly recommend ordering the Paella and the Rollitos de Berenjena (Grilled Eggplant filled with Goat Cheese). Out of the several tapas dishes we tried that night, these two were my favorite. However, I must admit that I was not too crazy about the Sangria, I've tasted better Sangria elsewhere.

My favorite thing about this restaurant is that they sing authentic Spanish birthday songs to the birthday celebrants. Very adorable and cute! 

Zarzuela is a keeper, definitely worth the hour wait and the 30 minutes of driving around to find parking.
author: Viennelyn C.

description: The fish in the paella valenciana was mushy & the rice wasn't fully cooked! I had a few bites that still had a crunch.  At least the waiters were kind & attentive.
author: Catheria S.

description: Typical tapas place. There is usually a wait, so be prepared. I have had almost everything on the menu at some point, everything is fine, but not mind blowing. The sangria is always good.
author: Leah B.

description:
The food here is pretty good. The grilled peppers sound boring, but are amazing. The mushrooms are a staple and well done. It's a neighborhood type of place.

But what's great about this place is the service. Efficient and friendly. They saved us one night when a group of hungry adults and hungry kiddos peeked inside, wondering if they'd have room. They whisked us to a large table, the waiters were very nice to the kids, and everybody had a great time.
author: Trevor S.

description:
This place just became one of my new favorite local spots!

The upside: 
Me and my husband went for a date night and it couldn't have been better. 

The best part of the meal was the creamy tomato bisque, It was heaven in a bowl. The soup had the perfect acid to creaminess balance. The chunks of buttery crab were to die for!

The goat cheese smothered in tomato sauce was perfect for dipping on the warm bread.

My husband ordered the beer braised  pork ribs, they were tender and flavorful. The onion were a little undercooked for my taste, but still delicious.

Another great highlight of the meal was the saffron mussels!! the broth was amazing so much flavor packed in that light tomato broth.

Not to mention the sangria carafe for 20 bucks!!  

The downside:
There is a long wait because they don't take reservations. And it was freaking cold outside ! Also, the host let in people before us that weren't even in the wait list. 

The service was a little slow and inattentive, we had to ask for water, bread and balsamic vinegar. 

This place is so bomb cant wait to try their paella!!!
author: Angela R.

description:
I came here on a Saturday night. We waited for about 30 minutes for a table for two. 
The food was generally good, but didn't leave me craving to come back. We ordered the chorizo, grilled eggplant stuffed with goat cheese, potatas bravas, ham and cheese croquettes--my favorite of everything we ordered--and the seafood stew. The seafood stew was very briny. On the plus side, our bill was only $40 for a whole lot of food!
author: Erica R.

description:
Came here on a BEAUTIFUL night. Seriously. It was warm at 10:30PM. In San Francisco. WHEN DOES THAT EVER HAPPEN?!?!

*Ahem* but weather aside, the restaurant experience was wonderful as well. Aside from the long wait (which was longer than we expected), everything went perfectly :)

We ordered the baked goat cheese in tomato sauce, potatoes in spicy tomato sauce, chorizo, pie of the day, and the calamari. And a pitcher of sangria. And every dish was AMAZING. Seriously. The squid was cooked perfectly, the chorizo was great, the goat cheese dish was AMAZING. It was definitely a stand out for me. That cheese and that tomato sauce went so well together! 

Service was very friendly as well. What can I say, I was totally happy with everything.

I was stuffed by the end of the night. I can't wait to come back :)
author: Jade R.

description: Felt like I was seating by the sea in Spain while eating my favorite paella and drinking my favorite sangria with the lovely Spanish music - that's why I gave it 5 stars! Oh, and did I mention their pie of the day and the mango sherbet cheesecake even topped the paella?
author: Yvonne N.

description:
Zarzuela is a place to come with a group since there are so many amazing tapas on the menu you'll want to try almost all of them! And they are all indeed amazing! Besides our Sex and the City-type fun, we had the following:

-Jamon Serrano Con Pan Y Tomate: The bread had finely diced tomatoes, which I scraped off since I don't like tomatoes, and went perfectly with the jamon.
-Pimientos Asados: Quite spicy--a bit too much for me. But nicely charred. 
-Plato De Queso Variado: If there's a cheese plate on the menu, this group of gals is getting it! The rosemary-infused cheese and the blue cheese were creamy goodness. 
-Chorizo Al Vino: Not only are the sausages rich and tasty, but the sauce is, too!
-Croquetas De Jamon Y Pollo: I usually don't like fried stuff, but this was perfectly fried. Not greasy at all, panko crispy on the outside and smooth and creamy on the inside.
-Mejillones Al Azafran: These mussels reminded me of being in Brussels.  
-Patatas Bravas: Crispy deliciousness. 

All were delicious. 

Stand-outs were the Fabada Asturiana and the Calamares A La Plancha Con Aioli, both of which I could have ordered a second serving! The calamares reminded me of Dalmatian squid I recently had in Croatia. 

We also got the bread pudding and the crema catalana. They were both good, although I've had better bread pudding. 

The sangria here was also a stand-out. It was smooth and not too sweet! The prices are reasonable for a large group. 

Don't forget to bring your parking karma!
author: Amy B.

description: The food quality out weights the possible service issues you might have. they don't take reservations for small groups and seating is limited but better than most in the area. I recommend eating here and dessert across the street at the ice cream place.
author: Eric G.

description:
After 3 years of living near Zarzuela, I'm finally getting around to writing the review I should have written a long time ago.

In short, Zarzuela is my go-to restaurant.  I consider myself a regular, as I go there with my wife at least once a week.  Zarzuela's food is excellent, the atmosphere is down-to-earth and welcoming, and their staff is great.  Andy, Arturo, and Carlos are all friendly and keep me coming back time and time again.

Their tapas are fantastic, especially the shrimp (gambas), the chorizo, the sardines, and the squid with aioli (calamares a la plancha).  We almost always get their paella as well, as it is fantastic.  After a long day at work, I CRAVE their sangria.  I don't know what they put in it, but it is like ambrosia.  Other dishes of note, are their shishito peppers and their Octopus.

When I have family or clients visiting in SF, I almost always bring them to Zarzuela, because they have consistently great food and great service.
author: D. L.

description: My sister has been wanting to come here for four years. New Years Eve seemed like the perfect time to make that dream come true. Place opened at 5:30 and we arrived at 5:00 only to find a line forming. Crazy!!  Everyone waiting in line were locals. They all raved about the place. It was amazing!! We ordered all kinds of tapas and enjoyed every single one of them. This place is so good!!!
author: Tonia B.

description:
No reservations, so it's a good idea to get there 40 minutes before you plan to eat.
After you get to your table and after you order, they will bring you a small bowl of dark olives and some good bread.

We started out with several tapas:

1. Gambas Aioli : a bit over cooked but the olive oil n' garlic was deelish.

2. Jamon Iberrico de Bellotta (this is off menu, lip smacking fabulous, pricey at $29.00 for 1/8 pound and worth every penny)

3. White bean stew with spanish chorizo: decent tasting, yet the beans were mushy overcooked.

4. A small carafe of their signature sangria: very deelish, first rate.

5. Spanish torta: a pan fried tortilla omelette; served room temperature. It tasted not freshly made.

Cost: $80 includes tip.

I really wanted to like this place, unfortunately, only the sangria reminded me of the few days I spent in Seville and Granada, Spain.
author: Bert K.

description:
Good but probably won't be back. Nothing spactacular. Service was great though minus the person who cleared our half-full plates without asking if we wanted things boxed up!

I had the patatas bravas (sauce on it was good), stuffed eggplant w/ goat cheese cold appetizer (really good!), and vermicelli w/ seafood (just OK). My friend had the lambchops which she enjoyed.

Overall, totally acceptable. Long wait though (45 min) for a table of two.
They do have a bread basket which is nice but the bread is a bit lack-luster (slightly made up for by the really good olive oil and olives that come with it). Sangria wasn't the best I've had.

Our server has an AMAZING voice (he sang Happy Birthday to the table next to us). I would have my birthday here again just for the singing!
author: Semuteh F.

description:
Zarzuela is a very special place. In its very simplest essence, awesome food at a reasonable price. It is unpretentious - Not fancy, nor hipster. Not egotistical, nor showmanship, nor divey. They're straight-forward delicious. And in San Francisco, that is to be revered.

The first time we tried to come here, we were deterred by parking. After circling the neighborhood for almost an hour, up and down the hills of Russian, we left and went to a not-so-good Italian place in the Marina. Boo.

But we're not quitters, so we came back the next weekend and parked on Van Ness and walked up. We were glad we did. Now, we try to be strategic and just come early to beat the rush.

What's good? Pretty much everything we've had, but some stars: The anchovies - super vinegared with that great pang of salt and fishiness - mmm! mmm! The Serranno Ham, complete with tomato bread. The mussels in wine broth - save some bread for dipping! The Gazpacho - tomatoey, tart, with a slight spice - chilled to perfection!

The special grilled dates wrapped in pancetta with almond - yes, it's as heavenly as it sounds. If they have that special - GET IT.

I honestly wish there were more places like Zarzuela. They are not trying to be anything but themselves. Tasty tapas without jacked up prices, and that's all.
author: Bonnie H.

description: Parking is cut-throat here! No ressies. Great wines. great food. No reservations! The peppers were amazing!
author: Kevin F.

description: My girlfriend and I were celebrating our 1st year anniversary, and decided to take her here. It is one of the best restaurants in all of San Francisco. The food is cooked by a Spaniard, giving it an authentic taste! They have a variety of tapas and their Sangria and wines are a must. I recommend the paella a la Valenciana! Wow... And the flan is out of this world... Perhaps the most impressive aspect of this restaurant is the service! The owner is very nice and will greet you... And the waiter is so cool!! He's truly a cool gentleman... He'll even serenade you If it's your bday! People, check this place out!
author: Alejandro G.

description:
Came here for dinner on a busy Saturday night.  First things first, our reservations (which I made day of) was honored to the minute - +1 cool point.

On to the priorities: the sangria was delish! There's something about sangria and tapas...you just don't go wrong with these two.

We ordered the baked goat cheese, the papas bravas, the croquettes, the pork medallions, and the sauteed chicken.  All were at least 4-star worthy.  

We also had the poached pear dessert which wasn't the highlight, but well received by the bf.

Service was also top-notch.  We needed help figuring out how much and what to order and our waiter delivered (pun intended) on both fronts. 

If you're in a Polk street dining rut, venture east to Hyde street and try Zarzuela! Go hungry and leave happy :)
author: Brianna M.

description:
Four of us went here for dinner during a weeknight and were seated right away. The host is a gregarious, humorous fellow. We sat in the back room. Our waiter was very funny also and friendly. 

The food was super yum! We ordered both paellas (the seafood one is wetter than the multi one), and three tapas: shrimp; calamari; sausages. All were super excellent and fresh. The sangria was out-of-the-park good. 

The busperson, however, seemed abrupt and even rude at the end - he seemed indignant that we were sitting there chatting after we'd finished eating and came by several times to see if we had paid. Seemed rather odd to me that everyone from the host to the waiter were friendly and funny, yet the busperson was acting as if the patrons were insulting him by staying put after the food was gone. It was also more than an hour before close time, so he had no reason to be rude. I will definitely go back for the yummy food, but will just remember to not be bothered by the busperson.
author: Frank S.

description:
Parents surprised me and had my 21st birthday celebration here with my other 14 cousins. I just remember it being a happy happy time, with delicious food. I loved their seafood paella and their tapas were perfect. The waiter sang happy birthday to me in spanish hahaha. 

probably pricey, but it was my birthday so I didn't see the bill :P
author: Kayla O.

description:
Came here on New Years Eve around 9:30pm, just before they closed. We had to wait as people who showed up after us got tables in what looked like pandering to friends of the owner since he greeted them with a bottle of Champagne. That's cool, I guess I need to be friends with more restaurant owners so I can use that trick. Regardless of that our wait was only about 15 minutes.

Once we were seated we took some time perusing the menu. Tried a couple of appetizers (ham and cheese croquettes and the Serrano ham with bruschetta) for the main entree we ordered the paella for two. All excellent choices. The paella was cooked in what looked like an iron skillet so some of the rice was crispy on the bottom I enjoyed that part but it might not be for everyone.
author: Charles A.

description: the very very top of the tapas scale & if your lucky, arturo will do re mi you to tears! carlos will make you feel so at home that you just might move in!
author: Rik K.

description: Tapas are my favorite and this place does a good job of Spanish tapas. I met a few friends so small plates made it easy! We ordered a few things and what stood out was the baked goat cheese with tomato! So tasty. The bacon wrapped dates were divine! It came with 4 pieces. Overall, nice place! I wish I tried more.
author: Priya S.

description:
The tapas are excellent, the service is horrible.

I've been to Barcelona Spain, where eating tapas are as normal as taking a 2-4pm siesta (aka mandated nap). Zarzuela's food is comparable, a huge compliment. I love Cha Cha Cha's in SF as well, which is better for one main reason, the service isn't as horrible here. 

I really wanted to give this place both a 2 and 4 star, so I'll meet in the middle.

I walked in and asked how long it would take for a reservation for 2 and the owner looked at me like I couldn't afford the meal because I was in jeans and a t-shirt and I look younger than I am. Luckily I saw and open table (many people with larger parties were waiting outside) and asked for it, so he obliged.

The waiter (older gentleman who seemed to have worked there for many decades) gave us little attention. He gave no recommendations when asked, and took forever to come back with the food, absolute failure in service. I almost wanted to yell at him, "Hey idiota, I speak Spanish!"

Luckily, the food was delish. We ordered a clam pasta that had wonderful flavors. The mushroom garlic tapa was a must, packed with flavors and marinades that worked wonderfully with the bread. The ribs were ridiculously tasty. It's not often you get tapas style ribs done right. The sangria was great as well, most places don't give it enough kick, but Zarzuela does.

Come here and feast! But if they give you a hard time on service, call them out. I might be back, and will be on the lookout to change my review to a 1 or 4/5 star next time.
author: Chuck N.

description:
We went to this restaurant to celebrate a friend birthday last week. We were a group of 8 and we arrived around 8:30 pm, so we had to wait to be seat but it wasn't to bad.

The place is really nice and the staff looked nice until the last minute when I felt that they took advantage of the large group to put two jar of sangria when we actually asked for one more not two more. We didn't say anything about it but we all knew what was going on.. I really don't like sneaky people. This is actually the reason I'm giving this place 3 starts instead of 4. 

The food was good, I had better paellas and chorizos, but in general the food was good.

I don't think I'm coming back soon. I'm still prefer Picaro, good food, not expensive at all, and friendly staff.
author: Lisdeymi P.

description: One of my favorite casual locations in the City. Good food and great staff. Go for the patatas bravas or the gambas al ajillo or the cazuela de queso.
author: Diogo R.

description:
Tapas in Russian Hill? Sounds fancy. I was dead beat tired from work, I just wanted dinner. Aya was dolled up like her usual self and I was dragging my feet in my scrubs. I almost felt embarrassed to go into the restaurant. 

"It's okay to go in with my scrubs on, right?" I had to ask for reassurance. 
Aya shrugged and answered, "Who cares!" 

Well, the host and waiter didn't care. Their service was excellent! 

We started our evening with two glasses of sangria and then ordered: 
-Patatas bravas 
-Grilled squid w/ aioli sauce 
-Baked goat cheese in tomato sauce 
-Paella de Valenciana 

I've eaten at many tapas restaurants before and I'm disappointed to say that Zarzuela couldn't even reach average for me. Out of the four dishes, my favorite was the grilled squid and everything else was either mediocre or not my taste of food. Aya says it was the best paella she has ever had and I will have to disagree. 

Zarzuela has been in my bookmarked for a long time now and based on the reviews, I've been itching to try it out. Now that I have, all I can say is ehhh...
author: Jenny K.

description: Everything was great. Ordered the Chorizo and it was really good. The Paella is the way to go and probably one of the better ones in SF. Sangria is not overly fruity and it does the trick. Good ambiance and it def. feels like a little piece of Spain lives there.
author: Roberto M.

description:
Great potential to be a good tapas restaurant. The food is consistent (somewhat)  and the ambiance is comfortable but the service is horrible!

We started going there about 3  of years ago and we used to recommend it to friends- but we no longer  feel like we can recommend it 
The last few times we have had such  bad experience with the service that  it has ruined the experience. 
The most peculiar thing is that they appear to know that they have bad service - in particular one server name Ricardo (older gentleman), however they don't seem to care about what the customers think. We  personally complained twice to the manager and he just minimized our concerns and moved on.

Too bad, it is hard to find good Spanish food and we thought we did, but bye bye Zarzuela-  You don't care about us, the customers (other than our money) so we will not care about you
author: Rosa Maria S.

description:
My honey took me here for what was essentially my birthday-weekend-getaway-romantic-dinner-out in San Francisco. We arrived on a Saturday night without reservations and the wait was only about 20 minutes. We were dressed up, but this romantic dimly-lit tightly-packed restaurant had diners comfortably dressed in yoga pants and t-shirts, typical Nor-Cal fashion...

Once sat, we ordered a bottle of wine for $30 and the first two plates: the Ensalada de la Casa (house salad) and a bowl of the sopa de langosta (lobster bisque), eventually followed by berenjena con queso de cabra (eggplant stuffed with goat cheese), codornices estofada (braised quail), gambas ajillo (sauteed shrimp), and the chuletas de cordero a la plancha (grilled lamb chops). Everything was spectacular, especially the braised quail-- that was by far our favorite for the night. Prices weren't too bad: roughly $8-$10 for tapas and the large plate of lamb chops at $22. 

The only downside is that the portions were so tiny!! The "large" lambchops meant 4 small pieces of lamb-on-bone, just as the "large" bowl of soup came in a bowl about 0.5" deep. The braised quail I think came with only 3 pieces. 

I suppose if we hadn't wanted tiny tapas we could have ordered the Paella a la Valenciana which is large enough to fill up 4 people... but I think in the end we got the better deal!

It was a really lovely date night meal.
author: Hannah R.

description: Paella is soggy and greasy. It was pretty average. It wasn't terrible by any means, but I have had better paella elsewhere. The sangria is very good! The food took almost 40 mins to come but that's okay we weren't in a hurry. The volume is quite loud in there so I had to repeat my words a few times but it wasn't too bothersome. The waiter was nice but he was very busy. They were definitely under staffed.
author: Sa M.

description:
This is my favorite restaurant in San Francisco.  The first time I came here, I couldn't figure out why we were waiting- there were tons of resturants nearby that didn't have waits.  But the wait at Zarzuela's is well worth it!

I try to fit in a visit monthly.  Everything I've had here is delicious- the baked goat cheese is amazing.  The Spanish Tortilla is delicious.  The eggplant rolls filled with goat cheese are another favorite.  If you want seafood, the shrimp is fabulous.  The mushrooms are wonderful- such a great sauce.

Even just the olives and olive oil to dip the bread in are wonderful.  It's the kind of fresh oil where you can actually taste the olives that you often see in Europe, a rare find in the US!

When I come with one other girl, we'll usually get ~3 tapas.  Without drinks, dinner with tax and tip is generally less than $15/person- very affordable!  With my boyfriend, we might get ~4-5 tapas so everyone leaves full.  If you add in a carafe of Sangria, that can get to about $30/person, but well worth it for leaving full with plenty to drink!
author: Rachael M.

description:
I remember dining here for a get together with close friends.  Whenever I think about sangria, I think of this place because it had the BEST sangria ever.  I'm not of a drinker, but I felt like I could drink the whole pitcher because it was that GOOD.  We ordered a red sangria and a white sangria and both were really tasty - I prefer the white.  For food, we ordered a couple of small dishes such as the potato bravas and the croquettes.  All of the dishes were delicious and with tapas style - we were able to order a good variety of dishes. (I love being able to try more than 1 dish and this type of dining is the BEST for that).

Service was great, except for the fact that it was super busy in here.  Nonetheless we got our food without having to wait too long and we really enjoyed ourselves here.  I'm definitely going to be back on my next visit to SF :)
author: Grace K.

description:
Stumbled upon this place via Yelp. I had to try it as it was close to my place and got great reviews.

I felt like I was in Spain. A lot of people talking, close seating and the owner knew everyone's name. The service was impeccable and friendly. Food came out fast, refills were plentiful. It was the owners friend's birthday the day I went and he announced it to the whole restaurant and then sang. Only in Spain! Oh wait, no...this is San Francisco.

The food was so delicious. I'd recommend the calamari. You can taste the smoke on these little guys and the aioli sauce was mouth-watering. I can't say enough good things about this place. I'm definitely coming back!
author: Ryan L.

description:
Zarzuela doesn't need more recommendations, but some tips on how to visit and enjoy yourself might help the diner new to this Russian Hill gem.

Do not drive here.  Parking is nigh on impossible.  Take a cab or bus, or walk.

They fill up early and - when full - the main room is super noisy - and that really makes it hard for me to enjoy myself (my issue, but... I tend to shy away from super noisy venues).  Service is wonderful, and very expert. The wine list is full of excellent Spanish wines.  The tapas are just as good as everyone says. The queso fundido is TO_DIE_FOR.  Do not miss it.  

My advice?  Go as early as you can and ask to sit in the back room if you want to have a conversation that doesn't involve shouting or white boards.  ;)
author: Juliana C.

description:
I really like Zarzuela. Simple, unpretentious, Spanish comfort foods. They don't try to overthink the presentation or how it's prepared. 

Atmosphere is charming but can be a little cramped. Service is efficient, and never harassing. They don't take reservations so plan on a wait of 15-45 mins depending on the night. 

If you enjoy seafood then avoid fried foods. Order the grilled squid. Delicious and a must try. Pulpo (octopus) is poached and also high on my list of musts. Papas bravas are always a favorite with me. It's potato goodness which I can never say no to.

Overall I don't think you can go wrong with any of your tapas or mains though I clearly haven't tried them all. 

Buen provecho
author: Jean Francois K.

description: The food is amazing and the service is great!!!! Authentic food from Spain. Highly recommend, we got almost every tapa on the menu. Go here!!!
author: Estefania M.

description: Make a reservation as the place can get packed for dinner.  Love the delicious variety of Tapas and really enjoyed the Sangria.  Give it a shot if you are around.
author: John C.

description: Our go to restaurant when we are in the city.  They have great Spanish tapas and sangria.  They do not take reservations so prepare to wait.  We try to arrive early to avoid the wait but sometimes that is just not possible.  We have pretty much had everything on the menu and have not ran across anything we didn't like.  They have daily specials too which are always a surprise.  Also the cable car runs right in front if you want to take public transportation.
author: April L.

description: What I liked about this place is that the dishes seemed more rustic and felt like they were made with a back-to-basics approach. The gazpacho was very refreshing, the aioli for the patatas bravas had a pronounced tomato flavor which I liked. I also liked the potato-egg ratio in the tortilla and the pepper relish that came with it. The other dishes we tried - vegetable stew, shishito peppers, fried goat cheese were good too. And the chocolate cake dessert had well balanced flavors - chocolate, espresso, brandy. One thing I'd like to see is more/different vegetarian choices, something to set it apart.
author: Manjesh N.

description:
I have been wanting to eat here for the longest time, even before I moved to SF. Back when we would come and visit as tourists about 2-3 years ago. I've always heard and read good things about Zarzuela. And I love tapas! But never made it before this weekend due to the fact that they don't accept reservations (we usually avoid those due to long wait times).

Well we decided to go this past Friday for dinner, and went very early, as soon as they opened at 5:30. And yes we got tables woot! By 5:50pm all the tables were taken and people had to wait. It's a smallish place in the front, and they have more tables in the back. Service is pretty efficient and quick so I don't think it's much of a wait. 

Things I liked: service was very good and attentive. The place has that neighborhood restaurant feel, like everybody knows everybody, and the owners/workers. (There are bunch of tourists tho because of the trollies). So it breaks my heart that this review goes south after all that. Namely, the food is .. how to put this.. really mediocre. 

Tapas:
Croquetas De Jamon Y Pollo - wow you can't even taste the chicken or ham. It tastes like  something you buy from frozen section of the grocery store and pop in the microwave.
Pasteles De Cangrejo Con Salsa Rosa - crab cakes so bland and I'm afraid had that frozen food aisle taste again.
Cazuela De Queso De Cabra - I liked it but it's just goat cheese on tomato sauce with no additional flavor or seasoning.

I think that was the overriding characteristic of everything was there was no distinct flavor. So bland. We kept wanting sauces for everything to dip in (they did not come with any). Even the bread they give at the beginning and olive oil.. just olive oil with no seasonings! How bland and boring! And unfortunately even the sangria that we ordered was meh. I may just skip visiting Spain if their food tastes like this.

The only saving grace was the paella we shared. Now that I would recommend. And it was tasty and flavorful. Too bad and too late though... if you're a tapas restaurant, you will have to shine with your tapas!  

I'm quite disappointed sorry to say.
author: Vol T.

description:
Zarzuela is a really great tapas place with some really difficult to find parking around the neighborhood.

The restaurant is actually quite big, with a back section (I kind of think of it as a kid's room), but hey the faster I get seated the better.

[time]
Arrived at 7pm, and sat down immediately with a large party.

Here is a review of the food I could remember:

[olive oil/bread]
They serve some really nice olive oil, but the bread is meh.

[deep fried smelt]
Smelt are small white fish similar to anchovies on how you eat them.  They are battered, deep fried, and you are supposed to eat the bones also.

[asparagus with goat cheese]
grilled asparagus with goal cheese]

[paella]
I never had much paella, so I'm not quite sure what is good and bad.  Their paella is cooked in a copper (?) bowl with the texture of the rice a little less than gooey.  Pretty delicious and meant to be shared.

[oxtail]
The oxtail is fork tender with a really gelatinous broth.

[overall]
I totally recommend coming.  Just try to take public transportation and come early.
author: Dan Q.

description:
Took my dad here on a Wednesday.  He is from Madrid, and loves any chance to get good Spanish food in SF.  Zarzuela was probably our best overall experience so far.  First step toward authenticity was our Basque waiter.  After that, the tapas we started with were great -- perfectly done croquettas and still simmering prawns with rosemary and lots of garlic & olive oil.  The entrees were not that large, but after the starters we were completely satisfied.  The sauces were the best part, and the $20 carafe of sangria tied it all together.  
The place was quite busy for a Wednesday, hopefully the food and service are just as good on the weekends!
author: Ben S.

description:
Food was pretty good except for 1 (the pork dish). Service was spotty as it started well but as it gets more crowded, they forgot about us. They forgot one of our orders. And it took forever just to get a sangria.

They do not take RSVP. The mussels was my favorite. Sangria was also good.
author: Tracy L.

description:
Tapas  is my favorite cuisine and I have eaten at some of the fancy places like Sugar Cane in Miami, all of  Jose Garcias restaurants in Philly, and all of Jose Andres restaurants in DC.  This definitely is more simple but also seems more authentic.  Definitely recommend the sangria and paella and recommend to save room for dessert, you will not be disappointed.  Overall it was an amazing experience and I will be back.

Food  5 Stars
Atmosphere 4 Stars
Service  5 Stars
Value  4 Stars
author: Christopher T.

description:
I have tried going to Zarzuela a few times but on the weekends the wait can be up to 2 hours! 

Danielle M. and I went on a Friday around 7 and surprisingly the wait was only 10 minutes! They do not take reservations either, so either be prepared to wait or have a back-up plan/ find a nearby wine bar.

I love that the host and waiters are old school Spanish dudes with the accents to prove it.  

Fabada Asturiana (white bean stew) - probably my favorite thing we ate here. I love beans and this was rich in flavor AND healthy!

Octopus - YUM!

Gambas Ajillo - shrimp in garlic and olive oil, a classic! And they do it right here. 

Chorizo Al Vino - also a great dish, fairly straightforward - sausage in wine.

Bread w/olive oil - you can tell they use a quality olive oil. Complimentary bread makes me happy.

Four dishes was enough for the two of us. 

Their wine selection is definitely Spanish, we went with a $30 bottle of Rioja.
author: Sara P.

description:
This place is amazing! Excellent choice of seafood for anybody that doesn't eat meat. The squid was delicious. And if you go you have to be sure to get the Sangria! It's house made and it's probably the best glass I've ever had. 
Between the food, service, and  the atmosphere, this place is definitely a good place to take someone you want to impress.
author: Andrew D.

description:
This famous Spanish Tapas restaurant in Russian Hill has a unique casual European vibe.  Many so-called European restaurants in San Francisco are too pretty, too perfect.  When you pop into a non-high-end restaurant in Europe, vibe is much rawer - imperfect and rough, much like this place.  Overall, I really appreciated what Zarzuela had to offer.  Zarzuela is on the list of Top 100 Bay Area Restaurant 2007 (http://sfgate.com/cgi-bin/food/top100/2007cuisine).

FOOD:  Much like their atmosphere, their food was a little rough, so expect some hit and misses.  I appreciated that they did not over season their dishes, like many other tapas places that want you to drink wine like water.  I enjoyed their Serrano Ham, Roasted Muscovy leg of duck, and Empanada.  I wasn't a big fan of their poached octopus or pork medallions.  Grilled lamb tenders were okay, but not too special.  

DRINKS:  They had nice value 8 wines by the glass ($6.00-7.50), but unfortunately I didn't like any of them.  I'm not a big fan of sweet drinks, so I haven't tried their Sangria.    

SEATS:  No reservations.  Pick where you want to sit.  Tight seating, so expect no privacy.  

PRICES:  All depends on how many little dishes you order.  Most tapas are $7-8.  

PARKING: Challenging, but not impossible. 

Don't forget to stop by Swensen's Ice Cream!
author: トモ T.

description:
I have been to tapas restaurants in a dozen cities, including very expensive ones in Las Vegas and Seville, and have never really liked any of them.  Zarzuela may be the best of the lot, but it is still rates only four stars.

The portions are not tiny -- more like small plates than traditional tapas, and 2 or 3 per person will probably satisfy most appetites.  I can't recommend anything in particular, but, on the other hand, I don't have any warnings.  Everything was good, although in general the food needs more spicing.

The desserts are very good and you should try to save room for at least "one to share".

This is a moderate size restaurant and they don't take reservations.  By seven it was full, even on a weekday.
author: David G.

description:
Tapas are yummy.  I would not say this place prepares the best tapas in the city, but everything ordered was good.  The roasted peppers with Sherry and garlic were excellent, and the crispy potatoes,  and goat cheese wrapped in roasted eggplant are rich and satisfying.  
I have never been to a place where the waiter and bus boy encourage your drunkenness by coming around the table to refill your sangria glass, no joke, like every 3 minutes.  Very thoughtful.
I have had better tapas for cheaper in SF, but this place is still pretty good.
author: Chelsey G.

description: I love this place - great tapas, lovely paella & delightful sangria.  AND the cable car runs right by.  Such a delight.
author: Marie W.

description:
My brother, a major foodie, wanted to have dinner somewhere DELICIOUS. I did ample research and came across Zarzuela here on yelp... so I said "why the hell not?" Not gonna lie, I was craving tapas, but my only experience was restricted to Cha Cha Chas on mission (which is not a family go to).

Wait time to get in Labor day weekend (saturday night): was 45 minutes so not bad, they told us 1 hour.


We ordered the:

-Banderillas De Solomillo Cordero - grilled pork tenders marinated in pimenton, garlic and oregano
-Gambas Ajillo - shrimp sauteed in garlic and olive oil
-Mejillones Al Azafran - mussels sauteed in white wine, garlic, tomatoes, onions & saffron
-Patatas Bravas - fried potatoes with spiced tomato sauce
-Pasteles De Cangrejo Con Salsa Rosa - crab cakes with salsa rosa
-Costillas Breseadas A La Cerveza short ribs braised with beer, onions, garlic and tomatoes

...and lastly the best part (mouth-watering as I type):
-Paella A La Valenciana - spanish rice cooked with seafood, chicken, vegetables & flavored with saffron

OMG food-gasm if its possible, the paella was my favorite and now I have to come back to order two plates by myself!

Tapas = small plates. Just fyi my family of 5 likes to eat a LOT. I felt like I was slicing and dicing portions to feed my family as if we were poor people in the movies, yikes. Next we shall order more hahah.
author: Maricel O.

description: Zarzuela is a good place to check out, but I think a little over hyped. We had several different tapas, but found the taste just ok and were hoping for more. Same feelings for dessert there, not quite there but could be. Service and ambience were good, but my rating is based more on food taste
author: Ali H.

description:
Absolutely Fantastic. 
And Yes get the Paella.
Eggplant app is out of this world.
Sardines done Spanish style delicious.
Very reasonable wine selection.
Service warm n friendly.
You may want to go later at night on weekends.
After 9.30 works and they don't rush you.
author: Mike H.

description: I waited to go to this place for over a year and then I went and then I was disappointed.  Bland is the right adjective for this place. I wish it was better because I live two blocks away. It seems like a tourist trap, that's because it is.
author: Peppa ..

description: Ok do the menu is awesome!! We tried a lot!!  But ask about some stuff off the menu! So good. We had a stuffed pepper with crab meat and a lobster sauce!!! Omg!  This place is authentic and amazing.
author: Damien P.

description:
Awesome. Might be a bit of a wait to get seated, but that's when you know people don't wanna leave..
Great food. Great service. Great time!
author: Fabian F.

description: If I could give this place negative 20 stars, I would. My wife and I went to this place for a birthday party, we got there and the table where the party was was full, so we had to sit on the other side of the very small restaurant. We sat there, and after 15 minutes, we still didn't have anyone ask us  what we wanted to drink or eat. They kept on ignoring us like we were invisible. I will never return to this place! I am Spanish and many of my family members are still in Spain and I have been to Spain. All I know is that if a Spaniard from Spain were to be treated the way I was treated, they would have spit in the owner's face. Bad service=no more customers. Two thumbs down, this place sucks!
author: Arsenio E.

description:
Brought a friend here for her birthday and it was delicious! We had a few dishes, don't remember which specifically, but all were very good. Service is awesome too!

Tight space, so conversations can be heard by neighbors, but a really cute tapas restaurant that I will definitely be re-visiting!
author: Angela S.

description:
One of my favorite restaurants in Russian Hill. Liked every dish we've had there except the potato with tomato sauce. My favorite dish there is the Paella, the Spanish pie of the day (they have variations) and the Shishito pepper (a little pricey though, last time we ordered it, it was 7.95 for a tapa dish). 

The service there is great. It's very accommodating and also personal. We like the ambient so much. One time we were there, one of the waiters sang a beautiful Spanish birthday song to one of the diners there. 

We did try some interesting wines there too. Too strong for us. Maybe stick with Sangria.
author: X L.

description: This is a place I would go back to in a heart beat.  This is a great place, the small dishes are tasty and reasonably priced. The Sangria was just amazing.  The place can be a bit noisy and make sure you get there when they open at 5:0 otherwise you will have a hours long wait.  It is so wonderful that everyone seems to know this is a place not to be missed.  Friendly service, good prices, awesome food what more can you ask for?  Again another awesome place in San Francisco not to be missed.
author: Nick C.

description:
We got here at 6pm with a party of three on a Friday night and were promptly seated. Service was decent. Food was ok: we ordered crab bisque, Jamon Serrano, chorizo, mussels and paella. Paella and the crab bisque were 
delicious and the best thing ordered. We got good suggestions on dessert: Mango sherbet cheesecake and the sponge cake were yummy. So I would've given 4 stars based on paella and dessert alone. However after we were done with our food the bus boy said TWICE (we couldn't hear him clearly the first time) for us to clear the table with no one waiting outside. It had only been less than hour in a half. This was the first time the three of us had tried this restaurant and probably the last after the rudeness. Also for $40pp I would've expected better service.
author: Jenny L.

description: This place has the most authentic croquetas outside of Spain that I've ever had. All other Spanish places I've tried have gotten the texture wrong, but Zarzuelas nailed it! The croquetas were light and creamy and so damn delicious. We also had patatas bravas, gazpacho, goat cheese with tomato sauce, and a meat dish that I don't remember. They were all very good, but I'm still obsessing over the croquetas. Service was quick and on point. I appreciate that you can call ahead and they'll reserve a table for you, which is key on a weekend night since the restaurant isn't very big. I was also very impressed with the price point given everything else in San Francisco seemed to be so expensive. I will be back if I ever find myself in San Francisco again.
author: Casey P.

description:
Fabulous service (waiter offered recommendations when we seemed to be having trouble settling on an extra dish, and brought over fresh glasses of ice for our sangria when he noticed ours had melted) and really tasty food.  We ordered the baked goat cheese with tomato sauce, which was tangy and brought to the table nice and hot, and the roasted peppers. The restaurant itself is nothing special, but the food and service make the experience great.

Edit: Upping this to 5 stars. I've been back 3 or 4 times since, and every time is truly a treat. There's no reason that they deserve anything less than a 100%!
author: Katie S.

description:
If you want to spend an evening in a spanish atmosphere, that's the spot! 
Verry good food, tapas are delicious, nice red wines list, and a lovely staff! It's always crowded and they don't take reservations so be ready to wait a little to get a table (you can give your name to the waiter and go have a drink in a bar nearby!)
author: Alice D.

description:
Great tapas and sangria!

Went here with two friends for Thursday dinner.  No wait.

To start, we had the gazpacho and the mixed greens + apple + walnut salad.  Super light, tasty way to kick things off.

For mains we had sausage, salmon (fish of the day), patatas, lamb chops, chicken with mushrooms, crab cakes, and asparagus. The patatas were pretty heavily fried, which I liked.  The salmon was good but I'm not sure if you'll be able to have it.  I loved trying everything, and the plates were pretty substantial, so it was a satisfying meal.  Sometimes tapas leave me feeling hungry, but not here.  Overall my favorite dish was the chicken with mushrooms.

For dessert, we had the bread pudding.  It took a long time to come and wasn't as warm as I was expecting.  Kind of a disappointing way to end the meal.

Service was generally with good with one nit: they didn't fill my water glass as much as I would have liked.

If you're biking from Polk, be prepared for a big hill in the last two blocks!
author: Max H.

description:
Food - diverse menu with very interesting options. Grilled aspergus special was amazing. Paella was awesome, very good food
service - restaurant was packed but didn't take us 5 min to set in a table, host is helpful in suggesting good dishes
author: M W.

description:
We went here for dinner this past Saturday night, and we had a great experience! There were two of us, and we decided to go the Tapas route, rather than ordering full-on entrees. We ordered 5 plates between us, and that was MORE than enough food - I think next time we'll probably get four and maybe some dessert. The atmosphere of the place is really nice. Someone had their anniversary, and that prompted the owner / manager to sing them a song in Spanish. Nice touch, and it made the evening even more fun.

As for how the food tasted, it was pretty good. The tortilla espanola tasted exactly how I remember it tasting (studied in Spain back in college), and I think the goat cheese was probably the best. Actually, no - the best was the jamon serrano. Everything was pretty good, but nothing blew us away. We found it priced very reasonably. The two of us were able to get one beer each and five tapas and be out the door for just under $26 each, after tip. Not too shabby!

All in all, very nice - will return.
author: Kevin H.

description:
Get the paella!!

The quail and sangria were great - I would probably pass on the vegetables next time (got the fried green peppers).

Bring a date!
author: Irving Z.

description: Loved the paella!! We ordered for 2 and we could have served both our children, too.  Good wine list. Servers are very attentive! Cheese tapas tray is delicious but very small. Overall it was a nice, fun experience
author: Laura L.

description: It doesn't get better than this. Every time I eat there I'm so satisfied, full and ready to force down another plate of bacon wrapped dates because they are SOOOO GOOOOD! I don't eat there nearly enough. Definitely a must in the dining out rotation. Love this place!
author: Marz W.

description:
Potato brava was a lazy dish of fried potatoes with a tasteless tomato sauce. The roasted peppers looked like something out of a can.
The mussels and the grilled goal cheese was decent. Service was rushed and not very personal.
All in all a disappointment.
author: Sune T.

description: Wonder by here looking for some place different to eat in the area. Was pleasantly surprised with the menu and the wine offerings. The staff was very friendly, a little slow but they looked pretty slammed with large tables. Our waiter recommended a nice spanish wine to go with the tapas we ordered. Nice variety of small plates with a little bit of everything
author: Lisa B.

description:
We really, really, really wanted to love this place after seeing it on "Check Please! Bay Area", but it was just okay.  Service was abrupt and unfriendly.  The grilled squid with aioli and olives were the highlight of the evening, while the paella a la valenciana especially disappointed.  

Been there... done that... Next Please! Bay Area.
author: Michelle C.

description: I was so disappointed. Everything seemed stale and flavorless. Even the olive oil for dipping bread sucked and so did the olives. I read the reviews carefully. How can it be so wrong?  I have been to Spain and I know what tapas and paella is supposed to taste like.  Service was not worth the automatic 20% tip that they charged. Definitely not going there again.
author: Nikki S.

description:
I loved their paella! The way they cook rice is the right way, not mushy.  It was one of the best, but its price was quite expensive with $36 as a"$$" category restaurant.  Over all, other dishes we took were also enjoyable and their salty level was excellent for me.   

In "$$" price range;
* Food: 4
* Service : 4 
* Atmosphere : 4
author: Momo S.

description:
The food overall wasn't that great.  I've listed out the dishes we ordered from favorite to least:

Gazpacho -- rich with a nice thick texture and just a little bit of tang/spice to it 

Eggplant wrapped around goatcheese -- delicious!

Mushrooms -- Tasted good, but it's very hard to go wrong with mushrooms in general.  Nothing too special about this.

Chorizo -- Good, but I expected at least a little bit of a spicy kick from this.  This was not exciting for me at all.

Serrano ham with bread and tomato spread -- Disappointing.  The ham was on the dry side. Serrano ham is known for being been soft, rich, and buttery tasting.  This was none of those things.

Octopus with potatoes -- This was kinda weird and borderline gross.  I have never had soft octopus at all.  The octopus was the same texture as the potatoes.  It should have been a lot more chewy to nicely contrast with the soft potatoes.  At least the flavoring was good.

Bread pudding -- This was not bread pudding at all.  There was no bread texture to it.  It had more of the texture of flan.

Red sangria -- Watered-down taste. (on both the alcohol and juice factor).  Predominately an apple juice flavor with a subtle hint of cinnamon.

The service was good.  At one point, one of the servers started singing this birthday song in Spanish (but I think it was actually a Mexican song), and it was quite beautiful.  

The pricing is quite decent (and on the lower end) for tapas in San Francisco.

I'm not sure why this place averages 4 stars on Yelp.  Maybe people have never had Spanish food before.  Maybe I'm ordering all the wrong dishes....

Anyway, good service and the good company I had that night prevents this review from becoming a 2 star.
author: Jeanne L.

description: Came here because of all the yelp reviews and was really disappointed with the food. The service was outstanding and we loved the coziness of the place, but the paella left us a little bit wanting. It wasn't as flavorful as everyone raved about, which was such a bummer. We've been to Spain several times and know what it's supposed to taste like, maybe they were just having an off night. One thing that did stand out was the quail. Oh my goodness! It was the best thing we had eaten all night. Their shrimp dishes were just ok, they were cooked perfectly but again, the flavor wasn't there at all. We had their bread pudding for dessert and that was just ok too. Such a bummer because we had walked from downtown to eat at this place. I would say skip the bread pudding and go to the ice cream shop across the street!!! Yum yum
author: Tiffany T.

description:
After seeing rave reviews for this place on Yelp, I chose this restaurant as my tapas choice during my vacation in San Fran. Now I'm wondering if somewhere else would have been better! We went on a Friday night around 8:15 PM and were told there'd be a half hour wait. Not bad for a Friday night. 

We waited inside since it was chilly outside (just a note: the waiting room can get a little cramped and we had the unfortunate luck of sitting next to people who needed to talk loudly about their worldly travels like anyone in earshot cared). Anyway, we were seated about 40-45 minutes later, in their back room. We got a carafe of sangria and ordered a few of their tapas - namely, the tortilla espanola, the jamon serrano con pan y tomate, and the patatas bravas. The food also came with bread, olives and oil. The food wasn't terrible, but it just didn't stack up to places I've been to in NYC (or Spain, obviously.) The jamon/pan combo was probably the best dish I had there, but the tortilla was just alright, and the patatas bravas were very dry (almost hard), and the sauce drizzled on them was watery. 

Was the restaurant horrible? No. Was it the best? Well, not sure, since this was the only tapas joint I hit in San Fran. You might be able to find better.
author: Doreen L.

description: Had dinner there last evening. It was a fantastic meal. Only regreat was that we were already quite full and could not try more of the dishes. Tapas proportions were very generous compared to other Spanish restaurants I have been to. Service was very quick and efficient. A slight wait if you order paella but thats expected for good paella anyway.
author: Han S.

description:
You can never have a bad meal here.

We had such a satisfying meal tonight - it helps with finding a large space less than half a block away!

Instead of their tasty sangria, we went with a bottle of Bodegas LAN 2004 red for $30 which was not bad for the price.  

If they have the fried smelt as one of the specials - please do not pass it up!  The little fish is perfectly battered and fried.  It taste so much better with the fingers than knife and fork - please enjoy yourself!  I could easily eat this and nothing else...I've been craving this since our last visit. $7.95.

Grilled sardines - with a mixed green w/ apples - this was tasty too.  Lightly battered and grilled - if you like sardines, you'll enjoy this dish.  $7.95.

fish of the day was wild salmon - we got the small dish $10.95 - a nice grilled portion w/ tomato sauce, the sauteed chard? w/ garlic and raisin completely stole the show.  We loved the veggie - the salmon was just ok.

Empanada of the day was tuna w/ veggie - $7.25 - this was so good.  The "bread" was crispy and the tuna filling was very flavorful - imagine it as the Spanish styled panini.  

Seafood stew - $17.95 - the sauce was SO tasty, loved it!  It came with two large chunks of fish - one salmon and one white fish.  The large portion was great so it's not over cooked.  With some mussels, clams, calamari, some small shrimp and one piece eacg of scallop and butterflied prawn in shell - YUM!

We had the mango sorbet w/ coconut flakes, macadamia nuts - $5.95 - so fresh and light. Perfect paired with the sherry (tasted like a lighter version of port) and their version of muscato...

A fantastic meal and wonderful friendly service.
author: Gloria H.

description:
Parking is hideous. Pay $20 to park at the garage nearby, instead of trying to go around steep uphill/downhill blocks to find a non-existent space. Having recently gone to Barlata in Oakland, it's interesting to compare the two. B44 is decent but can't be considered at their level. Zarzuela and Barlata are both top-notch, yet have different styles. Zarzuela is more refined, a little more old-school. Barlata is earthier, with a younger hip vibe. Both are excellent, just different.

Patatas Bravas were bland, but the Croquetas de Jamon Y Pollo, chicken and ham croquettes, were sensational. The empanada that night was tuna, and it was amazing - what tuna salad should be, but never is in this country. It is served in a pie-shaped wedge, BTW. 

The Cazuela De Queso De Cabra, baked goat cheese in a tomato sauce, had a wonderful earthy, acid-y taste that begged to use up every slice of the generous serving of bread each table receives. The Champinones Plancha, mixed mushrooms, were roasted (the restaurant often uses those small iron skillets for serving). There was the slightest tang of white wine, just enough to enhance but not so much it detracted. 

The Gambas Ajillo, shrimp sauteed in garlic and olive oil, also came in an iron skillet. It was so redolent of toasty garlic that any one of us probably could have killed a vampire with our breath alone at ten paces - IOW, it was perfect. 

The Pulpo a La Gallega was tender thinly sliced poached octopus, layered atop slices of potato with mild seasonings of onion, olive oil, and pimenton. Like the grilled pork tenders (two skewers of moist, tender pork served with a dollop of mashed potatoes), both were simple yet excellent. 

Another winner was the Boquerones, marinated filets of fresh anchovy served atop red and yellow roasted bell peppers. Tangy fish and sweet bells - a great combo. The loser was the chorizo - the Bay Area's many great Portugese sausagemakers do better.

For dessert, stick to the caramel flan or the rice pudding. Both are traditional, and Zarzuela's versions are excellent, dusted with high-quality cinnamon. The sherries are excellent - and if you want to splurge, get the 20-year old Sandeman's oloroso. Truly a perfect ending!
author: Jean K.

description:
Not often is a place worth waiting over an hour for in the blistering cold. In fact, we waited so long that I had to go across the street and grab a bag of chips to hold me over until we were seated. But trust me - Zarzuela is WORTH THE WAIT.

Cold Mussels - the vinegrette perfectly complemented the fresh mussels, and was one of my favorites here.

Grilled Squid - I have honestly never experienced squid executed so well. READ: this is the BEST squid I've ever tasted in my life! Getting hungry just thinking about it.

Grilled Mushrooms - also delicious.

Sauteed Mussels - I couldn't really decide which one was better: the cold mussles or the warm sauteed mussels. They were both amazing, so order both and decide for yourself.

Patatas Bravas - how can you have Spanish tapas without patatas bravas? Love it!

Sea Bass - in the midst of all the other delicious tapas, I actually forgot what I thought of the Sea Bass, which gives me an excuse to go back and try it again.

Beer-Braised Short Ribs - bring on the meat! It was cooked beautifully and the dish was cleared as soon as it hit the table.

Grilled Lamb Chops - Yummy! The only gripe I had was that they were a bit on the fatty side (as are 99% of lamb chops). Still, that didn't stop me from devouring a few bones-worth.

Paella - YES! This is how you do Paella! B44 needs to take note. We thought about ordering two, but warning: serving size is large on their paella.

Red Sangria - who can complain?

By far my FAVORITE tapas place in the city. I wish they took reservations so we wouldn't have to wait so long. Oh, and parking around this area sucks. Even with all that, this place DESERVES five stars from me.

By the way, if it's your birthday, they will serenade you. Not sing to you... SERENADE you.
author: Tony L.

description:
An overall pleasant dinner but not sure if it warrants a return anytime soon.

We arrived 20 minutes before opening (5:30PM) and there were already people waiting outside. Within 30 minutes of opening the place was completely filled including their back room. I had no idea that even existed until I went to the restroom.

FOOD:
*Roasted Padron Peppers - Good. A few of them even had a nice kick.
*Jamon Serrano - Dry. I seriously wish they had Jamon Iberico instead.
*Grilled Mixed Mushrooms - Mix of 3-4 different kinds of mushrooms. Flavored nicely and goes well by itself or with other dishes.
*Poached Octopus - Comes out looking a lot more flavorful than it really is. Cooked nicely and potatoes were a nice compliment. Nothing really special.
*Roasted Moscovy Leg of Duck - 1 leg barely enough to share between 3 people. Cooked very nicely. Smother the meat in the sauce and it's quite deliciouso. 
*Grilled Lamb Chops - 3 pieces of lamb chop. Again, another dish that was cooked nicely but lacked a bit of flavor. Seems like they just lightly seasoned it with spices.
*Oxtail Stew - Best dish of the night. Make sure you eat all the cartilage off the bones! 

BEER:
*Estrella - Didn't taste like the Estrella I had in Spain. That one tasted more like a Stella and this one a Bud Light?
*1906 - A nice medium brown ale.

DESSERT:
*Flan - Good but wish it was more custardy.

So all that food, 2 beers each person and shared dessert was $150 including tip for 3 people. Not bad!
author: Ken N.

description:
This place has AWESOME food. Only been here once on a date and the food was pretty dang good if you ask me. We started off with some sangria (I've had better). Ordered the Paella, the spareribs with potatoes and I think a veggie dish?

The most memorable thing was the paella which had TONS of seafood in it and the rice is not mushy at all. The spareribs were also very tender and tasty. When it is your birthday, the staff sing to you but not in the tradition 'happy bday' song, they do some Spanish song where one of the waiters goes opera. This place is A LOT of fun. They don't even care if your entire party isn't here to seat you (we only had 2 so could be different).
author: edward k.

description: Very good atmosphere and service. Delicious tapas that taste exactly like you are in Spain. The paella is authentic, meaning it is very good but relatively bland. I would prefer more spices, however it is one of the better paellas I have had outside of Spain.
author: Hannah B.

description: One of my favorite restaurants in the city. Arturo is probably the most welcoming server i have ever met. The food is amazing the wine is amazing what else can you ask for. Highly recommended.
author: niko t.

description:
I have no idea why this place gets 4 stars or is considered amazing tappas. The food is less than amazing. I waited to review until I'd been three times. I have now experienced this THREE times. Still not good.

For one, they didn't de-vein the shrimp! Eew - seriously, it tasted like you know what.

The food is just OK. The prices are better than other tappas places but the food reflects the price. The service is weird. It's not good and in fact, sometimes it borders rude.

I've tried it three times and will not be back a forth.

Try La Lola or Pesce, both better. I even think Marbella (new on Polk) is better.
author: Cheyenne C.

description:
Oh myyyyyyyy this was so good!! Walked in on a Saturday night for dinner w/the BF and had a 30 min wait but went to a wine bar close by and had the table waiting and ready when we came back.  Ordered a bottle of wine based on the recommendations of the table next to us.  Complimentary bread and olives were a nice way to start the meal.  We ordered the grilled calamari (4 large and 4 small pieces on a butter sauce base) that was good but nothing exceptional.  The other starter that we ordered was a special of the day (walnut stuffed dates wrapped in pancetta) OMG these were so good.  Perfectly cooked and the walnuts added an earthy crunch that was to die for. We were planning on ordering a couple of other small plates, but everyone there was ordering the paella sooooo we had to try it.  So. Glad. We. Did.  Perfectly cooked with tons of seafood and chicken, and the crisp bottom rice was amaaaazing! Between the two of us, we basically cleared the entire dish.  

At this point we were the last people in the restaurant, but they brought out the desert menu anyway.  Typically I pass on desert, but we were temped to try a chocolate dish to round out the meal that reminded me of a chocolate tiramisu.  We were still there as they were starting to clean up the dining area, but were not rushed out at all and the staff was joking around with each other and us as they ended their evening.  Wonderful place with great service, food, and attitude.
author: Raina D.

description:
Are you ready to talk PAELLA? Well, I'm not. I'd want to start with the SNAILS first. Yep those creepy crawlies! They're neon green at this place and taste like buttah! Everything else that followed was pretty much as wonderful. Including the Paella. Hey if the snails are good, what do you expect!?!

The wait can be a bit of a challenge. Not to mention the parking. I suggest you park at a lot somewhere and take the cable car or muni to go here. Enjoy the San Francisco night, order a glass of vino when you get there and sigh your worries away - its easier to wait this way, trust me. 

Lastly - enjoy the very Espanyola-esk decor. Love love love.
author: Cholita L.

description:
Overall very nice experience. 

Split the Paella for two and 3 tapas between 4 people. The tapas are very small, so its necessary to order a variety...but they were delicious. The paella was pretty good...and the sangria was good.
author: Julianne S.

description:
Okay, I'm keeping this short and sweet. 

We came here to have dinner with friends from the East Coast. We were pretty much taking a chance since we've never been to Zarzuela before, but we trust our fellow Yelp reviewers. I'm not a picky eater, but I know who is. Luckily, the food turned out as expected. We pretty much ordered tapas: grilled eggplant, sauteed shrimp in garlic and oil, spanish sausage, crab cakes with salsa, spanish omelette, and one entree: a large dish of lamb chops. We loved every dish. It was cooked to perfection. Lots of flavor. Went well with the red wine Sangria. It couldn't have been better. Our waiter was great. After each round, they would clear our table and give us clean plates.

Even though, the restaurant itself was small, it wasn't too loud for us to have a decent conversation with our friends. It may be a little tight for some, but no one accidently bumped into anyone or spilled drinks/food. We had a great time and I would totally come back for more.
author: Lena N.

description: Food is super yummy! They don't take reservations since the place is small. The people are friendly. Come early if you want to be seated right away the place gets really busy.
author: Maries M.

description: It's been a while since my last review, so it is time for an update. I still come here pretty often because we live very close so it is a convenient stumble home after dinner and a bottle of wine. I was just here 2 weeks ago and had the jamon, gambas al ajillo, octopus, shishito peppers, grilled oysters, and short ribs. Everything was great as usual. I loved the grilled oysters and octopus, which was the first time we had those dishes. The octopus was so tender, which is hard to do. I also recommend the braised quail and paella.
author: Jessie L.

description: My favorite dish was the prosciutto-wrapped dates (special of the day). My husband's was the chorizo. The fried potatoes and sangria (not too strong) were also delicious. We were least impressed by their paella. Surprising, since according to Michael Bauer, they serve some of the best in the city. A beautiful dish with an abundance of seafood and chicken, but the seafood just didn't taste all that great and the shrimp were overcooked. Ended on a good note though with their marzipan sponge cake and possibly the best creme brulee I've ever had. Not at all dense, but silky with a perfectly caramelized topping. Also top-notch service.
author: Sophia B.

description:
So, as I knew I would . . . I visited the restaurant again a few months ago.  Everything was still as delicious as before.  I got close parking just across the street and down the hill.  These lamb chops were delectable!  Moist, cooked perfectly and the flavor of the rosemary was superb.  Just WOW!!!  Of course the sangria was delicious and as an appetizer I had the almond stuffed dates.  They were different, but really good - sweet and sticky with a balsamic reduction.

This place is a must-visit!
author: A C.

description:
Ate here a little while back for one of my birthday meals.  The plan was to go to Elephant Sushi, but anyone who's ever been there knows how slammed it gets, so we diverted to Zarzuela.  And I'm quite glad we did.  

I just remember ordering a TON of small plates and really enjoying all of it.  We had a cold eggplant & goat cheese dish, which was super tasty.  I'm not a dates fans, but we had stuffed dates that were ah-mazing.  Grilled squid with an aioli was also really stupendous.  

I'll definitely go back.
author: Shannon B.

description:
Zarzuela is a keeper when it comes to rustic Spanish tapas-style dining.

Celebrating their 18th year in business, Executive Chef Lucas Gasco brings his Spanish heritage to the kitchen and his menu by offering an assortment of tapas frias, tapas calientes, along with your sopas, ensaladas, and platos principales.  In other words, you have a bunch of small plates to choose from, both cold and hot.

Some of my favorites from the tapas frias list would be the tortilla espanola, which is a potato and onion omelet, full of flavor and served cold.   The ensaladilla rusa - potato salad with vegetables is very refreshing and well-seasoned.

From the tapas calientes list, albondigas guisadas (aka meatball stew) is rich in flavor and the broth used is really good.  I would also recommend the mejillones al vino tinto, sauteed mussels in red wine sauce - I just love the mussels here as well.

Chef Gasco also serves up a mean crema de crustaceo, crab and shrimp bisque.  This was definitely something I was not expecting from a restaurant like this but it was delicious.

The specialty of the house may be considered the paella valenciana - Spanish rice cooked with an assortment of seafood and chicken.  The consistency is perfect, not too watery, not too salty, just the perfect balance of substance and spices.  Its comparable to the paella offered at Fresca, if not better.

Street parking can be difficult on busier nights since we're talking about the Russian Hill district, but it gives it just the right amount of neighborhood charm to go along with the neighborly service inside.

The decor is very rustic but also romantic with the white linens and intimate dimly-lit setting.  However, I would still recommend it for groups of all sizes.

And how can I forget about the sangria... its fantastic here.
author: Tony L.

description: The jamón with bread+tomato is really delicious, they use a good quality of jamón. The pulpo a gallega is also delicious and flavorful. After having the appetizers, we moved on to the arroz caldoso. Unfortunately it was not so good. It didn't have much flavor, the fish was overcooked and the collor was not bright. We found it very pricey for what we got - although we like the 2 first dishes.
author: Raissa E.

description:
Easy to say this is my favorite go-to restaurant in the city!! I've been here several times and it never fails. 

The food is AMAZING, the atmosphere is electric and the service is superb.  My top dishes are the calamari, the eggplant wrapped goat cheese, the chorizo and the white bean stew.  There is often a wait, but they are more than happy to open a bottle of wine for you outside (or in the cozy waiting area) while you wait.  The one waiter will typically sing Happy Birthday in Spanish tradition at some point in the night, which is a great show in itself. Also, the Sangria is - excellent!  For such an amazing experience, the cost is very reasonable.  

Overall - FANTASTIC everytime!!
author: Sarah F.

description: God I love this place. I've been a few times with my friend's Spanish family and they approve as well! I've tried so many things but my favorites are the jamon serrano and chorizo, the tortilla and the patatas bravas, and most recently we tried the stuffed squid which was incredible. Not many people at the table liked seafood so I got to eat a lot more than I had intended. The mixed paella was good, and the sangria is good as well. You can pretty much order anything off their menu because it's going to taste great.
author: Jessie M.

description: SO. GOOD. The giant white beans with ham, the quail, the prawns... All SO GOOD. I will definitely be back. I don't have anything bad to say. The service was good, the atmosphere was good, and the food just really hit the spot. The quail was my favorite, hands down.
author: Brianna C.

description:
Huge selection of seafood tapas! They are tapas, therefore the portions are rather small. My personal favorite was the empanada and their special for the night: grilled dates. 

Don't get the sangria, super watered down and seemed like the people sitting next to us had the same problem.
author: Sukhana S.

description: The tapas here are good, but not great. Even for tapas, some of the portions were small. It is really, really loud, especially on weekend nights so don't come here for a romantic atmosphere.
author: Tracey K.

description: What a fun place, tasty small dishes that are meant to be shared. If you are coming with a group of friends, you have a great chance to try everything. I have to warn you about parking! There is no parking in this part of the town, so plan accordingly. They were out of octopus that everyone raves about on the day i was there, so it's a perfect reason to come back again.
author: Galina F.

description: My husband and I have been coming here for years and I am constantly amazed by their consistency.  Our paella was so perfectly cooked, and every small plate was delicious!  I appreciate how Andy (owner) takes care of everyone who comes thru the door.  The place was packed tonight, so great to see them thriving.  If you like Spanish tapas, try this spot.  If you love paella, this is the ONLY place in SF worth your time.
author: Angela O.

description:
Top marks for this place! Great food and awesome sangria.

Warning: the wait can get fairly long here during the weekends.
author: Nipul C.

description: Best Spanish food outside of Spain I ever had ! The patatas Bravas and the empanadas ridiculous!
author: Alvarez R.

description: The food is good, I will admit. Lots of selections on the tapas and the paella is excellently made. But to rate my experience with all things in consideration, it's just alright. There can be an incredibly long wait, they may sit you on tables where you are too close to the next party (sitting on the same long table) and it's not exactly a bargain in terms of pricing.
author: Ross I.

description:
Don't understand the hype. Yes, nice wine and friendly waiters but overpriced and only OK food.
- tomato with goat cheese: cheap canned sauce
- shrimps: no flavors
- dates: too sweet
author: Chris S.

description:
Terrible service! We arrived and were put in a corner table and then ignored for 15 minutes. There was a large party that was loud and had the wait staff working for them . When this was brought to the managers attention that we might leave, his response was ok.
He did not even try to find a different server for us. Unless you know the staff, skip it. We ended up frascati's a block away and had a fantastic meal
author: Stephanie L.

description:
I'm a sucker for a friendly waiter/waitress. I walked in an detected a Castilian accent in Arturo's voice and he proceeded to call me by my first name and treat us well for the rest of the evening.  

Considering I live two blocks away, I'm sad I haven't been here before. I went to Zarzuela after being unable to get a table last time on a random weekday night. 

The star of our meal were the chuletas (pork chops). It was the unanimous winner amongst the five of us who dined that night. Our larger order came with 5 or 6 small pork chops that I almost stabbed my friend of 10 years to get to the extra chop. They were that good. 

In 2nd place was one of the specials, the sea bass. Easily one of the best examples of sea bass I've had.

Other notable dishes were the figs with pancetta we had. They were smaller than the ones I've had here and in Spain but delicious nonetheless. 

The croquettes were also good. 

We had an order of jamon serrano and pan con tomate and I can't say it was outstanding but given the fact that everything else was good having an ok plate of jamon with pan is nothing to complain about.

The sangria was also quite tasty relative to the other sangrias I've had in SF. 

I definitely want to thank Arturo for being a friendly waiter and humoring me in speaking Spanish through the evening. 

Gracias!

[Two notes: they don't take reservations and do not under any circumstance try to find street parking. You will be sorry]
author: Carlos A.

description:
Hands down one of the best restaurants in America. Yes I said it. I've eaten in the Bay Area, in Las Angeles, in Las Vegas, in Chicago, in New York and this is one of the best restaurants I've ever been in. I have not had a single bad bite or even mediocre one all of the times that I have eaten at Zarzeual. 

The tapas are a delight. The best dish by far in the whole place is the goat cheese with tomatoes and bread. This is so simple of a dish yet completely delicious. We always order around two of these every time we go. Speaking of goat chese there are the grilled eggplant wrapped around goat cheese, the croquetas with chicken and cheese, the skewered pork tenders with mashed potatoes, the ham plate with thin slices of ham with bread and tomatoes, etc. etc. I could go on and on. They are all great

For the dinner dishes are just as good. We've had the ox tail, the lamb chops, the short ribs. It doesn't matter. They are all great.
author: Joel W.

description: Everything was so good here! Really small space, so expect a wait time for sure.. They have a small waiting area below the restaurant so that was nice. We got the chorizo al vino (sausage) , gambas ajillo (shrimp), and the crab cakes. All were excellent, only complaint about it I have is that portions were SUPER small. I get that it's tapas, but I wish they could have given us a little bit more... Even with some appetizers we weren't very full. Other than that, nice, helpful staff that really knows their stuff! Would be back for sure.
author: Sam U.

description:
I came here on a dinner date with my parents on Thursday night. I got there around 6 and as my parents told me they would soon be there, asked if I could be seated before-hand. They obliged, but then proceeded to completely ignore me until my parents showed up. OK, that's a slight exaggeration. They came and brought me a glass of water. But no one asked if I wanted something to drink, no napkins/utensils were set down, and not one server came by my table to see if they could get me anything. Sort of started off on the wrong foot. THEN, we ordered:

Wines: my dad got a red, I got a white from Galicia (recommended by the waiter when I told him I was a fan of Pinot Grigio). I really liked mine and it paired well with the tapas we ordered.

Food:
- Lambchops: 4.5 stars. SO FREAKING TENDER AND FLAVORFUL. Served with onions and thinly sliced potatoes in a delicious gravy.

- Poached octopus: 3 stars. This is probably the best-cooked octopus I have ever tasted, but it was lacking flavor compared to the rest of our dishes. Also served with thinly sliced potatoes.

- Mussels w/ saffron sauce: 4 stars. Again, suuuuper flavorful. The complimentary bread they serve you is perfect for soaking up the sauce, which I did shamelessly.
