- Salad: 2.5 stars. I forget which one we ordered but it had apples, blue cheese, and a vinaigrette dressing. Your average salad, nothing bad but nothing amazing.

- Rice pudding: 2 stars. I dont' like cold rice pudding and this one was REALLY thick and creamy and not very smooth. Not my thang.

Overall, I would want to come here and order more items off their menu in order to possibly bump up my review. I do like the fact that it's small and intimate, and their wait staff was friendly for the remainder of the evening (once my parents arrived).

Zarzuela, I'll be back.

OH, and one more thing. Their bathroom sucks. So if you can avoid going #1 or #2 during your dinner, I highly suggest you do.
author: Nicole W.

description:
Zarzuela is a charming restaurant in my neighborhood that's always busy and doesn't take reservations. After having walked by the restaurant 40 times, I finally tried the tapas a few weeks ago with my girlfriends. Although Zarzuela is good for dates with its rustic look and white tablecloth, it's even better for small groups because you get to try more plates.

We had everything from dates to duck to seafood to snails, including classic tapas like goat cheese in tomato sauce and potatoes in tomato sauce. Everything was tasty, though nothing stood out for me. The portions were also very small. I had amazing tapas at La Trucha in Madrid, so Zarzuela faced a bar that it failed to meet. 

I would recommend Alegria's (http://www.yelp.com/biz/alegrias-san-francisco) for traditional Spanish tapas or Destino (http://www.yelp.com/biz/destino-san-francisco) for a Latin American twist on them.

It was about $25 per person for seven plates (6 small, 1 big) and a carafe of sangria. Zarzuela is therefore reasonably priced, but I'd rather pay more for tapas that make my eyes roll back... to memories of Spain.
author: Liz T.

description:
Delicious.

Started with some tapas, goat cheese wrapped in fileted and chilled eggplant and some crab bisque. Good stuff.

For an entree, we went for paella for four. It cam out on two plates, and was plenty of food for all of us.  Being pescatatians, we substituted the chicken element for seafood only. I personally would have liked some more white fish and mussels. But it was great, regardless.

Most hoity toities would make the automatic decision to order wine with the meal. Well, I highly recommend you pair your meal with some Estrella Galicia. The best beer Spain has to offer.
author: Jonathan B.

description:
Great place for Spanish tapas!

We came with our friends, one of which was born in Ibiza and is rather picky about tapas...needless to say, Zarzuela passed the test!

Dishes we sampled:
Tortilla Espanola - very traditional and delicious!
Patatas al Ajillo - one of my favorite tapas! Can't go wrong with patatas! 
Pimientos Asados - wonderful with the endless bread they bring.
Jamon Serrano - tasty pork parts with bread and tomatoes...yum!
Paella Valenciana - the BEST I've had so far! SO DELICIOUS!!!

Service was excellent. Our host was gracious and treated us to a pitcher of sangria due to a hiccup in our reservations.
author: Christy L.

description:
I love tapas. Period. Anyplace where you can order 5 different things and sample them all is fine by me.

Zarzuela is very delicious. Why the three stars, you ask? Because I think LaLoLa is better. And cheaper.

Anyway, the absolute best dish we ordered here was the goat cheese in tomato sauce. It was totally delicious (then again, anything with goat cheese is yummy to me). 

The crab bisque was also delectable.

One thing that did set this place apart was the service. I actually felt like I was being waited on. We ordered Paella and the server actually SERVED it to us instead of putting the pan on the table and giving us a spoon.

Note: They don't take reservations.

I'll definitely be back if I'm in the neighborhood!
author: Lauren F.

description: Consistently good.  Reasonable prices for outstanding food. Friendly neighborhood atmosphere where as a regular diner there, you're appreciated by the staff and they make you feel like an invited guest.
author: Fadi B.

description: My quest to find good paella in SF hat doesn't cost half a paycheck continues. Paella was weirdly undercooked in some areas/over cooked in others. It's like the person who makes it has a vague understanding of what paella should be. I had high hopes, but no dice, sadly.
author: Amy S.

description:
My husband and I are pretty much regulars here. The owner always welcome us with a smile and shakes our hands. Even though they don't take reservations for small parties we are always seated quickly and while waiting we can sip their tasty and very authentic Sangria. Whenever we have guests from outside of the state or even the country we are taking them here and they always love it! My personal favorite tapas are:
White anchovies salad (if you like white anchovies marinated in vinegar you gonna love it!)
Croquetas (we usually order more then one...That's how much we both love it)
Shrimp with garlic (yum, specially with their fresh soft bread)
Warm goat cheese with tomato sauce (you've got to try it!)

Also, if you're planning to celebrate your b'day at Zarzuela, you won't be disappointed. In fact you're never gonna forget the experience...

Cheers.
author: B P.

description:
Con:
-The LONG wait even when we had reservations!
-The waiting area was like a dungeon...or the underside of a stairwell...weird

Pro:
-Food was delish!
-Drinks were great!
author: Jenny L.

description:
Casual yet slightly romantic spot, excellent service and a fantastic selection of cold and hot tapas. Only downside is parking! 
We were greeted and sat right away, our server was extremely friendly and knowledgeable. Our food came so quickly even though there were quite a few people in the restaurant. 
The squid was great, and so were the scallops, I did expect maybe a few more considering the price but good nonetheless. The cheese plate was a perfect way to end the meal, and I would certainly recommend it.
All and all, a really nice little spot for tapas and wine.
author: Elyse C.

description:
Went there on a Friday. Even though we had called and made reservations for 8 when we got there the host said they don't do reservations, and we had to wait 40 minutes before being seated.

We ordered:
Gambas Ajillo(shrimp with garlic)-- 3 stars
Slices ham--3.5 stars
Calamari--2 stars
Eggplant wrapped goat cheese--4 stars and the only dish I would order again!

Would go back for the seafood paella!
author: Soseh Z.

description:
Took the 45 bus to get to Zarzuela on a Saturday night.  Parking is essentially impossible in this neighborhood.  Our party of 16 had to get there early because they don't take reservations because they're so popular, they don't have to.  We got there at 5p and got in the door at 5:30p.  Because we had spoken to them before, they had set up the back room sub-basement next to the kitchen and the sole bathroom for us.  Only one way in and out to the back room as far as I could tell.  

We had a special tapas multi-course meal.  I especially enjoyed the ceviche squid and the pan fried sausage.  Of course, the hit was the paella.  When we left, the main room upstairs at street level was packed and there were people waiting.

Wonderful service.  The back room isn't too much to look at.  The main dining room is very crowded, but nice.  There's a small room between the main dining room and the back room where you can sit a wait for an open table.
author: Doctor G.

description: Ordered several tapas as well as some entrees to share amongst the three of us in my group. Everything came out pretty tasty and in a reasonable amount of time. The sangrias were really good! Between all the food and alcohol we ordered we were expecting some damage to be done, but the bill was actually quite reasonable. Great service as well! In general I'm really not much of a tapas fan, but I'd gladly come back here!
author: Morris C.

description: Went last Friday. Showed up around 7 and got right in. First time to a tapas place and this has set the bar high. Food comes out fast, service is great, and good was excellent!
author: Sarah G.

description:
We have been to Zarzuela a few times and last night took my mom who lived in Spain during the 80's and she fell in love as quickly as my husband and I did. Everything was authentic, delicious, simply and freshly prepared. She commented on how it took her back to her days of living in Barcelona. My husband and I always feel like we're eating at a friends house. The staff are all so friendly and knowledgeable, and they never forget a face in an effort to make you feel welcome. 

Must have tapas:

Squid with aioli (please do squeeze the lemon over it)
Almond stuffed dates wrapped in Serrano 
Anchovy salad
Patatas brava
Cheese plate
Serrano ham plate with tomato spread
Goat cheese stuffed eggplant
Escargots 

They have a great wine selection but we always order a carafe of the Sangria, which is not overly sweet but seems to go well with everything we order. 

The only huge con is the parking. My husband always comes in hugely frustrated after looking for parking, one time for over an hour, but that goes away quickly has soon as he has a seat.
author: Soha L.

description: Got there on a Friday at 7:45 cause we heard about very ling waits, but to our surprise we got seated fairly quickly. Service was very good, our waiter was very good at keeping the sangria glasses full, and making sure we were enjoying our food. The tapas were delicious, good flavored, the sangria was easy to drink but just slightly sweet for my taste, calamari alla plancha was the best, the calamari was soooo tender and had a lovely grilled taste. The croquettes were also very good as well creamy on the inside and crunchy on the outside. Over all great Friday night date night with the boo.
author: Bertamus R.

description: Normally I wouldn't write a review of a place where I didn't get a chance to enjoy the product, but they practically kicked me out with their bad attitudes. We came in half an hour before the kitchen closed, but were assured by our waiter (at first) that is was long before the restaurant as a whole was set to close and as long as we didn't wait too long to order if we wanted paella, that there would be plenty of time for us to order and eat. Two or three other groups were still working on their meals. We were taking a few minutes to peruse the menu because, well, nothing seemed particularly appetizing! Then someone else came by our table and basically told us to hurry the hell up, just not in so many words. He told us repeatedly that the kitchen was about to close, and his tone was a complete 180 degree reversal of the other waiters. Given that only one or two dishes on the menu sounded vaguely appetizing and unwelcoming vibes, we made a mad dash out and were just thankful that we hadn't spent too long parking.
author: Jenna J.

description: Always have a great time whenever we go. The place is fun, easy going and solid food.
author: Matt B.

description:
Zarzuela has a wonderful ambience and lovely execution of its menu items, but I do feel that I've had better tapas elsewhere in the city. Service was pretty great until the place filled up after which we had to ask for water three or four times before finally getting served.  Our server did have an excellent wine recommendation that went well with the paella of the day... which I found to be a bit bland. The snails plate was not what I expected, but was tasty nonetheless. I would've skipped the cheese plate as it was somewhat one-note.

The owner was a wonderfully pleasant man who clearly took pride and joy in running his establishment.
author: Lisa P.

description:
One of my favorite all time dining experiences.  Waiter was friendly and interesting to talk to.  Small local place.  I think we were the only ones not known by the staff.   We went for tapas.  First time tapas eaters. We had quail,  shrimp, crab cakes (Or favorite! Lots of crab.. NOT lots of filler! ) mushrooms (large portion), chorizo and wine (only disappointment- bland chorizo. I love the chorizo my Spanish grandparents got from Silva's- this was not tasty like that), spanish pie of the day yummy cheese and vegetables. 
Leisurely meal.   Good spanish wine. Seemed all that a good spanish tapas meal should be.
author: Susan B.

description:
Went there last night for tapas dinner and sangria carafe....
Food was mediocre and unimpressive.

Tried the croquettes, mushrooms, snails, quail - was blend and lacked flavor and aroma of well prepared meal.
Prosciutto wraps dates were good... of course they were wrapped in Italian thin sliced bacon...:)

Then after discussing at the table that we probably got the "wrong dishes" we asked server for recommendations and he brought us Poached Octopus with potatoes  - which again was too blend to remember.... was wired combo too, octopus is too plain to match it with plain potatoes...

Overall: not memorable dining experience, food was way under seasoned, and simply unimpressive.
author: Anelya S.

description:
Went there on friends recommendation ( they live 2 doors up). Great part of town.
Very nice staff, good Tapas and a nice atmosphere...( ask for the back room if you have a large party, we had 10).
I think we had at least one of everything on the menu to be honest..the Scampi was great..the Mussel's excellent..the Sangria...very nice.
The owner was very gracious...
I'm looking forward to the next visit!!!
author: Paul F.

description:
It's a nice tapas bar but expect to come away feeling satisfied rather than full.  We ended up waiting 45 minutes, but there is an indoor waiting room so it was okay.  The sangria was super good and the carafe is a much better deal than the glass.  I liked the eggplant with goat cheese, the squid, and the mussels.  The croquettes, crab cakes and the empanada were okay but I wouldn't order them again.

Fyi:  Parking is absolutely killer so don't waste your time and gas driving around, rather you should either bart/muni there or just park and pay 20 at the garage across the street.
author: Emily W.

description:
Another Spanish restaurant we wanted to try in SF after our venture to Spain this past April. 

My tips --

PARKING - I circled 3 times (up and down the hill/on the cable car track) and finally scored parking on the street. Free street parking for 2 hours until 9pm on the street. Or you can park inside a "lot" structure for $10 (2 hours) diagonally across from the restaurant.  

Come right at 6pm or else you may be stuck waiting in line for a bit. There are a few Japanese sushi/bars you can grab a drink at around the neighborhood. 

AMIBENCE - rustic and dim with bull fighting posters along the walls. You see #41 bus and the Cable Car whisking by every few minutes. 

TAPAS:

Bread, Olive Oil and Black Olives on the house. 
Padron Peppers - $8/tapa dish. This was delish and grilled just right
Calamari with Aioli - okay.
Mushrooms - tasty.
Octopus with potatoes - The octopus was too overly cooked and not chewy.

Main dish - We shared the seafood stew ($18). 

Desserts are $6/each but we didn't try it.

--------
 My notables were: SANGRIA, mushrooms, padron peppers. 

My note to the owners:

Have a website for your restaurant so it's easier for your patrons to look up parking information, peruse the menu, etc. 

Not the best tapas I've had. Avg price for the tapas $8-$10. I did not try the Paella but seem popular amongst the bigger groups. 

A small room in the back without window seating.
author: Jboogie L.

description:
We have lived in the neighborhood for 7 years and never been, so were excited to go.  Everything was good, not great but good.  Our favorite was the serrano ham on toast, but honestly, that's not something you really cook.   Pasta with seafood, short ribs, beans with sausage, all good, but not great.  We were also not wowed with service - felt like he was punching it in, not terribly friendly or with many suggestions.

$5 Sangria and $4 Spanish beer was nice....we probably won't be back.  Too many other great options.
author: michael d.

description: Been coming for years and love the place. Never had a bad meal. Really like he no reservation policy. Its all good and the staff is great!
author: Brad B.

description:
This place was my (then) girlfriend & I's first take on authentic Spanish cuisine. We found this place through Yelp & expectations were high due to the overwhelming positive reviews. In short, we both came out extremely satisfied!

We ordered the paella Valenciana to share,  jamon y pollo & calamari tapas with glasses of sangria on the side .  Everything was excellent (with the exception of the calamari because I've had better elsewhere but it was still good). The paella was by far our favorite dish. It definitely lived up to the hype!  The sangria was also delicious. 

The only drawback to this place is the parking. Even with that, I would still gladly drive up and down the city's steepest hills for 20+ minutes just to experience this place again!
author: Jay B.

description: SO DISAPPOINTED. They messed up my order for a seafood only paella (I don't eat meat) and gave me one that had meat. When we notified the waiter, he acknowledged his mistake (said he didn't write it down) and offered to get me another dish. He said that another paella would take a long time so he persuaded me to order the seafood fideo instead. I really wanted to try the paella but didn't want to wait an extra 40 minutes for another one so I agreed to the fideo. We kept the paella for the rest of my table since we weren't getting another one. The rest of my group said the paella was pretty disappointing and didn't have much flavor. When the bill came, we were charged for both the paella and the fideo. They did give us a free dessert even though we didn't order one. However, I was still disappointed that they would charge us for the fideo when the waiter made a mistake and then offered to get me a new dish that I could actually eat. If you're not going to comp the extra dish, then just take the messed up one back and give us the correct one. Don't try to convince me to order a completely different dish that I didn't even really want and then charge us for it. The food overall was okay. Nothing to rave about.
author: Al L.

description:
On a recent business trip I was craving some tapas.  I asked a few associates what a good tapas restaurant was in the area and most everyone recommended Zarzuela.  Because I had a large group with me I called ahead to make a reservation and luckily they could fit my group in.  We arrived at the restaurant and were seated in the private room in the back.  Our server was friendly and made us feel like we were at home.  We all decided to order a  variety of different things because there was so many tasty things to choose from the menu.  Here is what we got.

1.  Homemade Sangria - Fresh & Fruity! YUMMO...
2.  Cazuela De Queso De Cabra - baked goat cheese in a tomato sauce - I could tell the tomato sauce was fresh and with the goat cheese it was perfect.
3.  Champinones Plancha- grilled mixed mushrooms with garlic and parsley - Love garlic, love mushrooms, love parsley.  Need I say more!
4.  Chorizo Al Vino - sauteed spanish sausage in a wine sauce - This was one of my favorite tapas.  I had never seen this on a tapas menu before and the combination was delicious.
5.  Gambas Ajillo - shrimp sauteed in garlic and olive oil - Has garlic so I was game!
6.  Chuletas De Cordero A La Plancha - grilled lamb chops in a rosemary & garlic sauce - I love love love lamb chops!  These were cooked to perfection.
7.  Paella A La Valenciana - spanish rice cooked with seafood, chicken, vegetables & flavored with saffron - This was one dish that was a little underwhelming.  I love Paella and have ordered in many times before.  This one was not bad but it was lacking in flavor to some others that I have eaten.

There was so many other dishes I wanted to try so hopefully I will get a chance next time I am in San Francisco.
author: Sayjul P.

description:
If you're looking for a great, affordable Spanish tapas place in the city, this is it! Seating was a breeze, despite the fact that it was dinner rush hour on a Saturday night. The ambiance is small, cozy and quaint; perfect for two people or a small group.

For food, I highly recommend the grilled squid with aioli sauce; the squid was cooked to perfection, soft and with a slight smoky grilled flavor; the perfect pairing with the creamy garlic aioli. The best dish of night. If it's not the signature dish of the locale, it should be!

The mussels were a close second. Light, garlic, buttery broth. It's hard to mess up mussels when you get them that fresh though.

Also a must, the carafe of sangria. One of the tastier sangrias I have had in a long time. A great drink to enjoy with your dining guest(s).

Complimentary olives and bread were served throughout the meal. The waiter was constantly replenishing them should they fall below half; how awesome is that!

Overall a great experience and a definite future stomping ground for amazing grilled squid!
author: Sis V.

description: One of the few places I've ever eaten at and had such a good experience that I put it down in my todo list to write a review for them. I actually ate there 3 months ago, and still remember the quality of service and the quite decent food.
author: Tommy D.

description: Fantastic intimate Spanish restaurant. A great date night spot. The food was authentic and delicious. Oh and be sure to try there sangria!
author: Jenn J.

description: What a nice alternative to the colorless yuppie eateries in SF. This is an old style place with a subdued Spanish decor .. and there is no piped in Flaminco music. The waiters are very professional and friendly. Food is extremely tasty and very soft on the wallet. Will go back and certainly take out of town guests there.
author: Don S.

description:
Last night, 11 of us headed to Zarzuela for Sadia's birthday dinner. Overall, it was a very good dinner. Here's what I thought of the food, drink, etc from best to worst:

- the company! but I guess I can't really give Zarzuela credit for that...
- the table olives: free and delicious!
- the anchovy over grilled red and yellow peppers special - a great combo and my dad recently got me into achovies...  
- the grilled peppers dish - yum!
- the goat cheese in tomato sauce tapa
- the sangria WITHOUT ICE - I'd definitely recommend ordering your sangria sans ice... it's not the best sangria I've ever had but the pitchers did keep magically appearing...
- the mushroom dish - pretty good though a little dry...
- the duck - nice and juicy :)
- the hot mussels - great sauce but mussels were also too dry...
- the baked potato wedges - boring and very dry...

The price was pretty good even with the gallons of sangria we consumed...
author: Meghan P.

description: Delightful relaxing Spanish Tapas experience! Stopped in after work on a Thursday. The sangria is refreshing and subtle. Food is tasty and satisfying. What we really loved was our service and the fact we didn't feel rushed. Also, the serenading by our waiter to a girl next to us for her Birthday. Go across the street for ice cream from Swensens for a nice dessert.
author: Kelsey S.

description:
3.5 Stars

This was nice place for a good meal.  Situated in the great neighborhood of Russian Hill, this restaurant offers good Spanish food (tapas and entrees) at not so expensive prices.  We shared some sangria, goat cheese-stuffed eggplant and paella - everything was good, although the paella needed just a bit more salt.  

Keep in mind that they do not take reservations so you have to show up and be prepared to wait depending on the night and time that you go.  I went on a Saturday night at 6pm and I had to only wait about 3 minutes.  By the time we left it seemed like there was a 15 minute wait.

The great thing about the location is you can walk off the meal by walking up and down the hills of the neighborhood.
author: Ken G.

description: Very friendly service and a nice vibe.   We got here towards closing time and felt no pressure to leave.  We ordered the tortilla espanola, patatas bravas and onion pepper zucchini stew to start.  Turns out the tortilla espanola is served with a healthy portion of onion papper zucchini stew so we would have appreciated it if the server mentioned this when we ordered (although I am now enjoying eating it as leftovers)  We also ordered the paella valenciana to share.  It was a bit undercooked and more soupy than I like, but tasty and with plenty of ingredients (clam, mussels, shrimp, chicken).  I probably would order something else next time.  The sangria was also good.   Seemed like it would be a fun place with a group.   I think the food is between 3.5 and 4, but the overall experience definitely 4.  Parking situation is awful but that's Russian Hill.
author: Vivian W.

description:
Sangria. Let's just put that as the first word because it is essential. Once that is taken care of the meal happens in the most European, warm and drawn out way. Dishes are small and come out as there ready, made for sharing. Lamb chops are great, calamari is a must, and roasted potatoes don't disappoint. I like to show up at 530 when the door opens to avoid the rush (no reservations). Overall, a fantastic restaurant in a great neighborhood. Tourist? Take the cable car to the restaurant. 
Perfect San Fran. Experience.
author: Alexander F.

description:
Everything about this restaurant is amazing: the friendly service, the intimate ambiance, the dangerously good sangria, the authentic tapas, and let's not also discount the fact that this is the restaurant where the SO first took me to on our first date over 2 years ago, and where he also brought me back to celebrate after proposing to me.

Oh, and not to mention, they serve up the best paella I've had in the States, second to my mother's.  Yes, you read right, my Cantonese mom makes a damn good paella.  Zarzuela's Paella Valenciana is a fantastic second though.  The rice isn't clumped together, so you can savor every grain of tasty rice and the seafood is cooked to perfection -- no rubbery shrimp, shriveled calamari or chewy mussels here!

It's a shame that Zarzuela doesn't take reservations though.  My advice to you is to get here early or get here late.  It's not surprising to see long lines during the weekends or on special occasions like Valentine's Day.  This place just screams romantic date place.
author: Diane L.

description: Loved the food, we went with cold and hot tapas based on other habitués recommendations. Gambas al ajillo, jamon serrano, tortilla de papas, croquetas and solomillo de cerdo were no mistake, along with a bottle of La B, Rioja 2009
author: Eduardo C.

description:
I had dinner with friends for her birthday today.  We shared only 2 appetizers: oven-roasted potatoes with some orange sauce, and the other was a pork on a stick thing that was kind of bland and not that warm.   I was surprised at how fast they arrived though soon after order, that we got bread at the table only after the appetizers arrived.  The olive oil was pretty great.

The sangria was also pretty good and not overkill with the fruit which was nice.  
We all shared a paella valenciana which was meant for 2 but we were able to share it among us 3.  Again, nothing incredible or memorable considering I've had paella from Valencia, and nothing beats the original I guess.  

But I would revisit if we get the front room best. I fell I was 2 steps away from cleaning the dishes, and I'm latin, so that's kinda awkward. lol.  Service was fast, friendly though it was more about us, they let us do our thing without much interruptions or suggestions.  I asked for a candle for my friend's bread pudding that we also shared, and the waiter was great and brought one.  I could do without pine nuts on my bread pudding, but I enjoyed heartily the bottom part which was sweet and light.
author: J C.

description: Love, love, LOVE this place. The service was great, we didn't have to wait long for our food, and the sangria was amazing!!! The only downside to this place is the parking, but the overall experience, was great.
author: Sandy N.

description:
When I came here a few years ago, it was my first time ever having tapas. It's definitely hard to park in this area, luckily my husband and I took the muni here. While our friend drove and met us here but he had to park blocks away. So parking is definitely tough and a deterrent for my husband and I. 

Also there is usually a line for this place so expect to wait awhile. It's a tiny place with packed tables and chairs. 

I wish we got to try the mussels, since I looove mussels and seeing the picture here on Yelp I'm so sad we didn't try it out. 

However the only thing I drool about from Zarzuela is the PAELLA. it takes awhile to cook so order it right away when you get seated. It was so deliciously awesome! So flavorful and yummy. 

I would come here just for the Paella if it wasn't for the parking and long wait. 

Mhmmm paella, how I miss you.
author: Grace L.

description:
Okay, consider this a warning: you'll walk out of there with a goat cheese obsession after trying their goat cheese stuffed eggplant, whoo boy - i never really liked goat cheese until trying this oozy delicious goody. 
Their paellas on the other hand didn't do it for me. rice was kind of dry, mussels were good, but didn't hit the spot.

It was awesome seeing one of the waiters belt out a happy birthday opera version song to an older lady who seemed like a reg. 

Totally lucked out the night i checked this place out - it was about 5 o clock, and got a table right away. about 20 minutes later, i overheard the waiter saying there was a 45 minute wait.

so.. get there early unless u consider urself lucky.
author: Ami Y.

description:
The Meal:
Bread served with olive oil and tasty olives
Crab ad Shrimp Bisque was creamy and delicious
Goat cheese in tomato sauce was tasty, but didn't come with enough toasted bread for dipping
Ham and chicken croquetas ... loved the breading! so crispy!
Grilled lamb chops and potatoes were very flavorful

The Drank:
A very tasty and dangerous carafe of sangria

The Ambiance:
Dimly lit
Lively and a little loud
Really feels like you're in Spain when the server asks for the attention of everyone in the room before he starts belting an operatic birthday song in spanish!

Service:
Very friendly staff and relatively quick service (especially since it seemed like there was one waiter for the entire restaurant)

I'll definitely be back for a late weeknight dinner -- probably the only time I won't have to wait for a table!
author: Dina H.

description:
Cold bread mitigated by otherwise fantastic squid (tender), shrimp, and quail tapas.

Perfect flan.

Authentic feel.
author: Inigo M.

description: They take only walk-ins so the wait is long on a Saturday night but worth it.  Most items we ordered were really good, in particular the squid w aioli and the mushrooms. Service is um..., very un-American so be prepared you might be served, as we were, by a taciturn old man who doesn't feel the need to be friendly or speak to you which in a way is pretty funny.
author: J L.

description:
I've never tried tapas before, but I'm pretty satisfied with this place. The dates wrapped in panchetta is tasty (it's their special). Calamari and quail are descent. The chorizo is pretty good, but a bit too salty for my taste after eating many of them. Like other people said, dunk your bread into the sauce, it's tasty!

I love the location, such a pretty neighborhood. The restaurant ambiance is warm and friendly. A nice date place, although a little bit noisy.

I was gonna order their Paella, but the tapas made us full already. Will try that next time!
author: Novalina N.

description: Delicious tapas and warm ambience. Don't miss the mango dessert
author: Monica H.

description: I love Spanish tapas, so I was excited to find this restaurant on Yelp. Me and my friend decided to go to dinner there last weekend. When we got there, there was a 40-45 min wait for a table since they take no reservations. It's always packed. When we finally sat down, we each got a glass of sangria and ordered braised quail, a tortilla tapa with veggies, a shrimp tapa, and coquetas. Everything was amazinggggg. I definitely want to come back to try the paella which I hear is also good.
author: Rebecca D.

description: Great Tapas that are reasonably priced-- fairly authentic Spanish cuisine.  What a pain to park though... and the hour and a half wait knocks it down a star.
author: MJ A.

description:
The food I had was mediocre at best, and the wait was sooo long (albeit, I wasn't there for most of it haha).  You can't make reservations either from what I hear.

I tasted the pork medallions (kinda gross), the scallops with the romesco sauce (ok), and the mushroom tapas (good, but a bit too salty).  I also sampled a few of the other tapas that the table had ordered, and that was a mixed bag.  The service wasn't bad though.

So why 3 stars instead of like.. 2?  Atmosphere!  Did you know that if it's your birthday (it wasn't mine, but it would've been cool if it were) this guy from the kitchen comes out with this crazy good operatic voice and sings you happy birthday in Italian?  Now that's just awesome.  The entire restaurant went silent in awe of his strong and great singing voice.  I wanted an encore, but I thought that'd be weird lol.
author: Alice M.

description:
I think this is one of the best tapas restaurants in the city. Their portion sizes are quite generous and they're expertise is part of the experience. A group of us ordered a few menu items and the waiter was very knowledgeable that he simply provided his input and it made our choices that much easier.

We had
- Jamon Serrano Con Pan Y Tomate: Simply Awesome
- Mejillones Vinagreta: Hyde Street Bistro's mussels were better
- Calamares A La Plancha Con Aioli: very good, 4-6 pieces
- Pulpo A La Gallega: Very tasty and a must!
- Sangria: Not bad, not bad at all...
author: Eric A.

description:
Tucked away on a corner of Russian Hill right across from Swensons Ice Cream shop is this little spanish tapas restaurant. 

I came across this place on my latest trip to San Francisco as I was looking for a place to get out of the rain. 

At first glance my impressions of this place was that it was a small cozy dimly lit restaurant ideal for single or double dates. The menu was a bit limited in my opinion for a primarily tapas place but they did have a nice selection of items.

I had the fried potatoes covered in spicy tomato sauce. It was tasty and had good flavor but not worth the price of the dish. 3.5 out of 5 sporks. 

Next I had these ham and Chicken fried sticks. The name escapes me at the moment but they reminded me of fish sticks. Very delicious, they just kind of melted in my mouth. My only grip was there was no dipping sauce. An aoli or marinara dipping sauce would have been perfect to go along with this dish. 4 out of 5 sporks.

Finally I had the snaills cooked in garlic on garlic toast. Very good if you enjoy escargos but not the best I ever had, worth I try I guess. 3.5 out of 5 sporks. 

They served olives and bread as a complimentary dish which was interesting and a nice change of pace. 

I have to say though one of my big drawbacks is the service was not very attentive. I had to ask for water 3 times before the waiter came by to fill me up. No it was not due to it being really busy I just think it wasn't his priority which in my book is a big mistake.

The price is a bit high for what you get. I think this place would make a great spot for date night or if you live in the area. They lose 1 star for the service.

All in all worth checking out if you live in the area but nothing special.
author: Dan N.

description: Finally got in here after all these years and they didn't disappoint.  A group of 6 of us got there right at 5:30 and grabbed a table on a Saturday night.  When we left the place was packed with a line out the door.  Paella and sangria, what more do you need?
author: Corey V.

description:
Far and away my favorite tapas in the city.  Not only for the delicious cuisine, but also for the friendly service, delicious tapas and Art's fantastic singing.

There's a wait a lot of the time but it is worth it.  The last time I came here I had the good fortune to be seated in Art's section, and we had a light hearted, joyful evening punctuated with his funny and charming comments and lots of delicious sangria.

I haven't had the paella here, but the tapas are to die for.  My favorites are the muscles, the gambas in the garlic-ey sauce, and the special dates wrapped in bacon.  Delish.  Zarzuela has my favorite sangria in the city, not too sweet and easy to overdo in terms of your consumption.

The service at Zarzuela is always extremely friendly.  Although they are always packed, I never feel like they are trying to turn my table and get me out.  Also, Arturo sings this great song for birthdays that is in Spanish and I'm not sure what it is but it definitely makes the night feel more festive.

Fantastic.  No reason to get tapas anywhere else in the city.
author: Bailey D.

description:
Came here on with a girl friend to catch up and have some good eats and ... we got both!  We asked our server for a wine suggestion and about portion sizes, he was very helpful.  

We ordered the Pulpo a la gallega - prepared nicely, great presentation.  The Mussles on the hot appetizers list was fantastic and well-seasoned.  We also tried the spanish tortilla on the cold appetizer menu - also great.  Lastly, we had the Chorizo en vino - another spot on dish with exciting (not in any way bland) preparation.  Everything came out pretty quickly except the octopus.  If you're hungry and get a seat, you won't be hungry for long.

It did take us about 25-30 minutes to get our check processed and that is the only reason I won't give this spot 5 stars.  Will come again!
author: Janelle C.

description: It was good not great. The service is fantastic; super nice. The food is but forgettable. The paella was delicious but far from the best. The the tapas good but again not great. Skip this place and go to Coqueta.
author: Mehdi A.

description:
I've been meaning to try this place for a while.  It was good, very classic tapas. 

We orders seafood paella which was cooked to perfection, escargot with toast and anchovies (my favorite!). And get the flan for dessert.

Overall, this place was solid, and a cute neighborhood spot. I would return.
author: Jordana C.

description: By far the best restaurant I've been to in SF. Authentic Spanish tapas as good as what I had in Barcelona. It's worth every penny.
author: Swannie M.

description:
Definitely a 4.5, maybe when I come back next time I'll be able to bump it to a 5.

We came in on a weekday and heard it gets crowded, so got there early. Definitely a good idea. Our server (maybe owner or manager?) was amazing and was the perfect amount of not too attentive but personable and helpful. You could tell he loved the food by just his descriptions! The place itself was definitely a bit more homey and rustic, a more relaxed atmosphere than a lot of more modern tapas places opening everywhere. Loved that.

Definitely tried the sangria, which was delicious and much less alcohol-like and sweeter than I'd had before. Worth trying even for those that don't usually like sangria.

The food was really good to great. Had the goat cheese in tomato sauce (my favorite) and a couple of the other tapas including the grilled calamari and the croquettes, I forget what else. All well done and very flavorful. Finished with a flan as dessert that was incredibly rich and smooth.

For the amount of food we got it was an incredible deal. I think the total was around $50 for 4-5 tapas, dessert, and a glass of wine. A hearty recommendation!
author: Sam H.

description:
The food and sangria are absolutely fabulous & delicious - 5 stars. The service, on the other hand, was awful! I wish I could give this a better rating, but maybe after I try it again.

We arrived at 6:55 on Friday night and anticipated a wait. The host told us an hour, so we went down the street to a wine bar for about 45 minutes. When we came back he told us we were next on the list, but we proceeded to wait ANOTHER 40 minutes or so and watched them seat other larger groups - very confusing. In total it was 1 hour, 35 minutes for a table. Since they have no inside space to wait, we were standing on the street in the cold - not so fun.

Then when we got our table, it took about 25 minutes to be acknowledged by our waiter. Literally no greeting, no water, no bread...nothing. It was really strange. He was serving the table next to us (and it's a small place) but was totally ignoring us trying to get his attention. We flagged down the host again to order some sangria, which he brought to us while our waiter served other tables.

Once we finally did order, the food came fairly quickly and we did love everything we tried. The goat cheese + tomato sauce was divine, as were the mushrooms, shrimp in olive oil, braised short ribs, crab cakes, and chicken and ham croquettes. It felt like a feast, and we ended it with the rum/chocolate mousse dessert.

If we had been seated in the time given to us and/or had a better experience with our waiter, it would have been 5 stars. Maybe next time, Zarzuela!
author: Kelly B.

description:
This place had some serious potential after a two mile walk up with the climax being a hike up some seriously San Francisco steep blocks.  

However, the food was just okay.  Every tapa place I've ever tried in my past was superior. And, the service included a (not once, but twice) reminder that the kitchen would close soon.  It was 9:45 pm on a Saturday night.  They close at 1030 pm.

The best dish was the aspharagus and goat cheese, hands down.  Not worth returning though.
author: Christy M.

description:
I had super high expectations for this place given the Yelp reviews and the fact it was recommended by a foodie friend but I have to say I was disappointed

So was the food authentic, absolutely.  The dishes are what you would find in Spain, especially in the Catalonia region.  However, I would describe it as the Spanish equivalent of the random diner on your block that you never remember the name of and only go to for convenience, not for culinary exploration, for great ambiance, etc.  aka not horrendously bad but not special.  The problem is it is in America, which by definition makes it special, and to that end, it just does not live up. 

I think the first thing that gave away that it was going to be disappointing was the sangria.  I can best describe it as box-wine frat house/supermarket sangria. Yes you do get sangria like this in Spain but obviously sangria would not be famous if it were supposed to taste like this. In other words, I can make sangria better than this. Took me about to the end of the carafe to feel even a slight anything. It was super watered down. Now what we ordered...

Pimientos Asados - This just wasn't what I expected. I was expecting the green roasted peppers that is hot and lightly salted, but my bad for ordering the wrong dish. It was okay, not what I would've ordered normally.  

Jamon Serrano con Pan, Tomate - This was also okay, the pan with tomate is very Catalan, but obviously better in Spain, felt like the spread is missing some ingredients but none the less it was alright.  The serrano ham both me and boyfriend agreed tasted somewhat different than the ones we had before but we couldn't put our finger on it. 

Gambas al Ajillo - This was the hallmark of the diner tapas. It just was not bursting with the garlic flavor and the texture of the shrimp itself did not taste fresh and tasted a bit old and stubborn.

Croquetas - This was okay but I have had Costco croquetas that you bake at home and I can't say I can tell the difference.  

Patatas Bravas - I don't think you can mess it up.  I mean it's like messing up french fries. So it was okay.

Pulpo a la Gallega - This was the dish that we were like okay this just took it another level below. It was not evenly seasoned, the first piece I tasted was bland and the second piece I got the salt seasoning. Texture also a bit overdone. 
 
Chuletas de Cordero - This in all honesty was actually pretty good but it came at the end of the meal at which point all the other dishes had somewhat spoken for the restaurant. But I recommend this if you are going. Very flavorful done just right. 

I do think we will go back another time to try some other dishes before writing it off because it is hard to actually find authentic Spanish food in America.  Overall I would recommend it if you have never had Spanish food but probably not if you have and are expecting to be wowed. I think I had extremely high expectations which probably didn't help.

In terms of portions, I would recommend 3 per person plus dessert.  We were starving and got 7 between us. It was a tad too much and we had no room for dessert.
author: Li Y.

description: My wife and I had a very enjoyable visit to Zarzuela.  We probably lucked out, visiting on a Saturday night during Halloween weekend, when many folks were probably otherwise occupied - the wait for a table was pretty brief.  Once seated, we had a great time - I was very happy to see that the entrees came in 2 sizes, so we could order small ones to go with tapas as well.  The variety of flavors on the table was terrific - scallops, squid, tortilla espanola, croquetas, braised ribs.  Very comforting food, indeed.  As a visitor to the city, the neighborhood was a great destination - a welcome relief from the rest of the tourists elsewhere.
author: John K.

description:
Dinner for 2 on a week night was an easy sit down. Food and service were great. 

We weren't starving when we got there but we ordered 5 of the small plates and that was perfect to split. 

I was a big fan of the goat cheese in the tomato sauce and the chorizo in the wine sauce. 

The pitcher of sangria is also fun to share for the $20.

All in all, I would definitely go back and I recommend trying out this place. If you don't get drinks, you can have a good meal for about $30.
author: Rachel R.

description:
Happy sangria time.

This is where I retreated with a good Jewish friend of mine plus another to celebrate a somewhat deserted holiday season.  We were all single and had no where to go but the restaurant welcomed us with open doors and wide spaces.  

Who else to share a fine pitcher of sangria to set off the mood on white linen tables.

A happy exchange of social banter and reminiscing about the year that had gone by so quick.  In all honesty, I've forgotten anything that we ordered from the menu, but the sangria was fabulous and after one cup, the brazen redness had spread from my cheeks to my fingers: warm to the touch.  Slices of blood oranges swam up against the sides of the glass pitcher and winked continuously at me.

There is something quite nostalgic about that period of my life and sharing it with a small group of good people will remain in my mind forever.
author: Miika M.

description:
4 stars for authenticity. I spent a month in Madrid in 2003 so I have a some experience with Spanish cuisine. I specifically ordered all the plates I knew best: gaspacho, chorizo, and croquetas. All were close enough to the real deal to fool my taste buds.

The ambiance isn't very exciting or romantic, especially when compared against the other Hyde Street restaurants. But if all you really need is real Spanish tapas, you'll find it here.
author: Jeremy S.

description:
If I died right now, I would have no regrets in life. I could safely say that I had my last meal, and what a meal it was. Dining at Zarzuela was the highlight of my trip to San Francisco.

What we ate -

Chicken Fritters with goat cheese wrapped in eggplant - While not a fan of the cold tapas, this dish was amazing. Note, that these are two separate items served on the same dish. The fritters were crispy and flavorful, but the highlight was the goat cheese. While goat cheese normally has an overpowering flavor, the eggplant balances it out nicely. 

Tortilla Espanola - One of my favorite tapas and this one was made to perfection. The dish was not too dense with potatoes, but fluffy like a souffle. 

Patatas Bravas - I could have done without this one. While the seasoning was amazing, the potatoes took up too much valuable stomach space to try other things. 

Jamon Iberico - This ham has been banned for import in the US for a long time, and now Zarzuela has it! This is served with tomato bread and is to die for. The ham itself is overpowering, but compliments the tomato topped bread nicely. 

Grilled Chorizo - The chorizo was just okay, but when paired with the 2003 Altun Rioja, it creates a flavor explosion. This was incredible!

Beef Short Ribs - Tenderly sliced cuts of short rib served with sauce over a bed of mashed potatoes. The meat just melts in your mouth and the potatoes have a smooth creamy texture. 

Lamb Chops - Those who are not fond of the gaminess of lamb can enjoy this dish. The chops are seasoned with garlic, butter, and other spices; and the meat is fresh, therefore eliminating the peculiar flavor associated with lamb. The lamb is served over a bed of grilled potatoes that absorb the seasoning and juices. 

Paella Valencia - While the paella was really good, it just added to the perfection of the tapas and wasn't the highlight of the meal itself. The rice is served al dente and the ingredients were simmered nicely in the saffron broth. 

Arroz Con Leche - Rice pudding. Not too sweet and amazingly rich. 

Crema Catalana - This is one of my favorite Spanish desserts and Zarzuela makes it perfectly. You can taste the lemon zest infused in the cream and the texture is rich and smooth and compliments the torched sugar on top. 

Mango Sorbet Tart - An incredible dessert of mango sorbet baked into a tart. I'm not sure how they made this one, but it was perfectly sweet and cleaned the palate nicely. 

While we ordered other things as well, these dishes were the highlight of the evening. Arturo and the staff know their wine, and paired the meal up with a perfect 2003 Altun Rioja that  was smokey and rich. The food was the most authentic I have ever had, and I would probably say that quality wise, it even tops the places in Barcelona. I was looking forward to dining here for over a month, and I was not disappointed. Zarzuela made my trip to San Francisco perfect.
author: Chris E.

description: Yum! I don't why they even have a menu, everyone in the place was eating the most awesome Paella. This is serious goodness for the soul!
author: Scott L.

description: Wow. This place is my second favorite in SF (after kokkari). Awesome squid. Great dates. Great gazpacho. Fine wine. Quick service.
author: Gordon G.

description:
After reading all of the great reviews, I was so excited to try Zarzuela last night.  We went early to avoid the long wait (around 6:30pm) and we were extremely happy to find parking and get seated with out a problem.  

We ordered a bunch of things that sounded very promising:  tortilla espanole, prawns in paquillo peppers, duck with prune sauce, pork chops and scallops.  One thing that surprised me was that every single dish came out luke warm, not at all hot (which was especially disappointing for some of the meat dishes).  Spanish tapas is usually full of flavor.  However, I found this food to be missing some of the flavor.  The tortilla espagnole, which is a very traditional dish, was bland and uninteresting.  The duck and the scallops were the best plates of our meal, but still not stellar.

The service was great and my glass of sangria was wonderful, but I found this restaurant to be just okay and not worth all of the fuss.  I unfortunately doubt that we will return.
author: Ashley C.

description:
Love this place but its a bummer they don't take reservations! At least while you're waiting you can side curbside with a delicious glass of sangria. 

Great place for a girl's night out! Its a bit too noisy for a first date...
author: Marisa C.

description:
"Love" doesn't even begin to describe how I feel about Zarzuela.

Coming here since I was a little girl, it has gone from a place I used to associate with fun family dinners to a place I now immediately suggest for dates and nights out with my friends.

The food here is amazing. I usually eat tapas when I come here, with some staples items being the Gambas Ajillo (shrimp in a garlic sauce that's great for dipping bread, etc.), Croquetas de Jamon y Pollo (ham and chicken croquettes), and the Cazuela Queso de Cabra (baked goat cheese in a tomato sauce with grapes!... frankly... anything with goat cheese, and I'm there ha). :) As for entree items, my favorite would have to be either the paella or the lamb chops. Both dishes are to die for.

On top of the authentic Spanish cuisine, the service here is beyond excellent and friendly. Not only do you feel extremely well taken care of when dining, the staff members are extremely knowledgeable about the menu and their recommendations and suggestions are usually spot-on and delicious.
author: Julia J.

description:
Fun meal, great service, tasty tapas on a busy Friday night.
We called ahead to get on the waitlist and were seated immediately upon arrival.  Service was fabulous, food was good to great, sangria was good but lacked punch (sorry for the pun), the ambience was excellent, and the price was really good for SF.

The best tapas was the calimari in aioli. Perfectly cooked and just the right tang in the aioli.  The potatas bravas were good, with a nice sauce, but the potatoes could have been crisped a bit more.  The egg frittata was good, but a little bland.  My gf liked it, though.

We shared paella and it was really good.  Excellent seafood, chunks of dark meat chicken.  The only minus was the lack of fond on the bottom of the pan.  It just needed a couple extra minutes of heat to get that crunchy, browned rice on the bottom that adds flavor and depth.

Overall, an excellent meal on a weekend trip, with 5-star service at a really busy time.
author: Peter J.

description:
I've been on a few dates at this place, and the decor, atmosphere, service were all impeccable. Our food came out quickly and together, and the wine selection was great!

Where Zarzuela takes a hit is in the food department. I remember going there when I was younger with my dad one of his buddies, and I remember the food being really good. When I returned a decade later, however, the food was much less flavorful and uninspired. I'm not sure if the food got worse or if I've become an overly critical douche as I get older (I'm a fossil almost....27 years old). 

If you've never had tapas in Spain then maybe this place will be of interest, but I can't compare this Russian Hill institution favorably to the tapas bars that I've been fortunate enough to visit in San Sebastian and Barcelona.
author: Peter F.

description:
We visited for dinner recently and enjoyed a satisfying meal and great ambiance.  The restaurant was quite lively but not too loud.   We were still able to have a conversation and hear each other which is often difficult in a packed restaurant.
The food overall was very good and service was attentive.
Our drinks were served in a timely fashion and seconds too.  We ordered the following:
Escargot - ok-the croutons were a little too greasy
Grilled Squid - very good -perfectly cooked
Patatas bravas -very good
Crab cake - very good
Croquettes - very good
White bean stew -very good
Chorizo- very good

We opted for having dessert across the street... the ice cream was yummy!  
Looking forward to returning and trying the paella.... it looked great.
author: Lizete S.

description: Loved it. They were great about pacing our dishes and ordered them perfectly. The pulpo was so tender and the anchovies had great flavor. They also brought bread, olive oil, and olives to the table, which was nice. The sangria was good but not really special. The dates to finish were delicious.
author: Kayla M.

description:
Tip- parking spots are very limited in this area.  I recommend taking public transportation.

Paella is excellent
author: Jan D.

description: went there  tonight  it was good we had a crab bisque .that was hot which is good usually soups are lukewarm and my husband had tripe he insisted I try it ,I haven't eaten tripe in a long time.  not for me, mussels and also octopus was actually not bad with some potatoes. I had prawns with  some spinach  and also short rib with mash potatoes. it was very good and we shared a chocolate mouse sponge cake with espresso and brandy in it ,no it was just a little brandy.
author: Nellie J.

description:
Went here with a colleague after a long day at the Moscone, and it was just the change I was hoping for.  We liked 6 of the 8 things that we tried and I'd definitely go back.  The service was quick and really good.  We got there a little before 7 and the place was empty, but a little after 7:30 people started streaming in and the place was full by around 8:00.  That's how fast two different rounds of hot tapas came out.  We were in and out in just over an hour.  It wasn't rushed, it was just quick.  I found the potatoes to be dry and oddly flavored, and we discovered that neither of us cared for tripe, but there were 6 other dishes that I'd order again: the chorizo, shrimp with garlic, eggplant and goat cheese, lamb skewers, mussels, and the empanada.  If you're going, go early and go hungry.

They don't take American Express and I wish they did because when I'm on a business trip, it's easier if it's all on the one card.  They do take Mastercard and Visa, and I understand that amex charges them more, but here's the way I see it.  On the next business trip I'm tempted to try a different restaurant just to keep my life easy, and what did the restaurant save?  Maybe $1.50.  I don't get it, but they serve really good food and they filled up quickly on a Tuesday night, so they must know what they're doing.  Anyway, if you're okay with paying with Mastercard, Visa, or cash, call them first to see if they're full, and then have a great meal.
author: Don W.

description:
This place does not take reservation.  We went around 7pm on a Saturday evening.  The place was packed.  We were asked to take a seat in the small waiting area.  It was small, but had a comfy, cozy feel to it.  Our table was ready sooner than expected.  We got lucky and were seated by the window.  Our wait person was Arturo, and he could easily be one of the best waiters I have ever had - friendly, customer-oriented, professional and efficient.  5 stars for him alone.

We ordered 4 tapas and one main dish (small portion) and it seemed like the right portion for the two of us.  We liked everything we ordered:  grilled lamb chops, braised duck leg, grilled squid, mussels, small fried fish - with a couple glasses of Cava.  Very nice meal.  

Would want to return with more friends so we can try more variety of foods.
author: nardo m.

description: Tiny restaurant with good food. The sangria and tomato w/ goat cheese were super good. Alot of the vegetarian options have goat cheese. The eggplant and goat cheese were interesting. It had thinly sliced eggplant wrapped around goatcheese and was a cold dish and also tried the mushroom dish which I thought was a tiny bit too salty. Busy on Fri night and parking was very hard to to find.
author: Irene L.

description:
Hands down, my favorite restaurant in San Francisco! The tapas is delicious, and very reasonably priced. The service is top notch! My husband and I have been coming to Zarzuela for over 5 years, and it's been the same group of gentlemen that serve. I've seen a change in bus boy only once. The servers are very friendly, quick, and attentive. My favorite server is Arturo, who is incredibly charismatic and happy, and Andy, the owner, always greets everyone at the door. Love these guys!  

As for the food, we couldn't be happier every time we come here. Favorites include: boquerones (white anchovies marinated  in garlic and vinegar) patatas bravas (fried potatoes in a not too spicy red sauce), croquetas (deep fried goodness), braised quail, roasted duck leg, scallops, braised short ribs, grilled lamb chops, and, of course, the sangria! Can't wait to go back!
author: Amanda L.

description:
We went there at exactly 530 p.m. On Friday Valentine's Day to celebrate our anniversary.

We got in right away.  I'm in a wheelchair so that's great to have the service so wonderful like that

Parking in the neighborhood is horrific so really make plans about that we both ordered paella because we wanted to try a vegetarian one and we wanted to try one of the regular paella.  The vegetarian was actually better than the regular paella.  I got the regular paella it had a lot of seafood in it which I'm not a real buff of seafood and I actually asked for just chicken and shrimp. They actually gave me shrimp clams oysters calamari and fish in it.  I ate it anyway since it takes a half hour to prepare.   It was okay not bad it was $36 so it's not cheap vegetarian was also $36 and it was just ok the sangria for $20 is a great deal and the sangria is handmade and it really tastes wonderful the desserts are the best part we got the sponge cake with a coconut cream on top and then we tried the cheesecake.  The cheesecake was half frozen still so that wasn't so nice but the sponge cake was phenomenal and I would recommend it highly we got coffee actually we asked for coffee but it never came into we're almost ready to leave by then most of our desserts was almost finished so don't get coffee   The goat cheese appetizer was delicious.  Thge service was okay it's not great  it seemed to really be a place for people that are repeat customers and they got a lot of attention from the maitre d I would go back someday but no I wouldn't run there to get there quickly

Our total with tip was about $160.
author: David F.

description:
Saturday Night Review.

40 minute wait? Are you... serious? Okay fine, 40 minutes really isn't that long, and honestly... it was worth the wait.

We ordered way more food than we needed to... paella (min. 2 orders required), roasted duck leg, potatoes, octopus, grilled eggplant w/goat cheese, and I think the potato/onion omelette. And a bottle of wine. Three of us managed to consume almost all of the food... and everything was excellent.

For such a busy place, the service was excellent. I haven't gone to THAT many tapas places, but this one certainly left a good impression for me.
author: Victor C.

description:
Spanish Tapas Orgasm!

Ok, so they aren't on the menu, but are usually a special: ORDER the dates, stuffed with almonds and wrapped in pancetta!  OMG!  Little, tasty gems of flavortown in my mouth!

Seafood Paella was very flavorful and chalked full of all kinds of tasty seafoody bites of goodness.

We also ordered the goat cheese and marinara - very tangy and deliscious.  Was wondering what made the dish so tangy when I found a grape in the marinara - Ah Ha!  Such a great idea.  I wanna try it at home.

Ssshhhhhhh!  Dont tell, but - I always ask to sit in the back.  It's so much cozier and romantic, and sometimes you can get that entire room to yourself.
author: R D.

description: Good food and great service. Coming back for more tapas next time.
author: Rosyan C.

description: This a place is straight from Spain. Casual, relaxed decor. The tapas are a must. Some of our favorites were chorizo, empanadas, jamon and tomatoes.  Then we finished with one of the best paella I have had outside of Spain
author: Suzi B.

description:
Good food, friendly staff and great selection for vegetarians. I love Tapas/small plates and wine/sangria  in general and this place was great as well. 

I am a vegetarian and we went here for a friend's birthday and there was lots to choose from!
author: Sapna E.

description:
There's so much to like at Zarzuela. 

1) Charming restaurant on possibly the most charming street in San Francisco, Hyde. 

2) Though no reservations are taken, getting a table was easy even on a busy Saturday night. 

3) Amazing food at even more amazing prices. Seriously everything from the wines to the mains is remarkably affordable. 

4) Rustic, authentic tapas. Highlights include a delicious goat cheese with savory tomato sauce, patatas bravas, and poached octopus. 

5) Great service. Swift and courteous.
author: Andrew K.

description:
My friends and I had several dishes.  We ordered 4 tapas dishes: Gambas Ajillo-shrimp sautéed in garlic and olive oil, Sauteed Mushrooms, Jamon Serrano Con Pan Y Tomate-Spanish Ham w/bread and fresh tomato spread, and Callos A La Madrilena-MY ABSOLUTE FAVORITE-Madrid Style tripe that also comes w/sausage, the tripe is cooked perfectly, it's tender and and chewy and has the perfect amount of seasonings.  I suggest soaking up some bread in the sauce the tripe is cooked in.  Also we ordered one main course: Chuletas De Cordero A La Plancha-which are lamb chops w/garlic and rosemary sauce, we ordered the large so it came with 6 lamb chops and this dish was also served w/scalloped potatoes. 

We also ordered a carafe of Sangria-which is a great value because at $20, you get 6 glasses of sangria.  I recommend the Tripe and the Lamb.  The only thing I didn't like about our visit was the wait was a bit long-about 30 minutes.  They did have a nice waiting room.  Also,  I did not like the shrimp dish, it definitely left something to be desired and the shrimp were so tiny.  I do like spicy food but the dishes I had are not spicy.  All in all, I think this is a very nice restaurant and I highly recommend it.
author: Linda C.

description:
The spanish dishes and sangria here are incredible! I came with a big party for a celebration, and the host gave us the entire back room. We asked the waiter to bring out dishes of chef's choice. My favorites where goat cheese wrapped in eggplant, grilled octopus and muscles. 

This place gets busy, so come during off hours and take public transit because parking is scarce.
author: katrina w.

description:
Let me start this off by saying I lived in Spain for a year back in 04 so I'm a bit of a freak when it comes to good authentic Spanish food. I've been many places over the years that claim they are authentic. Psssh.
This place, however, is truly amazing! I swear to you I could imagine being back in that little beach town in the south of Spain when I closed my eyes. :)
The food was incredible. Just the way I remember it... in fact, a little better! My husband and I split 4 tapas between us and a pitcher of sangria. The sangria was some of the best I've ever had. Except for that bar in Las Ramblas... best Sangria on tap ever!! 
We shared the croquetas, patatas bravas, mussels, and serranno ham.
The service, top notch. Our waiter was extremely nice and very attentive.
I cannot wait to go back!!!
author: Kari M.

description:
good stuff here. sangria was fruity and excellent. special grilled sardines we're great. we nervously tried the tripe and it too was excellent - that sauce was phenom. 

this is a tapas place - small plates. the squid was fantastic. we went for the octopus which was good but in the Valencia style (so the waiter said) so it was far softer than we were used to. grilled octopus in Greece is meaty, for example. and that's how we really like it.

all the meals we're great. and the best ice cream in town is on the adjacent corner!  swensons.
author: chris m.

description:
I used to come here all the time when I lived a few blocks away. It used to be the place I would take guests to when they came to visit. But I moved out of state and sort of forgot it even existed until some nice old man from Barcelona told me it was his favorite spanish restaurant in the city. So after six years of being away, I decided to try it again. It did not disappoint...

The wait was just as long as I remembered it being. The restaurant is tiny and popular so the wait, even on a Wednesday evening for two people is a 20 to 30 minute wait. However this seems like a small price to pay for the amazing food that will entertain your taste buds. The sangria is good, and better than most places, but the real reason to come here is for the paella. It's features a generous amount of seafood and chicken and perfectly cooked rice. The tapas are also tasty. We had the goat cheese and the pork tenders. The goat cheese was delicious but only came with two of the tiniest toast slices. How in the world is anyone supposed to eat a whole dish of goat cheese and tomatoes with two tiny pieces of toast is beyond me. That is my one and only criticism. Otherwise I was pleasantly surprised to find the same great food and service.
author: Dani D.

description:
Usually we walk by this place and wonder how we will ever get a table considering the usual wait out in front and the fact that they don't take reservations.  I had some friends in from out of town and we all decided just to go for it...and I'm so glad we did.

Only had to wait for about 15 minutes for a table, and got one right by the front window.  The patatas bravas were excellent, and the serrano ham and chorizo were both mouth-watering.  I was hesitant about the empanada...but it turned out to be the best thing we had all night.  Word to the Wise: if you're going for the paella, don't get much else.  It is super filling, even for 4 people.  No dessert for us, just vino.

I was actually expecting to pay much more, but it worked out to about $20-25 per person including corkage.  Not bad at all, especially in this neighborhood!

This is a wonderful little place on Russian Hill that deserves all the hype.  I'm not sure what all these other Yelpers are griping about, but this place was thoroughly enjoyable.  Cheers!
author: Drew W.

description:
We wanted to treat an out-of-town friend to something special and made our first visit to Zarzuela, long deferred because of concerns about parking.  At opening time on a Saturday evening, we were seated promptly and immersed in the pleasant ambiance.  Though the service and our overall experience were good, food and drink were definitely a mixed bag.

Our Sangria was a fruit punch, with little evidence of wine or solid fruit.  Tortilla Espanol was more like a souffle with an artificial quality but no sign of potatoes or onions.  The Mejillones Al Azafran (mussels) were small, dry and over spiced.  On the positive side, the Calamares A La Plancha (squid) and Gambas Ajillo, though small, were very good.

We've enjoyed tapas for years in Spain and elsewhere in San Francisco.  For us, Zarzuela did not live up to its reputation.  But with a well-planned selection of edibles, it may offer a very agreeable experience.
author: David H.

description:
I picked this place on a whim going purely by the number of stars on yelp. This worked out great. The food was amazing. We had crab cakes, sangria, the duck, and some other tapas I can't remember right. Everything was perfect.

The service was really good. At first, our server forgot the duck. But once we mentioned it, he had it to us in minutes. We got the mango cheesecake-like dessert. It was fantastic.

I will be back and recommend nobody else go so that I never have to wait for a table ;)
author: Ben V.

description:
After years of wanting to try out this place but never having the patience to (a) search for parking in the area or (b) wait for a table for an hr outside, we FINALLY did it! Perhaps my expectations were super high because of the time it took to finally get inside OR maybe I read the yelp reviews a tad too much :( but we were very disappointed with our experience last Sat.

Here's what we tried that was delish:
- Jamon Serrano con Pan, Tomate (toasted bread with a tomato chutney spread and prosciutto on the side)

- Champinones al Ajillo (mushrooms in garlic sauce)

- Gambas al Ajillo (Sauteed Shrimps in Garlic and Olive oil - slight spice kick thanks to fresh garlic)

- Seafood Paella

- Definitely get the Sangria (but ask for less ice - as it definitely dilutes the delicious flavor)

The rest was so so:
- Patatas al Ajillo (Fried Potatoes with Garlic & Sherry vinegar - overcooked)

- Pimientos Asados (Assorted peppers - tasteless and limp)

- Tortilla Espanola (Potato & onion omelet - stodgy and tasteless) 

I've lived in Britain most of my life and had a ton of Spanish friends, but have to admit have not been to Spain. So, I don't disagree with those who say this place is authentic. We just didn't enjoy it. Sad that we've become more accustomed to the flavorful tapas at other non-authentic restaurants!
author: Sonal P.

description:
Yo vivía en España y este lugar es muy auténtico, pero que no tenía la Patatas Brava esa noche, que, en mi opinión es la vara de medir para la comida de España se hace bien.

Highly recommended!

Everything we got was delish. Goat Cheese in Tomato, Plato de Queso, Setas Caliente, Mejillones, and the pancetta wrapped dates, wow. Just tapas this time but I'll be back for some of their Paella. 

Good place for a date although parking sucks and there are no reservations but its a nice neighborhood to walk around.
author: Michael V.

description:
Just a really, REALLY great place.
Exactly what we wanted, an authentic Spanish restaurant. 
Food was awesome and very flavorful.
Service? The waiter was amazing! Made us hungry, offered advice, then? Serenaded my lady for her birthday with a voice fit for a stage. 
Not only will we go back, we can't wait to go back.
And? I tried at least 7 different items, shared a carafe of Sangria, enjoyed a fantastic poached pear, and somehow stayed under $100 before tip.
I wouldn't recommend for someone short on time though. This is a true Spanish restaurant, eating is the experience so give yourself time to enjoy!
author: Reino C.

description:
Delicious!

There was a line outside at 5:20!!! We managed to snag a table and the food was soooo yummy!

Here's the rundown

-The calamari is tender and not chewy and it's smothered in this amazing creamy buttery sauce.
-Mushrooms, a little oily but delicious.
-the chicken and ham croquetes are crispy on the outside and soft in the inside. I honestly couldn't tell there was chicken or ham inside. In any case, ithey were perfect!
-shrimp and muscles, I didn't try them but my companions did and they really enjoyed them. The sauce from the clams are especially delicious with their bread... So I hear any way 
-empanadas, hmmm I have mixed feelings about this dish. The crust was crispy and the inside soft but the flavor from the green peppers was a bit overpowering
-potatoes with spicy sauce, comparable to potato wedges with hot sauce... Similar to home fries.. Meh

-location is great, swensens is right across the street!!!
-the trek to the potty is a little weird and quite a journey
-wait staff is nice, very attentive
-the dishwasher needs to pay a bit more attention as I had crusty food on my "clean" plate... Yikes!

Overall it was a great dinner! Oh, I almost forgot about the sangria, it's a bit watered down and they don't have the traditional fruit bits in it... They do however add a slice of orange an apple on top... A little weird but what the heck.... Why not?
author: Minie J.

description: I came for dinner with 3 others.  I was going to give it 3.5 stars until I tried the chorizo.. It was fantastic. Best I've had that wasn't homemade from my grandmother. The service was a little shoddy..my gazpacho came with the hot plates and the people who I were with who had cold plates were finished eating before I got my soup. We all go Tapas and they were a good size. 2 each with splitting a third was enough food for the dinner.  Everything was reasonably priced for Russian hill.  The place is small but that gives it the neighborhood feel we are looking for having just moved to the area.
author: Steven G.

description:
I stayed with a family in Spain for three weeks and the flavors from that summer came flooding back when I ate dinner here last night.  The pisto manchego was especially delicious, tasted just like my host mom's cooking. 

As a strict vegetarian, I am surprised that I left a Spanish restaurant happy and full.
author: Molly S.

description: This place is really small. The ambiance is quite intimate and romantic. However the tapas were not as good as everyone said for them to be. One dish that stood out the most was probably the Anchovies. We also ordered the paella; and it was not as good as we thought. The sangria was watered down because they fill the cup with ice! Service was pretty good at least, the waiter made sure we were comfortable  and always checked up on us. I don't think I'll be coming back to this place though.
author: Allie B.

description:
It was time for a girls night out and we all decided tapas was a good choice plus who doesn't love sangria. When we arrived there was a 10-15 minute wait. Since the restaurant is on the smaller side, we had to wait outside which was fine because it was a gorgeous night in the city. The host came outside and offered us to wait inside. That was very sweet. We were brought in and our waiter was very welcoming and had a Spanish accent which made the meal even better (Spanish food served by a Spanish waiter just makes it seem so authentic).

We ordered the prosciutto wrapped dates stuffed with almonds, octopus with potatoes, the Serrano ham, patatas bravas, and paella. Everything was excellent ( with the exception of the patatas bravas bc I've had better elsewhere but it was still good) and reminded me of my trip to Spain, although I did prefer the paella here than the one i had in Madrid. The dates were by far my favorite dish. I still think about them 3 weeks after.  The sangria was also delicious. 

I can not wait to come back and try the other tapas and specials!
author: danielle l.

description:
Here's a little secret: Spanish food is not that hard to pull off -- take one big bottle of olive oil, a couple heads of garlic, a bottle of white wine for cooking, and you're ready to open your restaurant.  This is no knock on Spanish cuisine; quite the reverse, it all tastes great.  But it helps explain why a restaurant as unnerving as Zarzuela still makes it pay off.

Zarzuela kind of feels like the El Torito of tapas; they've all got shirts with Zarzuela logos on them, and they're just kind of shuttling the food out from the kitchen and the people in an out of the restaurant without any particular effort to create a "dining experience."  That may explain a clientele that seemed to be dominated by parents and their teenage kids.  ("Let's go somewhere where everyone likes the food, it's quick, it's relatively cheap without being a pizza joint, and let's get the hell out of there so we can go watch CSI: Miami and the kids can finish their homework!")        

So to cut to the chase: no complaints about the food -- it was all super flavorful -- the service was lousy, but ulimately forgiveable, and the dollar for dollar value was unbeatable.  I'll probably even go there again... once I have teenage mouths to feed.
author: Laurence W.

description:
let me begin by saying stepping into Zarzuela is like being transported instantly to a restaurant in Madrid.
