The decor, ambiance, service, the patrons (even down to that tiny waiting area in the back) and of course the food...made me feel like it was an early evening in Madrid enjoying simple yet delicious tapas.  Everything was amazing: the serrano ham, tortilla, melted goat cheese, patatas bravas +++.....muy delicioso!

I especially love it when restaurants can take you to places and Zarzuela does it amazingly!
author: Teresa T.

description:
We arrived around 8 on a Thursday night - the front room was fairly full, with no room for a table for 4, so we were immediately offered the back room. It was nice to be seated right away, and it was a lot quieter in back, but we also ended up basically sitting between the kitchen and the bathrooms, which was less than optimal.

The wine selection is all right, and they have half bottles as well as a few offerings by the glass. We had:
tortilla espanola: not bad, but pretty bland - not much going on here.
chorizo al vino: I thought this tasted really hot-doggy, but other people seemed to like it.
Jamon Serrano con Pan, Tomate: This one was pretty good - the bread was nice and slightly toasty and the jamon serrano went really well with everything. It would have been a lot better if the tomatoes had had any flavor, but overall the dish was nice.
Champinones al Ajillo: I liked these quite a bit, and more than at other restaurants I've been to. The mushrooms themselves seemed quite tasty and weren't overpowered by the sauce or anything. One of my favorites of the evening.
patatas bravas: I agree with other reviewers that these were not a specialty - in my opinion, it's probably better to pass on these.

We also had paella for two (to share among four), and combined with all the food above, we had some leftovers. The paella was a bit greasy but pretty tasty - there were a couple of good sized prawns in there, along with smaller shrimp and pleasant, juicy mussels. 

Overall, I was happy with it, but it wasn't great - I'd go back to Alegrias rather than come back here.
author: Lisa K.

description:
Excellent paella! The sangria is also excellent. We managed to get a corner table and had decent dim lighting and a romantic ambiance to it.

While we were there, there was a couple celebrating the wife's birthday, one of the chefs came out, gathered everyone's attention, and sang an upbeat birthday song I've never heard of. It felt like I was listening to an opera singer performing, he was THAT good!

Onto the food.. The paella was amazing in all aspects, taste, looks, the whole nine yards. I'd recommend to try it.
author: Joseph W.

description:
The food was average, nothing really stood out and made me want to order more. It lacked flavor and seasoning. I understand if they want to showcase the natural flavor of the ingredients, but even adding a pinch of salt would have helped. Don't get me wrong, I love Spanish food, but the food here didn't do it for me.

The sangria was definitely good, not as strong as the one you can get at Cha Cha Cha's. Service was friendly, and they don't take reservations.
author: Jun W.

description:
Such a cute little place! My friends and I came here for a birthday celebration. I was sure to skip the tight top and go for the loose, forgiving t-shirt. To prepare myself, I loosened my belt. :) Hey, I'm not here to impress anybody, just eat good food! I was starving when I arrived and so excited to start pigging out! 
Between the 3 of us, we ordered the following: small special lamb dish, the paella, the hot mussels, the snails, the duck breast and the grilled octopus. Oh yeah and a carafe of the Sangria. 
Honestly I wasn't a fan of the lamb- it was gamely and my portion had a lot of chewy fat on it (ewwww!). But it did come with delicious mashed potatoes (whoever invented such a perfect food should be lauded as a hero!) that I hogged. 
Everything else was fantastic! The paella was FULL of yummy things- chicken, veggies, fish, shrimp, mussels! The waiter was kind enough to serve us... probably because he saw that we were having trouble. I'd rather leave it to the professionals. 
The octopus and mussels- yummy! Just the way I liked them. Full of flavor and juicy! 
The snails were surprisingly good. They were served on a piece of toast with a green sauce (pesto? I dunno) and some sweet purple veggie stuff. 
And the duck breast!!!!! Wow! So juicy and tender! Definitely a must-have! 
The sangria was meh. But it was $20 for a carafe ($5 for a glass) and we didn't finish it all so it was a push. 
We grudgingly ordered dessert. Only because my belt was no longer loose! As always, my eyes were bigger than my stomach and I wanted us to share 2 desserts. My dinner mates vetoed my greediness and we got the sponge cake. It was ok... I'm curious about the flan and chocolate!!! 
At the end of our meal, we were all extremely full and satisfied. Mission accomplished!
author: Amanda W.

description:
The best thing about this restaurant was the European service.  The wait staff leave you along and don't pick up plates until everyone is done.  This makes for a nice long and lea-surly evening of enjoying tapas with friends without feeling rushed or eating too fast.  The food service is also well paced and not too fast.

The actual food however is lacking in authenticity.  Having lived in Catalonia, Spain I did come in with higher than usual expectations, esp given the raving Yelp review ... but was left disappointed.  A lot of the dishes just weren't authentic or particularly flavorful.  Probably the best thing on the menu we had was the Jamon Serrano and Pan con Tomate.  How can you mess that up though?  Still searching for authentic Spanish style tapas in the bay area....
author: Prachee V.

description: Blown away. Have been to Spain and this is just as good if not better. Had several Tapas and some sherry and bill was under $60.
author: Rhett S.

description:
Having just gotten back from a business trip to Madrid where I ate high end Spanish cuisine on an expense account, I was ready to compare Zarzuela with the "mothership."  Overall, it doesn't compare well.  For that matter, it doesn't compare that well with my favorite Spanish restaurant,  Cesar's across the Bay.  There are some hits but, sadly, a few more misses.  

First, the hits.  They got the seafood salad right.  It's a simple dish but very good.  My only complaint?  It's served straight out of the refrigerator whereas in Spain its kept at room temperature to help enhance the flavor. (Perhaps this is a health code requirement and if that's true, that's BS).  Next, their flan was actually quite good.  I usually hate flan. 

The misses?  There are two issues with the menu:  blandness and too much refrigeration.    The chorizo empanadas were bland.  My 10 year old even hoped for more spice.  The octopus and potato salad was blandness defined.  If you're going to serve octopus, you really shouldn't screw it up.  We also had grilled eggplant stuffed with goat cheese.  What they do is grill the eggplant the night before, stuff it with the cheese and stick it in the fridge and serve.  Goat cheese shouldn't have the feel of an ice cube.  I also had the mussels in vinaigrette.  In this case, it was the same dressing used for the seafood salad so really nothing new.  The biggest miss?  No decent selection of Iberian hams.  At Cesar's in the east bay you get an amazing selection.  Nada here.

The wine list is a decent sampling of Spanish vino.  However, they were out of Cava.  For dessert, I ordered dessert wine that the waiter forgot to bring.  

As for service, it was decent but nothing that stood out.   

Overall, I recommend the owners take a trip to Madrid for a little inspiration.
author: Rob R.

description: Came here for my birthday dinner while on vacation in S.F.  Shared the patatas bravas and steamed mussels.  Both fantastic!  Then shared the paella which was great but a little small for the price.  Overall, the food was fantastic and the service was amazing!   Would return for sure!
author: Marina S.

description: This place is nice and cosy, tucked away in Russian Hill. The food is wonderful. If you like seafood order the paella and even if you don't like the lamb order the lamb. The service was a bit slow although the servers were nice and let us know we had ordered too much food. Also sangria was great and cheap if you order a karafe. Nice place, good for couples and small groups ( it's small so a large group could wait quite a while).
author: Jennifer S.

description:
I lived down the street from this restaurant this past summer for a month or so. After a lot of research on what the locals loved, I chose this for my fiance's visit. 
We loved the atmosphere and the service. The tapas were very good! My fiance said they have the best pulpo (barely cooked octopus) he's ever had...and he knows his seafood. The jamon serrano was great too.
We had Izadi Crianza which paired really well with our dishes.
The only thing we weren't crazy about was the desert...but I can't remember what it was. I think it was the tres leches...?
Fortunately for us, someone had a birthday that evening. A man came out and sang a very loud but very beautiful spanish song. Just another nice touch to such an authentic place. I'd definitely recommend Zarzuela's to others!
They don't take reservations so be prepared to wait unless you show up early.
author: LeAnna C.

description:
FANTASTIC tapas! 

After a week of incredible dining in Barcelona over the summer, my boyfriend and I have been craving tapas but have yet to find a great tapas place in San Francisco. Zarzuela was a surprising find, and right by our apartment in Russian Hill. The restaurant is really small and charming; it feels like someone's very nice dining room or patio. All the tables are very close together, which gives it more of a European feel, and the walls are covered in Spanish art.

We ordered the patatas bravas, calamari, goat cheese, empanadas, and mussels. The patatas bravas, goat cheese, and mussels were fantastic; the empanadas and calamari were good but not great (although my boyfriend said the calamari were his favorite dish). Everything was pretty reasonably priced, at about $7 per dish -- not bad, considering that the portions were larger than I expected for tapas and that 5 dishes was enough for the both of us for dinner.

Downsides: longish wait (we had to wait about 15 minutes for 2 people without a reservation), disappointingly small options for cava :(

As a side note, the restaurant was much more dressy than we had anticipated. We stopped by on a Friday night, so it may have been mostly people dressed up for dates, but almost all the guys had a jacket on and the girls were mostly wearing dresses or nice slacks. We felt awkward in our sweaters and t-shirts, but forgot about it once the food came...
author: Jackie C.

description:
Parts of this meal were great, others not so good. I really enjoyed our server - wonderful personality (and a great singing voice!). I also respected the fact that when he forgot to put in our mushroom order, he apologized profusely and seemed sincerely sorry about the mistake (other restaurants should take note...errors don't need to ruin a meal if they are handled properly). I also really enjoyed the sangria and the crabcakes (lots of flavor).

Unfortunately, the rest of our food wasn't spectacular. The short ribs were overly salty. The goat cheese with marinara, lamb chops, and mushrooms were all good but nothing special.

I will probably try this place again because it's close to my house and because I really enjoyed the service. Maybe other dishes are more memorable.
author: Amy F.

description:
I live a couple blocks from here and have been wanting to try Zarzuela for a while now. Finally with an excuse to go, I left not as impressed as I thought I would be. The food was just okay, and our waiter forgot we ordered and then forgot about us later on too. Whoops! I think it was just a very busy Saturday night for them, but we didn't feel the mom & pop atmosphere everyone raves about. 

We ordered the cod croquettes which were nice - we would get those again! Enjoyed the olives and bread. We tried the lamb and the beef tapas. The beef was so salty we could barely eat it. The lamb was good. Not amazing.

Overall paid about $90 including a half bottle of house wine. For that price I don't think I will be back on the regular.
author: Natalie N.

description:
The wait was about 10 minutes to be seated without a reservation.

We ordered a few tapas to share between two of us. My two favorites were the Patatas Bravas and the Sauteed Shrimp. The sangria was pretty tasty as well, although I can't think of a time I didn't enjoy sangria.

Good spot for sure.
author: Amanda S.

description:
We took some friends from out of town along with our teen kids. Right off the bat, I will say the food is alright. Every time we ordered a tapa it came out within minutes. We figured the dishes were pre-done and put in the refrigerator. They dishes themselves came out cold along with the food. 
The dinners were not very Spanish authentic. I had the pork tenderloin and there was nothing creative about it. Same goes with my husband's fish dish and our guests lamb chops. 
We didn't try the authentic Spanish Paella and probably because the waiter wasn't that interested in us. So, the service was okay. 
Last, the ambiance was just okay. We were seated in their "cave." It wasn't so bad but the room smelled like disinfectant. Sometimes too much to handle.
author: Jane K.

description:
I don't care much for this type of cuisine, but I managed to find several dishes here that I enjoyed.  The service was perfect, and the prices reasonable.  Four of us shared multiple dishes and left very satisfied for a total bill, including tax, of less than $80.

This is a small place and is very popular.  They don't take reservations.  I would suggest getting there before 6:00 p.m. to avoid waiting for a table.  And don't even think of driving here - parking is impossible and they don't have a valet.
author: Bay G.

description:
Espana, que lo hecho de menos. 

I'm not gonna sit here and tell you I'm Spanish, have lived in Spain and know my tapas and this is as good as you'll get in SanFran.

I'm not gonna tell you that the gazpacho, pisto, jamon serrano, and zarzuela are as good if not better than most you'll find in Espana.

And I'm certainly not gonna tell you about how perfectly the ambiance captures Spain nor how the reasonable prices are a perfect alternative to experiencing Spain (you're welcome, I just saved you a $1,000 plane ticket).
author: Gabrielle J.

description: This is one of our favorite restaurants, fantastic food!  The servers are efficient and friendly, ensuring a a perfect dining experience each time we are there.  I haven't been served anything that hasn't been absolutely delicious but the oxtail stew, shrimp with garlic and olive oil and short ribs are amazing.  I have to share my enthusiasm for this place even though it may make my wait longer.
author: Karen S.

description: I've traveled throughout Spain for many years and hoped Zarzuela would be the answer to my need for authentic paella.  Not to be.  Although the waiter was courteous and well-informed of each dish, I knew there would be a problem when he said the paella would only take 25 minutes to prepare and serve.  The rice was so under cooked that I should have sent it back (my fault).  We took the majority of it home and separated the rice from the other ingredients and ended up cooking it another 20 minutes (it was THAT under cooked)!  Very disappointing, especially on their signature dish.  Prior to the paella, we did have several savory tapas - all well prepared.  The sangria was so-so; stay with the wines.  Although the gazpacho had many things to praise, I prefer the recipe used by Botin's in Madrid (if you have to ask, then you haven't tried the best gazpacho!), and this version did not hold a candle.
author: Richard C.

description:
My boyfriend has taken me here twice and both times the food and service were excellent.
Most recently, we got the potatoes in spicy sauce, crab cakes, pie of the day, and the short ribs.  All the food was tasty, but the sauce on the potatoes was so good that I was using the bread to soak it up. The short ribs were so tender and tasty, almost like a beef stew. We also had sangria and the chocolate mousse soaked in brandy and espresso - both good. 
Overall, the service was speedy and pleasant. The restaurant is romantic and intimate. 
Hopefully we will go back :D
author: Vivian C.

description: The food and service level were simply excellent. The paella looked delicious though did not try (this time). Will be back again soon.
author: Kent H Y.

description:
My favorite place in San Francisco for tapas.

Gone there since they open about 16 years ago.  Food is consistently good.  Service is very friendly and has had the same staff.

Paella and sangria are a staple for us.  The oxtail is excellent and so are the lamp chops.  For tapas, tortilla espanola, mushrooms, shrimp with garlic oil.

They do not take reservations so get there early if you don't want to wait.  On a nice day you can wait outside and get sangria.

Must try place in SF!!!!!!
author: FoodieSF U.

description:
I am sorry to be the bearer of bad news. I love the look and feel of this restaurant--it has a lot of potential and great things to offer, but their food was just... lacking.

A friend and I went here and practically ordered half their menu--because we're fatasses.

- tortilla espanola: always my staple at Spanish tapas restaurants. This one was good but more like.. ehh good enough.
- jamon: this one came with cured ham served with toasted bread slathered with tomato spread. Delicious... best plate of the night.
- tripe: I love tripe. This dish reminded me of the good days, but it didn't taste as spectacular as it looked. Just--lacking flavor. The Cantonese do it better.
- empenadas: these were made with chorizo. And they were pretty good--the crust was flaky and crispy but not quite the empenadas I had in mind. Generally I'm used to a more oily and savory taste--this one was kind of like a pie. Still good but definitely not the best empenadas I've had.
- seafood paella: this was the biggest disappointment. I've had quite a few paellas in the last two years and this one was one of the less flavorful ones I've had. Just an overall disappointment. The rice was too chewy too.
- flan: this was good but not great. A little thicker than I'm used to. I think I can make better at home.
- sangira: good but a little watered down. Also, not the best sangira--probably ranks 5th or 6th on my list of top sangiras I've had.

At least it was priced well. Under $100 for all that food! But alas, nothing spectacular.
author: Joanne Y.

description:
I had dinner here with two friends on a Tuesday. The setting was intimate and dim lit.  It has a very classy feel to it.  The food was good but the service was outstanding and extremely accommodating.  I've never had such great service that was on point yet very genuine before.  The service was so outstanding that the table next to us asked for ice cream and the waiter went across the street to order them an ice cream cone! 

We ordered the following items: 
Calamares Andaluza (Fried Squid):  The squid was very tender, fried in light oil but not breaded, and had a good balance of flavor --it was lightly spiced.

Roasted Potatoes: These did not impress me very much.  It's nothing but mere roasted potatoes from the oven. 

Championones Plancha (Grilled Mushrooms): I enjoyed the mushrooms very much in its garlic sauce.  I would order this again. 

Scallops: The scallops were very small, comes in 4 pieces.  I can't say that I was very impressed but the flavor was delightful and I did enjoy it.  It was cooked perfectly.  

Seafood Paella:  I would have to say that the paella takes the cake and I would go back here just for that.  It was bursting in flavor and had a great mixture of shrimp, clams, scallops, squid, and octopus.  It is probably one of the best paellas that I've had. 

Carafe of Sangria: Their sangria is extremely tasty! It was quite perfect.

Chocolate Cake: The cake was very rich and filling. It was fairly good. 

Overall, I would go back here if I was craving for paella and sangria.  I'd definitely return again if I'm in the area.
author: Brenda T.

description: Out of almost 2 handfuls of dishes, only one was great, and that was the grilled calamari. The service and the ambiance are pleasant enough, but not enough to entice me to sit down again for more lack-luster dishes. And- The search continues for the go-to tapas in this city.
author: F S.

description:
I stumbled upon this little Spanish tapas spot by hanging out in the neighborhood one Friday evening with a friend! Not sure why I don't venture out to the Russian Hill all that often. Walking by it, it was packed, which is a good sign, means the food and service is pretty great. 

So, I decided its a definite go to spot, and me and my friend decided to go give it a try. 

It was a Thursday, and we got there around 7:30ish-8ish, and they don't take reservations, the front of the house was already packed with people enjoying all their meals. So, we thought it'd be a wait, but nope, they have this cute little room in the back, which we were worried it was like 2 tables by the bathroom, but not so much! 

We opted for a table in the back, which was nice, we were able to talk, and the service didn't lack whatsoever, it wasn't one of those sit in the back and we'll make it out here eventually! In fact they were very attentive. We started with their homemade sangria, which I have to say was incredibly delicious. They brought out a bowl of olives, and olive oil with a bread basket. 

We ordered a few appetizers, the goat cheese in the tomato sauce in the clay pot, seriously who would not enjoy warm goat cheese on a toasted bread with tomato sauce. I have full intention of replicating that dish. We also tried their veggie empanada's, they were ok, a bit too much dough to my liking. We also ordered their shrimp for an appetizer, which was just cooked shrimp in garlic, I'm not a huge shrimp fan as it is, so they were ok, kind of thought they might be filled with a bit more excitement. For an entree we shared a special, which was a pork shoulder with mashed potato's, I have to say the sauce the tenderness of the meat, and the mashed potato's definitely hit the spot. 

We didn't try their dessert, because we saved room for Swennson's Ice cream across the street, which was ok, I'm still a huge fan of Bi-Rite! 

Overall experience was fantastic, definitely will go back to try this place out again, and try other things on the menu.
author: yana Z.

description: I highly recommend this restaurant!! The atmosphere is inviting, warm and welcoming. The wait staff is very friendly and the service was very good.  The food was delicious, and large and small plates are available.  This was our second visit to the restaurant and were very pleased both times.
author: Laura S.

description: Long wait; they don't take reservations. Nothing special at all. Paella below average. Tapas: lamb chops, shrimp, eggplant, crab cakes, meatballs below average too. Sangria was good. I would not go back. Too many great restaurants in SF to  go to.
author: Suzy T.

description: The Paella from this place is made by the heavens and served with love.  I normally take a few trains in order to share a few glasses of wine and a healthy portion of paella. I hope to try some other dishes soon but for now I cannot get enough of the paella.
author: Andre C.

description: No reservations but we were able to walk in. Everything was excellent. The jamon/bread, grilled calamari, and scallops stand out in my mind from visiting here last month. Go here and be adventurous - we enjoyed everything.
author: Sean S.

description:
With 85 reviews already, there's little I can say about Zarzuela that hasn't been said before.   It's probably my favorite Spanish tapas restaurant in the Bay Area.  They don't really do Paella, or at least they don't do it all that well, so I go elsewhere for that.  Still, as far as tapas are concerned, Zarzuela dominates.  The have a nice selection of Rioja wines, as well.   All in all, a wonderful dining experience at the top of Russian Hill.

Va a zarzuela para comer y beber!
author: David O.

description:
Wow.  This is my new favorite restaurant in the city.  

Food: Delicious!  I had to restrain myself from eating all the goat cheese covered with eggplant appetizers myself.  Great tapas selection - everything was excellent and worked well together.

Drinks: Can there even be bad Sangria?  If there can, this wasn't it.  I split a half carafe and wished we had gotten more.  

Service/Ambiance: My favorite thing about Zarzuela is actually a tie between the food and the people.  This was truly old world SERVICE.  You are waited on and served by the entire staff.  Recommendations were spot-on and respectfully delivered.  With all the attention and special touches put into everything, we felt like favored regulars.

5 stars all the way.
author: K R.

description: Authentic Authentic Authentic!!! I've got nothing but good words for this place! We went to Barcelona for our honeymoon last year. We were literally speechless from the food out there. The tapas, Paellas, sangrias,  etc. u name it, we tried it. I can honestly say that this place, hands down, comes pretty darn close! Its the great quality. My favorite tapa is Jamon Iberico w/ bread light tomato spread. Their Paella is very yummy. U must try the lamb chops. They're wonderful. We're from L.A and we have nothing to compare it to. We will definitely be back!
author: Bryan D.

description:
Zarzuela is delicious! I finally made it out here after one attempt on a Saturday night almost three years ago. Now that I only live two blocks away, I really didn't have any excuse. I came on a Wednesday night and got seated right away.

Some highlights:
-Red sangria was delicious and tasted like graham crackers
-Chicken paella was hearty and good. Definitely enough to have as a leftover meal
-Croquettes were cheesy and yum

The inside is very cozy and they have small heaters in hand. Great service and will be back!
author: Jeanne C.

description:
I really don't have any complaints, this place was fine.  The servers were really nice.  The place was cozy.  The tapas were good, as was the sangria.  It's just tough to rate this place higher than being "okay" after having AMAZING tapas at Ficelle's in Winters, CA.  

Zarzuela is totally fine.  Cool atmosphere, nice people, slightly pricey for what is served, but it is in SF.  I have no frame of reference for other tapas places in the city, but it's decent.   Just not the most delicious tapas I've had.  I would come back, but it would be mostly for the atmosphere and location, not any strong cravings for so-so tapas.
author: Jaclyn L.

description:
This yelp is a little sangria induced, so bear with me.

I wanted to love Zarzuela. I really did. Long on the list, heard rave reviews, dinner plans with the rocking sister and two friends. I wanted to be blown away.

It ended up being a notch below love, but I did really, really like it. The entire experience was great, but nothing jumped out at me that had me wanting to run up and down Polk Street urging strangers to go.

Well, two things did, and I'll get to that.

Our friendly waiter (though a bit slow in taking our order - he was clearly enjoying himself bouncing around the room assisting all patrons) delivered plate after plate once we had our order in. There was no hesitation once the kitchen got word of what we wanted. Soon enough we were sampling plates of pork loin medallions (one of my favorites), ribs (also delicious), scallops (nothing stood out), snails baked on croutons (inventive and good, but no distinctive taste), eggplant stuffed with goat cheese (too much cheese for me but I can see why people like them) and white bean stew (loved it!).

Again, very good if not just a tad below exceptional.

We ate and ate and talked and talked and ate some more. The buzz of the room was loud and engaging and we added to it. The final dish of the night, a chocolate mousse sponge cake soaking in brandy and espresso was wonderful, and all four of us took turns savoring each bite.

Not sure I needed the brandy, as one of the two things that I absolutely loved was the sangria. A carafe got each of us 2 and change full delicious glasses.

Which brings me to the last thing I loved - all of that listed above came to less than $25/person. An incredible deal, and solidifies a very strong four stars.

I wish I had more of that sangria.
author: Jason B.

description:
NO RICE (except paella)

Even though the chorizo was decent, the fact that a Spanish-inspired restaurant doesn't offer sides of rice for their tapas forces me to give this place a low rating. 

Egg omelette was disgusting too. Cold and looks like it came out of a can.
author: Kyle S.

description:
Cute atmosphere, quick service, friendly co-diners, and delicious sangria.

Would re-wait that line all over again.

But, must agree with yelpers on the paella.  Not the greatest.  The rice was underdone.
author: Anda K.

description:
I don't know what the big fuss is about.  I mean, it may be one of the oldest, if not the oldest tapas place in SF, but the food was mediocre, if that.  We ordered the goat cheese and tomato dish which everyone talks about but it was just okay, nothing special or memorable.  We also got the potato pancake which was not very good in my opinion and would have been better if it was hot, even if its supposed to be served cold.  The croquettes were pretty good but you really can't go wrong with ham, cheese and mashed potato that's been deep fried, can you?  We also got a sausage dish which was, again just okay.  

What I did love though was the location, minus the parking.  That area on Hyde St. is so cute and so San Francisco!
author: Jessica T.

description: The meal was quite disappointing. The sangria seemed really diluted and fake with barely any fruits in it, and we took the gambas dish that was actually made of shrimps (do not order this- not very good)
author: Clément P.

description: I thought the food was only ok and a bit too expensive. The empanadas tasted like it was canned tuna, but the paella was really good. I won't go back but didn't regret going one.
author: Jocelyn S.

description:
3.5 stars. 

The ambiance here is amazing. Lively. Friendly. Jovial. The food, from what we got, was just OK. So, yeah, the ambiance here is much better than its food for me. So I probably won't be back unless I'm with the same group of friends and we share another carafe (or five) of sangria. (:
author: Chung N.

description: Arturo will you marry me! :-) Seriously, the experience was incredible. The food was amazing, the atmosphere was cozy and friendly. Arturo treats his customers like special guests. Thank you!
author: Eugenie D.

description: My friend and I were hoping for a tasty tapas dinner at a nice place. While we enjoyed the ambiance, we were unimpressed by the tapas. From what we ordered, i was left under impression that they don't know how to cook. At all. We didn't finish our dishes and didn't have any desire to pack them to go. We had quail, potatoes, empanadas, sausages and mushrooms. Mushrooms were the only good dish. Flavorless quial, dry potatoes, soggy empanadas, nothing special sausages. On a good note, they have an interesting selection of red wines (as you may note, they don't have a chance of ruinung them by cooking). Their sangria is kind of lame, tastes artificial.
author: Lydia P.

description:
Already well rated... but just wanted to add my two cents...for the nay sayers that indicate the food is bland, I have breaking news... Spanish food, especially tapas, is somewhat bland.  Dont get me wrong, Spain produces some of the greatest chefs and food in the world, but tapas is really all about food that is simple with little seasoning except oil, garlic, and the occasional spice... while travelling through Spain I can't tell you how many times we thought, "hey, can I get some sauce for dipping!"
So, with that said, Zarzuela has very good tapas, decent and cheap sangria, nice atmosphere, great place to come with friends and munch on some niblits...
author: Brett P.

description: We were seated very quickly (though it took a bit longer to flag down a server!) we ordered the potatas bravas, short ribs (which came with a bit of mashed potatos), the seafood paella (delicious!) and the sangria. The sangria was good but pretty strong! Potatas bravas were delicious: crispy on the outside and soft on the inside. The sauce was amazing for all of the dishes (we later opted to dip out bead in the rib sauce versus the olive oil with vinegar. Excellent idea). Overall the service was very good and friendly (despite the slow start). It's a bit pricy, but you get what you pay for. Street parking only, I believe.
author: Jenni I.

description:
Really nice atmosphere, excellent service and great food. Could a girl ask for anything more? How about a pitcher of sangria? Check. 

We ordered 5 dishes to share family-style: potatoes, stuffed mushrooms, empanada, ham with bread and lamb. We were a very happy family. All were flavorful and decently priced and the lamb was super tender. I believe we referred to it as a food-gasm. Definitely coming back.
author: Joan S.

description:
Most tapas restaurants are pretty casual and loud, even if the food is great. This place is a classy white-table-cloth type establishment, quiet and romantic, with great service and very reasonable prices.  

Our favorites were the garlic sautéed prawn, served still sizzling in the pan, and the short rib special, which was extra tender and savory.  My husband had a glass of Sauvignon Blanc and I had a Spanish sparkling wine, both at about $6/glass and quite excellent, so we didn't have to triple our tab by having a decent drink with our meal.

I recommend going early evening, when there's still plenty soft light coming through the front windows. And I recommend not parking on the nearby steep slope of Filbert St, where it is difficult to get out of your car without falling down the hill and worrying that your car is going to roll after you.
author: Indigo S.

description:
This is one of the few Spanish restaurants that I've been to in San Francisco and they do a nice job. The decor is really authentic and the seating layout allows for a nice ambiance. I was surprised to find more seating at the very back room. On a nice evening you can sit outside while waiting to be seated and the hose was very friendly, the wait on a Saturday night was around 15-20 minutes.

We ordered some sangria and it was very refreshing (although I would recommend trying the sangria from Cha Cha Cha as well). The chorizo was probably the best dish we ordered, the chicken was pretty good and they seem to have a different empanada every day.

The location is great since there are tons of bar options near by if you feel like an after dinner drink. I think I'll come back here when the weather is nice since sangria always tastes better then. Only reason this place isn't five stars is that the food didn't blow me away.
author: Bryan B.

description:
I'm from Spain and I've been in other Spanish restaurants in San Francisco and for sure this is THE BEST ONE! I recommend the tortilla de patatas, Jamon serrano, Croquetas and the goat cheese with tomato!!!

Enjoy and congrats to the restaurant!
author: Miriam G.

description: pretty good. chorizo is nice. also dem taters with the red sauce. I enjoyed it a lot :P
author: Jeremy H.

description: Just returned from a vacation in Spain.  This restaurant is as good as any in Madrid!
author: Jeff S.

description:
I love this place because of Arturo. We were first directed to this place by the brilliant barista at Philz coffee, Greg. He highly recommended it because it's got the best server in the world. OK...

Upon arrival, we mentioned Greg to Arturo, and he took us to this incredible tapas journey. 

Everything was tasty, the pitcher of sangria for $12 is great, the lamb was amazing, calamari and octopus dish are both very nice, the port poached pear just hit the spot after a heavy meal. 

Have been back a couple of times just to continue the great relationship with Arturo :)
author: Yuchi C.

description:
I came here for my 30th birthday and absolutely no regrets, which is good because I was a little anxious about planning the right evening for my thirtieth. Zarzula is a great place to celebrate birthdays, the caveat being that they do not do reservations which can be tricky. However, many other places will hold your credit card and then not seat you until your entire party is there, some places will then give your table away after 15 minutes and proceed to charge your card. So, I decided to do to the no reservations because although I adore my lovely friends, many of them always run 20-60 minutes late- due to pub trans, parking etc., We arrived at Zarzuela around 6 and the place was already packed! The host was very nice, he took my name and asked that I let him know when my entire party had arrived. Around 40 minutes passes by and two friends have not yet arrived, but the host sat us at the table that had just opened which was nice and my friends arrived only minutes later. We sat by the door so it was a little cold and we waited a bit before having our drink orders taken, my friends and I began to talk about the wait in annoyance, I was worried that my b-day was off to a bad start- and it was my 30th! We were all in desperate need of sangria so perhaps we were a bit impatient and there aren't many waiters there. Our waiter arrived and was so friendly and upbeat that we all forgot about the wait and cheerfully began ordering carafes and tapas galore!

My favorite tapa was hands down the grilled calamari! I've eaten grilled calamari many times and it's never tasted so good- the texture was perfect, not too rough and they use a ton of fresh lemon. I also loved the bell peppers which are delicious with the bread. We also had the potatoes, the mussels, shrimp, spinach pie and the goat cheese and tomato sauce- apparently one of the most popular items and it was good, but the other tapas stood out more. We also ordered the Spanish omelet, I've tried this tapa at other places and wasn't impressed, but here it was great- it's moist and not dry like others I've had, it's also served with a tomato mix in the middle which is very good. 
Also, the sangria is amazing! I think they must add cinnamon or cloves, I don't know what their secret is, but it's dangerously good! Since it was my birthday our waiter brought our table a chocolate mousse cake, I'm not much of dessert person so a couple of bites was a shock to my palette- a good shock, it was very decadent and my taste buds were pleased. Our waiter also had the entire restaurant stop what they were doing so he could sing to me in Spanish, it was adorable and he has quite a voice! We had many, many tapas and even ordered a total of three calamari plates and two potato plates, I was expecting the bill to be outrageous but it ended up being around $25 per person- not bad considering we ordered a lot, had 2 carafes of sangria and they will refill your bread basket as many times as you would like, it's a great think because the bread is really good. I'm so happy to live only a couple of blocks away from this place and I can't wait to go back!
author: Natalie M.

description:
We spotted Zarzuela while riding the cable car down Hyde Street on the way to play tourist on Lombard Street. I'm glad we went back. What a sweet little restaurant. I started with the tasty house-made sangria. We started with a couple of Tapas Caliente: a baked goat cheese in a red sauce and the calamares. Both were great and got us ready for the paella. I've eaten a lot of paella in my days and Zarzuela's is right up there. 

Our waiter was great. He advice on a bottle of wine was helpful since we weren't familiar with most of the labels on the list. He assured us we would enjoy it with our selection of food and he was right. 

So two thumbs up to Zarzuela. I look forward to our next cable car excursion to Russian Hill.
author: John F.

description:
For the most part the food was excellent. I enjoyed bruschetta with ham enormously and the braised octopus was mind blowing - seriously, you have to get the braised octopus. But on the other hand, there are sooooo many tapas restaurants in SF that I'm rather tired of them all. The bruschetta and octopus were delicious, but other than that I can't imagine anything that really makes this particular restaurant stand out. 

Also, the sangria was rather disappointing. There was no fruit in our carafe! They must have made a big batch of sangria and poured it into smaller containers because it tasted like sangria but where was all the alcohol stained fruit?

I would come here again, but only if somebody else brought me here or if I just happened to be in the area.
author: Tian X.

description:
FOOD:
1.) Pork skewer appetizer = Preetty good. Succulent, tasty. With mashed potatoes 
2.) Seafood Paella =  Preeety good as well. Assortment of clams, oysters, shrimp, squid, and the pieces of fish in the rice was sooo soft yummm
3.) House Sangria = Wow! Their sangria was bomb! I've had sangria before but this ws yummmm, had like a sweet punch taste on my lips mmmm


SERVICE:
haha They pamper. They serve you your food, they pour your wine, and refill your water frequently. It's nice if I'm in the mood for that, but also it seems a little bit like they're rushing us and trying to get faster turnovers.

ATMOSPHERE:
It's small, quaint, personal character, like a nice dinner date with dim lighting, but in a casual way.
author: Angela L.

description:
DELICIOUS. 

Paella was the most authentic I've had in the states. The spices are full and complex. Large portion too (enough for next day's lunch).  We also had the patatas bravas (on the spicier side fyi but in a good way). The ox tail stew special entree was so good we cleaned the bowl with the crusty bread they served. Great wine selections.

Service was attentive and they were able to get us out quickly so we didn't meet an appointment. Although I would have loved to stay in such a welcoming atmosphere. I'd come here for groups or double dates so that you can try lots of plates!
author: Jacqueline S.

description:
I admit I love tapas. Whenever I get a chance to try a promising place I will, unfortunately my current home town does not provide many choices so I was thrilled to see the reviews here and made the trip up the hills to try for myself. 
Good thing I arrived early enough to be seated within 15 minutes, the place draws a crowd. 
The food was phenomenal, I have my list of favorite dishes and they had them all. The baked goat cheese was the best I ever had, and my wife confirmed this assessment. The other dishes were equally great, and the service was friendly and efficient for such a busy place. It's bustling and loud like all good tapas restaurants it seems, and sitting by the Window provides additional entertainment as it's a busy intersection. Don't try to take the cable car though, it's packed with tourists and there is no room to get on at any stop it would seem.
So, if you love Tapas (the traditional way, not the random small serving of anything kind), Zarzuela is a the place to go.
author: Uli B.

description: It was just okay. We ordered the Paella, Gazpacho, some Tapas, Bisque, and Sangria. Everything seemed fresh yet nothing stood out as being all that special. The poor service really irked me and felt unappreciated and sometime ignored. Luckily in San Francisco you never have to go to the same place twice.
author: William F.

description:
This is a very, very special place.
My fiance (boyfriend at the time) and I had just returned from a 2-week vacation in Spain, where I was introduced to paella.  How I missed this virtually perfect dish for 26 years, I don't know.  We moved to Nob Hill, and while waiting for the bus saw the giant paella mural on the wall at Union and Hyde.  As we wiped off the drool from our mouths, we promised that Zarzuela would be the next restaurant we would try.  Although we were hesitant coming right off a trip from the land of paella, we thought we'd give them the benefit of the doubt and try the cuisine.  I hate to say it......but Zarzuela may be, no IS,  the best Spanish food I've had ever had.  Truly authentic, delicious, and the best part about the place is the staff.  Mostly the same guys every night, and aside from being gracious and friendly, they are so welcoming that you feel like you're in their family house in Spain.  Sometimes when I walk home late at night I see them sitting in the restaurant after everything's closed up, just drinking wine and enjoying each other's company.  And there's one guy, I don't know his name, but he sings a Spanish happy birthday song that is simply beautiful.  Overall, one of the best restaurants in San Francisco.
author: Courtney K.

description: Love this place. Have family in Spain and been many times. This is way Spanish tapas should taste. We had many dishes and they were all very good. Great sangria too. Last but not least Excellent service. Orders come out quick and they keep the drinks flowing. Highly recommend!
author: Paul H.

description:
Great food and our waiter was very cool.  They had the tempranillo that we love (Pago de los Capellanes) and they had our favorite jamon as well -- Jamon Iberico.

It was a great start to the meal.  We didn't get Paella this time around, but, I think we'll definitely try it next time.  We had the seafood stew and that was good as well.

For dessert, we ordered the Pears in Red Wine sauce and our waiter was kind of to bring us a mango cheesecake as well!
author: Zivago L.

description:
All decent, but nothing really note-worthy.

We ordered a wide variety of tapas, roasted peppers, albondigas, patatas, cured meats, and several others, and they were all ok, but not as flavorful as some of the other tapas spots around the city and certainly not on par with the value of other places.  Again nothing was horribly wrong with any of the dishes, but really there's just not much to say about any of them negative or positive.

The sangria was good, and the service was good too.  It's a great restaurant space at the corner of union and hyde, fun to watch the people/cable cars roll by, but with the other options around I don't foresee coming back here really.
author: Jake D.

description:
I ate at Zarzuela for the first time on a rainy Tuesday night, and so I wasn't expecting a wait. The place was hopping--it took my two buddies and me 40 minutes to get a table. There isn't a bar inside, so leave the poor conversationalists in your friend group at home, or it's going to be a long 40 minutes.

Nice decor with an intimate feel. In addition to the 30ish seats in the main dining room where we sat, there's a back room with a table or two. Much quieter, I suppose, but lacking some of the charm of the main room.

We started off with Pimientos Asados (peppers), Rollitos de Berenjena (eggplant and goat cheese), and a pitcher of sangria. I especially recommend the peppers. Moving on to hot tapas, we ordered Gambas al Ajillo (shrimp in garlic and olive oil), Mejillones al Vino Tinto (mussels), Patatas Gravas (potatoes) and another pitcher of sangria. Both the shrimp and mussels were excellent--I recommend ordering seafood from the tapas menu.

Last, we split two entrees: short ribs and pork medallions. Short ribs were oh so tender and melted in my mouth. Pork medallions were enjoyable but not particularly memorable, though we were two pitchers of sangria deep at that point, so my focus was not at its finest.

For dessert, we ordered the port pear. Light and sweet and a good palate cleanser. I had plenty to eat, and our bill (including the sangria) was only about $100, which I consider a good value for the quality of the meal and the ambiance. 

In short: come ready for a wait, and take advantage of the whole menu. You're missing out if you don't share the dishes among your table.
author: Mike W.

description:
This place is marvellous. Let's put it this way, it is a romantic spot, family restaurant, and also works for big parties too. Service is superb; the servers are SO friendly that you'll think they made your day. 

I went there for dinner on a weekday night and it wasn't packed, we got seated right away next to the window. The waiter came and greeted us in a very polite manner. Since it's our first time eating in Zarzuella, we took awhile browsing at the menu. But, the waiter didn't seem to rush you at all, even when he checked on us once in a while, but always returning with something: a dish of olives and spicy peppers. The spicy peppers is an extra thing he brought us, because he learnt that we love spicy, so he gave us that pepper from his friend who just got em from Peru. How sweeettt :-D

The dinner overall was really enjoyable. They make great sangrias, and their traditional dishes are excellent. The croquette is really good (it's a must), there's seascallop as the special of the day, it was yummy too. really juicy.

I'd want to go back again, it's something I would seek more. Furthermore, the pricing is just right for a great cuisine like Zarzuella.
author: Rika P.

description:
Great tapas, fantastic wine menu, and very knowledgeable & friendly service staff.

I went back to Zarzuela and actually had a far different experience than the first time.  On my second trip, the manager / host / maitre'd / whatever was incredibly rude.  The table service was cold and impersonal, though the food was still excellent.

My first visit was  "4," while my second visit is a "2."  Hopefully, I'll get a better experience if I ever go back.
author: Bryan G.

description: Wow. Just wow. From the simple goat cheese and tomato spread to the amazing shrimp and garlic concoction, this place will take you straight to Spain without breaking the bank!
author: Emily D.

description: These are the most authentic Spanish tapas (pinxtos) that I've tasted since I spent a couple weeks touring the Basque country. AND that is after spending a few years in the DC-area eating at Jose Andres restaurants. BOOM. Well done.
author: Aubrey O.

description:
I've been eyeing this place and its playful muraled outside wall while sitting on the 45 for a while now. decided to try it for a date night and it did not disappoint. The ambiance was bright but not overwhelming, bustling but not busy. We got some great recommendations from our server. All the tapas we had were very good...

Favorites: garlic olive oil shrimp, lamb shanks, bomba** sangria

Service from all the waiters it seemed was really helpful, knowledgable, and attentive- which is a huge plus.

Repeat spot for sure
author: Sean M.

description:
Went here off Yelp recommendations and could not have been happier.  We walked in and the guy told us we could wait for the front or get a table immediately in the back room.  We took the back room and haven't regretted it for a second.  It's like you're in the back room of someone's house and they are cooking especially for you and the few other tables there!

We got the goat cheese in tomato sauce, croquettes (which you should dip in the tomato sauce from the goat cheese), sauteed shrimp in garlic and olive oil (dip bread in the leftover oil) and tortilla espanola.  EVERYTHING was incredible along with the bottle of red wine.

The waiters were friendly and attentive and I'd go back and request that back room anytime!
author: Samantha S.

description: We love this restaurant. We have been regulars since 1994 when it first opened and still love going there. The tapas are tasty, the service is very attentive, and the ambiance is understated Russian Hill. The parking is tough in the area, and the wait for a table can be long but that is to be expected with any high quality restaurant. If you are looking for spanish food or something in Russian Hill, this gets top marks from us.
author: Rob C.

description: This place was awesome. I miss San Fran and this is one of the reasons. The food and service was wonderful.
author: Randy H.

description:
If you go on a weeknight you can usually get a table pretty easily (no wait) unless you come right at the peak of dinner hour. If you do have to wait, there's a room off to the left side. The first time we stopped by here there was a wait and we didn't realize there was a waiting area so we ended up going somewhere else. 

The tapas are very authentic basque spanish style and very good. It's hard to go wrong with most items on the menu. Nice selection of cold and hot tapas with a good mix of vegetable only and meat tapas. There are also some delicious large plates/entrees.

The atmosphere is relaxing and the service is great without being intrusive.
author: Emily C.

description:
I have had amazing tapas in Spain, and let me tell you, this comes nowhere close. I had been fairly excited to eat here, but after my meal on Friday, I'm pretty shocked that this restaurant made the 100 Best of the Bay. Now, I don't really like ranting about restaurants and I try to only write things on Yelp that I would tell the chef/owner of a restaurant. That being said...

The food was uninventive, very under seasoned, and simply unimpressive. Now, because it's tapas and they have a lot to choose from, I'm going to say that maybe we just ordered all the wrong things. But I don't even like using that sentence "maybe we ordered the wrong things" because if something isn't stellar, it shouldn't be on the menu in the first place. We had the tortilla espanola, the chorizo in wine sauce, the braised quail, and the grilled calamari with aioli. The first was screaming for salt, the second was tasty but was pretty much a piece of chorizo that you could buy anywhere and cut into pieces yourself, the third was too dry and also screaming for salt, and the last one was good but nothing special...and needed salt.

The best part of my meal was the bread, which wasn't even that good, but by that point I was just that hungry. But the olive oil they served it with was delicious and I literally soaked 5 slices in it as my dinner. 

And, I didn't even have time to enjoy the company I was with as much as I would've liked because the food came out so fast it gave us no time to talk. It's obvious that they either had everything pre-prepared or the dishes didn't take much time whatsoever to whip up because 1 minute after we ordered we had our first plate. We couldn't have been there longer than 30 minutes!

Our waiter was friendly, but his smiles were not enough to save the errors in execution of the food. I left feeling disappointed, and a little angry we took so much time to find parking only to end up with a meal like that. 

Could I cook what they served me at home? Yes. Could I do it better? Yes. There are plenty of great tapas restaurants in the city and next time I go to one, I want to be far more impressed.
author: Kelsey E.

description: Below average tapas and over priced. Go to the Mission for the real deal!
author: Romita J.

description:
I can't say I've ever been to Spain but if all Spanish food is like the food here I'd be 100% satisfied. Great flavorful but not overly heavy food and very aesthetically pleasing. 
 We loved the short ribs with caramelized onions, the calamari and the pancetta wrapped dates. Great service and nice staff, if I lived around here I'd definitely be a regular here. Enjoy!
author: Jayne E.

description:
I apologize Zarzuela....I've enjoyed your food numerous times, but yet to write a review.

Sangria-It's good, not great.  But it's tapas.  You have to get it.

Crab Bisque-Absolutely phenomenal.  Not too crabby, not too creamy, just the right amount of everything.  Start with it....it's a good thing.

Eggplant wrapped with Goat Cheese-It's cold, which turns some people off, but not me.  It was a different experience, but one have again.

Jamon Serrano-My favorite dish of the meal.  The ham is perfect, the bread(and spread) are great, and honestly, you can't go wrong with a perfectly done ham.

Empanada of the day-I've had this a few times, and I've loved it and not been a fan(obviously it changes every day.....duh.)  

Creme Brulee-It's Creme Brulee.....you can't really screw it up.

All in all, a phenomenal experience.  The cook/owner even came out to check on our meal.  I like it better than Cha Cha Cha.....
author: Ashkahn M.

description:
This is, by far, the most authentic Spanish/tapas bar in San Francisco.  Every time we go, it does not disappoint.  

I've never lived in Spain, but I've been 4 times, visited cities there large and small, and got married there for crying out loud - and every time I go back to Zarzuela I feel like if I close my eyes, I'm back in Madrid.  

Kudos to Zarzuela for not selling out (like so many other 'Spanish' restaurants in SF) and putting tacos or arepas (not that I have anything against those foods, they're awesome, but decidedly not Spanish) on the menu and still calling themselves Spanish.  They're old-school authentic tapas and paella, and I love it.
author: Jennifer A.

description:
I love their tenderized pork, octopus tapas and their paella. 
Their sangeria is decent, I have better ones at Cha-Cha-Cha. 
I like their very homey, friendly waiters and cosy atmosphere.
author: Catherine T.

description:
A sweet and savory taste of Spain.  I went because I'm a fan of the Basque region and wanted to see what they offered. 

You sit down and are immediately brought olives, of course Sangria is a staple so I ordered that while I waited for a cheese plate for a starter. It felt good to not be rushed, the waiting staff leaves you alone and lets you enjoy your food. if you're glass is empty they'll come to the rescue, just the same as when you're bread basket is empty they save the day. Very attentive. I recommend the Mejillones Vinagreta 
(Mussels vinaigrette) super flavorful and great to dip your bread in.
author: Morgan M.

description: Love this place. It is not quite the same as eating Tapas in Spain but Zarzuela's offers great food for an incredible price. Always fun to come here with some friends to share some Tapas. I would definitely recommend it to anyone. Just be aware that is is very popular and there might be a line, especially Thu-Sat evenings.
author: Lisa L.

description: My friends and I had a great dinner here. We got here pretty early, I think right when they opened, so we didn't have any problems getting a table, but we could see what it would've been like had we arrived just a half hour later. A popular but unpretentious spot in the Russian Hill neighborhood, and everyone loves tapas, right? So between the four of us we shared: croquetas, sauteed mushrooms, empanadas, paella, and a flan. Oh, and some sangria, too (yum!). Everything was very good, but I think we all liked the sauteed mushrooms extra-much! They come to you in this little iron skillet, like fajitas, and they were de-lish! Their empanadas were unusual in that they weren't enclosed little pockets like you'd be used to--it was more like a strata or a lasagna. Still good, but I don't know if my brain actually though of them as "real" empanadas. The paella was good, but it did seem to get a tad dry as the evening wore on; eat it fast out of that pan. Finally, the flan was very tasty, but nothing extraordinary. The waiter was great, and it was a very enjoyable experience overall--a good casual place to hang out with friends and loved ones. I'd say probably a bit too noisy and crowded for a romantic dinner, though.
author: Steph H.

description: Cute neighborhood date spot. Love the Spanish wine and tapas. We had the lamb chops, baked goat cheese and mussels. The lamb chops were a joke. They were sliced super thin and they only give you 3 so you basically are paying $15 for 1 lamb chop. Not cool.
author: J F.

description:
Mmm tapas!  They are delicious BUT don't come hungry because you will be waiting for at least an hour should it be a weekend and a party larger than 4.  But just head down to your fave Polk or Hyde street haunt and have a drink or 3 - they'll call when your table is ready.  Awesome.

My fave dishes are the goat cheese in tomato sauce, the eggplant and goat cheese (I like cheese!), tortilla espanola, and my new find- the mushrooms.  The bf swears by the spicy chorizo but me and my pescatarian ways can't vouch for it.

I came with 5 peeps, ate lots I'd delicious food, and drank delicious sangria.  And the bill was $20 per person - woo hoo! Or, ole! (couldn't help myself - long day at work)  

Just don't go on sun or mon - I've tried about 5 times.  Just tend to have tapas cravings then I guess.  Alas turns out they're not kidding when the say they're closed then.  Sigh.
author: Lisa R.

description:
Get their early if you have a group since they don't take reservations! Especially if you'd like a more private table on the perimeter of the restaurant. Otherwise, on a busy night, it can be a bit of a tight squeeze, and you will be rubbing elbows with your neighbors.

The service and food were both good, and I enjoyed the overall experience and would definitely go back. 

Although, I was a little disappointed with the waiter's lack of knowledge on the wines. I asked about pairings and what he recommended, but all I could get out of him was "that one is good....and so is that one." It negates the point of having a wine menu! 

While the tapas were excellent, the paella was not the climactic point in the meal I was hoping it would be. The paella was good, but I've simply had better.
author: Sonya Y.

description:
Nob Hill Gem. Charming, romantic, and cozy tapas restaurant with fast and friendly service (the owner seats you). I'll have to jump on the goat cheese bandwagon here....amazing! Best dish by far. Everything else was good, but by no means a show stopper. 

4 dishes, a carafe of sangria, which was really freakin' good, and dessert (bread pudding was absolutely mouthwatering) for $56.....total!! Great value play.

They don't take reservations so be prepared to wait...if it's not too cold out there's some fun antique shops you can check out in the immediate vicinity, otherwise they have a waiting area inside (FYI - there's no bar).

Can't wait to go back.
author: Kristy M.

description: I tried the paella which was pretty good.  I did need to add salt.  The sangria was refreshing and yummy.   My husband said the chicken dish he ordered was good.  The only problem is, of course its in San Francisco and the tables are tight together, small waiting room and parking can be hard.
author: Aerin L.

description:
I had the pleasure of growing up with the son of the chef and co-owner of this restaurant. In my opinion he is a world class chef. I remember once his son and I had come home from the gym. He had a couple extra steaks on hand and asked if we wanted some. We said sure and in 5 minutes he had them cooked up. As I ate it I was floored, here, on a whim and in 5 minutes, he had cooked some of the best steaks I had ever eaten!
There were BBQs and other events, I always LOVED attending as the food was always amazing. Of course the company was good too.
I have of course eaten at the actual restaurant, the food is all amazing, the waiters are very Spanish, which I think is a good thing, although it gets very crowded on the weekends and you had better have a reservation if you are planning to go Friday or Saturday night. 
Basically this is one amazing place run by an amazing guy. If you live in the area or like to go to the city for dinner you HAVE to check this place out at least once. 
-Shahab
author: King R.

description: The food here was excellent. Even my parents thought so and they're very picky eaters. We had the calamari, shrimp in garlic and olive oil, scallops and ox tail and everything was great. And to top it off, the service was outstanding. Our waiter was very attentive, gave great recommendations and did it with a smile. You could tell that he took pride in the restaurant and his job. I will definitely be going back since I only live a few blocks away. My only tip is to get there early because they don't take reservations and it is always packed!
author: Kerry K.

description:
We loved this place.  It was a busy Saturday night and we did have to wait about a half hour.  They have a cozy sitting room with waiters dashing through madly as they delivered meals to customers with the foresight to arrive earlier than ourselves.  We brought our own wine and they opened it for us so we could imbibe as we relaxed.  

Once seated the wait service was excellent;  terse, polite and responsive.  Our tapas arrived quickly and were excellent.  The Cazuela De Queso De Cabra (baked goat cheese in a tomato sauce) was outstanding, the hearty chunk of cheese slowly melts into the warm sauce.

Chorizo Al Vino (sauteed Spanish sausage in a wine sauce) was also excellent.  We had 5 or 6 tapas in all and the bill came to $55 including $15 for corkage.  We were surprised and delighted and I trust we tipped well.

We all agreed to go back soon.
author: Tom M.

description: I recently returned from a one-month visit of  Spain and had several opportunities to sample their tapas.  I have yet to find an eatery that offered the same experience in the Bay Area, until Zarzuala.  Zarzuala has a good selection of Tapas options.  Be sure to ask about other tapas items that are not on their regular menu.....you'll be pleasantly surprised!   The paella was good, but I would focus on the various tapas instead. Otherwise, you get filled up with the paella and missed the opportunity to fully experience the tapas scene.  The following tapas were on top of my list: garlic shrimp, goat cheese on tomato sauce, & egg plant.  While you are inside the restaurant, the staff and decor will make you feel like you are in Madrid or Barcelona.  After diner, stroll across the street and get a scoop of your favorite flavor ice cream at the famous Swenden's or hop on the cable car inbound to Union Square or outbound to Fishermen's Wharf.
author: Jean T.

description: Good food, good authentic Spanish food. Great ambience, worth repeat visits.
author: Malia C.

description: It was yummy, and the service was wonderful. We were fortunate to not have to wait, and had a lovely, lovely time!
author: Anastacia B.

description: Nice hole in the wall spanish place. Got a few tapas that were good. Going to try paella next time
author: Kevin C.

description:
Zarzuela San Francisco, near Nob Hill

How do I honor you Zarzuela?

This past Saturday evening was equally as exquisite as many evenings spent celebrating, remembering, having deep soulful conversations, anticipating tastes treasured from distant visited travels being with a best friend that shares the same intuits.   A birthday was announced by rhythmic spoon sounds played by our dear server/manager/owner of this restaurant.  He wanted everyone to share in the celebration of this persons birthday and if there was anyone among those in the restaurant whose birthday needed acknowledgement, he did not want anyone  left out.  Amazingly, it was just hers and the restaurant was completely filled.  After drinking a glass of the richest Porto he serves in the restaurant, this beautiful man sang a ballad, full voice, from his soul in his native Basque enough to illicit my tears (i want to be here for my birthday!) for the happy celebrant.  When he was done, applause filled the room and then he went over to her for an embrace.  Being here tonight was like being home and being with family.  The atmosphere is simply conducive to its culture of people, food and of Spain, in San Francisco!!.  It has been like this for the many years I have dined here.  I will return many more years.
author: Alohameansilu S.

description:
We decided to do a date night here one Tuesday night. It was totally hoppin' in there that night! 
The server was GREAT! The service was just incredible and he was really on top of everything, gave us great recommendations and was very welcoming. 
The food was excellent! I would DEFINITELY come back here!
Mussels = amazing. 
The bacon wrapped dates = scrumptious.
Ensalada de la casa = perfect
We had a couple more plates, but I forgot which they were right now. They were all very delicious (I have dined out a billion times since this place, forgive my lapse of memory). 
The wine = great selection from South America, but "he" chose, so I don't remember what it was...
I think the best part was that the plates were all spaced out quite nicely. We didn't get everything delivered to our table all at once; very nice.

In all, I would absolutely come back here. Don't come here with someone who is hearing impaired or can't speak up (I had laryngitis when I came and my date had a hard time hearing me). The acoustics are not that great as there are no curtains or carpeting, anything to absorb the sound. Not that big a deal, though. I want to come back and try a whole new dinner, and it is so very possible with their selections!
author: Emdeezy F.

description:
This is a strong 4 stars for a cute and popular spot. We went on a rainy Tuesday so yay there was no wait (no reservations)

We ordered sangria and they brought out bread. Then we shared the paella and got 4 tapas: sauteed shrimp, scallops, sausage, and mussels. My favorite was the shrimp. 

No idea how authentic the dishes are, but they are definitely tasty! I definitely recommend trying it out, but maybe on a weekday if possible so you don't need to wait.
author: Caitlin B.

description:
Undeniably the BEST Spanish tapas in San Francisco. Incredibly authentic and unbelievably delicious. 

Definitely order the croquettas and goat cheese in tomato sauce. 

Service and ambience are both great. But they don't take reservations, so expect an hour-long wait (at least) on weekend nights. It's totally worth it, though.
author: Cristina P.

description:
Fabulous Friday night, filled with delightful food and laughter at Zarzuela!

Arrived at about 8:30 PM to the rich sound of a singing waiter and our party of 2 was told there would be a 45 min. wait.  Zarzuela's is well worth the wait, so we grabbed some seats outside the enjoy San Francisco's *beautiful* summer weather...

About 20 min. later, we are being sat at a table for four - plenty of room to stretch out.  This may have led to them shipping the four things we ordered all at once, but that was my only complaint.

The friendly and non-intrusive waiter brought our half bottle of 2004 Spanish Tempranillo - a perfect fit for the meal we were about to share.  And, he made us toast before he'd take our order.  That's my kind of service!

Padron peppers roasted in olive oil and sea salt are my new favorite!  Too bad they are a seasonal find.  The calamari was done in a delightful lemon aioli, so tender.  I think this will be an "always order" item from here on out.  The scallops in romesco sauce were ok - not writing home about them.  Their romesco does have quite a bit of almond to it, which I did enjoy with the wilted greens that accompanied the small scallops (6 to a small order).  Finally, I don't know I can say enough about the pork medallions in a Cabrales cheese sauce with roasted red peppers over mashed potatoes.  The lightly pungent blue cheese mixes so well with this dish you kind of wonder why you don't try this sauce instead of gravy come Thanksgiving.

All in all, a perfect meal enjoyed in a small, neighborhood establishment with great company.  What a Friday night should be, in my opinion.
author: Charla W.

description:
I love this place! I don't care that I have to wait a bit for a table. The food and the people are so fantastic. All the tapas we had were scrumptious and the paella was perfect. 
My father is a Spaniard and I have had my fair share of Spanish cuisine. Zarzuela is the best in San Francisco.
I do recommend taking a cab there. Don't even bother looking for parking.
author: Melissa E.

description: I won't bore you with details about exactly what I ate or every detail of my experience. Zarzuela has great, authentic Spanish tapas with really good sangria. I highly recommend it, especially for a date
author: Pete K.

description: LOVE LOVE LOVE me some sangria, and theirs was really good!  We had a few tapas as well, and the bread was delicious.
author: Nicole H.

description:
Thoroughly enjoyed Zarzuela's. The service was second to none. Our waiter was professional, responsive and attentive. We had 5 of the hot tapas which at the recommendation of the waiter was the best start quantity. Just the right amount it was indeed because when we were done we didn't feel stuffed or still hungry. The Sea Bass was absolutely delicious. In all honesty I could have had 6 of them I think just didn't want it to finish. Melts in your mouth, flaky and with just the right crispyness on the outside all on a bed of steamed spinach.

All in all I'd most definitely return to Zarzuela's
author: Alan W.

description: A group of friends and I went out to dinner here just last night and everything we ordered was delicious. My favorite tapas that we ordered were the patatas bravas, Gambas al Ajillo, Rollitos de Berenjena and Chorizo al Vino. If you are planning on eating here expect a long wait..we waited 45 minutes for a table, this was expected since there were 7 of us. Parking is horrendous in this neighborhood so either über cab it or plan ahead.
author: Valerie F.

description:
On a recent business trip to San Francisco, I asked the hotel concierge at The Palace to recommend the best Spanish food in San Francisco, and he suggested that I try Zarzuela.

I studied in Spain as an exchange student, and I've been back many times.  I love everything about Spain (especially the people and the food).  The food at Zarzuela reminded me that I need to make another trip.  I haven't had Spanish food this good and this authentic since my last trip to Madrid.

I ordered more food than I should have, but it was so good, I couldn't help myself.  I started with the Jamon Serrano, which was served with a hearty toasted bread and tomatoes.  It was fantastic, aged to perfection, and the best that Spain could offer.  I then had the Calamares a la plancha with a savory garlic aioli.  If you're used to the more typical deep-fried presentation of squid, you are in for quite a treat.  This typically Spanish preparation is healthier and more flavorful, and Zarzuela managed to cook the squid to absolute perfection.  I then followed with the Gambas al ajillo.  The shrimp were again cooked to perfection, and the spicy garlic oil had just the right amount of kick.

For the main course, I had the cordero (lamb), which is prepared with rosemary, garlic and olive oil.  The chops were fork tender, and like everything else at Zarzuela, cooked to absolute perfection.

And of course, I washed everything down with a glass of their authentic and delicious Sangria.

Service was fantastic.  The restaurant is a little noisy, so its not the place for intimate conversation.  But who wants to talk when their is so much good food to eat!!!
author: neal z.

description:
What started out as happy hour in the neighborhood turned into an impromptu date with a stranger. My first visit wasn't meant to be with some dude I met through my group, who asked if I wanted to get some food as everyone else was leaving to their respective destinations. But how can I turn down food? I actually had plans to come here the week following, on a real date. But whatever.

The seemingly small, cozy restaurant truly serves some of the best tapas I've had. It is definitely designed to set the tone for a delicate and meaningful dining experience. Every dish was fragrant and beautiful, and reflected well on the taste. I can't distinctively recall everything we ordered that night, the additional bottle of wine made me forget, but there were lamb skewers, cheese and grapes, spinach pie, and croquettes involved. All were fantastic, that I am certain of!

I would've probably fallin in love with him, right there, by the bathroom if it hadn't been for that additional bottle of wine that made the end of the night so blurry.

But I didn't fret, I had another chance next week. (Which is another story, for another time.)
author: Deanna T.

description:
Great experience dining here. Highlights were:
-great service
-nice atmosphere
-peppers (special) were best peppers i've ever had
-scallops (entree side of menu) were amazing

Fun spanish tapas, I'll be back!
author: Jane C.

description:
In Madrid I ate so much that I threw up. So I do love me some tasty tapas. I had high expectations after it made SF Chronicles best 100, but it was just ok. I think I might give them another star if the dishes more consistent. Also, the portions are small, so eating a lot of bread is important if you don't want too much expense.

Hit and Miss:

HIT- Grilled calamari/squid. Great sauce, soft and tender.
HIT- Papas Bravas. Crispy and hot.
HIT- Beer braised short ribs. Rib slices smothered in gravy and mashed potatoes.
HIT- Marzipan and Chocolate Cake. Oh so tasty, and not heavy at all.
HIT- 6-7 dollar glasses of wine, AND they pour you a good glass.

MISS- Croquette special. Blah tasting.
MISS- Sardines
MISS- Gambas Ajillo. Needed to be spicier, punchier, and bubbling hot.
MISS- Chorizo. I like'em crisped and fried. These were not.
author: Joy L.

description: Great tapas place. They don't take reservations so you'll have to wait for 30-45 mins on the weekend, but it is totally worth it. They have a great Spanish wine selection (maybe 2-3 of their wines are not Spanish) and the food is delicious. Save room for desert, the wine poached pear is brilliant!
author: Anna J.

description: I think my expectations were too high and I was a bit disappointed.  There was 8 of us and so we were able to order a lot of food but there was nothing that stood out and made me want to come back.
author: Suz L.

description:
Quite honestly, I think we ordered the wrong stuff here. It's not that it was bad, I was just really excited after reading some reviews and sadly it fell a little short for me. 

I'm not sure if it was my mood or whether the food just wasn't my forte', but Zarzuela didn't wow me. The eggplant and goat cheese was okay, I wasn't a fan of it served cold, though. The onion potato pie dish was a tad more to my liking although, again, I would have liked to see it served warm. My favorite item was the chicken and ham croquettes - YUM. I would definitely order those puppies again. The bread pudding was good too...but it tasted more like Rose's french toast than a bread pudding to me. 

I think, "okay," has become a bit of a theme for me here because this is how I felt about the sangria as well.  I was hoping for a good buzz to help me along with the fun evening ahead of me but unfortunately it gave me a headache instead.  I had to switch to champagne to get over the hump. 

Not sure if I'll be back but if I do, I'll definitely switch up what I order off the menu.
author: Julia N.

description:
It was date night for my honey & we booked a babysitter & went here. He LOVED the squid in aioli, I LOVED the garlic shrimp & seafood paella with huge chunks of seafood, mussels, clams....mmmmm mmmm mmmm...

Sooo good, please go you will enjoy it!
author: Ashlee F.

description:
