I've been looking for a great tapas restaurant ever since visiting Spain-
    well I've found one.

Everything was superbly cooked and very tasty.

The grilled calamari was my favorite- texture was tender like a stick of     butter- flavors were subtle yet delish. Everything we tried was great- even
the muscles were ok, which would normally make me yack.

 On my second visit to I shared the Paella with a friend. The best one yet for me. Unfortunately I failed to try a Paella in my adventures through Spain so I couldn't compare with the real deal, but I can't imagine it being much better.

Oh yeah - their Sangria rocks too!!
author: Josh H.

description:
During my trip to SF, I came here with my boyfriend and a friend who was in town also for a medical school rotation at a hospital in Pacific Heights. I had Yelped this place before heading up to SF and was curious to try a good tapas restaurant since there are almost none here in LA. We ordered the following items: one carafate of sangria, grilled squid with aioli, patatas bravas, chorizo cooked in wine, tortillas espanola, and the Serrano ham. The total cost of everything was just under $60, but the price was well worth it because everything we ordered was so tasty and the portions were reasonable. Also, the food came out really quick. Overall, I enjoyed the food and ambiance and will definitely be back here whenever I'm up in SF. 

Note: the place gets packed quick. We came here on a weekday at 6pm and noticed that the dining room filled up by 7pm.
author: Tiffany L.

description:
All up a great fun place (but then with sangria and tapas I think almost any place could be fun!)

Party of 6 we had:
*Pork tenders: came with mashed potatos
*Date wrapped in prosciutto
*Chorizo in a wine sauce
*Goat cheese with tomato sauce
*Potato Croquets
*Leg of duck
*Empanada

2 bottles of sangria
Complimentary bread & olives

I'm not sure if any one of them stood out but they weren't bad either.  

Sangria was a bit too watered down in my opinion but still not bad.

I would go back there.  Price per person including tip around $22.   Parking is horrible around here.  I drove around several blocks and ended up having to park in a lot for $20 for the night! (Saturday night)
author: Sujan H.

description:
What happened to you, Zarzuela?! I moved into the hood and the first weekend my sister comes to visit, I take her here (see previous review). But what a disappointment. Quality has definitely gone down. 

The only 2 dishes that were good: potatoes and the chorizo. :x

So many other restaurants on Hyde to try... I'd skip Zarzuela.
author: Han C.

description:
nice, cute lil spot here.  I came here to celebrate a few April bdays and it was definitely a good choice.  For such a small place, they accommodated a group of 11 pretty easily.

If no one told me we got sangria, I would thought I was just drinking juice.  Wouldn't have even been able to tell it was alcoholic if it wasn't for my roommate who turns red just from the smell of alcy.  We kinda split the table up and our half went with 8-9 dishes for 5 people.  Things that really stood out were the crab cakes and beef dish.  Mushrooms were great.  Everything else was good too, but I honestly can't remember the other dishes we had.

Overall a good spot to come out to, but only if you aren't super hungry.  Your wallet disappear if you tried to get eat until your heart's content.
author: Tom Y.

description: Tapas were perfect. We ordered several items. Our waiter gave great advice throughout our ordering.  Fun for all trying different plates of food. Very reasonably priced.
author: Gaetan H.

description:
I give Zarzuela 3+ stars for their food and 4 stars for their service. But the restaurant gets 2 stars for the noise level in the main room (which is where you probably wish to sit). We started with a tasty gazpacho soup and an average salad and then had tapas of patatas, fresh deep-fried anchovies, quail, 4 little dates stuffed w/ almonds, mussels with garlic and saffron (yum but very salty), chicken on skewers and a main entree of delicious short-ribs and mashed potatoes. Sharing nearly everything (there were 4 of us) along with 2 carafes of sangria, we still managed to cross the street to Swensen's. 
OKAY...here's my 2 cents. Zarzuela is VERY popular. We went there on a Tuesday evening around 6:15pm and within 15 minutes, all tables were full in the main dining room. Zarzuela is also VERY noisy, uncomfortably so. Zarzuela's food ranges from average to very good but not spectacular and most dishes can be salty. The tapas are very small portions, so you end up ordering quite a few to get a meal. My suggestion is to order one or two tapas and then order from the main entree list. You can share the short-ribs for the price of two tapas and enjoy a lot more food (although not the variety of course).  We didn't try the paella but it looked good (they require two persons to order one at $17pp). The sangria was YUM; service very nice and spot on.
author: fused g.

description: I was craving paella so came here based on the good reviews and pictures I saw on Yelp. First time I was let down by Yelp! The paella was very bland.
author: L B.

description: After returning home from a summer of travel to the Basque Country, I was craving authentic Spanish cuisine...Thank you fellow Yelpers for bringing me home.  My partner in food crimes and I headed out for a special dinner and were not disappointed.  This place is excellent quality product, traditional spanish seasoning and flare.  Great sangria and wine list with Spanish and local wines.  Don't miss this meal if you want that Spanish meal:  paella, squid in ink sauce...seriously delicious at a good price.  Bring your appetite and hit the tapas.
author: April C.

description: Food was very good and is authentic.  The oxtail was so tender and delicious!  The sangria is also noteworthy.  While I cannot recall the names of the other dishes I had, I surely remember the taste and I'm definitely coming back for more.  Service was great too!
author: Em D.

description:
Zarzuela is one of the great grandaddies of Spanish Tapas restaurants in San Francisco.  They serve a wide variety of good food, and though it isn't cheap, you do get what you pay for.  The atmosphere is good and convivial, though it can get quite loud when full of people.

It can be hard getting a table here, however.  And the biggest caveat is the fact that this neighborhood (Russian Hill) is impossible to find street parking.  If you have a reservation, plan on arriving at least 30 minutes beforehand to find parking and walk in from from a distance.  You have been forewarned.
author: Dave N.

description:
This place would be a solid 5 stars if it tasted just a bit better.

You can't beat it for a date night -- the charm of the neighbourhood and ambience is fantastic.
author: Alex M.

description:
We decided to give this place a try after seeing a great review of it on Check, Please! Bay Area. Since the hubs and I have been to Spain we wanted to see if this place could really offer authentic Spanish food. Much to our disappointment, we were totally let down. 

When we arrived, I gave my husband's first name for the waiting list and they guy said it would be about a 20 minute wait. No problem, we were willing to wait. So we made our way outside and stood on the sidewalk with about 15 other people. After 20 minutes of listening screaming kids, the matradee came out and said the name "Kenny" in a barley audible voice. He then seated a couple that had just arrived. Hubs and I were confused so I went in and asked what name they just called. The matradee said Kenny. I replied did you mean Kerry? He rudely said, "Kenny...Kerry...whatever."  Then he seated us in a dark dirty looking area in the back of the restaurant. Our table was lopsided but we weren't there to eat the table so we didn't say anything. After a few minutes we ordered a large selection of tapas. They came out quickly and we're guessing that's because not a lot of effort went into making fresh tasty food. The portions were small and we were very underwhelmed by the flavors. With that said, we didn't bother to order a main entree or dessert. 

Later that night, both of us had stomach problems. Maybe it was something else we ate...who knows.
author: Shara H.

description:
A very crowded place. You'll probably have to wait to get your table.
Service is fast, friendly and messy like in Spain. We didn't get exactly what we have ordered but the update was done quickly and we got some extras for free...
I am a big fan of Spanish food and this is probably the best you can do with local products. Will definitively come back here.
author: Georges L.

description:
4.5 Stars 
I love Zarzuela! My first Z outing was on a date (and didn't really pay attention to the food) and the most recent time was for a friend's birthday. Now, I thought the only dining area is the one that can be seen from the street (super small without a real waiting area, and the host stand towards the back and not by the front door). However, with our party of 12, we were led towards the back, by the kitchen, where bigger groups are accommodated. 

Straight away, we ordered the alcohol. Pitchers and pitchers of sangria! 
So tasty and not too tart nor sweet. 
Tapas and Food! With such a huge party, we practically ordered everything, and here's what I remember being on the table and liking: 
- Tortilla Espanola (Potato & onion omelet) 
- Grilled Eggplant filled with Goat Cheese - reminded me of a canolli, and so yummy! It's goat cheese, which is one of my favs! 
- Fried Potatoes - perfectly fried and sauce was tomato based with a slight kick to it 
- Croquetas - Wow is all I can say about these! So yummy!! 
- Gambas al Ajillo (Sauteed Shrimps in Garlic and Olive oil) 
- Mejillones (Sauteed Mussels) 
- Goat Cheese with tomato sauce - Being the cheese freak that I am, this was one of my favs and scooped it up with the bread since there were only two pieces of the crostinis. 
- Empanadas - Special of the day was Chorizo. Me gusto! Que bueno! 
For our entree, we ordered the Paella Valenciana, with seafood and chicken. This was ginormous and enough for everyone to have a serving of it. Savory and topped with enough seafood and chicken in every spoonful. 

Our server was nice and accommodating. He brought over a dense chocolate dessert for the birthday girl. We all sang "Happy Birthday" to her, and later, another server sang a Spanish birthday song. Our main server announced that his cohort doesn't usually perform, and we all were expecting "Feliz Cumpleanos." To our surprise, it wasn't, and sounded more like a romantic love song than a birthday one. He had our table, and section totally mesmerized with his wonderful voice as he put so much feeling and heart into it. We all gave him a rousing applause! Wow, who knew Zarzuela could provide that kind of entertainment?
 
Dinner was reasonably priced, at $32 each, which isn't bad considering the amount of food and sangria consumed! 

The interior is authentically Spanish, with the warm colors and tiles. 
Z's is a great place for a date or for groups! 

I would've given Z a 5 star rating but we waited a long time for the olives, bread, and bill. Also, I felt like they crammed too many people at the table, and who enjoys eating with their elbows glued to their sides? 

Zarzuela- Hasta la proxima!
author: Gill C.

description:
I wanna give this place 6 stars.

Their tapas = hooooly shit it's soooo good. Grilled calamari (or something) is gonna knock your socks of. Patatas bravas sauce is omg amazing. The people that go there are just a class of their own too!

First time I went there, a family sat at a table across from me. Their two daughters made me lol: the older one just kept going "HA HA HA! HA HA HA!" and that made the younger one laugh!

Second time I went there, my friends had to wait a little bit before getting a table. While waiting with 2 other groups, this 50-ish man starts a conversation about this "product" that he invented to hide bigger dollar bills. He shows us a 20, 50, 100-dollar bills; then he waves the stack around, slaps it in his hand, and shows it to us again, and magically they all became 1-dollar bills! Turns out, he's a freakin' magician! As in a real performing magician! Haha, top class! 

Amazing food, AND great company!
author: Vien N.

description:
I've eaten here twice now, and it's just ok. I studied abroad in Madrid, so I was really looking forward to tasty tapas. The price is fine, but the food is eh. I found everything to be slightly too oily/greasy and the sangria isn't very strong.

They don't have a liquor license (only beer + wine) which they get around by cooking the brandy down with the simple syrup but it doesn't really make for an alcoholic sangria, which is how I prefer mine.

Try not to sit in the dark cave in the back room if you can help it. The room in the front is at least very well lit with nice people watching. Seriously, I tried everything from paella to chorizo to bravas etc. and I can't think of a single stand-out. They were just "ok" meals. I feel like there's no reason to settle for that in SF. I do appreciate the good service.
author: L C.

description:
Oh man, sooo good! Can't believe I had not been before yesterday. In Germany we have a lot more authentic tapas places than there are in SF but I had no idea how much I missed some proper tapas. 
We ordered the clams in romanesco sauce, the octopus, the boquerones, the mushrooms and a seasonal asparagus dish and all were amazing! The patatas bravas were okay, more of a filler. The olives you get on the table seem to be cured with a hint of cinnamon, which is quite delicious.
To finish off,  we had the cheese plate. Manchego cheese with drizzled olive oil is a great way to finish a meal like that. 
I definitely have to come back! Muy bien!!
author: Alexandra D.

description:
Was here this past Saturday - several birthday parties were going on here that night and the wait was about an hour long (at 7PM). Since we cabbed it here from the hotel and it was windy and sprinkling, we headed to the antique shop next door (Busacca Gallery). I'm not any kind of antique art aficionado, but Mark in the shop was extremely friendly and told us stories about his schooling in PAC, his art collection as well as some classes he's teaching - and our wait went by before we knew it. So make sure to drop in when you're waiting for this joint!

Anyhow,  after being seated, our group of 5 ordered different hot tapas (of mostly shrimp, sauteed veggies, mushrooms, chicken, short ribs) and they were just delectable - yum! Can't comment on their extensive drink menu- was so tired that I would be in a coma if i had a drink at dinner. (but had their orange jasmine tea - fab!)  So after packing in some food and were good to go, the bill came - at a shock  was less than 15 pp- very impressive for the quality of food and knowledgeable staff at the restaurant.

one downside- does not take reservations, but certainly worth the wait.
author: Lena K.

description: Okay little neighborhood joint.  Not one of my favorites though.
author: Anthony D.

description:
Had a mixture of tapas here for dinner:  

Goat cheese with Tomato: yummy. 
Potatoes w/ spicy sauce: pretty basic, but good
Mussels with white wine: good tasty sauce. use the bread to soak up the rest of the broth
Sauteed mushrooms: good
Stewed white beans: a little dry
Chorizo pot pie: tasty but also a little dry
Dates wrapped w/ bacon: delicious and unique
Scallops dish: good
Shrimp dish: garlicky
Chocolate mousse sponge cake: good

Saturday evening around 8:00 pm, no wait. We each had a few drinks and out the door w/ tax and tip was $34. Not bad. Parking is horrible around this area though.
author: Cindy Y.

description:
After honeymooning in Spain last year, I was so excited to tryout the great dishes at Zarzuela. The food was delicious and authentic, the staff attentive.

- Carafe of sangria, an affordable $12 that lasted the whole meal for 2.
- Patatas al Ajillo (fried potatoes) YUM!
- Paella was just ok, would stick to the tapas.
- Assorted cheese plate was awesome

For a romantic and fun Catalan fare, you must go!
author: Shannon B.

description: We went here for a friend's birthday, it's his favorite restaurant in SF. I think it is now my favorite as well. The most authentic tapas you are going to find in SF. The pulpo if out of this world. The staff is amazingly friendly and  they'll even sing opera for you on your birthday..I can't wait to go back.
author: Heather W.

description:
I love Zarzuela for it's authentic Spanish tapas.  

I love Zarzuela because it's SO close.

I love Zarzuela for their croquetas!!!!  Mmmm!!

I love Zarzuela for the sauteed mushrooms!

No one I ever bring here loves Zarzuela.  
Must be the "authentic" Spanish tapas?!?!
author: Lauren C.

description:
Keep the motor running, jump in and sign up for the wait (30-40 mins). The parking here sucks...unless you don't mind paying across the street. 
 
The great tapas here easily justify the wait. The food here is very fresh and authentic. I am a big fan of their Squid Aiola and Seafood Stew. 

We'll be back soon :)
author: Vince N.

description: Great tapas place! Really nice service! Simple basic tapas but delicious and tasty! Very good sangria!
author: Ornella G.

description: You must come here. Warm, professional service, a wide variety of delicious tapas.  I just found this incomplete review on my account 3 months after our visit, and don't remember many specifics -- but I still think about the almond-stuffed dates in a sherry sauce. Love it, and would visit again when I'm in San Francisco.
author: Kim L.

description:
I ordered two dishes, Paella A La Valenciana and Pulpo A La Gallega.

Paella -  The flavor overall was very good, as I could tell they used quality authentic ingredients including the cooking liquid (broth?) and olive oil. The Paella was well prepared with a variety of good ingredients including mussels, clams, shrimp, scallops, chicken, red peppers, garlic, green beans, parsley and lemon wedges as garnish.  I really did not pick on  the saffron flavor, so I don't know if enough was added to the dish, and  it really only takes a pinch to make a difference in the flavor. 
The seafood and chicken where all very tender and not dried out from over cooking. 

Getting the rice to be properly cooked in a Paella dish is very difficult when cooked in a traditional Paella pan, since the pan is traditionally left uncovered for the entire duration of the cooking process.  In this case the rice was still a bit al dente ( undercooked).

Complaints: 
The menu price for Paella is $16.95.  However when I ordered, I was told there is a two order minimum for Paella.  I feel this should be stated on the menu.  The stated price should be $33.90. 

I also asked the waiter what type of rice they use for Paella and he could only tell me that it's "special rice."  I consider the to be poor knowledge menu ingredients.

Pulpo A La Gallega is poached octopus & potatoes - the Octopus was very tender and potatoes were well perfectly cooked but the portions very small, however I understand this because it's a tapas menu  item.
author: Ralph F.

description:
Places like this make me glad I moved in to the neighborhood. I felt like this was my official welcome to city life, being able to walk out my front door and end up at such a great local gem.

Very authentic tapas and, as such, a rather predictable menu with all of your Spanish favorites. All of them executed very well, too. Match it with a solid wine list and you have a winner.

Our waiter, who had all the appearances of being a grizzled old man, turned out to be wonderfully friendly and attentive, reminding me that I'd really be better served not prejudging people.

Prices are totally reasonable for this kind of food, too, and the wait turned out to be much shorter than they estimated. Take note: there will be quite a wait - no reservations taken! - but it will be overestimated.

You'll enjoy this place.
author: Jim P.

description:
Went here for the first time in at least 7 years recently and I'm not sure why I don't think of it more often. The spicy sausages were good but the portion was a little small (6 small slices or so left 2 each for the 3 of us). But the spicy potatoes (I kinda like spicy things if you're noticing the pattern) were great and flowing freely and I think I ate more than my fair share but hey, life is tough. You gotta be quick girls!

The sangria was good as was the paella. Should be back in another few years next time ;-)
author: Michael K.

description: Quite a wait but worth it. Wish they would split the big single bathroom into two smaller ones to cut the wait. At times the bathroom wait seems longer than the wait for a table :(
author: a l.

description: One of my absolute favorite restaurants of all time. I make a point to eat here anytime I'm in the city. Very authentic and very, very, very good food. I've tried various menu items and specials and I've liked every single thing I've ever ordered. Looking forward to my next visit already!
author: Stephanie H.

description:
I live by a bunch of itsy-bitsy and uber cute restaurants, yet I have only been to a few!  So the other day my friend and I decided to go to dinner on a last minute whim, and decided to check out one of the restaurants nearby.  We walked up the street, stopping here and there to peruse the menus at the front doors, and then decided on Zarzuela.  

The place was packed on a weeknight, so we sat outside and watched the cable cars go by for a few minutes while we waited for a table.  We were seated in less than 10 at a lovely little table by the window, and were greeted immediately by a cheerful server who then rushed off to get our drinks (but certainly not before stopping by a large table to sing a wonderful rendition of Las Mananitas).  He got the crowd going and some even joined in!  (I know I was about to!) 

We munched on the bread, olive oil and olives that were placed on our table, while we waited for our drinks.  Our server returned and we then ordered the mussels, the chorizo, the papas bravas, the Serrano ham, and the Spanish tortilla.  I literally enjoyed every morsel of that meal.  The Serrano ham, mussels and chorizo were real standouts and were washed down perfectly with a swig of Cava.  I topped off the meal with an order of rice pudding that was almost, ALMOST on par with my mom's.  And that my friends, is HARD to do!

I loved my entire experience at Zarzuela.  I couldn't stop saying how much I loved it!  The food was so simple and delicious, the restaurant warm and inviting, just like their wait staff.  A perfect evening indeed, and the grand total...about $60.  Small price to pay for such a wonderful time!

I will definitely be back and I suggest you get yourself there STAT.  Take a cab, take a walk, take a bus, just get there and save me a seat!
author: Jennifer H.

description:
Besides the no parking, this place gets 4 stars...They say it gets really packed at this place so we decided to take and early dinner and boy were we glad we did that. After a half hour into our meal it was flowing with people in and outside of the restaurant. 

We ordered a bunch of things to go with our paella. Paella is already filling itself but, we had to over do it and try everything or close to it. The paella was really good but, not as good as the reviews said it was.  Sangria + Paella = good time.
author: Trisha C.

description: Excellent paella, and great service. I tend not to give away 5 stars on any restaurant. But when I'm certain of something, I'll like to share it so everyone can have the same great experience.
author: Gian C.

description: 2 stars for mediocre tapas and pricey paella that costs 18 dollars per person.
author: christina s.

description:
Me gusta SOOOOOOOOO mucho Zarzuela!!

Ok, i can't order what i want in spanish, but it dont matter, cause the server always repeat it for me while writing it down:

me: we'll have the mushrooms..

server: o-ke, los champinones..

me: ..and the croquettes..

server: ..las croquetas..

me: ..and the sausage..

server: ..el chorizo al vino..

me: ..and the meatballs..

server: ..las albondigas guisadas..

damn it, why did i study 2 years of spanish if i can't even order from a menu???

one of my favorite for tapas. it's the real deal. small plates, for good prices (none of this small plate for more then $10 crap...)

the food is truly tasteful. every plate i had there was great. the service is good, and it's kind of casual, so i can go there in the middle of the week without getting ready to go out for a classy night. it's down to earth and friendly. 

the atmosphere is not going to bring my sexy back, but that's fine. there are other places for that. the crowd include people just a bit older. after 5 plates and a 2 sangrias, the bill is around $50, which i like. 

hasta luego!! (is that even correct??)
author: Margie B.

description:
This place needs to get 5 stars just for making me feel at home. Considering it's so far from Spain, they've managed to get quite some things right. For one, the atmosphere is casual and relaxed, homey even, although it's not loud and the place seemed completely devout of obnoxious people. The maitre d' didn't speak Spanish, but once seated were were treated like kings by Arturo, a very friendly Mexican of Spanish origin, who almost sounded like he came from Spain.

The small plates neatly cover the whole Iberic Peninsula, are certainly well prepared, and are not nearly as expensive as at other small plates restaurants. We also shared a bit of paella, not as good as many that I've had in my life time, but certainly better than many others that I've had. I got a glass of a spectacular Rioja for only $6 (OK, I got a second one as well). My dinner companions, as good non-Spanish folk, had sangria. I tasted some. It's made with the leftover wine from the day before, or with some cheap ass wine from Safeway, just as it should be. I haven't even looked at the big plates yet. I will do so in my second visit.
author: Cris L.

description:
Ok, are you ready to order?

Yes, we'll have the patatas bravas, banderillas de cordero, croquetas de jamon y pollo, mussels, fried squid, empanada, paella...

(interrupting me):  Wait, wait, wait how many people are joining you?

No one, it's just us two

You're ordering TOO MUCH FOOD (booming voice)!!

Oh uh, well then, what do you suggest...(feel embarassed for being a piggie-LOL)

BEST PAELLA I've had in the U.S.  Parking makes you want to down a pitcher of sangria once you arrive, but the food is totally worth it.
author: Jennifer H.

description:
The T-shirts don't lie:  Zarzuela has the best tapas in the city.

We've been going to Zarzuela for almost 10 years now, and it is always a great experience.  It was one of the first resautants we visited when we first moved to San Francisco, and it has not changed much over the years, thankfully.  This is tapas done in the authentic Spanish way, not in the trendy wine-bar way.  And it's  a grown-up experience, very different from Las Ramblas or Cha Cha Cha which are too insane on the weekends to be enjoyable, and Thirsty Bear, which is only good if you are very drunk.

They don't take reservations, so expect to wait.  There is a small waiting area in between the two rooms where you can study the wine regions of Spain on a map while sipping a glass of sherry.

The sangria is very good, heavy on the wine and light on the fruit, not too sweet.  A carafe is about $20 and will serve 4.  One thing that they do which is very nice is add additional ice to your glass throughout the meal so that you can enjoy your sangria cold at all times - a nice touch.

And oh, the food.  Tapas are such a treat because it is like having a cocktail party with fantastic hors d'oeurvres right at your table.  Once you get your order in, things come out quickly and the eating frenzy can begin.  Here is what we had on a recent visit with friends:

Tapas Frias:
Jamon Serrano con Pan, Tomate - if you love cured meats, you MUST try this dish.  Slices of bread are rubbed with garlic and tomatoes, and served with wonderfully soft and tender slices of Jambon Serrano.   I could eat this all day long - makes me think of vacations in Spain

Tortilla Espanola - classic tapas dish, wedges of a potato, onion and egg "omelet" with a ratatouille-like garnish.  Light and fluffy

Boquerones - these are not the salty brown oily anchovies you know from a jar - they are marinated in citrus almost like a ceviche, and are so tender and tasty, and they are white, not brown.  Served with a salad with delicious slices of apple

Plato de Queso Variado - 3 assorted cheeses including Manchego, a blue cheese, and a soft white cheese, served with grapes and candied walnuts and apple wedges

*We also shared a bowl of the gazpacho, which is so garlic-y and wonderful, perfect Andalusian-style preparation, with crunchy croutons on top, like Summer in a bowl*

Tapas Calientes:
Calamares Andaluza - classic fried calamari, even better if you use the goat cheese in tomato sauce for dipping

Cazuela de Queso de Cabra - baked goat cheese in Tomato sauce, warm and tangy, great on bread or with the calamari

Croquetas de Jamon y Pollo - I LOVE the croquetas here - light, creamy on the the inside, crunchy on the outside (panko-type crust) - mmmmm.

Gambas Ajillo - very garlic-y sauteed shrimp dish, tender shrimp

Mejillones al Azafran - mussles in a saffron sauce, plump and savory with a good sauce for dipping

Patatas Bravas - potato wedges in a spicy sauce - somehow the potatoes stay crispy under the sauce

Zarzuela is one of those institutions that remain a good bet, no matter what.  They take pride in their cooking and hospitality.  Worth driving across town for, finding parking in an impossible parking neighborhood, and waiting for a table.  I wish that there were other good tapas restaurants in the city, but for me, Zarzuela is where I will always recommend if you want a well-rounded, authentically Spanish, experience.
author: Liz S.

description: This place is just OK, Years ago it was much better but since it has become so overly popular the staff has stopped caring and the food is assembly line production....last time I had send 2 plates back, Success ruined this place---if you want something special look elsewhere.,
author: Bill B.

description:
4.5
Tapas mmmmmmm!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
Everything is mmmmmmmmmm here!!!!!!!!!!!!!!  
No mmmmm for no reservations, but get there early, roll with an entourage of like 16 deep, ask for the back room, a few pitchers of sangria, order one of everything on the menu and you will not be disappointed.  This is an old San Franciscan spot, so don't come up in here all high maka maka.  
Excellent service, mmm and no parking, no mmm!!!
author: Aaron I.

description:
Too. Much. Food. 

As in my friend and I ordered way too much and then ate it all because it was so good. Oh, AND the pitcher of sangria, oh AND the dessert. Do not send 2 girls who haven't had a thing to eat all day on a wandering mission to find a place to eat in which neither one can agree and there are hills every turn you make. Mass quantities of food will be consumed. 

It was totally worth it though. I love tapas, so I was excited to introduce my friend to my love of tapas. We stumbled upon Zarzuela by chance after deciding that neither one of us wanted to cook, and neither one of us wanted to get on muni, so we walked, and walked, and then walked some more to end up here. 

I had to deduct a star for the wait. We were seated relatively quickly at a back corner booth, but then no one noticed us for a good 20 minutes. So strange. The waiter was apologetic and sweet, but it kept happening all night. Maybe he was having an off night or something, but dinner turned into a 2.5 hour adventure. Beware of the back corner booth! It also got kind of loud, but there was a large party in the room. 

Food is great, Sangria is great, Decor is great. Yum Tapas!
author: Jessica R.

description:
Other places serve Mexican tapas, or Mediterranean tapas

Here they dare serve....tapas-style tapas.  What a concept.

There is no twist, there is no edge.  Just tapas.  Sit-down table style.  Lots of little things marinaded, fried, lots of goat cheese, sausages and vinegar.  It is real, and tasty, and honest, and fills the soul.

The atmosphere is jovial, comfortable, homey, nice, unpretentious.  You can laugh out loud here, grab a friend and slap his back.
author: Gil S.

description:
Walked in at 8 on a Wednesday night and the manager of the place greeted me with a wine list. I waited for the girls to meet me for dinner and drank a delish Syrah from Catalunya, Spain delivered by the manager himself.

Great service. Great Sangria. Great tapas! 

This is my new go-to for my dining out needs. (Oh! The cable cars rolling adds to the ambiance!)
author: Ashley K.

description:
I would definitely go back! 

*Great Food
*Good Spanish Wine (Tempranillo)
*Authentic Spanish Flavors
*Great Selection
*Great Waitstaff (Tenors Extraordinaire)
*Recommendation:
Crab Cakes, Lamb Chops, Octopus, Paella Valenciana, & Squid

Tip:
     Come early as they don't take reservations
     Parking is scarce in Russian Hill (cab it, cable car it or walk it)
     When celebrating a birthday as for a Birthday Song :)
author: Christina D.

description:
First time I tried a snail, but not the first time I poured salt on one. 
Zarzuela is great for both large groups or an intimate 2 person table. If you don't like the noise, I recommend arriving before 6 or after 10. Every time in between is packed, but worth the wait. The service is enjoyable and the food is fun for you can order a variety off the menu. The main appeal is tapas idea. Awe... and I almost forgot the sangria is  perfecto!
author: Dee C.

description:
Whilst in San Francisco on Election Night (a red dot in a blue ocean), the UF and I happened to go by one of our fave tapas restaurants.
It didn't disappoint.
As usual, the manchego cheese plate was awesome - we paired it with a never-fail albariño.  Gambas al ajillo was next and, yes, the olive oil and garlic was absorbed into my bread (the UF, sadly, is gluten allergic).
Croquetas were so-so; I don't know why I keep ordering them everytime I go.
The arroz con leche kicked the flan's ass - I totally recommend it.

Our waiter was cool; though Basque in origin, he was born in Mexico and insists on calling himself Mexico so he received the appropriate levels of abuse.

On the cable car line on Russian Hill - don't miss out on the whole experience.
author: Juan M.

description:
Love.This.Place!!!!!

Such Heart!  Such Good Food!  Such Great Service!  
What more could one want.  

Ahhhh. a parking lot perhaps?

They don't take reservations but did suggest that I make an effort to get there with my party of 7 others at 6pm on a Saturday night.  It's early to dine but you know, we stayed until about 8:30 and never felt like we were being vibed to leave.  It was a remarkably good dinner with LOTS of Sangria and I really think that this place is Not Too expensive.
I think that for the amount of food that we ordered and for the amount of Sangria that we drank, $50/person was great!

Arturo is amazing for several reasons.
First he is just a great attentive waiter.
Second, he is a fantastic singer and I want to go there for my Birthday so that he can croon his beautiful birthday ballad to me!
Thirdly, because he convinced me that the paella rice was NOT undercooked, that what I thought was undercooked were the crispy burnt bits from the bottom of the paella pan (and if you know me, you know that I LOVE carcinogenic food)!!!

So there you have it.  We ordered nearly everything on the menu and i have to say that the squid was my most favoritist!
author: Leslie I.

description: Friendly little place in Nob Hill. Food is delicious! Service is great! Their tapas are tasty and perfect to share and did I say delicious?!
author: Kajal P.

description:
Wow.  I live nearby, but usually don't make it all the way up to Hyde street.

It's interesting that one of the comments complains about slow service - we got our food in a blink of an eye.

However, what really deserves five stars is the food.  Even the simplest tapas plate we ordered (pork on skewers, essentially) was the most exquisite meat that was tender and done in a very not run-of-the-mill fashion.  

To summarize - food is light but ample and VERY delicious.  Prices, for those concerned are well below what they could have charged.   A great discovery and I'll be sure to be back there soon.

This was also my "virgin" time with eating snail.  Again, prepared so that it melted in my mouth and I can't wait to try again.
author: greg s.

description:
I was introduced to you, Zarzuela, for the first time back in 1999. Since then, yes, I'll admit that I've been to other restaurants. 

But please don't call me unloyal, Zarzuela. Although I was fairly happy with you back then, you see there *are* other restaurants out there. I returned with fond memories of passing plates of tapas to friends, laughing, soft, glowing light...but I had never tried the paella...until now. 

I will come back again & again to sample your small plates (the escargot & mushrooms are great) & your tasty sangria, Zarzuela, and I may...just MAY even give the paella another chance. 

UPDATE 4/16/06: An acquaintance from Spain said their paella was the best she ever had in the states. Maybe it's just not what Americans expect. I would go there again to have it. 

UPDATE 1/25/07: It seems that every time I go to Zarzuela, I love it more. Not a trendy, pretentious vibe, but very down-to-earth. The Paella was great. We had several tapas--the lamb, the shrimp, the mushrooms, goat cheese w/tomato sauce, sausage, and some others...and couldn't seem to get enough. 

If the sangria seems not to your liking, try some of the wines from their wine list. A member of our party said they had some wines on their list from the best region of Spain that are somewhat difficult to get. I had a nice red by the glass. 

Oh yeah: it's best to cab it there. Parking can be a major challenge in the neighborhood.
author: N B.

description: Excellent food and service. Highly recommended. Who doesn't like tapas and sangria?
author: Sarah W.

description:
After a meetup in the city, my coworker and I were hungry. We walked around Russian Hill for a bit looking for a place, but it was quarter to 10 and everywhere we went wasn't accepting new customers into their restaurants. Finally we were directed towards what was described as a great tapas restaurant. 

Turns out, that was an understatement.

This place not only welcomed us in 15 minutes before closing, but they kept bringing us wine and telling us not to rush. Our server, who I suspect may have been the manager or owner suggested lots of good dishes and we sampled many of them. I can't recall all that we ordered, but I do remember that I especially loved the grilled asparagus.

I highly recommend this place and I hope I am able to dine there again soon!
author: Adiel N.

description:
i heart tapas.

this place is wonderful. chic, but not stuffy, and just really delicious food with authenticity.

i love eating tapas because you get to try a lot of different dishes since the portion size is smaller. we had the Plato De Queso Variado (basically cheese plate), Mejillones Al Azafran (mussels), Banderillas De Solomillo Cordero (grilled pork tenders), and Costillas Breseadas A La Cerveza (short ribs braised with beer). Everything was really yummy... this is definitely a place i'd go back to and keep on my list for a no fail meal!
author: Kimberly F.

description: This place seems like that it caters to the locals in the neighborhood, or to tourists. We couldn't figure which one exactly which is probably not a great sign. The food was average at best. We had the paella and some tapas to start with which were also bland. It was busy for a weekday night which we did not understand. There are much better tapas places in the Mission.
author: Mike C.

description:
Absolutely loved this place!  First the seating area is so cozy and cute, it has a very European feel inside.  Service was excellent.  We went early to avoid the crowds as they don't take reservations.

4 people is a good size party because most of the dishes come in 4 pieces and you can try more dishes.  We ordered a total of 8 tapas, including the croquetas, tortilla espanola, grilled eggplant with goat cheese, mushrooms in garlic sauce, chorizo, calamares, grilled shrimp in garlic olive oil, and the empanada del dia.  everything was great.  My favorites were the grilled shrimp in olive oil and the croquetas.  The shrimp were perfectly cooked with a tasty garlic oil that we used for dipping bread.  The croquetas were perfectly crispy on the outside, light, and creamy on the inside.  All the food (even the fried ones) tasted light.  And they serve you tons of olives with the bread!! 

The best thing was that everything was priced very reasonably.  Next time I'd like to go back and try the other items as there was so much to choose from.
author: Emiko M.

description: This cozy Tapas restaurant was a lot of fun.  The food was delicious, the carafe of Sangria plentiful,  and the serenade to the restaurant delightful. The staff works very hard to please, and is on top of orders/refills. I would not hesitate to recommend Zarzuela for a nice date, or small to medium sized birthday party. Taxi or walking would be best since parking is at a premium in the neighborhood, if not there is a lot nearby. Enjoy!
author: Drew A.

description:
There are a few chairs outside for those waiting for the doors to open at 5:30pm. I was expecting this place to be much more busy on Thursday night. By 7pm, all of the wall tables were taken, but none of the middle tables were filled.

Location is a nice area, not too many shops, but there is a Swensen's kitty corner. I've heard the horror stories of looking for parking when you come in the evening and want to eat here. Apparently, people end up leaving because they can't find parking. I took the bus since I was meeting a friend after work. You can take the Muni 41 from downtown and get dropped off right in front of the restaurant.

The service was excellent. I only had to ask for water once. They immediately took empty places, replaced the tapa plates with fresh plates for the paella, they remembered I wanted my water with no ice, even during the refills. 

The main part lacking here was the speed and timing of the dishes. I think it took them at least 15-20 minutes to come and take our order. They brought out some bread, olives and olive oil. The first dish came about 20 minutes after we ordered. The second dish came 10 minutes later. The third dish (paella) came another 20 minutes later. I think it would have helped if they had taken our order a little earlier. I'm surprised they were slow because the service was great and they weren't really crowded. I would be very hesitant to come on a crowded night. 

Luckily our ride home, was stuck in traffic and running late which meant we had time to eat the paella, although we could have eaten more if we had more time.

Our order:

Paella -- TONS of seafood and chicken, barely enough rice, lots of saffron. Really good, but I was secretly daydreaming about extra white or brown rice to mix in.

Grilled oysters -- The sauce was good, but the oysters had a negative flavor. Without the sauce, I'm not sure I could enjoy them. I love oysters. The texture was pretty good for me. My friend said they were a little chewy though.

Fried squid -- Light, fluffy, perfectly cooked. Not much flavor, no sauce or dip. We added tons of lemon to give it a little flavor.

Total including tip: $60
author: Lorrie N.

description:
Authentic...
tight-pants-wearing...
eurotrash-listening...
mullet-clad...
cat-calling...
lisp-enducing...

...SPANISH... TAPAS!  

None of that wimpy nuevo latino stuff... Zarzuela serves by far the most authentic spanish tapas I've had since I lived in Madrid.  If you want generic "small plates" go elsewhere.  

To my knowledge, they are also one of the few tapas places in the city with genuine jamon serrano as opposed to prosciutto.  Yes, there is a difference... Ask any Spaniard.

I just wish there were more tight pants and euro-mullets in this joint.
author: Sarah J.

description:
I went here recently for my birthday with friends and I am a fan.

A little backround on me: I spent 5 months in Northern Spain (Santander) in Highschool, and so feel like I have reasonable basis for judgement of Tapas. 

Highlights:
White Anchovies - Incredible. These are real anchovies, nothing like most people have tasted. Try them. 
Sangria - Delicious. I don't really like Sangria, but I like theirs. 
Octopus - Never had Octopus that was so tender in my life. 
Tortilla - Tortilla is kind of like a spanish frittata/omellete/quiche, but different. Their's is DELICIOUS. 

Why not 5 stars? 
The Chorizo was uninspried at best, and tasted like Kosher Beef Franks. 

No Patatas con Aoili, a CLASSIC Spanish Tapas of boiled potatoes, green onions and garlic mayo (Aoili). 

The baked goat cheese was just goat cheese plopped in Tomato sauce the night I went, no crust no bubbling, boring.

Stuffed Mushrooms were slightly bland. 

No reservations, which is hard, I went with 7 people and waited 45 minutes on a Tuesday, and I would rather stick needles in my eyes than to park around there on a weeknight again.

On the upside we got a free round of sangria while we waited, which was a nice touch. 

Overall, a great place for Tapas, with a little room for improvement.
author: Jake R.

description:
Holy crap I can't believe we waited 2 hours to eat here.  The wait may not have been 100% worth it but enough to keep me satisfied and get 4 stars.

Tapas to order:
Mushrooms
Goat cheese and tomato
Fried potatoes

If you order the dishes and get a small..they are small.  Not tapas small, but appetizer in a normal restaurant small.   There was also a bowl of seafood noodles that someone ordered - this was very delicious.  It reminded me a little of Asian noodles, but not.  Also, I really wanted the croquettes but they never appeared :(  Hmm.. did the rest of my table eat it without me?

Tapas, paella, dishes, sangria..that was like $40/person -_-  Ok despite the wait AND the price, I suppose it can keep my four stars.  Lucky the sangria was good.  Get the sangria.
author: Yosie G.

description:
my Spanish friend, national pride and all, gives this place his grudging thumbs up.  It's not as good as his wife's, but the gambas aljillo and paella valenciana pass muster.  *shrug*  Definitely get the arroz con leche and if you'd like...a splash of anise over it gives it the right touch.  

Decor, service, and ambiance are perfect for this medium sized (for this street) restaurant.  don't forget the sangria...my sister likes.
author: Chung-Man T.

description:
I have been eyeing this place every time I pass it on the bus, it always looked like it had a great atmosphere and always packed.  A few subtle hints to my boyfriend later and BAM! there I was on a Saturday night.  I was not wrong!  The tapas were amazing, and don't get me started on the Sangria!  

We had the calamari,  the goat cheese, and shared the paella!  Everything was fabulous and I will definitely be visiting this restuarant again to try everything else.  I thought on a saturday night at 8pm we were doomed to wait hours, but they got us in within 20 minutes! They do not take reservations so be prepared to wait a little if it is a busy night!  The Service was great, I have nothing but wonderful things to say about this place, and have to say writing this review is actually making me crave the Sangria...
author: Natalie L.

description:
My first experience dining out in San Francisco and what a tasty one it was. We were told that the wait was 30 minutes and roughly an hour later we were seated, which had my brother and I kind of fuming, but we got over it.

We split a carafe of Sangria, which was freaking awesome (to say it bluntly). It provided enough to drink for the duration of the meal. As for the food we ordered the olive oil and garlic shrimp, the goat cheese in marinara sauce, the mussels in a tomato sauce, and the jamon serrano. The shrimp were awesome as were the mussels, but both seemed to be so small. I know they are tapas and they aren't supposed to be massive but the goat cheese was very filling as was the jamon. The cheese was fantastic. It was so rich and bursting with flavor. The jamon was a perfect way to end the meal and the bread and olives that started off the meal all had us feeling very full and content by the end. 

It ended up being about 65 bucks with tip for the two of us. Our waiter was friendly and in no rush to get us out despite the restaurant being so crowded.

About the restaurant being crowded: its really really loud in there. Probably not the best place for a date because I found myself asking my brother "what did you say?" almost every other sentence. 

Seeing as it was my first time in San Fran as well, it was cool seeing the cable cars cruise down the hill in the window in front of our table.
author: Danny K.

description:
The first time I ate here was a rainy Tuesday afternoon around the time the restaurant opened at about 5.30/6 which was very quiet time for the restaurant.  We were welcomed by friendly staff and our order was taken very quickly.  Within less that five minutes after we ordered all our food arrived on the table.  It was tasty enough but was not warm enough to have just been cooked.

Due to it being so quiet, I had to wonder, was that the fasted chef in the west or the ping of a microwaved food I could hear coming from the kitchen?

I might have to go back and try it again to find out.
author: Claire m.

description:
So, I've lived in Spain, I'm from Mexico and I love futbol soccer. So, if you've ever met Arturo you know that nothing compares to coming here. The food is super authentic, Arturo can talk about soccer the way an SI or FSN commentator would. Throw in running into the owner at Whistler when we were BOTH there for bachelor parties along with the 1 block walk and you can see they had me at "hola".
Parking is horrific, sangria is amazing, paella is perfect and I tend to app my way through the night. Arturo will always recommend the perfect wine. And, btw, he's a true blue Mexican and a great person overall.

UPDATE: They still rock.
author: Raul L.

description:
I was introduced to Zarzuela courtesy of a co-worker that I was out on a date with, and even though we didn't make it as a couple, I was smitten enough with the restaurant to keep coming back. So much so that in the last 7 years I'd say I've taken over three dozen people there on various occasions - and "when are you taking me to Zarzuela" has become a bragging right in itself for many of my friends.

I try to make these reviews balanced with the good vs. bad, and avoid giving out five stars unless the place is exceptionally good. With Zarzuela this is pretty easy to do - only one real negative: parking. Russian Hill is a terrible place to park, and you're much better off parking in Pac Heights and taking a cab to the corner of Union and Hyde. Also, they're not open on Sundays and Mondays, so be prepared to be disappointed if you're planning on visiting then.

The good - well, where do I start? The place is always packed - so prepare yourself for a long wait. I like to show up and leave my cell phone number, then shove off to the Bacchus wine bar on the next block to enjoy a nice pre-prandial apertif. You could choose to sit or (more likely, stand) outside as you wait for a table. Ask for a table in the front of the restaurant - they've recently expanded into the back because of the demand, but thats not the same experience as being seated up front. One of the window seats, if you're lucky.

The Tapas and Sangria are top notch - I've always ordered both and tried everything on the menu. If you're new to Tapas, they're literally 'small plates' and you order a whole bunch of them and eat them with bread and olives, both of which are provided gratis for the table. My favorite tapas is definitely the pulpo a'la gallega (the octopus), but also worthy of mention are the gambas ajillo (shrimp), chorizo al vino (sausage), patatas bravas (potatoes) and of course, the empanadas. The Tapas is all authentic spanish, and the staff are like family - they'll be glad to cater to your every wish and never hurry you out of there; in fact I've stayed past closing time on a few occasions and never felt like I was rushed. Also, everyone I've taken there has commented on the quality of service and attentiveness to the customer.

I wouldn't bother with the entrees, and I'd strongly suggest going here on a weekday (other than Monday). Also, get here early and you won't have too long of a wait. Of course, with Yelpers doing their part, that might all change soon enough :-) Zarzuela deserves every single star in this five star rating.
author: Maxx L.

description:
I am a huge fan of these place. Every single time my sister, former SF resident, comes to town she INSISTS we eat here.

The servers are great and I have to absolutely recommend the goat cheese tapa and the Sangria. Some how I always manage to burn my mouth on the goat cheese EVERY TIME and I'm positive it's because it is so fabulous I cant wait to stuff it in my mouth... beware of the heat!

You might be wondering... why the three stars if she loves this place. WELL the wait wasn't too long which I never mind waiting especially since we got a great table by the window BUT once seated it took like 30 mins just to order drinks. Then another 30 mins to order food. Granted I had good company so I wasn't too peeved but I was shocked that we were there for 2 1/2 hours! Sheesh!

Lost another star because this place used to be a $$ place... now its $$$ inflation or popularity? I'm kinda sad it had gotten so pricey.

All I got to say is Goat Cheese and Sangria... worth every little penny.
author: Nancy B.

description: Great spanish food. Had some nice rioja reserva to start with some some sauteed mushrooms. Then had the seafood bouillabaisse with fish, mussels, clams, shrimp, calamari. Really enjoyable experience
author: David M.

description: Save your money. And thats no joke. Sangria was tasteless. The "tapas"  came out way too fast which means it was either made days before or frozen. Best thing about this place was the bread they got from the local Safeway. Again, SAVE YOUR MONEY.
author: Michael M.

description:
Authentic and delicious tapas and paella washed down with great Spanish rioja wines in a friendly neighborhood restaurant setting.

Minus one star due to really difficult parking in the area. Last time I checked, they didn't take reservations so the wait can be painfully long (inversely proportionally to how good the food is). This makes it difficult for us suburbanites to get in and out easily on one of our rare date nights.
author: David P.

description:
Oh MAN.  My boyfriend and I rushed up to Zarzuela after work earlier this week, eager to finally be able to eat there. We've been trying to go for months, but since I don't have a MUNI pass (and refuse to pay $5 for a cable car), we've had to try to coordinate our visit around the end/beginning of the month.  So finally, FINALLY, we were able to go and it was deLICIOUS.

We both had a glass of sangria, and shared the eggplant with goat cheese, tortilla espanola, the chorizo and the mushrooms.  The complimentary bread, olives and olive oil was perfect.  I was surprised by how quickly everything came out--I think we were in and out in just over an hour.  We are definitely, TOTALLY returning for more.  SO, so SO so SO good.

The main room does fill up pretty quickly, so plan your arrival carefully.  And, y'know, the Hyde cable car stops right outside, and several buses run through the intersection.
author: diana s.

description:
Zarzuela reminded me of why I'm not a huge tapas fan anymore BUT ALSO that I should also visit Ramblas soon. Oh yes it seems I have two small brains and they work against each other. 

The food was pretty mediocre, but the service was outstanding; chivalry with an accent? An age-old woman-melter!
author: Shannon V.

description:
Zarzuela's is a treat!  We didn't save room to try the paella, but I think we tried practically all the tapas!  

We had the warm goat cheese with tomato sauce, shrimp with garlic, mussels, chorizo, anchovies, octopus, plus others I can't recall, but all good.  Fresh ingredients and wonderfully prepared.

If you love rice with milk and cinnamon for dessert, this is the place to get it.  

Service was very good.  Atmosphere was a pleasant surprise.  This is definitely a neighborhood place, so if you come in by car and can't find street parking (good luck) there is a convenient and pricey parking garage nearby.  We will be back to try the paella!
author: Michelle P.

description:
I was not blown away, but I would say that I did enjoy my dining experience at Zarzuela. The seafood paella is a must-order, as was the sauteed shrimp dish, which was delicious. 

I would give the place a B+.
author: Elle M.

description:
hopped on the powell-hyde cable car which dropped me off in front of the restaurant. there was no wait on this tuesday evening (7pm). got a nice table for two by the window. although it was a tapas restaurant, i did not see a bar but the atmosphere was nicer than i expected from the yelp reviews (i didn't venture from my window seat though). server was friendly and amusing, just like the servers in barcelona. 

my cousin and i were hoping to have tapas and paella, but the paella was $15.95/person with a minimum order for 2 so we skipped the paella to save room for tapas. we ordered the crab bisque (which they thoughtfully split into two bowls without us asking), chorizo, patatas, garlic shrimp, and the scallops in romanesco sauce special. everything was tasty except for the chorizo which was too tough. maybe because i haven't seen my cousin in over a year and had a lot of catching up to do, i thought the tapas weren't served hot enough and got cold quickly (even the ones served in the cast-iron skillets). price was very reasonable with the tapas being around $5-7 except for the special which was $13.

their red wine sangria was very good, but el cid in nyc's rose wine sangria is still my favorite.

didn't try dessert. took a yelp recommendation and crossed the street for swensen's ice cream - yum!
author: Diana B.

description:
I just got back from Barcelona, so I may be a bit biased. The tapas were pretty authentic. Based on the other reviewers, Zarzuela sounds top notch in comparison to other SF tapas places. 

Pros: tapas, friendly server + host, atmosphere
Cons: sangria, parking, aggressive clearers, no reservations/long wait times
author: kathy c.

description:
After reading some of these reviews,  I can see why some bemoan the lack of authenticity:

- the service is great, unlike the surly waiters I encountered in Spain (cute bartenders at El Tigre exempted)
- food is more upscale and actually flavorful, unlike the salty fare of Madrid
- ambiance is classy and gorgeous, unlike the local tapas bars everywhere in Spain which more resemble hole-in-the-walls

All of this makes Zarzuela just as good as the real thing if you want something more elegant than the divey places I thoroughly enjoyed while living in Spain.

The staff were fabulous. Our server was so incredibly amiable and helpful. For the three of us, he recommended getting 6 tapas if you just want to be full enough and have room for dessert. It turned out to be quite true. My kind of man.

Our group went for the chorizo in white wine, hot mussels, cold eggplant, patatas bravas, croquettes, and the crab cakes.
Chorizo: never had it in white wine in Spain, but it was still delicious.
Mussels: amaaaazing, sauce was great for sneaking bread pieces into.
Eggplant: had similar dish in Sevilla, which was served warm. Still good cold.
Patatas bravas: authentic in appearance, much better in flavor. The Spaniards can't handle spicy food, so I was pleasantly surprised to find brava sauce with a kick here.
Croquetas: exactly like the ones my Señora made as a dinner side.
Crab cakes: They were served on toasted bread in San Sebastian, but still scrumptious here.

Dessert: I didn't know what to expect since Madrileños finish up with fruit or flan, but the chocolate cake mess was really good.

+ Ambience
+ Pretty authentic; most of the menu items we didn't order were things I found over there
+ Stellar service
+ No wait on a Tuesday

PS. Tortilla (the egg and potato omelette) was served both hot and cold at tapas places and by my Spanish family. I just hate seeing this cute place downgraded for it.
author: Kim L.

description:
I'm always genuinely surprised to see underwhelming restaurants get decent reviews...Makes me wonder if they actually have discerning tastes or perhaps they've never really experienced/enjoyed quality food from the genre.

Having lived in Chicago, I set the bar high on Tapas cuisine and it's hard to beat Iberico for great food and sangria...Chicago has several worthy challengers to Iberico and so some prefer others but the competition is strong there.

In SF, we benefit from some great sushi and french restaurants but tapas is a genre of food that is pretty underwhelming from what I have experienced (However, I am going to give Destino a shot next).

Everything (Apart from the Paella) was underwhelming, even slightly old tasting.

Patatas Bravas are simple tapas and pretty much every tapas restaurant has them but these were terrible...Potatoes tasted old and seasoning with the sauce was nonexistent let alone spicy.

Champinones al Ajillo were also pretty disappointing.

Chorizo al Vino was fair although only had one variety of chorizo rather than a sampler of different types.

Gambas Plancha are a pretty simple dish but these were also pretty fair, nothing to write home about.

Croquetas De Jamon Y Pollo...Closest thing I could compare them to is frozen tater tots with barely a hint of jamon let alone pollo...These were terrible

Cazuela De Queso De Cabra is also a pretty typical tapa and this was fair, as well...Goat cheese simply had little to no flavor...Just another in a long line of disappointments really.

Calamares Andaluza...Very poor, about as rubbery as calamari should never get...Just a crying shame compared to the ones at Iberico 

Paella a La Valenciana was about the only decent item really, IMHO.

Very disappointing experience and will never be back...Could not actually recommend this to a soul but I'm sure people will be coming back.

Worst thing that could happen to this restaurant is for a legitimate, authentic and delicious Tapas restaurant to open and subsequently thrive
author: Barca F.

description:
Whenever my girlfriends and I gather together, Zarzuela is our go to spot. I absolutely love it. From the ambiance, to the awesome host/owner, and the amazing food, this place hits the mark every time. I've never had a bad meal here, and it is reasonably priced and reasonably portioned for tapas. I don't understand the people who go out to tapas and expect huge plates of food to come out at you. That's what's so amazing about tapas! Small plates means you get to try everything! And believe me, I've gone here so many times that I'm pretty sure I have had everything on the menu. My two favorite dishes are the duck dish and the cheese wrapped in eggplant. I know people normally do the paella, the tortilla espanola, patatas bravas and the croquetas (which are all delicious), but branch out people! There are so many more excellent dishes aside from that! Their sangria is decent, more syrupy sweet than alcoholic.

Although Zarzuela does not take reservations, you can call in ahead of time so that you can get your name on the list before you even get there. We've done this many times and our wait becomes so minimal that by the time we walk over, our table is ready!

If you don't call in before hand, have a glass (or carafe) of sangria while you wait. It'll make the experience all the better.

Oh! I also forgot to mention! Tell them it's your birthday. The wait-staff will come out and sing the traditional Spanish birthday song-- Las Mananitas. I hadn't heard that song since Spanish class in High School and they were so very entertaining in singing it. I might come back and pretend it's my birthday just so that the wait-staff can sing that song to me ::sigh::
author: Ratha K.

description:
Went here back in August

Neighborhood -This is in a great location on Nob hill.  Loved the area

Food - the food was amazing.  We had so many different things, not sure what we had but it was all great.  The quality of the food is good, variety is great.  We even had the tripe and it was good.  Sangria was good - just loved it.  

Athomosphere - Great decor and ambiance. Feels very homey and cozy.  I really loved this place.  The owner has only a few tables but love it.

BTW there is little to zero parking, so cab it!
author: Mary B.

description: Awesome, authentic Spanish tapas at reasonable prices (including wine).  I've been to Contigo and Alegrias on previous searches for tapas and though I enjoyed both of those places, Zarzuela is superior. I would recommend going early (senior citizen hours) before they get overwhelmed with the crowd later on.
author: Noel B.

description:
Yum, yum, yum!!! Small and cozy little tapas bar with great sangria. I joined some friends here on Friday night - the place was full. I loved the ham and chicken croquettes and the mushrooms. Chorizo was ok, a little too hard to chew for me. We also got shrimp(yummy!), potatoes covered in tomato sauce(pretty good), calamary()too oily, and some enchilada thing (blah). 

The service was great and our waiter - friendly and attentive. The carafes of sangria kept coming and coming. If it's watered down, I don't mind - you can have 3-4 glasses and still drive without being too drunk. 

The atmosphere is pretty chill but loud, definitely not the place to go for a romantic dinner. But if you're looking for quick, good food with a bunch of friends - this is the place!

Oh and parking - AWFUL. There is a valet garage across the street - first hour $10, max $20. It beats trying to find a street spot.
author: Tatyana K.

description: A friend of mine had recommended this place. Zarzuela is one of those restaurants where you really do feel at home. The food and ambience feels very authentic. It prepared my partner and I for our trip to Spain. The tapas are just fantastic. We had the fried squid, croquetas, and seafood salad. Just fabulous. I recommend a glass of alberino as well.
author: Jason C.

description: Relaxed and Romantic Ambiance. It is a bit small and the wait is a bit too long even with reservations, but the food makes up for it, no doubt! Seafood paella and sangria are very tasty!
author: Karina A.

description:
Charming ambiance and tasty vittles. They have tapas or large family style ordering. My husband and I went here on our very first date which makes it a special place.  The food is wonderful and the waiters fantastic which makes it twice as special.  Parking is scarce, so try and walk or cab it there.  Reservations are recommended, because this place is always jumping.
Check out the Halibut Cheeks, you won't be disappointed.
author: PictureGirl F.

description:
On a recent cold night in SF i met up with a friend at Zarzuela has some of the best tapas that I have ever had. The olives and bread w/ olive oil are a nice way to kick things off.

We started with red wine and the salad with walnuts, pears and cheese, which was a great way to start the meal. Next came out the goat cheese in tomato sauce which is amazingly good. It's worth going to Zarzuela just for this dish. After that came out the shrimp in garlic olive oil (gambas de ajillo) and the muscles. The garlicky olive oil is a great dip for the bread that you get to start the meal. Next came out the lamb dish special which was served with potatoes and for dessert we had a chocolate mousse roll. 

Highlights: The olives that come as soon as you sit down, the goat cheese in tomato sauce, and the shrimp in garlic olive oil. 
Disappointments: the service - the dishes came out fast and orderly, but there was no follow up. I had to wait a long time and ask more than once for a refill of water, our bread basket went empty and our olives were taken away without the server asking us if we were finished.

The food gets five stars, but the service only gets three. The pricing was also reasonable - we had five dishes plus dessert and a glass on wine each and our bill came to $64. The patrons did tend to lean toward the marina crowd a little especially later in the night, but even the marina crowd couldn't take away from the great food we were eating.

I'll definitely be back, maybe the service will be better and I'll be able to give them the five stars their food deserves.
author: Russ C.

description:
WHAT ARE THESE PEOPLE ON ABOUT?

Yelpers let us down. I know once in a while, it just has to happen, because the reviews are what they are, mostly people who are crazy about the restaurant or scrutinizing food or service.

My SO and I went on a much-anticipated outing to Zarzuela, braving the ultra yups and scary incline parking to go here. And I say, if this is the "best Spanish tapas in SF", just go have chinese or japanese or californian, italian or french and eat good food.

Unsalted food (!), nice people, crappy, nearly non-alcoholic "house sangria" : / = BAD TAPAS. I seriously doubt that any of these reviewers have actually tasted real tapas in Spain or elsewhere. Bleuck. Don't waste your time.
author: G Z.

description:
The best tapas restaurant in San Francisco. Everything is excellent every time you go. Personal favorites include Champinones al Ajillo (mushrooms sauteed in garlic sauce), Gambas al Ajillo (sauteed shrimp in garlic and olive oil), Solomillos de Cordero (medallions of lamb tender grilled with sherry vinegar sauce), Paella Valenciana (Spanish rice cooked with seafood and chicken, and, of course, their sangria.

The place is very popular, so expect a 30-45 minute wait. But it's worth it. If you come here for your birthday, a burly gentleman sings you a birthday song in Spanish (Las Mañanitas). He's quite good and when the last note passes his lips, the entire restaurant erupts into applause. A great meal, a great dining experience, and a great cultural experience.

Tip: Parking is no existent near the restaurant, so bite the bullet and pay for parking at a lot next to Swenson's Ice Cream Parlor (diagonal to the restaurant). Max is $20.
author: Baxter L.

description:
At first sight this place is bit packed, the ambiance is so so .
But the price is pretty reasonable, most importantly the food is delicious, the mixed wild mushroom is the best.
Parking is a nightmare here, we circled around 40 minutes to find a parking lot.
author: sherry g.

description:
Did I go on a good night? I didn't have to wait at all! I was surprised!
Ok, so i think I am going to unjustly review this as i am desperately trying to find something that can stand up to Barcelona's food which is out of this world. THought I reviewed this a long time ago so sorry if I dont remember everything...but what I do remember is that the environment inside was adorable! I felt like I was no longer in SF. The sangria was great and my BF and I had a wonderful time. Our favorite thing was probably the sizzling shrimp and the Jamon Serrano con Pan, Tomate 
Imported, Cured Serrano ham with bread & tomato. We got some poached octopus bc that was AMAZING in Spain. But it was bland bland bland. Yuck, no flavor and the texture was not ideal. But the rest of the experience was good. I might try a few other places before returning though. In the hunt for the knoc your socks off experience.
author: Kai T.

description: Overpriced and small portions. Would say that it's not worth it.
author: Amanda L.

description: We came here last Friday night since we had tickets to Cobbs Comedy club. This place was one of the places that had good reviews and was nearby the comedy club. I tried to make reservations, but they don't take any. So my husband and I decided to head to the city early, but there was absolutely no parking. I even called the restaurant to see if there was a parking structure nearby, but nothing. The man that answered the phone even laughed and said don't drive here just take a taxi. So we did. When we got there, we were advised there will be an hour wait. We waited even though we were starving. When we were finally seated, the service was alright. Our waiter was an older man that just cuts to the chase. He was not very friendly. We ordered 5 dishes and sangria. We had the calamares a la plancha con aioli (grilled squid), crab cakes, short ribs, braised quail, and paella. The dishes were all good, but compared to other tapas restaurants the portions seemed a bit small. My husband was not happy with that. Overall this was an expensive dinner that tasted just ok. Nothing spectacular about this place. Also there is only one bathroom for both men and women so there is a wait for that too.  Not sure why they had such good reviews. I don't believe I will go here again.
author: Kimberly L.

description: Great friendly service. Good amount of sangria for the price if you buy by the carafe. Paella is made to order and totally worth trying. I would also recommend the tripe and escargot. Coming back for sure.
author: alexandria n.

description: Exceptional service, great food and killer Sangria. My wife and I started with a     surf-n-turf appetizer of Muscovy Duck and Potato Octopus. Duck leg was crispy and sunbathing in a velvety plume reduction sauce. Octopus was tender, tasty, and full of flavor. For our final course we had the paella and it was unreal. Everyone around seemed pleased and happy. Great 30th birthday dinner!!
author: Keala C.

description:
Yea know.. I came to Zarzuela on a late night match date and was tempted to run up the bill and eat/drink all the tapas and sangrias I could.  Turns out - date became a cool friend and well I didn't eat as much as I had intended on. 

The shrimp in garlic sauce was good, potatoes were good, mushrooms,  eggplants, they were all pretty good. Sangrias is very watered down.. Although, I'm a semi alcoholic.

The place is tucked in a nice neighborhood and the service was pretty good. I'd  have to say the atmosphere is much better than Cha Cha Cha or Esperpento where it's really loud and dim (depends on if you want to see people's faces or not). 

I guess it's just a little more pricey than the other two places - it's just not amazing though. It's cute and somewhat romantic, so take someone here on a casual date, eat tapas, then walk down to a nice wine bar such as Amelie and then unwind. 

3 1/2 stars.
author: Miss Pigg y.

description:
I ate here about 4 years ago, way back before the Yelp days. I came here on Saturday night with the BF for some "authentic" Spanish tapas. The place was packed with multiple large groups, so we had to wait about 20 minutes for a table. Unfortunately, this place doesn't take reservations, so be warned!

Once we got seated, we ordered a craft of sangria and nibbled on our basket of soft bread with olive oil and various olives. This place truly reminded me of the tapas restaurants from my trip to Spain last year. Very authentic selections and combinations.

We started with the lamb skewers with rosemary sauce. The meat was very juicy and tender and the rosemary sauce was delicious! The meat was not gamey at all. Next, we had the mussels served with white wine and garlic sauce. They were really good too. Then came the stuffed mushrooms with serrano ham and garlic. This is my all time favorite tapas dish and it really reminded me of the one I had in Barcelona. For our veggie dish, we had the mixed stew of zucchini, tomatoes and onions. It was a cold veggie dish, light and flavorful. 

For our entire meal, food and drinks, the total was only $45! It was cheap!!! We were full too! We didn't order dessert.. since Frascati was down the street and I HAVE to have their black and white chocolate bread pudding!

I'm definitely going to come back here again with a larger group and order the paella.
author: Denise L.

description:
Undeniably my favorite place for tapas.  I see another person (and perhaps more) loves Arturo as well!  I always wish we'll get seated at one of his tables.  This place is sooooo good, I don't mind driving around looking for parking.  When we lived in the city, we took a cab.  Works great.

Please do try.  I have traveled far and wide in Spain (and I am part Spaniard), and this place takes me back each time I get the craving and I can't do the trans-atlantic trip.

I recommend pulpos (octopus) and lamb skewers (banderillas), gambas (in garlic) to name a few.  If you are adventurous, the tripes won't disappoint.
author: Scarlet L.

description:
Best tapas so far in my life. Been here a couple of times, haven't been able to find anything that would make me dock even an arm on a star. Great food, acceptable wait time, great service, reasonable prices, delish wines, blah blah blah blah. Go there and see for yourself.
Recommendations: Goat cheese in eggplant, anchovies, croquettes, mussels, leg of duck...
These guys are pros and they don't serve flukes.
author: Marko J.

description: Sangria + Tapas!!!  Zarzuela was exactly what we were looking for on Friday night after visiting a couple of wine bars for happy hour. Walked right in on 8:30PM and got seated. I highly recommend the egg plant wrapped goat cheese and the tuna and vegetable empanadas. Very small and cozy laid back atmosphere. Good food, good drinks, good way to spend a Friday night.
author: Debbie C.

description:
Visiting friends with my wife and hit this place for dinner since it was close to where her friend was staying.  Adhering to tapa tradition we shared:

Croquetas De Jamon Y Pollo (Chicken and Ham Croquettes) were good, not great.  The combination of the ham and salty cheese was a little overpowering.

Champinones Plancha (Mushrooms Grilled with Garlic, Serrano Ham, Parsely & Olive Oil) were perfect.  After the first bite I had to hold back from taking the rest before anyone else could.  I would go back just for this dish.

Empanada Del Dia was vegetable and cheese that day.  Flaky and delicious crust around perfect vegetables, potato and a hint of cheese.  This was almost as good as the mushrooms.

Paella a La Valenciana (Spanish Rice Cooked With Seafood, Chicken, Vegetables & Flavored with Saffron) had tons of tender shrimp, calamari and chicken.  The rice still had a little bite which I really like.  If I want mushy rice I can eat what I make at home.

Flan for dessert was nice.  It had really light citrus added which we at first thought was some sort of floral flavor.  A really nice finish.

The service was excellent.  Patient with us while we sat and BS'ed for almost half an hour before we decided what we were all going to share.  It was still early though, so not busy enough for them to need the space.  Great recommendations on what and how much to get.  He suggested the four of us get paella for three (which was plenty)
