Great dinner, great place, great people, great evening!
author: Michael M.

description:
So as you usually get a lot of stuff at tapas places, I suppose I'll follow Meghan's example and review everything in order of best to worse. Interestingly enough, the meal kind of went in order of best to worse.

The homemade sangria was absolutely delicious, probably the best sangria I've ever had.
The olive oil for the bread was absolutely delicious! I'm sure they didn't make it themselves, but kudos to them for finding a high-quality olive oil that they can offer complimentary.
The goat cheese/eggplant was also incredible. There are so many chefs doing really cool things with goat cheese in SF, I love it.
The asparagus and goat cheese was quite flavorful, nothing amazing, and a bit spartan even for a tapas.
Good bread and olives too.
The sea bass and the mussels were both disappointing; they weren't bad, but they tasted like something I could pretty easily make myself, and I didn't taste the wine in the sauce in either of them. It was pretty good to dip the bread in though.

Service was excellent, though.

They did have some bug issues, which was a bit annoying.

Definitely would recommend.

And I'm sure it would have been very possible to get a bunch of dishes that would have made it a 5-star review, but at 5-star restaurants, the quality is consistent in every dish.
author: Mark A.

description:
FANTASTIC TAPAS. From Grilled oysters  and Sea bass tapas to eggplant and roasted peppers, wonderful olives and SANGRIA that will keep you wanting more and more...

terrific service and a nice room atop Russian hill...

Better than A Cote or other small plates places I've been to so far in the bay area-- HECK this place would kick ass in Madrid!
author: A K.

description:
When I lived 3 blocks from here we used to walk straight up the hill to get tapas probably at least monthly. You can get a ton of food and soak up the sauces with bread for a reasonable price. We didn't typically drink much and I remember the price of dinner for 2 being under $40 consistently. 

More recently going back with friends several times I can still say I LOVE their chorizo, cold eggplant and goat cheese, duck, patatas bravas, and the scallops that they call a special but seem to always have! Great- in fact, I need to go there soon!

Parking is definitely a pain, so cab it or take a cable car or a 45 bus.

Oh, and the host guy (owner?) looks like Frankie Avalon- how funny is that?!
author: Diane S.

description:
It's Okay. 

The tapas options are good, not great but most certainly good. 

The paella I would skip. B-44 has much better paella. 

The sangria is easy drinking which is a definite plus. 

It's a good place for groups as it's always full so there is a nice lively atmosphere. I love tapas and live near Zarzuela so I've been here a few times. I'm not "impressed" by the food, but I keep returning, so it can't be so bad :-).  I have no dishes in particular to recommend nor do I have any dishes to complain about.  

A solid three stars.
author: Jennifer C.

description:
crab cakes deserved 5 stars.
paella is what makes this 2.

the buddy we went with recommended the paella, but it was just not great at all. maybe it was a bad night for it..?

sangria was good, but I've had better.
author: Lauren J.

description:
Arrived here after hopping off the #45 bus from Downtown--a very convenient drop off right at Union and Hyde.  That was a plus!

Overall the meal was tasty, and the quality of the food good, however I give the restaurant three stars for it's authenticity (or lack there of) to Spanish cuisine.  I lived in Madrid for two years and have to admit that the only two dishes we ordered that tasted remotely like Spanish food were the Pulpo a la Gallega and the crema catalana.  I was craving Pimientos de Padrón.  If they had these and made them well I would have been satisfied!

What we ordered:
-Pulpo a La Gallega: Poached Octopus & Potatoes with Onions, Olive Oil & Pimenton--  This was pretty good, although I would have liked it more if the octopus was cooked a tiny bit less.
-Pato Con Ciruelas: Roasted Muscovy Leg of Duck in a Prune Sauce-- must admit, this was quite tasty, but I've never had it in Spain before!  Maybe I just missed out?
-Fideos Con Marisco: Vermicelli and Seafood Tossed with Garlic, White Wine & Saffron-- I finally am able to place my finger on the taste; I swear it tasted a bit like rice a roni
-Vieiras a la plancha con Romesco: grilled scallops with romesco sauce-- these were good, but the dish did not seem quite Spanish
-Crema Catalana--this was a pretty tasty desert.
-Sangría-- ok but nothing special, especially for $20

I think I expected Zarzuela to be a little more "homestyle" but instead it seems like this place has sold out and made everything a little more upscale to charge a higher price.  Bummer.

I did chat with a table of Spanish guys that claim that this place is the best Spanish food in San Francisco.  Perhaps they've been away from Spain too long?  Perhaps I need to give Zarzuela another try or maybe my search for good Spanish food in the Bay Area continues...
author: Christopher W.

description:
Like another critic here, I am mystified by the heaping of praise and 5-star reviews. No doubt Zarzuela offers authentic Spanish food, though their aesthetic seems to originate from the 1950-60's. If I were stopping in after a hard day of work in the Spanish countryside I would appreciate their hearty, rustic grub. But this is San Francisco, 2012, and there has been so much progress in culinary awareness and sophistication of ingredients that I try to avoid most restaurants trapped in a time-warp like Zarzuela. As with a number of North Beach places that have been open for decades, nothing seems to change and with a crowded dining room, why consider it? I'll tell you why - because we know so much more now and our palates have advanced. All of this is just blather, however, without examples. Let's do it:

- the bread on your table says a lot about the chef's opinion of what constitutes a complete, satisfactory dining experience. The bread at Zarzuela was a generic, cardboard-y, nothing sort of loaf - clearly, not a moment was wasted in sourcing this lowest-common-denominator example. The olives that accompanied it , on the other hand, were a nice touch.
- goat cheese wrapped in eggplant: well prepared and the ratatouille-like condiment was a nice accent, but the cheese is what could make this dish sing. The goat cheese we ate was notable for its lack of any real character. Here's a perfect example of my thesis - there are so many possibilities, but they seem to have opted for the "easy-dining" variety.
- pato con ciruelas (duck in a prune sauce): meaty and tender, but with virtually no taste of prune to counter the bland meat. One-dimensional.
- fabada Asturiana (white bean stew with sausage and ham): the beans soft and buttery; the meat either chewy (ham) or just plain scarce. I would have expected a meatier, smoky flavor in the plentiful broth but what we got was lots of beans. End of story.
- Castilian style oxtail stew: probably the most satisfying dish of all - tender meat and tender veggies, just like tu mama used to make. Still, we're back to basics in terms of flavor here, which isn't a bad thing, but hardly is cause for a 5-star coronation.
- sangria: take it from someone raised in Mexico City who knows sangria (yes, it's popular there too) - this was nothing to brag about

To finish: the noise level on a Saturday night was absolutely deafening; it took 20 minutes of circling to find a parking space;  and the decor reminded me of a Spanish-themed rumpus room with bullfight posters et al. None of this would matter overly much if the food were exemplary but it's not. It's just OK. 

It sounds like I'm a hater with this review even though that is not my intent. Rather, I hope to give pause for thought when someone is on the lookout for "the best tapas in San Francisco".
author: Jim H.

description:
This is the best Tapas place that I have never ever vote for 5 stars for a Tapas restaurant. 
I love the Octopus with potato,  Seafood saffron stew rice and the stew cold vegs (it is perfect match with the bread). The service is also attentive and comfortable. The chef sang the Spanish birthday song solo next to our table. That was a bomb!! Great place for drinking Sungria!! This place is definitely will be my favorite spot in town.
author: Jenny C.

description: Okay Tapas, wish I could be more positive, waiter was not friendly, felt rushed for the table, food was fair.
author: Mark W.

description:
Not sure what all the hype is over this place, cause I feel like I've had better tapas in and around the city. I think given the price and its location in Russian Hill, well, that's a rare find. So for that, it is unique. But honestly as the food goes, I thought it was just - ok -. 

- We had the Patatas Bravas. It was crispy but the sauce wasn't special. 
- Mussels. About 8-10 of them. I'm not a fan of mussels but tried one just to see... eh. Still unconvinced. On top of it all, the sauce which I usually love to dip my bread into was really fishy.
- Muscovy Duck. This was my favorite dish. The skin was crispy, the meat was tender. That's the way it should be. Just sad that 1 leg = $9.
- Seafood Stew. From the main entree size we opted for the stew (over the ox tail). While the stew was full of fish, calamari, shrimp, clam and mussels, the broth and flavors weren't very interesting. I could have been getting this at an italian restaurant or anywhere else.

What I did like were the complimentary olives that came with the bread. and the Sangria $5 was very tasty though it was served with ice cubes instead of being chilled.

Given the parking hassles and average food, I think there are other tapas to be tapped.
author: Cindy W.

description:
te amo zarzuela! 

hands down, my favorite spanish restaurant in the san francisco bay area. while there's usually about an hour wait, it's well worth it. the food is authentic, there is a ton of variety, the portions are generous, and the staff is incredibly warm and hospitable! let's just say it's a completely different experience than iberia in the peninsula ;) 

they have all the staples. i'm a big fan of the gambas al ajillo and patatas bravas in particular. if you're adventurous i'd definitely recommend trying the callos a la madrilena. it's tripe that's been sauteed with chorizo. unbelievably good! 

while it's more often featured as a special, you definitely need to try the dates stuffed with almonds and wrapped in pancetta. to. die. for. 

in addition to having great food, their sangria is also fantastic.
author: Jessica S.

description:
Do you want to go Spain? Of course you do! You just can't find the time in life between turning off and setting your alarm clock. Well, you can at least make it for dinner. Of course you can!

Zarzuela is the perfect escape!

Amazing food! 

Wonderful and charismatic host!

A perfect setting for a romantic dinner next to large windows with views of Russian Hill's subtle and quietly energetic neighborhood.

A Perfect setting for a group of friends at the center tables where wine glasses are never empty for too long.

Finish your trip with a cup of coffee and Crema Catalana for dessert!

Every good meal is deserving of an equally good walk to follow. It is the best way to allow food and life to settle into one. Stepping out of Zarzuela, you are treated to the Russian Hill neighborhood. Quiet, tree lined streets filled with classic SF architecture with a mix of cafes and wine bars create a zest for living in the moment; a moment for which Zarzuela created.

Enjoy Spain for dinner and worry about setting your alarm a bit later!
author: Michael R.

description:
disappointed again! 
We went here for our anniversary. The place was very crowded. The little old waiter as brusque, distracted and slow. Ready to leave after a long wait at the table, he finally bought the menu. Two of the 4 tapas were excellent, the others not good. 

Getting bread, water and attention was difficult. Waiters overworked and inattentive. We had a lovely tie with the people on the table next to us. So much so that they very kindly paid for 2 glasses of wine for us as they left.

The waiter promptly filled up our half full glasses of Syrah with Merlot and scurried off. Sheer ignorance and arrogance!!

Don't bother with this place. It's not worth the effort. Alegria's is far,far, far, far better ... but, unfortunately, closed on Tuesdays.

Oh, and Zarzuela's crams you in. Hope you like sitting on the laps of strangers :)
author: norman w.

description: Great neighborhood location, charming inside. We entered to the owner singing a spanish song to four tables that were celebrating birthdays. Very cozy and inviting. Service and wait time was quick and food was yummy. I recommend this place.
author: Jennifer M.

description:
Haven't had Spanish food for a while, so decided to come here based on the strong Yelp reviews. 

This place was great!  the ambiance was fantastic and the food was delicious  Not as pricey as some of the other tapas place I have been, their food however, is definitely on top my list.

Try the crab bisque, and the snail. Yum!
author: John L.

description: We use to come here all the time when we lived in SF cuz we loved it so much.  7 years later, it did not disappoint.  This time we even brought our 2 and 4 year old who are not that experimental with their palates.  My 4 year old told me that he would like to go there every night.  The Sangria is amazing!  Every dish we ever tried has been great.  You can't go wrong here.  The service was good as well.  Although you may want to stay away from the grape juice for the kids.  It costs $5.50 a glass.
author: Helen P.

description:
Unfortunately, this restaurant does not take reservations.  We went around 8:30pm, and waited for about 45min for a table for 4.  It was freezing cold yesterday, but they had an indoor seated waiting area...sweet!  

Between 4 girls, we ordered 5 tapas and a carafe of sangria.  I really enjoyed the Jamon Serrano and the shrimp with garlic/oil.  The sauteed mushrooms were light yet flavorful.  I probably wouldn't order the potatas bravas again...the sauce on top was a bit too bland for me.  The Mixed greens salad was good, but very simple/standard.  

The food came out pretty quickly and they also gave us the chocolate mousse cake on the house as a birthday dessert :)  YUM!  must try!

The total was $64.  Not bad at all~
author: Jenny K.

description: First a tapas bar this is not... a spanish restaurant yes.... is there a difference? Anyone that has traveled around Spain knows the difference. Great tortilla.  Great pulpo.  Wish they had rosado by the glass....
author: Lee B.

description:
This place is gooooood!!!

It took about 30 minutes to find a nearby parking spot on a Saturday night.  but it was totally worth it, especially since seating was fast for 2 -4 people.

We had mussels, grilled shrimp, duck, roasted mushrooms, and a few other tapas that I don't recall right now.

But all i know was that aside from the duck, everything was tasty, juicy, and absolutely delicious.  

Totally recommended and definitely I would go again.
author: Alan T.

description:
Loved the spanish style tapas here.  We had some really good Jamón ibérico.  It reminded me of the Jámon my flatmate's mom used to send to him from Madrid...

The service was great, and the atmosphere was not too noisy, but definitely social.  The waiters seemed to all be from Spain, which was a nice touch.  Our waiter was very good, and gave some good recommendations (but without telling us the price unfortunately!  We ended up ordering a special that was far more expensive than we expected...)
author: Jen Z.

description: Good selection of tapas with generous servings. Squid and lamb chops are a must try!
author: mimomai i.

description: Food is good but the service is better. I especially liked the desert that was a sponge cake roll with chocolate orange mousse. Muy Bueno!!
author: Neil C.

description:
My husband made dinner plans to eat here for our anniversary.  We honeymooned in Barcelona and wanted to relive our experience and he'd heard rave reviews about the tapas here.  That being said, we came here on a weeknight so the we had a very short wait but there was a steady stream of people coming in and out.  

We had a carafe of sangria which was really delicious.  They don't make it with cava (sparkling wine), like we had in Spain, but it was equally good.  Our culinary experience at Zarzuela overwhelmed us with emotions and nostalgia for Barcelona - it might have the the effects of the sangria ^^

Jamon Serrano con Pan y Tomate - the jamon was flavorful, the tomato bread reminded us of the bread we had in Spain
Tortilla Espanola - Spanish potato and onion omelette with a side of salsa,  reminiscent of the breakfasts we had in Spain
Banderillas de Cordero - Grilled Lamb in Rosemary sauce, I recommend getting the Large portion of this, it was delish
Patatas Bravas - potatoes with spicy tomato sauce, good for french fry lovers
Croquetas de Jamon y Pollo - Chicken and Ham croquette, fried, creamy goodness
Chocolate Roll Cake - the description sounded like Tiramisu because it was soaked in Espresso and some liquer but there is this layer of chocolate and fudge ....mmmmmmmmm  mmmmm!

If you're thinking to yourself that this is a lot of food - it was!  But we devoured it all!  Check it out for yourselves!  Oh, the prices are very reasonable too.
author: Blu n.

description: Went  here with a group of 6 for a friends birthday. we luckily got seated within 30 min (no reservations here). Everything we ordered was delicious! The mussels, paella, mushrooms in garlic sauce, jamon serano with tomato, calamari (not your usual calamari you get at cheesecake factory or something, this was more of the actual squid), sangria, and chocolate cake. And i thought it was a perfect amount for sharing for all of us. However, i agree with the one yelper, not too many vegetarian options. Also, service was slow (they took forever to bring us water and acknowledge us, and then a long time to give us our check so long that we had to hunt down our server)!-otherwise i would have given 5 stars.
author: Loe B.

description:
i've had tapas all over this city and zarzuela is the best.
Legit spanish food. don't stop!
author: Mimi C.

description:
My friends from SoCal came back with me to the Bay Area to visit my family.  I wanted to take them to a cool tapas restaurant.  I found this on yelp and decided to try it on a Friday night.  

We had to wait a bit for them to set up the table but it wasn't that long.  Our server was a cute little old man.  We started with a carafe of their sangria.  It was good.  I can't remember how much it was but I wish they gave us more!  Bread and olive oil and kalamata olives were served as starters.  I loved the olives.  We ordered the sauteed shrimp, mussels, crab cakes and the chorizo.  The food was good but the portions were way too small.  I understand they are tapas but come on!  The shrimps looked so small and lonely and blah.  But it did taste decent.  The best dish was the crab cakes and the chorizo.  We didn't order desserts because we wanted to save room for drinks afterward.  =)

Parking in the Russian Hill is impossible.  We probably circled five times around the neighborhood before getting lucky and found a spot right across the street from the restaurant.

The restaurant was small and intimate...I liked the decor and the feel of the place.  Tables are close to each other so conversations can be overheard by others next to you.  

Overall, I liked the restaurant.  I might have to think twice about going here again though because of the parking situation.
author: Cindy L.

description: Wow what a find! The review are right on! The atmosphere and food and wine and homemade sangria and oh my god I could go on forever! Simply put, I love this place.
author: Thomas S.

description:
My partner and I were craving for tapas....we live on Russian Hill and had three choices: Illuna Basque, Bocadillos or Zarzuelas. 

ILLUNA BASQUE:
Pros: Guarantee reservation (opentable), close to home (2 blocks), cocktails
Cons: so-so food (patroned the establishment 5-6 times and food quality/portions deteriorated every time), NO foie gras!!!!! They use to have this on the menu so I inquired on my 2nd visit....the waiter gave me a blank look and stared at me as though I asked for his liver!!!

BOCADILLOS:
Pros: Rachael Ray visited this establishment on one of her shows...so just wanted to visit and see what the hype was about
Cons: A bit of a walk from where we live (Greenwich/Jones)

ZARZUELAS:
Pros: Excellent food, good service, no wait (Friday night @ 7PM)......good value! Except for the specials, all tapas dishes were under $9...can't beat that!!!
Cons: Does not take reservations

WE ENDED UP @ ZARZUELAS. For a party of 2, we left stuffed and a bit tipsy (finished a bottle of red wine) for under $75 (gratuity included).

WE'LL BE BACK!
author: Alan N.

description:
My boyfriend and I love Zarzuela. Sometimes the service slows down a bit as the restaurant gets busier, but that wont stop us from coming back!

I dream about the almond-stuffed dates. They are topped with a tasty balsamic sauce and are usually on special. My manfriend doesn't eat fish or anything too crazy, so we usually order the:

Jamon Serrano-- a very generous serving of thinly sliced, tasty ham with four pieces of bread with tomato.
Croquettes-- bite-sized delicious fried bites with chicken and ham. Light and fluffy. I love these.
Patatas al Ajillo-- good for two people who like potatoes. 
Chorizo al Vino-- this doesn't "wow" us. It just seems like sliced sausage in a thin wine sauce. We won't get it next time.
Sangria-- love it. But the Spanish beer is refreshing, too.

They bring around a hefty basket of bread with olive oil for dipping and a bowl of tasty, salty olives before your meal arrives. (My mouth is watering just thinking about all of this food.) The waitstaff works hard and is always courteous. We went here for a big anniversary, and were happy as always.

I would suggest going early-- on weekends there is a wait, so we usually go around 6pm during the week to avoid any wait.
author: Lauren M.

description: I love love love this place!!!  I've been coming here for the past 10 years - Arturo and Andy always greet me with a big hug and a fabulous dinner!  This IS my favorite place in the city - Love it!
author: Jodi B.

description: Was in SF last week on vacay and a friend recommended we try this place for dinner.  It worked out really well as it is right off the cable car line.  If you like tapas, this is a great place to try.  It was crowded when we arrived but we got a table right away.   We asked the waiter what their top dishes were and went with those.  My favorite was the garlic shrimp!  I also really  loved the sangria!  If you want to try something a little more local, I'd definitely suggest here.
author: Alissa B.

description:
This is a hidden gem.  We ate here two nights ago while visiting the city.  The food was great and the prices reasonable.  Most plates are about $5 - $6.  Our server was nice.  We were seated quickly.  Food was a little bit slow, but that was expected since the restaurant was completely full.  It's a fun experience.  We enjoyed it.

We had:
- grilled scallops: tender and firm, excellent (A+)
- garlic shrimp: good flavor, especially if you like garlic.  A little bit on the oily side, however (A-)
- grilled shrimp: excellent, salt and pepper seasoned, with heads on , good value at $6 (A+)
- chicken strips: good (B+)
- New York Steak : very tender, with peppercorn sauce, $10 (A+)
- Fried Calamari: good (A-)
- salad with apples and walnuts and blue cheese (A)
- shrimp bisque (A)

If you go, get their early before they run out of some of the house specials.
author: John S.

description: Great goat cheese food was good. Every one comments on the good service, sadly we experienced poor service, and would not return again.
author: Rob G.

description: What a pleasant surprise, not only for the authenticity of the menu and the Spanish friendliness of the proprietor, but the food was honestly good with prices that should put all other tapas locales to shame. Not that it's cheap, they just do not skimp on their food - and on the quality of their food. We started off with an obviously freshly cut plate of Jamon Serrano on garlicy roasted bread with fresh tomato spread, followed by a very very tender poached octopus with potatoes, chunks of a very flavorful empanada (very filipino - tasting, actually) and a beautiful plate of veal in wine sauce. Wonderful!
author: Paolo D.

description:
Absolutely charming! The staff is warm and welcoming delivering plate after plate of authentic tapas in a cozy setting. 

The sangria is a must as you peruse the menu over warm bread with olive oil. Be careful, the bread is delicious and you may find yourself full before you can even place your order. 

I love the fried potatoes and the goat cheese with tomato sauce--I always get these, but then experiment with a few more. 

Another great note is that it is affordable and worth it! I love leaving full and then strolling around such a lovely neighborhood.
author: Jennifer W.

description: The aroma when you walk into this place is yummy, smells of garlic and seafood.  Get there early because they don't take reservations and do not seat you until your entire party is there.  Six friends and I celebrate a birthday dinner here and we had a good time! We ordered 2 carafes of sangria, 5 tapas plates and 2 dinner for two and were more than satisfied.  The Paella was excellent & so was the cold seafood salad! Our server was entertaining and everthing came out timely.  Oh yea.. don't forget to lock the bathroom if you use it!  I got walked in on, mid pee! =O
author: Earlene C.

description:
I lived in Spain for a year. This food took me back. I felt like I was in an authentic Spanish tapas bar. 

All the food was very delicious and very reasonably priced. Had an amazing meal of 4 items to share, a dessert, and a bottle of tempornillo/Grenache all for about $70 including gratituy. 

I love quality food and service that is properly priced. This delivers both.
author: Ryan K.

description:
I have been coming here for 10 years and I hope to be coming for the next 10 years!!!  Love this place.

They don't take reservations so come early, or come and wait in their little waiting room area with a pitcher of sangria.  But once you are seated, service is fast and the food is great.  Favorites include garlic shrimp, chorizo, stuffed mushrooms, potatoes, and poached octopus.  Pretty much everything we ordered, we loved.  The best thing about tapas is that since everything is appetizer like, and meant to be shared you can order everything and not feel like you are ordering too much!  

Super reasonable prices, and relaxed, warm and inviting atmosphere that is perfect for gathering with friends, or a romantic dinner for 2.  Either way, coming here, you can't lose!
author: Denise B.

description:
MMMM Spanish food. 

Vale, I'm still a little hazy from all the sangria that I had there (which by the way is the best sangria I've had outside of actual Spain). The place was packed, but thankfully we were squeezed into a cozy table perfect for two of us. We started off with some of their rioja, not too sure what year, but it was very smooth. I'm not a wine conoisseur, but it was really good. We ordered the mushrooms, lamb, chorizo and shrimp. The mushroom was the only "eh" dish, decent, but still eh. Everything else was soo succulent and tasty! I definitely recommend Zarzuela to anyone who wants a taste of Spain, or whoever is like me and wants to relive every gourmet experience they had in Spain. 

I would suggest going early and during a weekday to guarantee a table, I think there was additional seating in the back, but not sure if it's for larger parties..go here, you'll love it!

PS don't miss out on the desserts! Also if you can, avoid driving, parking is a bi*ch
author: Ruchita P.

description: Super easy to get reservations, but may have been lucky.  This place had great tapas!  I definitely left this place a tad happier.  Every dish we ordered was great.  I particularly liked the
author: Sonia M.

description:
I love tapas and so I've been on a search to find the most awesome tapas places in the city and I do believe I found one of them.

We went the day before Valentines to beat the crowds, but this neighborhood jem was still packed Friday at 7pm. The location is great, but extremely hard to find parking in Russian Hill so we aware of that.  There is a garage down the block, but it's pricey at $20.  

The food was great.  Had the sauteed mushrooms (my favorite), shrimp, mussels, goat cheese in marinara (another fav), and empanada. I must say the empanada was mine and my bf's least favorite (knida salty). Overall the food was great and so was the bubbley, our waiter was fantastic and gave good recommendations.

Also had the chocolate mousse cake...yum and finished our meal perfectly.  

I plan to come back when I'm in town again.!
author: ellainne v.

description:
I usually agree with the mass of Yelper's but not here. I showed up for dinner last night around 7:40 and was seated immediately while waiting for a friend. The place was about 2/3 full. We weren't planning on meeting until 8 but I figured I could have a drink and relax for a while. So I sit down at a nice table in the middle and am given menus/wine list. And I wait. And wait. And look around. And wait some more. Ok I try catching the waiter's attention, no luck. So after about 12 minutes, I start staring at the host guy who's literally 6 feet away from me. 3 minutes later he realizes I'm giving him the evil eye and approaches to offer me a drink. I went for a carafe of the sangria which was underwhelming. My friend arrived and we order dinner. I'd just come from a dinner meeting and wasn't super hungry. We ordered the braised quail and the goat cheese in tomato sauce. The goat cheese was warm and actually pretty damn good. The quail was like something out of the bizarro world. They gave us 4 of these tiny bite size pieces, mostly wings so we're talking like half of a normal adult bite. The flavor was decent and I fully understand that tapas are small plates, but come on. 

While the experience last night was lackluster, I'd definitely try Zarzuela again on an empty stomach because the menu had some attractive choices and I love the neighborhood (see my review on Swensen's, across the street).
author: Jonathan G.

description:
Me gusta muchisimo.  La comida es MUY delicioso.  

Vale, vale. I lived in Spain last summer and I haven't had tapas since.  So you could imagine my surprisingly delightful experience I had here.  I LOVE gambas ajillo and I thoroughly believe that they executed the dish perfectly.  

The olive oil they used was so damn delicious that I wanted to wear a lifesaver-sized baguette and swim in it.

Although we brought our own bottle of Pinot Noir, the wine selection was relatively reasonable.
author: Rochelle B.

description:
In the summer of 2003, I found myself in Barcelona, studying Spanish and reading Catalan.  My host mom made me food from scratch: paella, yogurt, pizza, ice cream, bread, spanish foods...you name it, it was all fresh.

Three of us celebrated a birthday at Zarzuela last night, and if it weren't for the summer in Spain, I probably wouldn't have fallen so hard for the food.  The jamon serrano, the champinones, la bisteca, a bottle of Cava...the flavors brought me back to the land I love.  

I'm already itching to go back and stuff my face with more of their authentic tapas.  I think I will.

----

No reservations, but there's a small waiting room with chairs off the main dining area.  Past that room, there's an unseen room with more tables - quiet and isolated, and that's where we ended up, along with several Spanish-speaking groups.  It's cozy, if you want a quieter place to spend time with friends.  Good for a casual date, good for quiet dinner that satisfies, good for anything!

Champinones - Grilled stuffed mushrooms, delicious.

Pan con tomate y jamon serrano (bread rubbed with tomato, arranged around slices of jamon serrano) - simple. yum. i loved the jamon serrano. flashbacks came to me.

NY Steak - soo tasty.

Gambas plancha - grilled prawns.  tiny but full of flavor, sizzling hot.

Croquetas - good as expected.  

I think I need to go back next week, and taste more.  So hungry I can't think or write straight.
author: Sarah W.

description:
The husband and I went here for old-times sake - we'd last been her 3 years ago and had fond memories. While the food was decent this time around, it just wasn't as great as I remember it. What we ordered:

1. Ham and chicken croquettes - objectively, they were well seasoned and  nice and crispy. I have an issue with panko. Don't know why - just don't like it. So, I only ate one. Husband finished the rest...
2. Short ribs - my favorite by far. The ribs are sliced thin (no bones) and came with mashed potatoes. Yummy!
3. Potatoes bravas - what more can you say about fried potatoes? Can't really go wrong here.
4. Octopus w/ potatoes. This was my second favorite. Usually, the octopus for this dish is chopped into chunks, which (in my opinion) is not at all appetizing. This version was sliced thinly and layered across the potatoes (yes, 3 potato dishes...) Very good.
5. Crab bisque - fantastic! 
6. Flan dessert - custard was tasty, but had too many "bubbles". Not as silky smooth as I like it.

In general, this is a great little neighborhood place. The service is attentive, and it has very homey atmosphere.
author: Eme L.

description: What a wonderful dinner!  I had not been to Zarzuela for several years, but every dish was just as delicious as I remembered, and I love the idea of being able to sample many small plates of both hot and cold tapas.  Personal favorites include the Gambas Ajillo (shrimp sauteed in garlic and olive oil, served in a hot cast iron skillet) and Patatas Bravas (fried potatoes with a spicy tomato sauce).  We sampled two nightly specials of perfectly prepared cod and grilled asparagus, and a new dish of almond-stuffed dates wrapped in prosciutto and grilled, served in a balsamic reduction, which went perfectly with a warm goal cheese dish we ordered.  The chocolate dessert was simply divine!  Also, Zarzuela's sangria is just right, and they put the ice in your glass and not in the carafe, as it should be.  The service was excellent, and the wait staff has been there for many years.  I'm already looking forward to my next meal at Zarzuela.  I recommend dining early, and allowing plenty of time for parking as it is a challenging area in that regard.
author: Alice H.

description:
I am so hot for this place!  The waiters can be a little daft (like topping off my wine glass w/ the OTHER red on our table, therefore mixing the two), but they are friendly and quick, without ever making you feel rushed.  

Although I've only come with large groups (6 people), it looks like the cutest little date spot.  Also, I was completely surprised with the price.  With bottles of wine, several tapas and desserts, it was something like $25/person.  And we were stuffed afterwards.

My absolute favorite tapa is the warm goat cheese...to DIE for.
author: Lindsay W.

description: My wife drags me to this place twice a year. The food is completely bland and the sangria is a complete alcohol free rip off.  The indoor scenery and patrons remind me of a nursing home.   The waiters have no personality what-so-ever you are lucky to even get a "hi".   If you want a place to learn about spanish food bail (the waiters haven't been).  The paella rice most of the time isn't cooked through. If you are forced to go -- order the cheapest wine and get through it.
author: James R.

description: Zaruela was a great place to host out of towners for dinner on a weekend night.  Our server was excellent in terms of menu knowledge and promptness.   He had an excellent knowledge of the daily specials.  All of the Tapas were excellent.  We ordered two tapas per person and that seem to be perfect for the portion size for our group.  The crab bisque daily soup special was awesome. Our party of four especially loved the grilled shrimp and sautéed sausage Tapas.  They serve beer and wine on the alcohol menu and the ambiance near the Polk St Trolley is very San Francisconian.  A great Spanish theme restaurant for the Bay Area whether or not you are entertaining out of towners.
author: Eric B.

description:
Was in the mood for paella and decided to try Zarzuela based on the star rating and number of yelp reviews despite there not being a website or menu we could look at.

I wasn't that hungry, so I only ordered a few things. The food on average was okay. Some was great, others only okay. Their homemade Sangria was good. The shrimp with garlic was great, the fried potato was rather lacking any flavor or seasoning. The paella was only meh. It was kinda bland. I've definitely had better. Service could have been better. It took over 15 minutes before a server came by to take our order, however, it was a Friday night and they were packed.

If you're in the neighborhood, I'd give Zarzuela a try, but I wouldn't recommend making a special trip out here. Oh, and if you're driving, good luck finding street parking! Just give up and park in the garage across the street. It's $10 for 1 hour with a $20 maximum.
author: Christiana C.

description:
At this point, with Zarzuela having over 600+ reviews any new reviews are fairly insignificant.  However, when I eat at a place and like it as much as I did at Zarzuela, I will still write the review as a thank you, if nothing else.
My wife and I went with friends and as they had been there many times before, we were promised a great meal.  To say this meal was great, maybe an understatement, it is a week later and I am still thinking about it.
I think it is fair to say that we ordered most of the tapas menu (the only way to really judge a restaurant) and there was not one dish that we did not like.
One of the highlights for me, was the Jamon Iberico Con Pan y Tomate, this was real Iberico ham and an off menu special.  While this dish was pricy ($28), it was well worth it.  This is cured ham like I have never tasted and a must try.
Other dishes we ordered: Pimientos Asados, Tortilla Espanola, Champinones Plancha, Chorizo Al Vino, Croquetas De Jamon Y Pollo, Patatas Bravas, Pulpo a La Gallega.  In my experience, when you order so many dishes it is common to rank one or two toward the bottom on how well I liked it, especially when trying new foods.  This was not the case at Zarzuela, we all loved everything, every dish was prepared wonderfully and  tasted delicious.  I do not remember how much the overall bill was and after such a wonderful meal, I could not have cared less how much it cost.
This place was awesome, can't wait to go back and I only hope that they have the Jamon Iberico when I do.
author: Donnie R.

description:
This is best Spanish/tapas bar in San Francisco Bay area - by far.  

We had the sangria, eggplant/goat cheese, sausage, empanadas, octopus, and vermicelli/seafood - and all were good.  The octopus was very tender and yummy - and would highly recommend.  The empanada was quite different, vegetarian, and like a casserole (versus a turnover), and the crust, both top and bottom, were very nice and not soggy.

And reasonably priced.  We did have to wait about 20-30 minutes, as they do not take reservations.....but worth it.
author: Paul C.

description: I had a hard time finding legit tapas in the city. We got drunk on sangria and had a healthy spread of tapas for less than $20/person in a great environment. Highly recommended. Also, there was no wait. This place was understated -- croquetas were yummers.
author: Andrew K.

description: A great place to take your wife when one more scream out of the kids is going to send her straight to the bottle.  Tapas, not bottles honey.  Tapas.
author: Mike F.

description:
Service is not good!! 
Walked in for dinner and was left standing by the door for a good 5-10 minutes while all the staff ignored us. They walked past us like 10 times and never made eye contact! Then we were ushered to the waiting room which is pretty sad like we were put in the corner for time out. Then they seated us and ignored us for the next 20 minutes, then came the olives then more ignoring..then the guy waiting on the tables next to us came by and said..'yes what would you like'....no apologies..no mention of specials etc...so then I ask him what the specials were and there were a few...anyways we order what we wanted..and then 5 minutes later...almost 30 minutes into sitting there...we get bread. This put us in not so good a mood..also the table which was seated 10 minutes earlier next to us, got their bread at the same time we got ours!!! 5 minutes later we got our gambas al ajillo...these were tiny shrimp (like the small shrimp that we get in Chinese fried rice) in olive oil and garlic...it was ok, not great. Then came our paella, which was pretty sad....the rice was chewy (undercooked) and definitely not to par with the paella we've had before, I make better paella. We were so done by the end of dinner, pretty sad considering people usually go out to eat to have a good time. The only positive about this trip to Russian hill was the neighborhood and the views of the city.
author: B P.

description:
I'm sorry, but I really didn't like this place. I'm sure it could have been a nicer experience had we been sat in the main dining room, but we were put in a window-less room in the back of the restaurant. I had to ASK to have my water refilled each and EVERY time. Our waiter didn't check up on us during the entire meal, and the food was tiny and un-special (read: bland and boring). I was dissapointed on many accounts. We all left feeling hungry!

I would never go back!
author: Vanessa B.

description: One of my favorite Spanish restaurants from SF. Love their tapas and wine selection. Restaurant also has great ambiance. Check out their menu here:  http://bit.ly/aB94kN. Chorizo Al Vino is my personal favorite. I believe they're closed on Mon & Sun.
author: Captain G.

description: I came here for tapas with some friends in August.  I think it was a Thursday night around 6pm and we were seated right away. We didn't order dinner, but we shared 5-6 plates of tapas and some sangria. The food was fantastic, the portions were perfect. I recommend the tapas to anyone and everyone who enjoys Spanish food. The sangria was good, but the tapas was amazing. I live in the South Bay and will gladly make a trip back to the city for a toasted baguette, tomato and ham tapas dish! The prices were good and the service was above average.
author: Matt K.

description:
this place= YUM

food was excellent , we devoured the mussels, leg of duck with plum sauce (my favorite- perfectly cooked), and pork medallions. octlopus- not so much, was bland for my taste but very tender. 

I was not a huge fan of the atmosphere here, but makes up for in flavor and value what it lacks in ambiance. Service was decent too. 

Oh and I almost forgot to mention the sangria- some of the best I've had in awhile- I think a must if you come here.
author: Christy D.

description:
A nice little Spanish-style Tapas place. It's relatively small and parking is a bit of a challenge being right on Hyde, but those obstacles are worth braving. 

I recommend the Ensalada de la Casa to start which was a super-fresh salad including goat cheese, walnuts and apple slices. I also recommend the mushrooms in sherry sauce and the Sangria.

Good food. Good atmosphere. Good times.
author: Charles B.

description:
All around wonderful experience. 

Had a carafe of sangria, mussels, lamb tenders, crab bisque, warm goat cheese, and stuffed mushrooms and then spanish version of creme brulee for dessert. 

Upsides:
I say the best was the crab bisque. 
My friend votes for the mushrooms. 
Great atmosphere / setup / service. 

Downsides:
No full bar - I just want a martini dammit!
The top of the creme brulee thing tasted like suspiciously like burnt cardboard. I don't think the Spanish know what they're doing on this one.
author: Josh B.

description: One of my friends made reservations here and she and another friend of mine dined here for the 1st time sometime this past March.  We three shared a paella and some kind of mushroom dish and another dish.  We ate all the complimentary bread & olives and olive oil.  The food was delicious.  However, I was a little disappointed with the amount of food since I was still hungry afterwards.  We made up for it by going across the street to Swensen's Ice Cream Parlor.  Then, not too long ago, I was on a 2nd time date from an on-line website and I suggested for my date to bring me here.  I think he might have been shocked of how much he spent on our dinner since he didn't ask me out again.  Lol. Then again I think it wasn't a match for us at all.  He and I didn't seem to have the chemistry going, but I enjoyed my dinner.  Anyway, I ordered the valenciana paella again and we tried the other tapas (stuffed mushrooms again, the mussels with saffron), a lamb dish and a seafood salad. We tried their sangria.  We were too full for a dessert.  Since my date really didn't work out, I really still enjoyed the full dinner since we had more of a variety of food.  The wait for a reserved table was a little long since we were there on a Saturday night, but we did have reservations.  Overall, the food is pretty good the 2nd time around for me, so I rated this place pretty high and the restaurant itself has a nice staff and a warm ambiance.
author: Arlene Z.

description:
The best tapas in SF.  What more do you need to know.
Oh, no reservations and closed Mondays.
author: Wakako U.

description:
Why oh why is Zarzuela constantly packed out on weekends? Is it merely the beneficiary of being in a sweet geographic spot? I just don't get it. 

I went there with friends last Wednesday around 8.45pm, not late enough for the place to be as devoid of atmosphere as it was. Nothing was particularly memorable, except the oyster dish which was so fishy as to be practically inedible (and this coming from a gal who generally loves fish). Everything else tasted OK, without being particularly well-integrated - in fact, there wasn't anything we tried that would have prompted me to order seconds. We even struggled to finish the sangria, which seemed to be largely lacking in alcohol. 

All in all this was a big disappointment - I love tapas and don't have any plans to return to this joint.
author: Leela S.

description:
First come first serve, good luck!  It's decent tapas, kind of overpriced if you ask me.  

Parking sucks, watch out for their neighbors, they WILL ticket you if your car is hanging out in their driveway.
author: Dong T.

description:
This restaurant has been around for many, many years. Right on the corner of Union and Hyde, diagonally across from the even older Swensen's Ice Cream.

The owners are chatty with their long time customers and the Sat. night we went there were a couple of large parties of big families.  Chose a selection of different tapas, including calamari and grilled eggplant with goat cheese. Catalan seafood stew and oxtail stew were both decent. While the cuisine didn't wow us, the atmosphere was great.  Good for dates or large parties, and very child/family friendly or welcoming.
author: Ye W.

description:
jeesh, what's all the hype about? after a 40 minute wait (quoted at 20) on a Tuesday night, we got seated and served by mr grouchy old man who thinks just because he's old, one word questions suffice. (dessert? beer?) I'm pretty sure we never got asked how the food was.....so i'll tell you. 

It wasn't the worse, wasn't the best. We got three dishes (tomato y pan, baked goat cheese, chorizo, short ribs, mussels) and the first 3/5 were actually pretty alright, but nothing to come back for again and again. 
the short ribs were bland and the instant mashed potatoes they were served with were..instant. and the mussels. if you like gargantuan gushy mussels, by all means, go to zarzuela, but those giant ones sorta gross me out, too much to handle. 

at the end of the day, the place just didn't do it for me.
author: callie m.

description:
Went here on a Wednesday night, had to wait about 10 minutes for a table that was vacant the whole time. Thought the staff was very kind, we even got a yummy piece of flan for free.

We did tapas only. I really loved the spicy chorizo sauted in a red wine sauce, super tasty. The fried calamari was good, but nothing different then what you get from other restaurants. The pork tenderloins were especially tasty; which were sauted in a rich white wine sauce. We also shared a carafe of sangria which I found to be excellent.

Be aware that there is only one bathroom with one stall that is unisex.
author: Ericka A.

description:
Went with no expectations, but the food was great! 
A group of nine of us shared 12 tapas and 2 orders of the seafood paella. 
Most of the tapas were good, not great. But I really liked the sauteed shrimp in garlic and olive oil.
The paella was yummy (from what little knowledge I have of Spanish food)...although the mussels in the paella tasted like they were straight from the ocean, saltwater and everything. 
Escargot was an interesting experience, not too sure how I feel about that one..

The place is tiny and difficult to accomodate larger groups, but the friendly waiter (who offered to take a picture for us before we even asked) and good food made up for the long wait.
author: Jess J.

description:
I decided to give this place a try tonight after reviewing it on SFGate's top 100 Bay Area.   After all, I've been craving for some tasty tapas since our trip to Napa's Zuzu (super delish!) a few months back. 

Unfortunately, I don't get what all the hype is all about with Zarzuela. First off, I hate restaurants that only have ONE SHARED bathroom.  Needless to say, the owner must be an inconsiderate male who doesn't care about his female clientele's needs.  After waiting 10 minutes which seemed like an eternity when you are just staring at the bathroom door, the woman before me finally come out.  To my dismay, I found that she had clogged the toilet and didn't even bother to notify me nor the rest. workers.  Of course, I ended up doing the dirty job of telling the owner about his bathroom situation.  Let me just note that by the end of our hour long dinner, the bathroom was still broken and my hubby proceeded to tell me that people just peed on top of existing "contribution" by others.  GROSS!

Enough about the bathroom situation, after all, we are suppose to be talking about restaurant so here's the food part.  We ordered chorizo, crab bisque, mussels, sauteed garlic shrimp, and patatas bravas.  The only enjoyable tapa was the crab bisque, which tasted heavenly with dipped bread.  The other dishes unfortunately were mediocre.  

Needless to say, I don't think I'll revisit this place again.
author: Jeannie L.

description:
I just got back from a two week trip to Spain and was jonesing for some Spanish food so we went to Zarzuela and sadly this place so did not live up to our expectations. We had been reading the reviews about how authentic this place was but sadly it was not. Or else we ate at all very inauthentic places in Spain but how could they be in authentic if they were IN spain. Questions, questions...
Anyway some of the dishes were passable, the croquettes, the patatas, but the paella was incredibly disappointing. Soggy, bland with huge chunks of dry chicken. Sob! I want to go back to Spain!!
author: Cathy T.

description:
First of all, parking is complicated! We may had had better luck if we were driving a compact car but our search took at least 15 minutes. No valet, no parking garages, just residential, beware of limited parking spaces.

I was recommended by a friend to try the tapas here. Our party of 5 was seated in the smaller back dining room. We could see the dishes being made and being retrieved by the waiters. Our older waiter was not quite up to speed with our requests for our water. He did bring out our sangria (a bit watered-down) but the water took a bit longer. The tapas came out pretty quickly and each one was finished within minutes: chorrizo, stuffed mushrooms and calamari. I didn't find any of them to be fantastic. Then there was a big break before our chicken and seafood paella came to table. I found the paella to be bland. No flavor in the seafood and the rice was just dry. However, the chicken was very good, similar to a chicken marsala, perhaps better. The mushroom sauce was sweet and salty all at the same time. 

Our bill was rung up incorrectly and a dish was not recorded or served. So, overall the dining experience was okay. Good prices and great spanish decor. The service not-so-great because the man whose glasses were as thick as Miltons' (from Office Space) showed signs of exhaustion such as the beads of sweat across his forehead.
author: Oanh N.

description:
well, I am now just one of the masses ~ who have been here and now love it! My brother has been here though I still lived in Spain. He told me about the place and liked the food....  most americans - I feel - don't understand too much real {I mean REAL} spanish food and I think even if they were served bare rug on a plate, they would say: "I like this". I read several online reviews on the place including several (many) Yelp reviews and decided TODAY would be my chance to see what the screaming was about. There's NO parking available though a garage just opened up 100 feet away...  well....  

I went with four friends and when I finally found a parking spot, joined them 16,2mins later. Passing through the door, one smells garlic...  and mighty good smelling garlic at that!!! Then there's the rustic ceiling and all the spanish bull-fighting posters - not very big cities but what the heck: GOOD bullfighting posters aren't easy to get (I have several in Spain still unclaimed by friends - I'm keeping them now!). They had picked a small table right next to the window on the Hyde Stret side and it was great watching the cable cars go by....  It was very casual and very nice, with the light down low. I ordered the Chuletas de Cordero which were fantasticly good and full of flavor. I thought it could use a bit more salt but since I've arrived in the states two years ago, have noticed a lack of salt on foods in general and thought this was just an american watered-down thing....  The Champinones al Ajillo was also very good, served in a small spanish-style black pan.... by time the food was served, the place was filling up! A friend who has tasted the tortilla I make, ordered the tortillas here and though it wasn't dry, I thought it could use a bit more olive oil and salt in the preparation & cooking, but still not too bad. Everyone agreed that my tortillas are better but this is a restaurant...  not a home kitchen where one can give more care and attention. The attention given was very good and professional. I enjoyed being in a "spanish" environment again and though I'll be in Spain and in my apartment before this week is over, I enjoyed this a lot. One thing I pointed out to my friends was the noise-level - it was LOUD in there, more than in any restaurant I've eaten at while in the states, and I explained that in Spain this is typpical, and especially in the southern region (Andalucia). I had a great time and the food was very good - I would certainly return plus I enjoy having the opportunity to speak spanish again. If you see an online menu, it is not the full menu they actually have at the restaurant....  I intend to return after I return from Spain. Though I have read reviews stating the place was very pricey - and to me when I eat at a place in Andalucia the prices - even in euros - is slightly below was charged, I think the flavor and friendly environment was well worth it. Bravo! Ole!!
author: Tony L.

description:
Small neighborhood place in Russian Hill. Parking is not the greatest. Better to take the cable car there and walk around afterwards.

 I think the food is just 'ok'. I'm not comparing it to places in Spain but the menu covers basically the dishes you would find there.  The food doesn't really sing though. 

We ordered:
 - crispy potatoes - would be better if they were piping hot; it was warm and lost some of its crispiness
- mussels - flavor was ok but i think the dish was left on the counter too long. I make this better at home!
- shrimp - same as the mussels...nothing really special
- octopus - ok
- sangria - can't really mess this up except that it was more juice than wine hence a diluted taste. 

Pricepoint is reasonable if the food was better. Not quite worth the prices since it's only mediocre.
author: Ling L.

description:
It was my roomie's birthday yesterday, and I planned a dinner for her at Zarzuela.  Although they do not take reservations, I called at 5:30pm the day of letting them know that a group of 7 would be arriving around 6:30pm.  They said that they would put my name down, and when we got there, they had our table already set up for us.  Basically, it was if I had made a reservation so don't fret over the fact that they say they don't take reservations.

Moving on, we ordered two sets of 6 tapas and a seafood paella to share. 

*grilled eggplant with goat cheese: this dish is amazing and I'm glad it was a cold dish.  It was a nice contrast to the rest of the hot tapas we ordered.
*serrano ham with crostini and tomato spread: better than what I remembered!  this is really good with some of the goat cheese and tomato sauce smeared on top
*pork tenders: good but not great.  it was just a dish with pork on skewers with some mashed potatoes, nothing special
*mushrooms with garlic and herbs: this was tasty, but too greasy for me
*chorizo in a wine sauce: this dish wasn't as good as the previous time I had it.  the sauce was a bit thick and reminded me of tomato goop instead of sauce
*goat cheese with tomato sauce: this is the dish I dream about and drool over, and the only reason why I ran a little harder at the gym earlier that day.  I've only had this once, but I am hooked.  
*seafood paella: I loved that they served this with plenty of thick lemon wedges and seafood.  It was a delicious entree, but definitely too big for a party of 2 as the menu suggests (unless you ONLY order 1 paella and no tapas, then that is a sufficient meal).  It was a bit under-seasoned to0.


For dessert, we all shared two desserts just to end with something sweet:
*mango sorbet with a layer of NY cheesecake on the bottom and toasted coconuts and cream on top: this is such a unique dessert, with different textures, consistencies, and temperatures!  Really loved this.
*creme brulee: too much custard, too little caramelized sugar.  I still think the creme brulee at The Slanted Door is the best I've ever had.


Overall, the food was great, our service was friendly, and I enjoyed everyone's company.  Great place to go for large parties or a romantic date.  I definitely see myself becoming a regular and perfecting my personal go-to spread of tapas.
author: Jen Y.

description: Great ambience, nice white tablecloths, a cute, romantic place. We were greeted by a friendly hostess. Our waiter helped us with the recommendations. We like tapas because you can try several things for dinner and its not expensive. We had the shrimp dish in garlic and olive oil which was awesome and not like any other shrimp dish I ever had. Crab cakes were also really good. We also tried the special empanadas of the day which were with tuna and were ok- we liked the other two items better. We had the decadent creme caramal which comes with toasted caramel on top similar to a creme brulee. This was a great meal because it came out to about $33 before tip for 2 people and we enjoyed trying different items and not left feeling super heavy or overly stuffed. It was the perfect amount of food.
author: Sheena S.

description: This is my number one favorite restaurant of all time.  Excellent Spanish food and wine.  Service is excellent.  Price, though not cheap, is a good value.  I take all my friends here when pursuing a San Francisco experience.
author: Ferd M.

description:
The litmus test for an authentic tapas place is good paella. Zarzuela's paella was dissapointingly bland. The dish clearly wasn't cooked long enough, it lacked sufficient olive oil, and it skimped on the saffron. Moreover, the bottom was charred, the rice was dry, and the dish missed the seafood aroma and essence that makes Paella Valenciana famous.

Albeit, the service was fantastic and each dish was beautifully presented. But the flavor and quality was not there. Avoid the sardine dish (it needed a cheese compliment) and the mushrooms with jamon serrano.
author: John M.

description:
Don't bother with finding parking, because there ain't no jack-pot at the end of the rainbow. I love tapas, so we tried a variety of their menu.
It was all disappointing. At least you can't go wrong with their fried calamari. Be prepared to spend $50 on 5-6 small plates. 
I have no complaints about the service.
author: Andrenaline R.

description:
I have never tried Spanish food before, so perhaps I was expecting something completely different.  But I didn't entirely enjoy this place.  Parking wasn't too bad since I got lucky (or perhaps I have developed Ninja Parking Skills living for so long in SF?).  The wait to get seated was around 30 minutes since the place didn't take reservations.

My girlfriend had Spanish food before, so I was trusting her to order the right meals.  I enjoyed a few of them, but most of it just lacked the savory flavor I expected.  I was told that this place is not the best, and that I need to try another place to reintroduce me to Spanish food.

Now the sangria on the other hand was superb! I've only had it at a few other places before, but this was one was the best so far.
author: Serge S.

description:
The great thing in life, or at least one of the greatest to me, is to get to eat exactly what you crave at the moment you crave it.  

My Saturday night was exactly that with Zarzuela.  I wanted me some paella.  The no BS, well cooked, with tender seafood and fragrant saffron all in that iron flat pan paella.  And when I got to eat it, man, was I a happy gal.  

We split a bottle of white, a poached octopus appetizer (mediocre), and 2 glasses of sangria.  The service was superb.  And the atmosphere warm and unpretentious.  I'd go back again, though in a cab, as parking is impossible in the neighborhood.
author: Jiajia C.

description:
The food was good, decent for what you pay, but if you raise the prices, I wouldn't come back.  Not as good as Cha Cha Cha's though.  

The paella was average.  Sangria could've been better.  The tapas were average to a bit above.  There was nothing that stood out for me, neither did anything tasted horrible.  The service is pretty good, one of the better places in terms of service.
author: Carrie-C N.

description:
I had my second meal at Zarzuela last night and it didn't disappoint! Popped over with a friend to fulfill a spur-of-the-moment craving for tapas (you know you've felt it too) and managed to snag a table for two at around 6:45 PM without too much trouble. 

We started with chorizo and mushrooms and then took it easy and got the paella. The food wasn't mind-blowing but it was certainly well-made, fresh, and delicious. I'm no sangria aficionado, but it was pretty tasty by my estimation.
author: Madeline N.

description:
I used to not be a fan of tapas but this place was pretty darn good.  They've converted me!  A group of friends and I dined here on a Wednesday night.  There was no crowd.  If you are planning on going, remember to leave extra early because it is difficult to find parking around this area.  I spent about 20 minutes looking for parking on a Wednesday night.

We ordered so much food because everything on the menu looked so good.  Let me see...we ordered lamb skewers, cheese plate, calamari, spanish sausage, garlic shrimp, stuffed mushrooms, tuna empanadas, seafood bake, roasted mussels, and probably because we ordered so much food - the wonderfully kind waiter brought us this seasonal pepper dish on the house.  Let me not forget that we also added two bottles of wine to our list; we practically had to roll ourselves out of there.  With the exception of the lamb (only because I'm not a big fan of lamb), I loved everything.  The food was well prepared and excellently flavored.

Like I mentioned above, the waiter was wonderfully kind.  He checked on us frequently.  You could tell he had a kind soul; big big heart.  He was genuine and he knew his wine very well.  He recommended this lovely fruit wine for our second choice and we were not disappointed.  

Value wise:  I don't ever think tapas is really of great value only because you get little food and the price is typically between $7 - $12.00 per dish.  Including gratuity, our total bill came out to about $185 for our party of four.   A little steeper than I expected but the food was good so I can't quite complain.  I recommend this place and will definitely be going back and bringing more friends.
author: Jess C.

description:
The corner of Hyde and Union.  Get there early.  No reservations and lots of people know about this place.   The room is a square, filled with relatively close tables.  Wood beams on the ceiling.  Plates and pictures on the walls.  The room fills quickly and everyone is happy.  What's not to be happy about?  Good food at good prices.  Service can lag at times.  But who cares?  The company is good.  You get to pick it.

Shrimp are sauteed in garlic and olive oil.  The shrimp are sweet, the garlic assertive and some onions crisped and tasty.  Simple food, simply prepared, simply wonderful.  

A half order of chicken and mushrooms sauteed in wine sauce comes over some mashed potatoes.  I say to myself that I could cook this at home.  Well, No.  The chicken is tender, tasty, and only a fork is needed to cut it.  The mushrooms are perfect.  The wine sauce nicely herbed.  A bit of pepper in it.  Not too reduced.  I could get the ingredients but not the talent behind this simple plate of food.  

A half order of lamb chops.  Three perfectly seared chops over a thinly cut, perfectly cooked potato.  The chops taste like lamb.  The potato tastes like potato.  Great food.

Rice pudding is nice and creamy but I would have preferred more rice and less cream.  But it's not too sweet and is assertively spiced with cinnamon.  

How many places can you find where a four course dinner of this caliber is just a tad over $40. tip included?

There's a reason this place has staying power.  The guys in the kitchen know what they are doing.  The host is welcoming.  When my service lagged, the  host got things to the table.  I love this place.  You will too.
author: David D.

description: Best tapas in all of SF. Sangria is good but not amazing. Price is reasonable.
author: Johanna W.

description: Delicious food, great service.  Seafood paella is their signature dish!
author: Elcin E.

description: Excellent service from Spanish-speaking staff (Spain).  They don't take reservations, but we went straight in. I recommend the goat cheese tapa.
author: Jeremy T.

description:
I went here a few weeks before a vacation in Spain in order to get into the right mental place before my trip.  Loved it -- we had such a great time.  The tapas are great & the sangria totally hits the spot.  The mushrooms and gambas were two of my fav. tapas on the menu.  Oh, and the service, let's just say our sangria pitcher was never empty, they are on the ball!

__________________
Update:  I had to take one star off because the service was so bad last night when we went.  We got there pretty early and had no problem getting a seat.  But once we were seated things went down-hill from there.  I had to ask three times to have my water filled.  We had to ask several times for the check.  Only once when we received the check (finally) did the waiter really start to be friendly, which left us wondering if he was just looking for a good tip?!?!  But then, we had to wait forever for the waiter to come back and pick up the credit card, meanwhile there were probably about 15 people waiting outside who would have liked to take our table ASAP.
author: Katie P.

description:
So I've been here twice, and both times it has been great.  If you know spanish, it makes it even more fun. 

Just make it easy if you have a group of people and get the carafe of sangria.  It tastes great, a good mix of everything.  I haven't tried the other drinks, ie wine and beer, but I'm sure it is a good mix.

The food is good.  I've done everything from squid, octopus, patatas bravas, lamb you name it.  Its all been great stuff.  And you can't beat the olives they give you to snack on as well, just watch out for the pits.  Overall a good place.  Maybe a little pricey, but if you have a lot of people it evens out.
author: Aaron G.

description:
Great food, unpretentious atmosphere, reasonable prices.

The menu has a great variety of tapas and entrees. My faves include the ensalada de la casa, chorizo, and the empanada of the day, which is always interesting. The sangria is a bit too sweet for my taste, but compliments the tapas nicely. 

The service can be a bit slow; let's call it leisurely. You definitely will not have a rushed meal here, so take the time to savor your sangria and tapas.
author: Lucia R.

description:
Cozy, charming and the feeling that you've discovered a tucked away spot, albeit it's right on Hyde street as the cable cars blair by, is how I describe Zarzuela.

The atmosphere is one of the reasons I gave this restaurant 4 stars.  The food is well prepared and feeling more like it came out of "mom's kitchen" then a restaurants. The servers are charming and have great recommendations.  I really like that they offer the entrees in tapas sizes so that you can try more.  The flavors are well balanced and the paella is not to be missed.  Plus pitchers of Sangria always make everything better. 

The only downside is the wait!
author: Kacey H.

description:
Cozy yet boisterious noise levels, small plates but filling, and obviously well known yet unique.  Tasty Spanish wines, friendly and sophisticated staff. 

The seating is cozy and it gets warm in here, perfect for that sundress you never get to wear in our foggy city.  They have some essentail starter dishes with olives, meats and cheeses, and of course oils and soft bread. Great spot for a double date.
author: Adrienne P.

description:
Spanish Tapas & jugs of Sangria...the only way to roll Friday after work.  This place is the number 1 seed for small plates.  Everything on the menu is excellent ranging from the sausage, lamb, potatoes, etc.  There is always a wait, and frankly you don't want to call in advance.  You can drink Sangria outside while waiting for the table, I have killed an hour doing this and can personally vouch for the entertainment value.  I love the fact they have an understated location and extremely authentic vibe.  If I am not mistaken the chef was actually brought in from abroad (award winning in Europe?) so you can count on authenticity.

For everyone in the Marina, NB, & Russian Hill this place is only a walk away at Union & Hyde.
author: T D.

description:
This is probably the best tapas place in the city. That's a strong statement, but find me another place that's this good.

The beauty of tapas is that you can try several several plates before you actually convince yourself that you need to stop eating. There's very little on the menu that I haven't tried, and there's nothing there that I haven't liked.

Except this one time we had a waiter who very rudely cut my friend off (he literally said, excuse me, stop talking) or something... But that was very much a one-time isolated incident (worth taking one star off).

I love the fact that if you're gonna be waiting a while, you can actually get a carafe of sangria and wait outside. That's amazing to me!

Oh also, do NOT leave without having tried the lamb chops. Trust me. :)
author: Anand I.

description:
Had dinner last night with some friends at Zarzuela.  I probably should have written this last nite when I memory of the experience was more intact...a lil too much sangria and after dinner drinks elsewhere...  Well, our party was in the lil back room b/t the kitchen and the bathrooms.  We were in the room with another group party, probably a total of 15 people in the room but man was it loud b/t the 15 of us.  Anyways, let's see what I can recall regarding the tapas we had...

I remembered my favorite was probably the cured serrano ham followed by the moscovick duck leg.  The spanish sausage = spanish hot dog...didn't care for it.  The waiter raved about the poached octopus so we ordered it and I didn't see why he raved about it.  The grilled lamb was mediocre...I'm very particulate about how lamb is done.  The fried garlic potatoes was pretty good.  The seafood paella is definitely not the best I've had...the rice seemed a bit undercooked.

Parking around this area is a challenge, however, walking back to the car was one of the best part of the night.  Walking along Hyde I was able to get a good glimpse of a fantastic view of coit tower and the bay bridge reminding me of what a great city I live in!
author: Rick P.

description:
I was very impressed with Zarzuela.

A star for being seated right away. A star for the friendly and prompt service. A star for keeping our wine glasses filled. A star for the fantastic food. And a star for being quick about getting our bill when we had to rush off to a show, after realizing time had completely slipped away from us in this place.

We shared a bottle of wine (a sauvignon blanc from Spain), grilled asparagus with goat cheese and balsamic vinegar, calamari, grilled mushrooms, Spanish sausage, garlic shrimp, and chicken strips, and not only would I enjoy all of them again, but I'd fully recommend them to anyone else going there. Especially the garlic shrimp.
author: Amanda R.

description:
I love tapas and I REALLY wanted to like this place, but there were just too many factors that will discourage me from coming back.

Unfortunately, most of the tapas we ordered lacked flavor.  The grilled oysters and the special of the day the scallops were fresh, but that's about it.  The one dish that had flavor were the snails, the parsley aioli had a bold taste (can't really taste the snails tho) and the only dish that I found memorable.  -1 star

Parking here in this area is very time consuming.  They don't take reservations too so be prepared to wait. -1 star

The service at first was one of the reasons why this would've been a three star review.  But unfortunately, our server forgot our stew order and we were eating with bread plates most of the night instead of dinner plates.  -1 star

If only parking was better, I would come back and want to try their paella.  But given this meal took three hours (incl finding a space, waiting for a table and waiting for our missed order), it would be unlikely that I would return.
author: Yun W.

description:
What a quaint and charming restaurant. I love Zarzuela. Forgive me for the butchering of Spanish that will follow:

Only a 30 minute wait for 3 around 7:30 on a Saturday night. That aint bad! Immediately, we ordered 1 caraffe of sangria, which was tasty! The menu had lots of delicious looking options; we're BIG girls and we were hungry so we went for 8 small plates between the 3 of us. 

-Lamb in rosemary sauce- very flavorful and tender.
-Spanish spinach sausage- tasty, not as spicy as I would have liked. The sauce was great for bread dipping.
-Ham and cheese croquettes- my friends loved these, but I couldn't taste the ham. It was more creamy cheesey- not my cup of tea.
-Shrimp in white wine and garlic sauce- ooooh the garlic. So garlic-y. Is this why I am single? Thoughts? Chunks of delicious, roasted garlic in olive oil. Yum.

We also ordered the cheese plate with manchega and prosciutto like ham, tortilla espanol served cold with roasted peppers, and the pan y tomat. Overall, delicious food. But I must say, we had excellent service. Our waiter was so friendly and fun, constantly saying "Anything for you senoritas!!" What an amazing attitude. He sure made our first experience at Zarzuela extra memorable. I can't wait to go back.
author: Laura D.

description:
Top notch quality and yummmmy! The paella is made to order with fresh ingredients and the rice is cooked perfectly. I love the variety of seafood in the dish...clams, mussels, shimps, prawns, squid, calamari. The grilled lamb chops were sooo tasty. The pork medallions were topped with an amazing cheese sauce. The fried potatoes were cooked with a spicy sauce, but i did not taste any heat. My favorite was the pie of the day, which was made with mango and chorizo. It literally comes apart and melts in your mouth. 

The only thing that might keep from coming back is the street parking, which is nearly impossible. I suggest finding a parking lot...save the time and effort of circling around. And due to its popularity, saturday night was packed! So, don't come here unless you are ready for a long wait.
author: Wendy L.

description: Old school tapas. The waiters are all old, spanish and ancient. They are super cute and help to add to that authentic spanish atmosphere. Loved all the tapas we had here...all are of the traditional persuasion - patatas bravas, padron peppers, serrano ham, tortilla, calamari....
author: Jennifer C.

description: My favorite place for dinner.    The neighborhood is pure SF, the prices are very affordable, Andy and Arturo are the BEST, and of course the food is GREAT.
author: Jon L.

description: This place is awesome, been here a few times and have always enjoyed everything I ordered. The sangria is delish, and there aren't too many places that can make good sangria. Kind of a funky atmosphere, but the staff is great! Can't wait to go back!
author: Alison W.

description: I didn't think the food was that special compared to most tapas places I've been.  We also ordered the ham, and it was very expensive.
author: Elena L.

description:
This is a family run place that specializes in making wonderful creations from simple ingredients.  I especially love the roasted chilies they do so well.  The owner , who used to be a bartender, is kind and he talks about how much he loves his daughters.  aw..

Ask to go back into the kitchen!
author: Susan K.

description:
no flashy ambiance (and damn do i wish they had a bar or big common table) but honest tapas at a very reasonable price (we ate like pigs for $50). once you find parking ("ONE MORE LAP AND WE'RE GOING SOMEWHERE ELSE"), you'll be ready for a drink.  Not a lover of sangria and not impressed with the list, we opted for the $15 corkage.

to recommend....:
- tortilla espanola- 4 wedges for $4.  seems like a good judge of a tapas joint, kinda like a corned beef sandwich at a deli. it was  decently seasoned (i mean, i'm always going to salt cold potato)
