- pisto manchego-thought it was odd that it was cold (and no, there is no cheese in here) but it was delicious, esp with the frittata :)
- sauteed mushrooms - so so but the tasty filling (definitely some chorizo in there) saved it.  the mushroom special looked better.
- 1/2 order of the chicken-insane value, tasty "gravy" (that sounds spanish, doesn't it?)
- chorizo - they may not look like much, kinda dessicated even in their cute little iron cast skillet but oh, they were juicy and bursty with salty goodness

waiter was fantastic - salud'ing with us as we offered him wine, etc.

haven't been here for years, had pretty low expectations, and it surpassed 'em.  i just hold out for star 4 and 5.

and what better way to top off dinner than with a pint of swenson's across the street (i'm not a flan sort of gal)
author: Laurie A.

description:
Oh well, another 5 star rating for one of the restaurants in my immediate neighborhood. Why?
First of all they're the most authentic Spanish place I've found in the U.S. so far. For American tastes, their service might not be as friendly as people might expect but I've found it exactly the way I like it.
And the food!!! I've been here many times, tried most Tapas on their menu and have yet to find one that I don't like. Personally, I stay away from everything that is not on their Tapas list but that's just me. Only negative here is that they don't take reservations and it can get very very crowded on weekends.
author: Heiko L.

description:
A farewell dinner for friends, being slightly indecisive and not wanting to interrupt the erudite conversation, we instructed the kitchen to simply provide a steady flow until all were sated. Silly me that I didn't take notes so I'm sure that I'm missing something...

Besides fresh bread with oil for dipping and marinated olives, I recall starting with Salpicon de Marisco which showcased fresh seafood including miniature shrimp, octopus, and calamari. Gambas al Ajillo served in a small cast-iron skillet were perfectly sauteed and piping hot. Bill did specify a desire to taste their Fideos con Almejas y Mejillones but also included shrimp. A serving of Pulpo a la Gallega was the only minor disappointment; while the octopus was perfect and not at all rubbery, the starchiness of the pototo seemed to conflict instead of complement the seafood.

With so much seafood, we finished up with a trio of vegetable dishes including Repollo con Pasas y Pinones, Champinones al Ajillo, and Pimientos Asados. All this was washed down with decanters of sangria.

Instead of opting for whatever was on Zarzuela's dessert menu, Turkish coffee ice cream from the Swensen's (the very first one!) across the street finished up a lovely evening.
author: Carolyn T.

description:
Like anything in the neighborhood, dim lights, intimate/romantic setting.. and tables a bit too close to each other

Food was alright


Yes
- garlic shrimp (though the shrimp is so teeny)
- lamb chops (x3) entree with potatoes
- stuffed mushrooms

Ok
- sangria

No
- fried calamari

Lookin good
- paella
- goat cheese
- poached octopus http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/MaQ2_SBnZN7DjiqtMOUUsg?select=n-AZQPQi0qQMY_-OqIm6Hg


Yeah service is spotty slow
author: xo x.

description:
Ferren and I ordered the Tostadas De Caracoles (snails) with parsley aioli, Croquetas De Jamon Y Pollo, and the Boucherones (white anchovies). We ordered a carafe of Sangria, which I thought was delicious. It was fruity and refreshing without being too sweet. I didn't mind that it seemed not to have very much alcohol, it still tasted great.

Our waiter was very nice. He seemed to have worked there for a long time. In fact, I would return there just to chat with him and have another glass of Sangria!

First off, I made the mistake of trying to order a side of aioli...I'm pretty sure I irked the owner, since he told me I didn't need it and they didn't have any in house. I wanted to eat the aioli with the bread and the anchovies...the tiny pickled fish seemed excessively vinegary...they almost took the roof of my mouth off...I love the way they serve them at Caesar's (in Berkeley)...with a dab of aioli, toasted bread and fish roe....but we were not at Caesar's and there was no aioli for me. 

The Croquetas were creamy and rich although I thought the flavors fell flat. They were cooked correctly with just a thin coating of bread crumbs and fried to a light, golden brown.

I did enjoy the Caracoles, except I felt the bread was toasted too dry (bitter) and the crumbs wanted to catch in my throat. I would have loved to have had more aioli (I think the owner assumed what I really wanted a side of "best food mayo") baked on top to better balance the earthiness of the snails. We ended up drizzling a little of the peppery olive oil over each toast. The "tostadas" were nestled around a mound of braised red cabbage that was slightly piquant and just melted in your mouth. Both Ferren and I agreed that it was delicious and probably our favorite ingredient out of all the dishes...it was too bad that  the bus boy cleared our plate before we could finish the last few tasty bites of cabbage...

Last, the Arroz con Leche...everything you want in a rice pudding...creamy and rich with a slight sprinkling of cinnamon on top...I liked how the dessert was served chilled but the rice still remained tender. 

I will return to try the octopus, tripe and oxtail...will post update.
-EFK
author: Eliza K.

description:
I do not understand the hype surrounding this place.  We went to Zarzuela after reading good reviews in SF gate, yelp and CitySearch. But alas, we were disappointed.  The food here is just not that good, period.  The service is great (everyone is super friendly), the ambiance is cute, the wine menu is pretty good, but the food is severely lacking. But I may also have my expectations severely high as the last time I was in Spain I ate at some phenomenal restaurants (Butafumeiro in Barcelona is just incredible, unbelievable).  But I have been to many Spanish restaurants in the U.S. which are better than Zarzuela for a comparable price.

What we had:
Tortilla Espanola (Potato & Onion Omelet)
Boquerones con Piquillo (Anchovies)
Banderillas de Cordero (Grilled Lamb tenders, Rosemary sauce)
Pulpo a la Gallega (poached Octopus)
Gambas al Ajillo (garlic Shrimp)
Paella Valenciana 
(we had other tapas as well, but cannot remember which ones)

Either things were cold when they shouldn't be, ingredients were not fresh, or the taste was just lacking.  Something was missing.

It is a reasonable restaurant, but the food quality does not deserve the hype in all the review websites.  Perhaps though it is a SF thing as I've heard the other Spanish restaurant in the Marina is also not good from our European friends.  There may just not be a good Spanish restaurant in SF for comparison, so this is as good as it gets.
author: susie w.

description:
This place lives up to the hype.  Very casual place but still nice ambiance.  It is quaint and you feel like you could be in Spain, if not for the cable car that rolls by. . . but who doesn't like to see that!

The waiter on Tuesday night was extremely friendly and helpful with the menu.  The scallops and lamb small plates were good.  The mushroom small plate (Champinones al Ajillo) is phenomenal.  The sangria may leave a slight hangover so take it easy.

Parking is tough, but maybe catch the cable car. . . be a tourist for a day.
author: E L.

description: The tapas dishes we ordered were a little hit and miss. I did enjoy my meal, but a few dishes stood out while a few fell a little short. The tripe, quail, and sauteed mushrooms were by far the best. Octopus, goat cheese, and the creamy lobster soup were good but I've had better. The pork skewer literally tasted like chicken. Paella was decent and flavorful. For dessert we ordered creme brulee (with a touch of ginger) and espresso mousse cake - both did not disappoint.
author: CS L.

description:
Again another fabulous dinner at Zarzuela's.  Paella was outstanding.  Tapas were very good especially the Ham and Cheese fried croquettes and the tortilla espanola.   For a true spanish tapas try the bread with fresh tomato spread with serrano ham.  Ham was not salty compared to t prociutto di parma.  
I would skip dessert and head across the street to Swensen's ice cream shop.
Not a sangria fan, but most everyone likes it.  Can't wait to go back.
author: Danielle E.

description: This place is incredibly popular and I can see why:  very friendly staff, decent food, decent wine.  It is not great Spanish but they do have a good selection of dishes.  I always have small plates.  They don't have bacalao, which is inexplicable.  They have a few times done some very tasty tiny flash-fried fish and I like their take on octopus.  I tend to lean toward the seafood because I like a nice inexpensive Spanish white.  I wish they would lay off the oil, but that may be asking too much, right?  I'll go back for sure.
author: Laura H.

description: Nice tapas place with authentic Spanish cuisine.  I recommend the goat cheese plate.  Not too fancy but not too informal.  They don't take reservations, though, so expect a 30+ minute wait on the weekends.
author: Jason T.

description: First of all location is gorgeous with crooked street right around the corner.  We came right at 6pm on a sat evening and there was no wait.  You get a basket or bread to dip in olive oil and side dish of olives..what a perfect combo!  Ordered goat cheese with tomato sauce, mussels, fried eggplant , and sausage dish.  All of which were delicious!  The sausage however, was just okay.  Sangria was perfect!  Service is just right.
author: Elle M.

description:
Came here for a bday dinner with a couple girlfriends.  Sangria was pretty good as noted by others...smooth going down. We didn't order any main entrees so I can't speak about those, but the tapas were delicious.  We ordered the garlic shrimp, potatoes bravas, croquettes, lamb skewers, and the special mixed mushroom dish of the night. With the exception of the lamb, just two skewers, everything was scrumptious and well worth it. The service was excellent, wait was ok for a Saturday evening, but the parking was awful. 

Definitely a place to relax with friends, but can be a bit loud. I didn't leave stuffed, but comfortably full with the help of the bread basket. I'd head to Swenson's for some ice cream for dessert afterwards.
author: Jessica K.

description:
Always charming, always delicious. I realize everyone knows about Zarzuela by now, but when I am there, I still feel I have a discovered a little hideaway for dinner.
This place has old world charm and tapas you will remember the next day. Ofcourse, there is also the allure of Hyde St....
author: polina S.

description:
Cozy Dine.  Great place to bring someone on a first date.  

Parking sucks... but the food is delicious!!!
author: Porsia B.

description:
Having just spent a couple weeks in Barcelona, it was nice to hear that there was a good Tapas place locally. We ordered a considerable selection of tapas, including the Serrano Jamon with Pan con tomate (fabulous-definitely recommend) and the garlic shrimp (not quite the "gambas" that you get in Spain...). The service was attentive, and the atmosphere cozy and comfortable. This place is suprisingly authentic and the food clearly had influences from many regions of Spain, including Catalonia...

We did arrive early (6pm)and were able to get a table for four, but the place filled up quickly, so plan accordingly! We will definitely eat here again!
author: Shira R.

description:
We went there on a Friday night.  Bf was told no reservation was needed and the wait was around 20-30 minutes.  It actually took 45 minutes for us to get seated.  It's a small place, crowded and noisy.  We later found out there was a small salon room further inside and it wasn't as noisy as the main dining room.

But the wait was worthy!  The service was good and the food was great!  We ordered a salad with blue cheese, stuffed mushroom with garlic and ham and of course sangria and paella.  Its bread with olive oil and different olives were so good and we almost couldn't stop (or maybe we were just so hungry after waiting till 8pm).  The mushroom was very good but the paella was better.  I asked our chef de rang any tricks about making paella because I always failed.  He was so nice to explain the whole thing to me.

Spanish food doesn't seem to be popular and food one is even rare.  But Zarzuela is a very nice neighborhood restaurant with great good at unbeatable price.  You can't compare it with a Michelin star restaurant but it deserves 5 stars here @ Yelp.  Will definitely go back!
author: Ile F.

description:
Delicious. Wonderful. An awesome experience. We came here for an early birthday dinner before the fireworks and were not disappointed. 

First, we ordered the paella for two people, since it would take a while. After, we about 8 tapas dishes, shared amongst our group of six people. The food was delicious, the service was great, and everything went well with our pitcher of san gria. Fast and friendly. Of course, we did get there early, around 6PM. 

I will definitely be back soon!
author: R H.

description: This might be my fav tapas place in SF... been going here for years.  Its a cute little place with tables for two as well as room enough for a bigger group.  Food is excellent.  Great wine selection and sangria.  The only negatives are that they don't take reservations, it can get loud and parking it a bit of a bitch.  Recommend the lamb, goat cheese, chorizo and patatas bravas!
author: Sherrie P.

description:
Having lived in Seville, Spain for 6 months I was so excited to see if this was authentic Spanish food, and it really lived up to it! I was totally taken back to my time there and the service was excellent! The waiters were so nice and friendly, and everything was QUICK. 

We had...Tortilla Espanola--my favorite spanish dish, ever, and they do it really well! (Egg/Potato kind of thing, so delish) 

The Goat cheese with tomato sauce--also great 

Chorizo en Vino--yum! 

and the Papatas bravas--these are like steak-sized french fries in a spicy tomato sauce--they were very authentic and delicious. 

I am absolutely going back...hopefully next week :)
author: Claire J.

description:
This is my second time at Zarzuela. I first went there last Spring, when a friend was visiting from abroad and a classmate of mine was so nice to bring us to this amazing tapas place. She knew the menu very well, and ordered amazing stuff for the all of us.

I've had the place in my mind for a while, and finally had the chance to go back two weeks ago with my friend. Despite being quite early, we were told we needed to wait 45 mins. No worries! We found a very cute and cozy small wine bar just a few meters away, called Bacchus wine bar, which I really recommend if you have to wait for a table.

Once inside Zarzuela, we both jumped on their Paella Valenciana. Since that was another half an hour wait, we ordered Chorizo al Vino and Patatas Bravas to start with. Both were really tasty and yummy! The Chorizo al Vino is really good, since the sausage they use is clearly a much better quality  than regular grocery store sausages you find around. 

When our Paella arrived, we could not believe we were going to finish the whole serving! It was great, full of mariscos and chicken meat. The rice was perfectly cooked and stayed really good the whole time we needed to clear our portions up. Of course we made it in the end! In fact their Sangria, full of tasty and fresh fruit, helped us finishing everything. 

The atmosphere was very informal and casual. Try to grab a table close to the long mirror they have on the wall: you'll have fun looking a what's going on in the room while eating!
author: france d.

description:
I walk into this place and it smells of authentic Spanish food.  You can almost taste the saffron by breathing in the air.  

The slightly sweet sangria has only fruit in the glass, so no slowing down the process, best of all no headache.

Don't expect your standard tapas here, this is Spanish and Spanish-Basque food served traditional just like my Great-Grandma makes.

If you don't like trying things outside of your food comfort zone, this is not a place where you want to eat.  If you like food like stuffed inkfish and lamb shanks...this is the place for you.
author: Nate B.

description:
This place is fantastic!!! We called earlier in the day to make reservations to find out they do not accept them. We got there around 8:30 after circling the block for parking and put our name on the list. We were pleasantly surprised to find out we could get our Sangria and drink it outside while we were waiting for our table. The Sangria is amazing too, very fruitful but not watered down, quite refreshing. We all ordered a couple different things and shared them all. My favorite was the ham and chicken croquettes, yumm!! Stuffed mushrooms, mussels, seafood and vermicelli, you can't go wrong with anything you order!!!

Definitely plan on going back sometime soon.
author: Kelly C.

description:
when my friend wanted to try out spanish cuisine, Zarzuela was our first choice being among the Bay Area top 100 restaurants. Though they did not take reservations for our team of 3, we could manage to get seats after a 20 minute wait on a saturday evening. Not bad i would say. But finding parking in the neighbourhood was a challenge!

The service was great.The items were explained before they were taken down to make sure we knew what we were ordering. One my neighboring tables occupied by a spanish family were celebrating their birthday and one of  the waiters sang a spanish birthday song which I thought was a great gesture.Service commands 4 stars. 

I was eating spanish tapas for the first time, but would say really enjoyed it. The grilled mushroom, roasted peppers,spanish pie of the day were all great. For desserts we ordered the chocolate souffle, flan and marzipan sponge cake. The sponge cake was the best among them. Overall the food was good and we were satisfied. Being from India, the heavy spices and flavors were missing, but we enjoyed it. Food commands 4 stars as  well.

The ambiance gives a rustic feel to it. The decor with spanish bowls, paintings etc gives homely feel. The noise levels are kind of high but not annoying. The prices were reasonable and not like an overpriced top 100 restaurant. I give a 4 stars for ambiance 

Overall a 4 - value for money
author: Sankar B.

description:
Over all i liked it though
 I've had better. Sangria was heLLa goOd!  parking is a B!tC%. Paella was so so.
author: T K.

description:
must haves: sangria, grilled eggplant stuffed with goat cheese, empanada, fillet and leg of duck

skip: potato wedges (basically home fries with spicy sauce--pretty lame in flavor and texture compared to the other dishes)

the restaurant opens at 530p and doesnt take reservations, so our party of 11 cabbed out there at about 515p and found that there were already parties seated. Luckily, we were easily accommodated for by pulling a few tables together.

sangrias came out first, which was delicious on a warm evening. the eggplant was AMAZING. I dont eat eggplants, so i was skeptical when my friends placed the order. It was a thinly sliced eggplant wrapping around a chunk of goat cheese that just melted in your mouth. The fillet was soft and delicious. We wiped the plate clean with bread. Empanadas were delicious, nothing like i've had before. The meat on the leg of duck fell off the bone and melted in my mouth. MMM...

Very delightful experience with close friends. the place got busy not long after we were seated. Go early to avoid the wait and get the eggplant goat cheese!
author: Rena Y.

description: I absolutely adore this place. The menu is full of tasty tapas, but I daydream of two plates in particular: the grilled squid with drizzled aioli and the baked snails placed on buttered toasted bread. This corner spot is quite small and doesn't take reservations, so if you snag a table without waiting, you're golden. It gets a bit loud inside, but you'll be busy scarfing all your food and downing your sangria, so it shouldn't bother you too much.
author: Cheri R.

description:
I'm in love with this place.
A fabulous tapas joint with a lot of 'panache'! The first impression was the cozy dining hall behind the big bay windows, with every inch packed. Parking was an issue, but we decided to park a little far and take a cab. There are no reservations taken for two, and when we reached, there was a wait in a tiny room where we entertained ourselves with ?sangrias?. The sangrias were not the best in town, but what followed was really fantastic. Breads and sauteed olives were provided as a welcome gesture, as we coursed our way through the interesting yet varied menu. We decided to go for the hot/cold tapas plates followed by small entrees. My favorites were eggplant wrapped around goat cheese (yummy) and the juicy chicken stripes dipped in cheese and breadcrumbs. Other tapas we tasted were calamaries, sauteed shrimps in garlic and olive. For entrees, grilled sea bass and chicken sauteed in sherry followed. In all, it was an awesome experience with great food; romantic ambience and a relaxed destination, which took us to a little dreamy, cozy villa in a make-believe Spanish countryside!!!
The staff/owner informed us about the chef's expertise, who is originally from a town near Madrid and the food prepared was therefore very authentic and original to the Spanish platter. A great experience and will definitely go back again for the tasty small dishes!!!
author: Lisa H.

description:
My friend and I both studied abroad in Spain, so anything remind us of that wonderful time in our lives we are all about. And I am all about Zarzuela. The ambiance and decor makes me feel like I am back in Spain. 

The food is never disappointing. Don't kid yourself with getting one glass of Sangria. Go for the gusto and get the carafe. It is so delicious and will leave you wanting more. 

Everything on the menu is out of this world. The empanadas change daily, and always a tasty treat. Last week we tried the Sausages and they were delicious. You can never go wrong with the Goat Cheese and Tomato sauce accompanied by some fresh bread. It is so good you will want to lick the plate. 

The staff is always a delight. Never once have I had a bad meal or service here. They don't take reservations, but there is a little sitting room where you can enjoy a glass of sangria while you wait, and if there is a wait it is totally worth it. This restaurant is a little gem.
author: Cortney H.

description: We were prepared for the wait, and it was well worth it. We were really hungry and ate our way around the menu finding everything delicious. When I return, I will once again dive into the rich oxtail dish on the menu. Hats off to the chef and the wonderful waitstaff: style and warmth abound here. Wonderful area, great atmosphere, fabulous fare.
author: Laura F.

description:
I have been here twice, usually on an off night like Tuesday or Thursday.  The servers are great and know how to recommend things to you.  Each time we have gone with 3 people and ended up ordering around 8-9 tapas, each better than the last.  The goat cheese (baked or cold) was delicious.  We have mussels, quail, duck, salad, ham platter, again Really Good.
Check it out on a slower night, and always order at least one of the specials, last night was stuffed peppers...YUMMY
author: Lauren F.

description: This place was so good! 4 of us ordred a lot of tapas... we loved the green peppers and dates. Everything was great! Great Price!!
author: Jaime K.

description:
Great Tapas!  Great Sangria! Great Atmosphere! Great Neighborhood!

The Spanish fare is authentic and the prices are a great match!

Enjoy
author: matt g.

description:
This past Tuesday, my husband, my sister-in-law, stumbled upon Zarzuela and had a great laid-back meal with excellent service. Having spent a bit of time in Spain, it was nice to find lots of the tasty things I remembered (and craved) - and didn't even know I was craving until I arrived.

We got there about 8:15 PM on a Tuesday, so there was no wait - and in fact, plenty of tables available.

And I was really impressed with the pace and involvement of the waiter - he didn't clear the table until we were all finished, made thoughtful recommendations, and was personable without being grating. Maybe not everyone's ideal - but I sure wish there were more waitstaff just like him.
author: Sarah G.

description: Great spot, probably my most frequent restaurant visited for the past 6 years. Why? Quality, price and ambiance. Staff is great, owner is always there with a smile to greet you. He also never forgets a face. Order something off menu? if they can accommodate they will.  How about a different bottle of wine? Let me see what we have. Food is great. Perfect order for two as follows. Split the cabrales salad, followed by duck, goat cheese with tomato sauce, poached squid(must order), mushrooms, crab cake. If there's 3 or 4 people order a paella for 2 on top of that. Enjoy!
author: Tom W.

description:
An okay spot for tapas, but not my favorite.  Pros are the affordable carafes of cold, refreshing sangria ("How do you spell regret? S-A-N-G-R-I-A!") and delicious, savory olives accompanied by warm bread, as well as an attentive, friendly waitstaff and cheerful, relaxed environment. The serving of Manchego cheese was quite generous and accompanied by refreshing, crispy, pears.  

However, the Spanish omelette, potatoes in spicy sauce, and crabcakes were nothing particularly memorable or exciting.  These three dishes leaned toward being too bland.  The crabcakes had wayyyy too high of a breadcrumb-to-crabmeat ratio.  Calling them "crabcakes" is misleading, they should be called "breadcrumb cakes."
author: Bear S.

description: Zarzuela was an enjoyable experience, great food and even better service. A+
author: Grant F.

description: Overall, the food here was delicious.  The only reason I'm docking one star is because some of the seafood was overcooked.  Now I understand why it was overcooked...and that is because we were a large party.  Other than that, the sangria was delightful.  The lamb lollipop was lip smacking good.  The escargot was nicely paired with a pesto sauce on a piece of bread.  Goat cheese galore...yum.  I recommend this place to anyone who enjoys good food.
author: Christina S.

description:
DELICIOUS Spanish tapas and excellent service. Plates are delivered to your table with perfect timing. I go here on nights when I am looking for something relaxing and comforting. This is also a great date night location! I suggest the asparagus, potatoes with spicy sauce, and lamb. Omg... mouth watering just writing about it ....

It seems as if other Yelpers have experienced long waits for a table at Zarzuela, however, I have always been seated promptly.
author: Kaitlyn G.

description: Delicious meal and very good service.  We loved the sauteed prawns, the sangria was tasty and the snails were a huge hit.  I will definitely come back here again.. consider taking a cab though as parking is really sparse.
author: Joshua H.

description: Made it out here for tapas recently.  Parking is tight in the neighborhood, so take a bus!  It's  a fun place.  We had the spanish tortilla, mushrooms, the ham, and sangria.  The ham was the star of the show.  I'll be back.
author: She-Ra ..

description:
What a great meal!  Got fish of the day, NY Steak, sauteed mushroom (daily special), crab bisque & calamari with a fine glass of wine.  Heaven...  Btw, EXCELLET service!

My 1.5 cents
author: Mike H.

description:
WTF is wrong with people?

If you throw a stone in the mission, it will hit a tapas bar a zillion times better than this.

Tortilla Espanola  served cold as ice..

Sangria served on ice and tastes like Cranberry juice


How the heck can people like this place? Go to Esperpento or even Picaros - way better food, way better sangria!
author: some g.

description:
Disappointing. We sat at our table for 25 minutes before our waiter came to take our order...Out of tortilla espanola at 8:30 on a Saturday night? Come on. We ordered the "greatest hits" of spanish tapas - anchovies (too vinegary), patatas bravas (boring), cheese plate (no explanation of which cheeses were which, thanks), pulpo was gross and completely overcooked. None of the food was better than mediocre. Sangria was okay; Cha Cha Cha's is better. Skipped dessert.

Like many of the other reviewers, I too studied abroad in Madrid, so I have some basis for comparison. This food is just not worth raving about.
author: Cate C.

description: Went there on a Saturday night and got seated right away. Our waiter was extremely helpful and friendly. The food was reasonably priced and it was fun to try so many different things.  We really enjoyed the shrimp, tortillas espanola, and the beef short ribs. And as an added bonus, Swensens is across the street!
author: Emily M.

description:
*update 4/30/2007*
Another dinner at Zarzuela, another hit and miss experience.  We went with a large party (hey, what better way to try lots of tapas?) and put our name on the list at 7pm.  We were told an hour wait, no biggie since we were celebrating a birthday at a friend's house a few doors away on Hyde Street.  So 8pm, nothing...8:30pm, still nothing...9pm, WTF?  Finally at 9:15pm they are ready to seat us, but wait!  Our table for 16 only has 12 seats.  4 of us have to stand while the four top next to our big table finishes paying their bill.  9:30pm, two and a half hours after we were told it would be an hour, we are finally all seated.  Food was good but we constantly had to grab our waiter for water and more sangria.  
I doubt I'll be returning anytime soon, even though the food was still good and quite reasonable (we got out of there for $30 a person and that included many carafes of sangria)

*original review 8/27/2006*
Zarzuela deserves at least four stars for food quality and prices but based on the service we had last night I can't give them more than three. Service was friendly enough but really slow...not slow in a cool "Hey, we're eating tapas and drinking wine, screw it!" type of way but slow as in "Where the hell is our waiter?"  The manager noticed us looking for our waiter and asked if we were ready to order-when we said yes it still took the waiter at least 5 minutes to make his way over to us.
That being said, the food was really good and cheap!  I'll go back but make sure that I'm not starving first.
author: phil h.

description:
mm...tasty tasty tapas...worth the long wait?...yes..definitely worth the wait...parking is horrible..no reservations and no valet...i would recommend a taxi to go here....$19 carafe of sangria was mild,sweet and tasty...so far...the best tapas i've had..

the food was fantastic...the tripe...so soft..so flavorful...and must order...meatballs with cubed fried potato...small portion..but slight bacon saltiness taste...and great.....the garlic shrimp...such a simple dish...yet...toasty garlic flavors with shrimp....excellent.....cooked peppers....some mild...some hot...you never know what you are going to get...becareful...but again..it was another great little tapa dish....pepper steak...it's hong kong style pan grilled steak....probably my least favorite item....fried chicken strips....fried hairstrands of potato...with chicken strips and a white sauce breaded and deep fried...chicken breasts are usually dry...but with the sauce inside...it kept the meat moist and juicy..ah..the fried ham within a potato like paste and again breaded and deep fried...nice little treat.....i almost feel like i need a sauce to dip it in..but tasty on it's own...so many dishes...hen was full and satisfied...
author: Hen A.

description: I have to say, I was a little disappointed in this place. I had heard such good things. I really wanted to like it, since I live in the 'hood and generally love tapas. But it was just 'eh. Nothing was spectacular. It was very run-of-the-mill tapas, I've definitely had better. No major complaints but I just wasn't impressed. Maybe I should have had more sangria... !
author: Priya N.

description:
bottom line: EAT HERE!!!!!!!!
one dish says it all: goat cheese in tomato sauce.

other favorites: gambas de ajillo, chorizo en wine sauce

drink you cannot go without during this meal: sangria

who to bring: someone who likes to eat well and likes bread. someone who likes Ice cream across the street at Swensen's after dinner

service:even when busy, the manager will serve the waiting patrons outside making sure they are taken care of.very good service. you can wear jeans and a t -shirt, doesn't matter, you'll still get good service. 

suggested attire: a sweater or jacket since you might have to wait at least thirty minutes on a busy night. but well worth the wait.
suggested transportation-cab or cable car or walk-but I'd drive all the way from oakland to eat here as well-if I'd lived in Oakland that is...
author: J A.

description:
By chance I ended up at Zarzuela for dinner before my first YES event earlier this year. My friend Joy had been _raving_ about it and I was hoping it would live up to all the hype ... which it did in droves. Our server was super friendly and quite good at his trade to keep up with our hungry party of 6. We had some sangria which was OK as far as sangria goes. We also had the grilled lamb tenders in a rosemary sauce, goat cheese in a tomato sauce, & paella all of which were fantastic.

Sadly, I've only made it back here one other time since then. I ordered some of the same things, but luckily read some yelp reviews before coming and knew to try the ham & chicken croquettes which are inexplicably scrumptious. I also had the gazpacho which was a nice starter. I took one of my mom's friends and her boyfriend (both visiting from out of state) and they were pretty much blown away. Both by the food and by the hilarity that ensued when a man eating alone at the table behind us got up to leave and plunked down his half-drunk carafe of sangria on our table, explaining that he only wanted a half-carafe but they didn't do half carafe's so we should enjoy the remainder rather than letting it go to waste. The one sangria drinker at our table wasn't planning on drinking more than his one glass until our waiter swooped in and refilled his glass from the carafe, citing he saw an empty glass an a half-full carafe which seemed like an obvious solution to him. Finally, for desert you should try the creme brule & the marzipan cake, both of which are very sweet and satisfying.
author: Todd F.

description: I reluctantly came back to the states after living in Spain for more than two amazing years. When I arrived, I was a little downtrodden, so some SF-based friends brought me to Zarzuela for a "even though you're not glad to be back, we're glad you're back" dinner. That was five years ago. To this day, Zarzuela is the one place I can go to feel like I'm back in Spain... if only for a meal. From the happy Castellano-peppered conversation to the simple decor to the pimientos del piquillo, it's just about as authentic as you can get. Some of my favorites: chorizo a la sidra, gambas a la plancha, berenjenas con queso de cabra (eggplant). The prices are extremely reasonable for SF; the wine is also quite nice and affordable. And the staff... always accomodating. Get there early, because it fills up quickly, and no reservations. Who cares. I'll wait!
author: Michelle W.

description: I gotta give Zarzuela five stars, seriously, this is most likely the best sangria that I've ever had!  That alone should warrant a couple stars, but the fact that the food is inexpensive (relatively) and really good just bumps is up that extra notch to a five star extravaganza!  The service has always been prompt, except when they keep stealing your fork away everytime you receive a new plate.  I particularly like the baked goat cheese and the crab bisque, but everything else I've had here has been really great!
author: Craig E.

description: Why does this place have 4 stars?? The sangria sucks!! Go to Picaro in the Mission if you want tasty sangria. The mussels were HORRIBLE. They tasted like sour fish so obviously they were poor quality. The jamon serrano and goat cheese were pretty good though. Eggplant was whatever. Maybe we just ordered the wrong dishes but overall I was not impressed. I won't be dining here again.
author: Fran M.

description: Love this place and so far the best tapas place I've found. Prefer to go with the tapas as opposed to their mains just because I prefer the variety and think paella is better cooked at home where you can customize it to what everyone loves. The octopus is fantastic, the peppers are a must along with the ox tails. I'm just ok on the quail and their empanadas but might be nitpicking. If you want to try sherries they have a wide selection and I've gone down that route with them. The sangria however is where I've decided to stay after several visits. The peaking garage across the street is no longer there! Major pain!
author: norman g.

description: Andy, the proprietor took the decision to be me waiter tonight. Had the garlic shrimp and the crabcake. When I MMS'd a picture of the crabcakes to "she who knows such things", she replied that they looked burnt. Burnt or not, they were delish. The wine was very good. One bottle was finished about halfway through, so the chap filled ANOTHER glass (a decided bonus). The bill? $32 with tip, I spent nearly that much on cheese for tomorrow night at Safeway. One star off for the promised sherry vinegar which somehow evaporated into thin air.
author: Hasan D.

description: The wait was somewhat long and maybe that was due to us hitting dinner hours. Anyway we waited for at least half an hour but other then that the entire service/ambiance was first rate. Our server was excellent. He made suggestion as well as filling my glass of wine for free on my next order because he made a mistake on my meal (me happy). The tapas were delicious and there were plenty to choose from. The portion were just right and by ordering 4 different types of dishes we were beyond stuff.  I'm definitely coming back!!!
author: Kathy T.

description:
*v* LOVE THIS RESTAURANT
although we've waited almost 1.5 hour in the cold, I think it still deserves a 5/4.5 stars
The food taste DELICIOUS!!!
okay, I forgot the names of the dishes...but I ll try my best to describe them
we ordered lamb chop, short rib, spanish seafood fried rice, crab bisque, Serrano Ham, grilled eggplant filled with goat cheese, mussels in white wine and of course the $20/bottle wine that they serve to you without asking you.
First of all, I am a big seafood fan, so undoubtedly. my favorite dishes are the seafood fried rice, mussels and the crab bisque*v*, they are taste delicious, especially the fried rice, they put saffron in the fried rice so it looks yellow and the seafood taste was emphasized. um...yumyumyum, the crab bisque was not very impressive, but still taste good:) 
The other dishes are great too, considering that I don't usually eat eggplant, I still tried it, I don't really like cold dishes, so the eggplant with goat cheese was not my favorite dish, but I think they match very well.
Serrano Ham was great *v*, taste good with tomato sauced bread!
lamb chop and short rib are fine, small portion though, but they are very tender and flavored. 
Finally, the wine, I was not mad, because we were gonna drink it anyway, Yet, I still feel that they should ask before pouring it to our glasses.(considering that I am still underage, they are violating the law..HAHA)

The service was great, a kind old man served our table and did not say a word even my friends talked super loud and was speaking whatever language to him. He even taught us some spanish, haha:)
the price surprised me a little, because it was $30/per person and I didn't even eat that much, but I realized that it was because we ordered 2 bottles of wine:p
author: Christy Y.

description: I am not a huge fan of Spanish food, but it was good as far as I was concerned. We got a pitcher of sangria which was pretty good but could have had more fruit pieces in it. We also got a couple tapas which were very good. Then we had the classic paella as our main course - it was pretty good, and I think for someone that loves Spanish food, it would have been impressive. The restaurant filled up quickly and had a crowd waiting outside, so it must have a good reputation.
author: Lina L.

description:
Sangria is watered down, but it was still good. Our waiter was friendly- we asked for some hot sauce and the restaurant doesn't have any, so he gave us some of his home-grown peppers. If you like peppers, you've gotta try his. They are so fiery, my tongue went numb with just a lick. 
We had the clams, pork, potatoes, and mushroom tapas.... all very delish, but it wasn't like OH WOW!
For the price, it was reasonable and very good! would defin go again.
author: Nancy Y.

description: I have no idea what it was about this place, but it was the BEST tapas I've ever had in my entire life!!!  Even the potatoes were good and I don't like Potatoes!  I am highly suspicious that it might have had something to do with their very potent and delicious Sangria... in any case, the stuffed mushrooms were to die for, and I wanted to try everything that everyone else had on other tables too!!
author: Sloane R.

description: Would I come back?  Definitely.  Can't wait.  Wide selection of Spanish tapas, standouts being the chorizo, shrimp with garlic, stuffed mushrooms, and poached octopus.  Desserts (chocolate cake and almond marzipan cake) were only decent.  Reasonable prices and and unpretentious service/decor.  Come with friends and let the sangria flow.
author: Leon R.

description: Delicious. The quail, short ribs, veggies, paella... everything is really good. The Syrah Catalunya is also a pretty good pairing with the tapas and paella if you like red wine with your meal. Thanks Zarzuela!
author: Brian B.

description: Well, it was alright, I s'pose.  The cold pimientos asados were pretty good,  but the prawns sauteed in garlic I'm sure were frozen. [Frozen seafood in SF?  Shurely shome mishtake]  The bread pudding was very much to my taste, but warm on one side and still cold on the other.  This was early-ish last Thursday evening, and on a good note, there were only two of us and the maitre d' sat us at a four table without a moment's thought - earns many brownie points in my book.  Atmosphere was good, clearly many other satisfied customers.  Really I'd give it two and half stars - I don't want to sound like a twat but you've got to go Barcelona for decent tapas (ok, that did sound twattish) so I've not really experienced better in the US or in the UK, but it wasn't A-OK 3 stars either.
author: Nick J.

description: Another happy customer.  I had the anchovies in vinegar, a special tapa of roasted piquillo peppers with shrimp, the chorizo, the tortilla, and some rice pudding.  My favorite was the shrimp tapa and the torilla.  Excellent.  I really liked the sangria and the sherry too.  Everything was really quick and friendly.  The restaurant was mostly empty at 6pm when I came in (on a Saturday) and completely full when I left at 7pm.  So I recommend going just slightly early... maybe that's why I got each order in about 5-8 min.  I got to recommend it and I want to come back and try a bunch of other stuff.
author: Andy P.

description: oh my. I just loved this place. Can't make a reservation so have to show up before the rush. It is very authentic, busy, bustling atomosphere, lovely staff and...the paella is COMPLETELY scrummy. I think about it often.
author: Carrie A.

description: Simple basic dishes and didn't really stand out in the creativity aspect. The croquettes (we had both the chicken and ham), Crab cakes, poached octopus and classic tortilla were our favorites.
author: Rita L.

description: Closest to grandma's cooking I've been able to find! Zarzuela snuffs out all other restaurants in the area - have been eating there for the last 7 years. Understated elegance and rich flavors. Tapas are cooked perfectly with many options for vegetarians and those allergic to seafood. Paella like Abuelita's! If you order paella or an entree, pace yourself with the tapas. Desserts are verrry homestyle so venture past the flan! Sangria is a must, but thoughtful winelist otherwise. With Russian Hill parking challenges, walking, Hyde Cable Car or cabbing is best...if driving, park closer to Polk and walk up, or snag valet from another nearby restaurant. Superb value and extra cozy.
author: Tanya P.

description: Fantastic food and service, worth the wait.
author: Paul S.

description:
I love this place, it almost makes me feel like I'm in Spain (especially when you walk through the back, cave-like room to get to the bathroom).  Never had to wait for a table, but maybe that's just because I usually arrive early by Spanish standards.  Sangria ($4.75/glass) is delicious, as are their wines.  I've never been disappointed by what I ordered.  The server we had last night seemed like he had some trouble multi-tasking, as we had to flag him whenever we wanted anything (like placing our order).  He was very friendly though, and I really can't complain.  I heard him speaking spanish with the couple a few tables over, and that just made the ambiance of the place even better.  The prices here are very reasonable if you stick to the tapas, it only gets expensive when you spring for something like the Paella (which is worth every penny).  Parking is close to impossible in this neighborhood, so definitely take either a cab or the cable car, which runs up Hyde.

Here's what we ordered (all to share of course):
Gambas Ajillo - $6.95: Served steaming in a cast-iron pan, be sure to mop up the garlic/oil with your bread before they take it away!
Tortilla Espanola - $4.95: Four slices served with a tomato/bell pepper mix.  Very light and refreshing.
Chicken/Seafood Paella - $15.95/person: Huge portion, you will be taking some home!  Everything is cooked to perfection, nothing is raw or overdone.

P.S. They do not take American Express (or so they told the table next to us).
author: Lindsay B.

description:
Era cojonudo!  I studied abroad in Madrid for a year and fell in love with the cuisine.  This restaurant was the closest to authentic Spanish food that I've found since being back.  The jamon serrano (basically spanish prosciutto but much better) was thinly sliced and it melted on your tongue, the boquerrones (anchovies) were nicely marinated with just the right bite, and the pulpo de la gallega (octopus) was delicious and not chewy.  
Nice touch to note that when you are seated, they immediately bring you warm, fresh bread and a small plate of olives.  Service was prompt and professional and the prices reasonable.  
Highly recommended though FYI, they do not take reservations.
author: Mike F.

description: My husband and I spent a couple weeks in Spain and ate our way through the country.  We ate tapas for breakfast, lunch, dinner, morning snack, afternoon snack, after-dinner snack.  I think we have a pretty good baseline of what "authentic" tapas should taste like.  Zarzuela is it.  The food is phenomenal and authentic.
author: Karen K.

description:
Woohoo!  As good as it gets!  Yes, 5 stars for Zarzuela.  

Our party of 4, which included a Spaniard, arrived at 7:30pm on a Friday night and were told it was a 45 minute wait, but we were dining by 8:00.  They don't take reservations.  

Although the restaurant was jam packed with a line out the door, the service was attentive and the noise to a "minimum"-- meaning we didn't have to shout at one another to have a conversation.

Parking was tough, but we found a spot within 10 minutes.  Be sure to avoid Lombard Street, or you'll hit all the tourists.  If you're absolutely desperate, you can park at the lot kitty corner from the restaurant.  At $10 an hour, it's a splurge, but maybe it's better than walking up and down several hills in the cold after you've stuffed yourself.  

A must have on the menu is the crab bisque.  We ended up returning to the restaurant the following night to pick up something we left behind and were tempted to stay just for a bowl each.  Highly recommend ordering your own bowl rather than sharing for a starter.  You won't regret it.

Other highlights from the evening: 
oxtail stew - meat so tender it falls off the bones and melts in your mouth; 
patatas bravas - not particularly spicy, but delicious just the same; 
poached octopus -fresh, al dente and paired nicely with new potatoes; 
mussels in red wine sauce - if you don't like shellfish, order it just for the sauce and sop it up with a piece of bread
shrimp with garlic and olive oil - so simple, yet so flavorful

With several other items, a bottle of wine and corkage, we walked away with a $130 tab, not including tip.  A steal, if you ask me.

We will definitely be back, and if not for the parking situation, Zarzuela could easily become our favorite jaunt in the City for Spanish food.
author: Anna V.

description:
Just came back from Zarzuela not too long ago.  I've always drove by this place and initially heard great things about it.  Although I've been coming across some mixed reviews as of late, I thought it's worth a try.  After all, there's no better judge than yourself, especially when it comes to food (and beverage).  

Do note however that it's my first time here and our group only ordered 3 appetizers and 5 dishes (tapas split 3 ways).  Moreover, I have a particular bias/standard towards Spanish cuisine, for the fact that the majority of my initial encounters has occurred in Spain.

First of all, not quite sure as to why the 4-star overall rating (from a total of 435 reviews).  The food is decent.  It's really not bad at all but it's nothing to rave about.  Put it this way, if someone asked (with either enthusiasm or curiosity): "Have you tried Zarzuela?'  My response would simply be:  "Yeah, it's alrite..."  I wouldn't necessarily recommend this place neither as a 'must-try' nor as a destination for someone who is looking for a place to eat some good food in the city.  With the amount of food we ordered + a bottle of red wine, it came out to be appx $45 per person including tax and tips.  I can find a plenty of other places to head to for some Spanish flavor (I'll save the names of my favorites for the purpose of keeping this review as genuine as possible).

Nonetheless, the decor and ambiance are pretty fitting for a casual date or a small get together with friends.  It's neither overwhelmingly fancy nor is it dull and boring.  It definitely allows for a natural and comfortable occasion.  

I wouldn't come here for the food but perhaps to just sit a while after dinner and indulge in great conversation accompanied by wine.
author: Ethan K.

description:
I am a research freak, I admit it. Usually, prior to going out to eat I will try to read about the destination restaurant on Yelp. Before leaving the house to 'roam' a neighborhood, especially one that I am not familiar with, I do my homework and pick out a few restaurants that are well reviewed. It pays off! Nothing makes me more upset than spending my hard earned cash at a crappy restaurant. Nothing, I say!

So...last night, after work and a few beers at the casa I decided to be wild and crazy... I avoided the laptop before we left to explore Hyde street, which is walking distance from our new place. It was a crisp, cool night and before we knew it we were standing on Hyde staring at a handful of restaurants, not knowing where to go. I saw ice cream..I saw sushi....what was I craving? We walked to the corner and saw Zarzuela. I heart  tapas, so we decided to give it a try. 

We were immediately seated, the host was quite charming and our waiter gave us a handful of "popular" recommendations. We decided to start with four dishes and it ended up being plenty for us since we totally gorged on bread, olive oil and olives before we were served. The olive oil served for dipping was very nice; mellow and slightly grassy tasting so I was excited for the dishes to arrive.

First we had the Salpicon de Marisco (Seafood Salad) which was filled with fresh seafood, chopped tomatoes and diced onions...not too tart and very refreshing. Our favorite was the next to arrive: Rollitos de Berenjena (Grilled Eggplant filled with Goat Cheese). I could eat 10 plates of these thinly sliced, pan fried pieces of tender eggplant rolled around goat cheese and served at room temperature. Next we had the Pulpo a la Gallega (Poached Octopus with new potatoes in Olive Oil & Pimenton) and the Champinones al Ajillo (Mushrooms Saute in Garlic sauce). The mushrooms were probably our least favorite dish; they were ok but not too exciting. We really enjoyed the Pulpo a la Gallega. Our waiter told us that this is a very authentic Spanish tapas dish and that it is very hard to get it anywhere in the city. Not sure if that is true, but I am no tapas expert. It was super yummy, but if you don't love octopus, don't order the Pulpo...it is all about the octopus.

For desert my husband ordered a really crazy chocolate cake; I can't remember the name of it but it was insane...full o' chocolate, soaked in something, drenched in something else, surrounded by raspberry sauce swirled with vanilla. My usual "one bite of desert" turned into five. Needless to say, despite the freezing $*#(* weather last night I was quite happy to waddle home and walk off that dinner.
author: Rebecca R.

description:
Last Friday, a coworker raved about this place over lunch.  That evening I made it my mission to experience it myself.
The evening started with some home brewed beer at mi casa followed by a short cab ride to Zarzuela.  (I wasn't about to walk those hills in my heels).
After about a 20 minute wait we were seated.  The restaurant has a casual atmosphere. The service was outstanding.  

Paella, paella, paella.  Sangria, Sangria, Sangria.  Sing it with me now.

I walked home in my heels happy as a camper.
author: Ashley Q.

description: When everything else sounds boring and bland I walk over to Zarzuela.  Every single tapas item is delicious, and you can order about 8 unique dishes (plus wine) and walk out paying about 80 bucks for two - not bad at all considering the top quality seafood and meat they serve up.  The staff takes good care of their customers as well, making the experience that much more enjoyable.  Try the tripe, octopus, and sardines.
author: Victoria G.

description: Nice mellow neighborhood location. We walked so we did not have to deal with the dreaded parking. Catching a cab after dinner took about 3 seconds. The paella was fabulous and we had an anchovy salad  and a white bean tapas which were both very nice.  The service was good. I am new to tapas so not the expert on that but am becoming a bigger fan.
author: Eric K.

description: I'd been eying Zarzuela for months and when I finally stopped in... it was better than I expected! What a wonderful escape to Spain! I am a vegetarian and the waiter and I worked to pick out every dish that was good for me and every other dish that could be modified... I know I know... I'm probably missing out... but any place that works with you (esp on a busy Friday night) get high marks in my book. They have a great selection of wines and tapas for sharing with friends. Parking is horrible (expected) but you can take muni very easily (41 or 45). Bring your wallet, friends and sense of adventure... Zarzuela won't disappoint.
author: Alex H.

description: this is the best place for tapas. eat here and go to spain.
author: george robert v.

description: The tapas are authentic. The tortilla espanola was the real thing, however, I like it room temp... not refrigerated. I liked the food, but having lived in Spain I missed the actual "bar" where you can sip beer or wine and see the tapas. The atmosphere at this place was not very Spanish. I am still eager to find a place with some authentic Spanish atmosphere and food. I need to feel like yelling Ole after my first bite of Chorizo and sip of Rioja.
author: Claudia O.

description: The wait was 30 min at 8pm on a saturday night for 2 people, but once you're seated, the food comes out fast.  The tapas were tasty compared to what I had in spain over the summer.  decently priced, 4 tapas and a carafe of sangria for approx $60.
author: T Y.

description: Cute little Spanish tapas place in Russian Hill.  Great spot for a date or small groups because you can choose lots of tapas and share everything.  I like their sangria better than Cha Cha Cha, but they don't put as much fruit in it.  There is no bar there to hang out and get a drink, but you can go to the wine bar down the street.  The food here is pretty authentic.  Considering Spanish food isn't my favorite, this place gets 4 stars for having pretty good food.  The quaint atmosphere is relaxing too.
author: Vanessa Z.

description: I'm not sure how this make Michael Bauer's Top 100 Bay Area restaurant list.  It's just another tapas bar in San Francisco.  I think there's better food on Hyde.  I loved our waiter though, and I want to adopt him as a great-uncle or something.
author: Alyssa W.

description:
I enjoyed Zarzuela. Our waiter was funny and attentive. He suggested the special almond stuffed fig wrapped with pancetta and it was amazing! Definitely try this if they still offer it. 

We also had the paella, which was really quite good. We ordered it for 4 and it was just right. The quail tapas wasn't really that good, but the chorizo one with roasted garlic was good.
author: Paul H.

description: After passing this place a billion times and noticing that there is always a line I decided to go during the week and see if this place is what I imagined it to be.  Nope- it was better than I thought!  We had a couple of tapas...good food-good service-good prices.  =)
author: Maria E.

description: Small plates for a small person!  Well, you don't have to be small at all for this place, because the food fills you up fast!  I'm a total non-veg, but I went w/ a vegetarian friend, and we only ordered vegetarian food, and it was amazing!!  Who knew roasted peppers by themselves would be so delicious???  The service was fabulous too.  We had a cute little Spanish guy making sure there was always something on the table, and he was quick too!  The chocolate souffle at the end topped off the wonderful dinner...  All you Russian Hillbillies -- this is a must!!!
author: Labonee M.

description:
sangria= water

food= oil

ambiance= eh. 


water+oil+eh = zarzuela, never again. 
(food was so oily I felt so horrible afterwards! feelings much worse than eating foie gras icecream!)
author: Hannah W.

description: Good tapas, but low variety. Service is high level, very soft mood style. Nice for a quiet restaurant, but i expect more variety for a tapas bar. I will say that I would probably go again, just because the food was good!
author: Preethum P.

description:
My evening at Zarzuela almost got ruined before it even started.  I was to meet my friends in front of Zarzuela by 7pm and wanted to take a cab to Zarzuela because parking in Russian Hill is horrendous.  I called Yellow Cab to arrange for a pickup at my house at 6:30pm.  15 minutes go by and nothing.  I'm watching a DVR recording of the Cal vs. Tennessee game (Go Bears!) and don't even notice until 30 minutes go by.  Befuddled, I call Yellow Cab again, only to be told that the designated cabbie must have forgotten the assignment and they would send another cab right away.  Another 30 minutes go by and I am pissed.  Finally, I get Luxor's number and call them for a cab and they send one to my place right away.  As I'm heading over to Zarzuela via Luxor Cab, I call Yellow Cab back to complain and the beeyotch friggin' HANGS UP ON ME.  SCREW YOU, YELLOW CAB!!!!  I showed up at the restaurant an hour late as a result, but fortunately my friends only held the table for 30 minutes for me because Zarzuela has a 'No Reservation' policy.  Needless to say, I won't be using Yellow Cab anymore because nobody, and I mean nobody, gets between me and my dinner!

Food:  5 stars.  The sangria here is way better than most Spanish restaurants.  I should know, since I drank alot of it after my whole taxi ordeal.   Everything here was so good, including the fish of the day (sea bass), grilled scallops, and grilled lamb chops.  The oxtail stew was good as well, but I wish there was more meat (and less fat) on them bones.  We also had the mussels, poached octopus, calamari, piquillo peppers, sauteed mushrooms in garlic sauce, and sauteed shrimp in garlic and olive oil (wish they gave you more shrimp).  For dessert, we had the flan, bread pudding, chocolate cake and mango cheesecake (all were good, but the cheesecake was the best of the bunch).

Service:  4 stars.  Our waiter was extremely genial, animated, and comical at times.  I felt like a tourist at a friendly restaurant in Madrid (only with better food).  He was also on point in terms of helping us determine the amount of food to order and balancing out the seafood and meat items.  I'm only subtracting a star for a lack of a reservation policy.  Nobody likes to wait for a table.

Atmosphere:  4 stars.  The restaurant, with its tiled floors and stucco walls, has a very homey, traditional Spanish feel to it.  The crowd ranges from young couples to casual families.  I'm subtracting one star for the families with young kids.  Nobody likes to eat with kids around - that's what Chuck E Cheese is for.

Hits:   Chuletas de cordero (grilled lamb chops), vieiras a la plancha Romescu (grilled fresh day boat scallops), torta de queso (mango cheesecake).

Misses:  Parking is a bitch, taking Yellow Cab to the restaurant, no reservation policy.

If You Like This Place, You'd Probably Like:  Cesar, Terzo, Thirsty Bear
author: Keith C.

description:
difficult parking.
no reservations.
very cold up on that hill waiting outside for dinner.
but super tasty paella (2 order size only) -- the rice made it my favorite dish.
rest of the dishes are quite classic spanish.
tapas perfect for sharing of course, and enjoyed most of them.
sangria on the weak side.
author: Rob C.

description: I give them 3.5 stars on the food, but 5 stars on the sangria. Get the carafe of sangria. They don't skimp on the alcohol (no ice in the carafe) so you really get your moola's worth. The mussels were my favorite, the paella is so-so. They offer a selection of tapas as well as full meals. I love that it's a neighborhood destination, but be prepared to wait awhile- they don't take resos. But you can pop over to Bacchus for a drink while you wait. Skip dessert and head over to Swensen's for a scoop.
author: Defne A.

description: Who knew... delicious tapas, original beers (Alhambra), simple yet sophisticated flavors, and I didn't even have to leave my neighborhood nor put on a black shirt.  While nothing was out of this world, everything we had of the affordable menu was great, with the exception of the Spanish Tortilla (psst, it's just a plain cold omlette). So come to Russian Hill for a few bites of authentic.  Enjoy the laid-back, yet elegant setting.  And leave with a sense of culinary content, some money left in your wallet, and a healthy wobble.
author: Calvin N.

description: Easily one of the best waiters I've ever had. The atmosphere was great as well, as we were lucky to get a table by the window and be seated immediately. The food was very good but not mind-blowing. In order of preference: Lamb tenders, Fried squid, Stuffed peppers with crab and oysters (one of the specials) , Chorizo, Salmon w/ green beans...
author: Nicolas H.

description: I went there with a large group of friends and we tried practically everything on the menu.  now, to be perfectly fair, i've not tried many tapas places before so i have no clue how they fare versus others.  i would say that the food overall was good, but nothing that really sings to the soul.  it's been about a couple of months and i vaguely remember enjoying the paella and a very good flan.  other than that, i don't remember anything that really grabs ahold of me or compels me to revisit this restaurant.
author: Bob C.

description: First time eating tapas, but after reading the other reviews here, I expected more. No surprise on the difficulty finding parking, and I was pleasantly surprised that there was no wait, but the food was really just so-so. The rice in the paella was undercooked (urgh!) and there was no sausage or detectable saffron. The poached octopus was admittedly a gamble, but it was surprisingly lacking in flavor. The fried potatoes in red sauce (supposedly the dish by which tapas bars are compared, according to my friend) was mediocre - we both agreed. However, the scallops were good, and the sangria was just right. Not enough for a return visit, though.
author: yolanda y.

description: Fab tapas (the seasoning and flavors are awesome).  Fab atmosphere (charming, cozy, and warm).  Fab sangria (I always drink lots).  Fab for a party of two or a party of 8 (really great for groups).  But not so fab wait and not so fab service (sweet as pie although a little slow). I will say it takes some experimenting to figure out what dishes you like (there were some that just weren't for me although good).  Overall it's one of my favorite spots in the city.  Especially when I top it off with some Swensons.
author: Em S.

description:
I really liked this place. My roomate has raved about the Menudo for a year so when the opportunity arose, I took advantage. I came in looking for the Paella, but alas, it wasn't in the cards last night.

Three tapas (2 cold, 1 hot) and a small entree for two people was perfect:
1. Goat cheese stuffed eggplant
2. Onion, zucchini, tomato "stew"
3. Whole roasted prawns
4. Mahi Mahi special

The goat cheese eggplant was really tasty. Easy to eat, and especially good if you combine it with the pitted kalamata olives that come with the bread. I simple but delicious starter.
The stew was also very cool. Its more like a marinated veggie salad, served cold, which tastes great. Pretty straightforward, but my gf and I really enjoyed it.
The prawns were probably the only dish I wasn't completely pleased by. They come head on, which does not bother me, I actually think the heads are underrated; the problem was the fact that they come shell on, which, to some people might be just dandy, but for me made eating them a little hard. Really delicious though once you battle your way in there -- they had a great rub/marinade.
The Mahi Mahi was a special, and came in what I think (almost done with a pitcher of Sangria at this point) was a basil sauce. The fish was pretty standard, nothing to complain about but I think we can agree that Mahi Mahi tastes pretty blah to start with. Don't get me wrong, I ordered it so I do enjoy it, its just more like chicken than say salmon. 

All in all a great dining experience and on the cheap, plus we were treated to an amazing song from Arturro for an eight-year-old's birthday, which was pretty great. I highly recommend.
author: Jeff G.

description: Good God this place has good tapas. My favorite dishes are the goat cheese in tomato sauce, the duck, and ummm...pretty much everything I have ever ordered. Unfortunately the sangria is whatevs (who serves it on ice???) and the lines can be a bit long because they don't take reservations. Would recommend coming here with a group of 4-6 so you can try EVERYTHING! Even my snobby NY friends like this place. Will definitely be back.
author: Sadia J.

description: Zarzuela is great and I will definitely be returning.  It is the perfect place to take a date.  The food and service are outstanding.  If you are looking for great Spanish tapas and sangria, look no further.
author: John C.

description: I was not impressed at all. Nothing we tried was really that great. The best dishes were the calamari, grilled lamb on skewers, and the sauteed shrimp in garlic and olive oil. The worst (meaning flavorless and nothing special) were the fried potatoes, potato and onion omelet, the grilled eggplant filled with goat cheese, and the Spanish style sausage (it was way overcooked). The sangria was fine though they added the fruit to the glasses and it wasn't soaked in the wine like I'm pretty sure it is supposed to be. I don't think I would ever come back to this place again. I'd much rather go to Picaro in the Mission.
author: Jenny C.

description: I used to be a Yelp frequenter until I sent me to Zarzuela.  Zarzuela is mediocre.  We ordered a lot of food to ensure we've tried a good assortment of food.  The waiter was unable to provide any recommendations.  I would normally suggest giving Zarzuela a try yourself... but, don't bother, skip it... go to Solstice or ChaChaCha.
author: Dan S.

description: The Paella was a bit undercooked for my tastes, but still decent. The Sangria, lamb tapas, and stuffed mushrooms were excellent.   We had a very nice waiter but It wouldn't have hurt the host to crack a smile. We got there at 6pm on a Friday evening and just barely beat the dinner rush. People seemed to be waiting for a good 20 minutes for a table.
author: Tien H.

description: Zarzuela used to be the best spot for tapas but not anymore. The search for a new and great tapas place continues!!
author: Reza E.

description: After reading the stellar reviews on Yelp, I was really thinking this place would hit it out of the park... I was so wrong. Clearly they have a really loyal neighborhood following, but it really was meh. The waiter didn't seem that into us, but made a huge effort with regulars around our table (not a big deal to me; we were unwinding and fine being left alone). We had the goat cheese with tomato sauce, ham, garlic shrimp, octopus, and chorizo. Literally nothing was delicious. We ate everything as we were starved, but left feeling unsatisfied. The pro's: it was extremely affordable.
author: Lauren L.

description: Tapas were somewhat tasteless. I had just eaten at Esperpento in the Mission, which was unfortunate for Zarzuela because there was no comparison. Everyone raves about this place but I have no idea why.
author: Allison B.

description: A friend lives near by so I'd seen this place for years but it wasn't until recently that we finally got to try it. It's a very cute place, and yes, parking is awful in this neighborhood, welcome to my hell. The garlic sauteed shrimp was impressive, very good flavors. I did not expect to enjoy the octopus but it was very well made and came out quite tasty! The eggplant with goat cheese so delish. The empanadas were pieces cut from a larger pie but it was still quite good. The croquettes were good but I seem to remember they didn't come with anything to dip or garnish them, and I like a little sauce or something. The sangria was good but very sweet, it's also very strong, we all got a little loopy on just 2 or 3 glasses from our carafe.
author: Melissa W.

description: After reading all the reviews for Zarzuela, I was SO excited to eat there...until I actually did.  I found the tapas to be mediocre and uninspired.  The special mushrooms were merely sauteed sliced mushrooms in oil and garlic....something I could easily prepare at home, same with the shrimp.  The goat cheese and crostini was very bland and disappointing.  However, the sangria somewhat mediated the whole meal.  Overall, the food is decent but not special....
author: Lisa L.

description: Loved the squid on a slab!  The sangria didn't get me completely wasted (or red faced)  before the entree arrived which was a miracle.  Not a really good place for a date - only because your neighbour will be 2 cms away from you.  Looked at everyone elses food around me (which I aways do) and the paella looked super yummy!
author: Melodie Y.

description: I always enjoy my meals and the staff is just fantastic.  I find it cozy place on a foggy night and love the neighborhood atmosphere.  It can be loud sometimes if it is especially crowded but that happens when everyone is enjoying themselves.
author: Jennie M.

description: Our family has eaten here three times. Each time it gets better. The menu has the ability to be both authentic Spanish tapas and contemporary cuisine at the same time. Simply put, everything we had was delicious. From the mahi atop a bed of beans to the lamp chops, the food was beautifully prepared. Be prepared for a wait on a Friday or Saturday night; it's popular.
author: J R.

description:
The best thing I can say about Zarzuela is that there is a parking garage right across the street, so that should tell you what we thought of the food there. We love Tapas and frequent Cascal in Mountain View often. I was hoping for a similar experience when a friend invited us over for dinner at Zarzuela.... in vain.

The restaurant was very crowded for a Thursday evening and they do not take reservations. Since there was no room to stand indoors without getting trampled by waiters, we waited outside for a table to free up. When we were finally seated, it was at a long table in a corner such that the three of us ended up sitting in a line making conversation very difficult.
We ordered the roasted peppers, the sauteed sausage in a wine sauce, the chicken and ham croquettes, shrimp sauteed in garlic, grilled lamb chops and a special plate they had of fried dates on a skewer. The food arrived remarkably fast - I'll give them that. However, with the exception of the dates, all the other dishes were considerably lacking on the flavor front. The waiter did not replenish our bread basket either. We ordered a carafe of Sangria for the table, but found it so  distastefully weak that we ended up leaving a lot of it unfinished.
Not worth the drive from the south bay.
author: Ush C.

description:
hmm.. delicious... my friends and I came here with a fairly large group (8) last weekend and didn't have to wait that long even though we just showed up around 8p.  

The food menu I saw is different than what's listed on the menu pages, but I still distinctly remember some of the dishes including goat cheese, chorizo, potatos fritas, and their special mushroom dish which was out of this world.  
A few us of also shared the large NY steak which was very nicely done and cooked to perfection.  I also recommend getting a cheese plate that you can eat with bread and olive oil since sharing small plates in a large group may not satisfy everyone's hunger (aka me).  

Even with sangria and a bottle of wine, I think the price is very reasonable as I recall paying less than $25 with tip per person which is unheard of in my group...

Overall I was pretty impresseed and would definitely go back another time for another try.
author: Ken S.

description: Spanish tapas in an older, neighborhood-y feel restaurant. Of our dinner, the duck leg confit, mussels, Spanish chorizo, and squid with aioli were standouts; the squab, ham croquettes and desserts not so much. The crema catalan, essentially a crème brulee, had a rather displeasing smoky flavor from the burnt sugar, and the chocolate cake soaked in espresso and brandy was probably store-bought. But otherwise a nice little corner place. It was very quiet at 6 pm on a Tuesday night, but was at capacity by the time we left around 8 pm.
author: J C.

description: This place does terrible things to my digestive system.  I think it's all the grease and fried stuff- a couple of hours later I'm never in good shape.  It's cheap...I think that's the only good thing it has going for it.  Since you're waiting at either place, go to Bocadillos.  It's WAY better.
author: Amy K.

description: Because of all the great reviews we went here on a Thursday night around 7:45pm and got a table in the back room near the kitchen which was still intimate and warm. Everything was delicious and the sangria was great. Good service even when the place was packed. Ordered 4 desserts and loved 2 of them one a sorbet like cake and the bread pudding. Yummy. The chocolate one and another one (can't remember) were just ok. We closed the place down! A great place for tapas you can be sure. And so reasonably priced too. Only bad thing which they can't help is parking is a bitch! Good luck finding a spot. Start praying for the parking fairy 20min before you arrive,..your going to need all the help you can get. But don't let that detour you from coming here as they have really good Spanish Tapas. Ole!
author: J G.

description:
Even after coming back from a trip to Spain, I couldn't wait to go to Zarzuela. Romantic atmosphere, authentic paella, great tapas and best sangria in town. What else do you need? 

Parking can be challenging but if you arrive early and are prepared to drive around, it's not such a big deal. Somehow, we always get lucky and end up going for a walk in the neighborhood and enjoying the views .
author: M K.

description: Most authentic Spanish cuisine I have sampled in the Bay Area. Finding Spanish restaurants or a Tapas place outside of San Francisco is hard to find. In the city, there a number of places, but none that really come through in quality across the whole meal, and none that offer the authenticity of Zarzuela. Zarzuela's tapas really hit the spot when you are looking for this type of cuisine, and their small but decent selection of Spanish wines and sangria, compliment the cuisine perfectly.
author: Fadi M.

description:
Que Delicioso!

IMHO this is the BEST Spanish tapas restaurant in the city.  I try to take all my friends here so they can enjoy authentic Spanish tapas and some of the best sangria around.

If you do end up going I highly recommend the croquetas, jamon serrano, tortilla, and the chorizo - you really can not go wrong with these dishes.

One word of advice - this is in Russian Hill - which means parking is a BITCH.
author: Mike A.

description: You will want to taste everything off this menu. The service was perfect. The plates were delicious. We had a small wait for a table late on a Wednesday night. No reservations so plan to spend a few minutes for a table in their waiting room sans bar. The goat cheese in tomato sauce was amazing as was the sausage.  For dessert try the chocolate sponge cake. Nice choice Rioja bottles for a decent price.
author: C J.

description:
Went to dinner with 3 others did the tapas thing, got 7 dishes and some sangria. Service was good, however the food was Eh. Certainly didn't blow me away. I was bitter the blue angels only flew for 5 min but that is beside the point. I was also dam hungry from walking around the city looking for a cab. 

I'd go elsewhere for small plates again.
author: Michael K.

description: Decor was very European, which was nice.  Service was great.  Tapas...eh.  Not as good as Cha Cha Cha's, but they put up a good fight.  We got the calamari, mussels, chicken croquettes, mushrooms, oysters, and, of course, the goat cheese.  One question: did everyone else's goat cheese have grapes in it?  I was just confused because there was like two halves of a grape in there and I thought it must've been some kind of mistake.  Otherwise, it was delish.  Not sure if I would run back here right away, but it's in a cute neighborhood, so maybe!
author: Michelle L.
