description: Pretty good. The tapas were authentic and tasty. I'd highly recommend that Meat Pie of the day (if you aren't vegetarian of course!). I subtracted a star for the ambiance - a little on the loud side. It was very reasonable priced for the city. And you can always grab a Swensen's ice cream afterwards!
author: Heidi B.

description: I know the menu off by heart and seriously want to have the maitre'd's children. The food is always top quality and authentic, plus if you are a regular you definitely get special treatment in being seated. I wouldn't come here on a date, as it's not especially atmospheric, but it is a great place to hang out with a group of friends. The Rueda is highly recommended!
author: jane t.

description: This has been a go-to place of mine since 1998, when I lived across the street. What can I say, a real neighborhood gem. Authentic no frills Spanish tapas, done the real way. The waitstaff and host are all very professional, friendly, and best of all, Spanish. It's also a very reasonably priced menu (it used to be a lot cheaper but I guess inflation finally caught up with them). The protocol for Zarzuela, since they don't accept resevations, is to put your name down (Friday and Saturday nights are the best nights to go), then tell the host you'll be at Bacchus Wine Bar, several doors down on the same of Hyde Street. Hang at Bacchus, a tiny, electro-groove, urban/modern wine bar until the host calls Bacchus to alert you that your table is ready. Head over to Zarzuela for a great meal including paella, spanish sausage, mussels, grilled lamb, sauteed mushrooms, squid, etc. Enjoy!
author: Scott H.

description:
Omg! So I was lucky enough to visit one of my Best's friends in the City after the New Year and she took me to this place over in Russian Hill. It was probably only my second time I've ever tried Tapas before. I consider myself to be an adventurous eater and will try anything when the opportunity is there. This place had my mouth soulful with every bite I had. If you go here, you have to try the goat cheese in Tomato Sauce, and eat it very slowly because you will be able to enjoy it more since it's that good. The sauce is Perfecto and delectable. We also tried their crab cakes, and I'm not much of a sea food eater, but they were the bomb! Each cake melted in my mouth! Savor the taste as best you can because it's that good! Next we tried the Tortilla Espanola, which are wedges of potato, onion and egg. To me it was like having a slice off a quiche! It was yummy! And you must try their empanadas, the ones we tried were made with tuna and garlic, very D'lish! Their Patatas Bravas were tasty too, which are potato wedges in a hot sauce...Spicy the way I like it, 'cause of my Latin roots! Ha ha... 

The ambiance is lively, and you don't need reservations, but if there is a wait time, it's usually about 15 minutes the most. There is inside waiting down a stoop, but makes you feel like you're in a dungeon! There are chairs outside, perfect to see the Cable Cars go by! 

Overall this place is really good, but I've had better Sangria. It was o-tay. Not the best though! 

I'd go for some fine wine next time!
author: Karla A.

description: It was okay.  I went with high expectations, so take this review with a grain of salt, but I just didn't see the magic.  There wasn't a single memorable dish- just a lot of bland food.  Maybe if I had been drinking sangria I would have a different opinion.  The saving grace is that the food is relatively cheap.  For the price it isn't a bad restaurant, but it didn't live up to the hype.
author: Chris T.

description: Go, just go.The parking situation is ugly but it was worth circling the block 20x. Nice ambiance and the food comes out fast. Each dish was unique and delicious! The wine/desserts were excellent. Try the queso platter!
author: Anne m.

description: Excellent small plates (don't even bother flipping the menu for the entrees), a great wine list and charming staff make Zarzuela my new neighborhood favorite!
author: Katie C.

description: I specially like the extended variety of the menu selection, as well as the authenticity. The service is great, regardless the large number of people that usually gathers at the place, mostly on weekends. It's a little pricy, but the quality of the food and the warm atmosphere balance out. Best choice for a great dinner night!
author: Rosa L.

description: Decent food, good atmosphere.  Some of the stuff was a little eh, but overall it was nice.  Didn't feel full until an hour after the meal.
author: Eric M.

description: Love this place. When we lived in Russian Hill years ago this was one of our favorite neighbourhood hangouts. Hardly a week went by without a visit. We go back from time to time, and its hardly changed at all. The most consistently good tapas I've had in the US, and you can't go past a few pitchers of Sangria between friends. Try just about anything.
author: Roger D.

description: I thought most of the food lacked flavor but it was pretty inexpensive.  The sangria was only so so.  It is a cute place but I doubt I'd go again.
author: Seong P.

description: A decent tapas restaurant at a decent price.  The key (to me) in making a great tapas restaurant is a wide variety of foods (to encourage experimenting) at reasonable prices (to make experimenting possible).  Zarzuela does both reasonably well.  Expect to pay $30-40 a head, but rest assured that you'll eat well and have a good time.  Good sangria, although the price is a little high.
author: Ben P.

description: This place is delicious! I love the mushrooms and sausage, the small dining room, the friendly staff.
author: Sara W.

description: My husband won't go back, he says it's too salty.  But then, we started with the olives.  I had one really good meal here and one so-so meal here.  I would stick to a weeknight if you are going to go.
author: T-Bone L.

description: Not American-style tapas, or French-style tapas, or Indian-style tapas, like you find so much of in the city. More like airlifted-a-restaurant-straight-out-of-Spain-style tapas. The croquets were so good that we managed to get a vegetarian friend to eat them. A pitcher of Sangria is a must when you come here.
author: Dana L.

description: After reading all the reviews, I can't believe I didn't get a glass of sangria.   I was stuck with a group that was drinking bottles of wine.  The tapas were definately different for the most part from what I've had at other tapa places.  The octopus dish, potatoe pie thing, calamari and the paella were all good.  I wasn't a fan of the goat chese dishes, but that's just me.  The service was friendly and they kicked down my friends a couple of desserts for the occasion.  Now I have to go back for the sangria!
author: Jason A.

description: Let's face it: the choices for tapas in the SF Bay Area are pretty slim, and good Spanish ingredients are hard to find in our Italian-dominated deli scene. As the daughter of a Spaniard, my taste buds have been anointed with plenty of tortilla de patatas, thick and musky olive oil, pimientos de piquillo and jamón serrano, so anything sub-standard just doesn't make it. However, if you can't fly to Spain to get your tapas fix, head over to Zarzuela and you'll have plenty of delicious tapas to choose from. My favorites include the chorizo al vino, patatas bravas, gambas al ajillo and the croquetas. As a family of four we order two of each of these, then sample a few others to complete our garlic-infestation quota. Plus, we go through at least three baskets of bread to fill up. The wine list is pricey, but they features some lovely Spanish Rioja that is impossible to find at most restaurants. Dessert lovers will enjoy the mango cheesecake and the brazo de gitano. The only issue with Zarzuela is the parking: Russian Hill residents and Lombard Street tourists are the competition, so plan on walking up several hills.
author: Rebeca M.

description:
I recently reviewed a place in the Mission called Ramblas, which also had Spanish Tapas.  The difference in the dishes at the two restaurants was remarkable. (I gave Ramblas a 2 star rating by the way).  We tried 4 dishes, all which were reasonably priced, but I can only remember 3 of them....I usually don't like cold tapas but the the tortilla espanola (egg/potato/onion omelette) was tasty ( and since it was the last slice, we got it free which is always great!), the chicken fried with ham/cheese was good, but my favorite was the sizzling shrimp sauteed in olive oil and garlic.  Wow.  First of all they gave us a healthy amount of shrimp..I believe 9-10... , while Ramblas served 4-5 garlic shrimp that were bland.  There was so much garlic on these shrimp it made the dish kind of spicy...but in a good way.  We went on a Friday night and the wait was kind of lengthy, especially since I was starving, so I might go on a week night next time.  But all in all a great spanish tapas place, I definitely look forward to going back and trying a few new dishes.

Update 5/27/06 - Took some friends here for Memorial Day Weekend and the Sangria was marvelous.  My friends raved and raved...  I also tried the Empanadas (vegetable and cheese) and that was my favorite tapas dish and I also had the ensalada espanola with tuna and roasted peppers, which was ultra yummy.  Try it.  Another great experience here and I'll have to bump this place up to a 5 star rating.
author: LaSha G.

description: Zarzuela is so consistently good!  After a four year hiatus from the Russian Hill tapas spot, I recently went back with a (large) group of friends.  Service could have been better, but the food was still delicious and the sangria still tangy!  Top three dishes:  grilled oysters, eggplant with goat cheese, and mushrooms.  Though it's first come, first serve for tables, don't be deterred.  Walk down Hyde and hit Bacchus wine bar for some pre-tapas libations and they will call you when your table is ready.
author: Tracy E.

description: This is the best tapas restaurant in the city.  I recently lived in Barcelona for a year and Zarzuela comes the closest to matching the authenticity of the Spanish cuisine that I ate everyday for a year.  Try the Pan con Tomate with the Jamon Serrano....it is just like Spain.  Also, the tortilla (some people refer to it as the "egg thing"), the mushrooms, the garlic shrimp, and the patatas bravas are excellent.  I've been to Esperpento and it was disgusting.....
author: Steven M.

description: Decent, but nothing special.  Patatas bravas were good, oyseters good too, but the seafood stew was nothing special, and the broth a bit pasty for me.  Too noisy, they should really use some tapestries on the wall to help with the noise level.  Better tapas to be found in the Mission, and more reasonable prices...
author: Ken and Yuri Q.

description: This quaint place in Russian Hill reminds me of Spain. I've never been. All over the walls were plastered maps of Spain and painted pictures of food. We had 4 dishes of Tapas and a salad. The house salad i highly recommend if you like blue cheese. The lamb was well don and juicy. The breaded chx was ok, and 5 out of the 6 desserts listed all had custard!  Bet on the sangria!
author: Peter N.

description:
This place is incredible...my friends and I came because one of my friends was recommended this place by her Spanish co-worker.  We came around opening time to avoid the waiting lines.  

We ordered the paella to share and each of us picked something else to share between all of us.  I was so excited, as this was my first experience at a tapas place.  Each dish was amazing, although the price was not worth some of the small portions that were given.  

However, my mind totally changed when I tried the mussels.  I felt like some kind of ravenous water bird that had tried seafood for the first time - a bird with taste buds rivaling those of a human's.  It was so fresh, so clean, so everything, and more.  "It ain't nothing like the first timeee" resounded in my head.  Damn.  

We had desert too and that was delish.  I can't wait till I turn 21 and can get some yummy sangrias...mmm.

Parking is an extreme bitch - carpool or take public transportation.  Every other element was fantastic, including the service.  Can't wait to go back.
author: M Y.

description: This is a great place for a date, family dinner or catching up with friends.  Upon entering we were immediately greeted by friendly staff and seated.  There was a group celebrating a birthday and one of the waiters sang her a beautiful song in Spanish (wish I understood) in a deep baritone, none of that cheesy happy happy birthday cheering.  The sangria was tasty and the food was delicious.  I would highly recommend this place to everyone.
author: Mo B.

description: Everytime I head to Zarzuela, I have a blast!  The paella is excellent, the staff is attentive and lively and the tapas are exceptional.  Even if you don't have reservations, stop by, the wait is usually not too bad.  Grab some sangria and relax......
author: Max C.

description: This is a local spot for me and always an easy choice. the first few times the staff as a little bit stand-offish but the duck and lamb kept us coming back faithfiully. the last time we were there, however, we had the sweetest waiter. i wish i could bring him everywhere i go so that he could be my designated waiter through life. he was attentive and thoughtful.
author: angela g.

description: Excellent spanish tapas, fun atmosphere. The octopus and potato dish is terrific.
author: Ross W.

description: Good eatin' here. Order the paella which comes in a huge skillet. All the disparate ingredients are cooked and seasoned to perfection, which I have found is something of a rarity in the paella business. Either you get overcooked shrimp or something else is not right - This place does it right. I have been to Barcelona, even some nice places there, this place beats them... What's up with that?! Good for us San Franciscans anyways. Other Tapas are great and the owner is a very nice guy. Check it out if you ever manage to find parking on russian hill.
author: Sven S.

description: This is a really good authentic Spanish restaurant.  The tapas, paella, and sangria are very tasty.  There can be quite a wait and the parking is horrible but defiantly worth trying!
author: Michelle M.

description: Honestly, the tapas were pretty run-of-the-mill.  It's been a few years since I lived in Spain, but based on the crowd this place attracts, I really got my hopes up for some Grade A tapas.  It gets a B- ... better than average, but just barely.
author: Chris R.

description: Zarzuela, visited on January 6, 2010, has a casual and cozy vibe with delicious hot tapas (did not order cold tapas or entrees).  Notably excellent tapas include the grilled calamari with aioli, steamed octopus with potatoes (you could really taste the savory seafood broth!), sauteed mushrooms, sauteed shrimp. The tortilla, chorizo, croquettes and paella were nice.  I also enjoyed my glass of dry crisp sherry and sangria.  Went very well with the tapas and complimentary olives, bread and dipping olive oil.  A pleasant surprise was the fact that the tapas were not overly salted and I didn't feel the need to ingest large amounts of alcohol and water.  If you don't want to wait for a long time for a table-as there is no indoors waiting area, recommend to come here before 7 pm (open at 5:30 PM), and preferrably mid-week.  You're also more likely to find street parking in this area earlier, too (but note, 2 hr parking until 9 PM).  Just a reminder, this is a Chronicle top 100 restaurant and endorsed by Gary Danko.
author: Lark A.

description: Wow, this is definitely THE place for authentic Tapas and Paella. Noticed that many of the negative comments revolve around the service, but that was certainly not our experience this evening; service was attentive and helpful. If you're in the mood for really great tasting Spanish fare then this is it. Be prepared for a bit of a wait and they don't take reservations, but what's a little wait for knock-your-socks off food? Eat it and love it.
author: Slaton C.

description: We stumbled upon this restaurant as it is on the cable car route on Russian Hill.  Excellent authentic tapas for a reasonable price.  The food and service were excellent and I understand why there was such a long line up to get in. Next time in SF we will definitely go back again!  Loved it and would highly recommend
author: susan r.

description:
first, the tapas here were super disappointing.
second, they have a picture of EL VALLE DE LOS CAIDOS, which is essentially a way of saying that they love spanish dictator FRANCISCO FRANCO, which is disgusting. i mean, would you eat at a german restaurant where there was a picture of hitler hanging on the wall of the restaurant? ugh.
author: stella k.

description: What a wonderful restaurant.  The people are so welcoming and friendly!  We lucked out and arrived right as a table was ready.  Ordered sangria, sauteed mushrooms, baked goat cheese, short ribs, and a chicken and wine dish.  Everything was delicious and we wiped the dishes clean with our bread.  Quite a neighborhood gem!
author: Emily F.

description: 5 of us ate here together, and all 5 of us walked away with happy stomachs and big smiles.  The service was excellent, our waiter had a fantastic knowledge of the wine and suggested something that, at least to my taste buds, seemed to fit perfectly with our feast.  The lamb chops, the shrimp, the fried jalapenos, the duck... You get the point.  Just go and everything you eat will be amazing.
author: Morgen N.

description: Gracias Zarzuela, my favorite tapa's restaurant in SF.  You have impressed everyone I have ever brought and have worked your way into my heart.  Your food and service are wonderful and with the parking lot down the street - you are my one sure thing.  A huge beso to the chef for making the most wonderful croquettas that have ever hit my lips and for introducing me to Miura wine.  xoxo
author: EVELYNE E.

description:
i really dig this place. part of its irresistable charm is the fact that it doesn't try to be anything other than what it is - a welcoming neighborhood restaurant specializing in solid, "authentic" spanish fare/tapas. no trying air of "hip" or "cool." the food was terrific! Their scallops with romesco sauce was simple and delicious; every sip of the crab bisque was loaded with savory smoky, crustacean flavor; their meat and potatoes dishes are hearty and satisfying, with the perfect accompanying sauce. the service is just fine. 
i'd definitely go back again and again.
author: jennifer y.

description: Parking, like most of the city is tough.  But it is worth the trouble, as this place has above average service and very good food.  The atmosphere is inviting and easy going.  Muy Bien!
author: Scott A.

description:
Note: Serge S. is my boyfriend and his review is half-truth. = ) I totally warned him that if you want good Spanish food, it would be a safer bet to go to the Mission. He didn't listen.

When I studied abroad in Europe, Barcelona was one of my favorite places to visit due to their amazing dishes and the dining experience. I was so excited to recreate that experience in SF, but fell really short. Pulpo- one of my favorite Spanish dishes that I hadn't found on any menu yet except Zarzuela's just didn't have the same strong flavor, all I tasted was the olive oil. All the dishes in fact were quite bland.

As for the dining experience, service was good, but decor resembled more of an Italian Restaurant and I was hoping for something a little more authentic and spirited.
author: Samantha F.

description:
3.5 stars.

The service was attentive and professional. The food was good, but I was kinda disappointed with how many fried options they had. Maybe we just made bad choices ordering and missed their specialty dishes. 

The $20 carafe of sangria wasn't anything special. Although this place may be "authentic", for tapas, I'd rather go to Cha Cha Cha or even Solstice.
author: Jenna F.

description: Arrived at 6pm on a Friday night and found seating right away.  Parking was a different story.  Probably better if you are a local in the neighborhood and can walk.  Definitely worth the trip.  Relaxed atmosphere with excellent food.  By the time we finished, the place was packed and full of good energy.
author: Carol B.

description: Okay, so I would say minus 1/2 star for inattentive service...not bad service, just not a "can I get you something else because your drink seems like its almost empty" kind of service. However, the food more than made up for it. The plates are definitely small, but the price is right. We went on a rainy night so we got to sit right away. The empanadas and the stuffed eggplant had to be my favorite...or maybe the mussels...or maybe it was the sangria that washed it down every so nicely!! Regardless we ordered two rounds of plates and a few pitchers of sangria and still didn't break $150 (for 4 of us!!) Definitely would go back...added bonus- ice cream right across the street!!
author: Jess W.

description: I really like the tapas idea.  We went with another couple and it made the dining experience that much better being able to try a little bit of everything.  I also tried for the first time oysters and snail, which I did not care for.  However, the goat cheese with tomato sauce, chorizo, mushrooms and sangria were very good.  The place is very small and cozy.  The server wasn't the nicest and was more than ready for us to pay our bills and leave.  Overall it was a neat dining experience.
author: Rise G.

description:
3.5 stars. This is a tough one. I think part of the problem was that we ordered too many larger dishes (fideus con marisco + rabo el toro) and could only fit patatas bravas for a tapas dish. I think I'll have to go back again retry other things, but I wasn't too impressed by the dishes I ordered. Great Sangria, could drink that up easily... Although good, it only hinted at my wonderful adventures in Spain last year (oh how I miss you...) - please remind me of the places in Grenada where we had free tapas if you ordered more alcohol *I know I know I'm just getting greedy now*. 

Patata Bravas was a waste of space in the stomach and was by no means super flavorful - just think fried potatoes with a bland tomato sauce. I miss the aioli that comes with patatas bravas and the slight spicy kick. The oxtail was grea (rabo del toro), but veggies had a pretty bland blanched flavor, but the oxtail & soup itself was fabulous. The fideu con marisco was a slight waste of space - although the seafood was PERFECTLY cooked and just the right hint of sweetness/freshness, the noodles were salty. After reading the rave reviews, I will try it one more time just to make sure I didn't go on an off night. Worse comes to worse, I'll just come to drink some sangria....
author: Jeannette L.

description: The service here was pretty friendly, and the place had a really nice ambiance.  I had a good time drinking sangrias and looking out the window.  However, the food was just okay and tasted like something you could make at home.  Maybe that is the draw of this place.  There are better places you could go to for good tapas like Fresca or Alegrias.
author: Molly C.

description:
Thank you, Mr. Kornish, for telling me about this place in my high school Spanish class!  Been coming here for over a decade.  Same host, same servers, same delectable dishes.  My favorite restaurant of all-time!

Don't be afraid of the no reservation policy and long lines - just order a carafe of sangria when you put your name in with the host.  He'll bring the drinks outside so you can get the party started!  

Gambas, mussels, paella, serrano ham, scallops, croquettas, are the favorites.  Just look over to the other tables and ask the server what they're enjoying.  The server and your neighbors will be more than happy to explain it to you.
author: ojos de pelota H.

description: Great food, good variety and excellent for Tapas. Great specials and inexpensive wine made for a great experience for a small (3) group.
author: Austin S.

description: Solid, very consistent place.  Ive been there several times over the years, most recently last week.  Most of the time we go all tapas, as was the case here.  Everything is fresh and at least good; the fried mushrooms, croquetas and salpicón de mariscos were examples of this, as they could have used a little more oomphy something.  The mussels and garlic prawns were a level better, and the tasty, tender calamares and outstanding octopus on top of potato rounds were the best of the lot.  Service is always good, efficient without gratuitous pandering.  Portions are decent sized, yet $110 with tax and tip for 9-10 tapas and a half-bottle of wine shows the price creep over the years that allows them to open only five nights a week.
author: Ultiminio P.

description: This is my favorite Spanish restaurant in the whole entire bay area. Authentic tapas and paella and sangria... what more can you ask for? My favorite things to order are: tortilla espanola, jamon serrano, gambas al ajillio, the poahced octopus and paella. I have of course branched out and tried other things outside this list and have never been disappointed. The only reason this place gets 4 stars is that they don't accept reservations. In addition, parking is near impossible, but they can't help it...
author: Jennifer S.

description: OK- When looking for a tapas place, I think of  Good food, casual atmosphere, friendly service, reasonable prices..... This place has it all.  In my opinion the best in SF.
author: p w.

description: We sat in their back room on a very busy Saturday night two weekends ago, and had a waiter who made the experience incredible. He described the origins, ingredients, and technique of the dishes served, and spent the time, unhurried, to do so.....everything was superb....the bottle of albarino, the sangria, the dishes-----gazpacho, halibut, mussels, cheeses......
author: M M.

description: The atmosphere is quaint, service is great, and most of all the food is mouth-watering and delicious! The poached octopus is definitely on the list of recommendations. My favorite dish is the poached pears soaked in wine. Truly scrumptious and exquisite ending to a satisfying dinner.
author: Jessica C.

description: Excellent food, superb service and all around great experience.
author: TravelBug L.

description: Great tapas place.   I have a friend who is married to a Spainard and this is their favorite tapas place - and they drive up from Palo Alto.   I love the Sangria and all the tapas.  I also like to get a small order of the lamb chops to share.   The only bad thing is they do not take reservations but I've been lucky a few times with parking and getting seated right away
author: P S.

description: ehn...didn't see what the big deal was.  the food was ok.  I think it was about $80 for a dinner for two.  I ordered the shrimp- pretty good. some rice and pepper dish- not good at all. some other stuff- none of it all that memorable.  it wasn't bad...just not very memorable.  only cool thing is it's across the street from martin richards.
author: Yvonne Y.

description: I want to go back!! The sangria was great. The food was awesome. We weren't rushed, we got seated right away, and it is pretty centerally located so we could head out afterward.
author: michelle k.

description:
love it! love it! love it!

so far the best tapas i've ever had.  serving size is larger than usual so you get more bang for your buck.

paella portions are huge. don't order a lot of other stuff if you're planning to get paella unless you want to be stuffed like a pig.

their sangria is not bad either.

five stars for the food and service. minus one star for the parking.
author: J S.

description: This is a lovely restaurant.  Cozy and food is great. Sangria is amazing!  I agree with fellow yelpers that this place is not the most romantic, but if you like some good tapas once in a while, this is my pick for SF.  Minus one star b/c parking is a pain.
author: Maggie C.

description: I often visit Spain and absolutely love their food. Zarzuela definitely is authentic with their cuisine. I highly recommend their Sangria. My only comment is the time it takes to find parking....what a headache. I've resorted to parking several blocks away at a parking garage on Broadway. The only upside to parking that far away is that, from the time I leave the restaurant to the time I get to my car, I've cleared out the mild hangover from the Sangria and wine.
author: Bill D.

description: 6 years ago through some miracle, I found parking nearby 2 times so I could eat there twice and really enjoyed the food.  I recall a walnut salad that was very tasty as well as an excellent paella.  Since that time long, long ago, I must have been back at LEAST 15+ times but could NEVER find parking.  There are no pay parking lots or parking options nearby as far as I know. No doubt one of the most difficult areas to find parking that I have experienced in the city so far.
author: J M.

description: Be prepared for a LONG wait if you get here later in the evening.  The lamb is amazing but the portion size is small for the price [6 very small pieces for like $7].  The other dishes were good but really nothing special.  The menu does have a wide range of dishes, so perhaps the 7 we tried were just not the better ones.  There is an impressive wine selection, alas I was driving so I couldn't have much.  Perhaps I should give it a second chance but as it is now  I would recommend Esperpento for similar food quality at a much cheaper price.
author: Alured P.

description:
i rate this place somewhere between 2.5 / 3. closer to 2.5.

it was decent but there was nothing memorable about our meal.  all i remember about the food...is that there was nothing memorable about it.
author: Adela K.

description: Yum, yum, yum! This place is truly one of the Top 100 restaurants in the bay area. I wish I could remember all the delicious tapas we had on the night  I had the privilege of eating here. The restaurant is very interment, there is a small room off to the side where you wait for a table. You can order drinks while you wait. I would say we waited about 30 minutes. The dinner was incredible, we ask for recommendations and then selected a few choices that sounded good to us. The service was very good. Everyone working at the restaurant was totally attentive to our table. We took a cab b/c we knew that parking would be limited.
author: Kimberly C.

description: Comes for the tapas, stay for the sangria.  Good quality spanish style tapas and wonderful sangria.  The area helps as well since you have the option to make a real evening by starting at Zarzuela and depending on your mood hitting Bacchus wine bar down the block or veering off to Swensen's for dessert just across the street.  Fun environment, friendly staff, and we were able to sit 6 of us down ona  Friday night with not too long a wait.
author: Johnson H.

description: There are much better places in the city to eat tapas.  Def not worth having to head toward the Marina for either... barf (jk)
author: Kurosh H.

description:
Came in here last week for a group of 3 - dinner on a Friday (~8pm). The place was packed, but we lucked out as a walk-in and snagged a table in the backroom. Gracious waiter, although the wait was a little longer, but I can't fault them for being busy.

Dinner started off right with the bread basket and olives. I was surprised at how reasonable the prices were ($5-$10 per tapa plate) so we got the shrimp in garlic sauce, chorizo, and beef medallions in a light gravy. All the dishes we ordered were well-received. We also ordered paella for 2, and it was enough to fill us all up. Bonus points for the waiter pointing out that it was cheaper to get two glasses of wine, vs. a half bottle for the two who wanted to drink. I will come back and try other selections for sure, but I definitely recommend this place. 

Cost of dinner for 3 w/ tip = $90.
author: Reeny L.

description: A fabulous neighborhood restaurant, never disappointing.  Great for light meal or something more serious.
author: H.A. ..

description: We had eaten here a couple of times last year, but had not been back for several months. This used to be the holy grail when it came to tapas and sangria... what the heck happened? I was more than mildly suprised to see that the place has indeed deteriorated in the last year... everything is now just... well, average!
author: Godot -.

description: Zarzuela is a fantastic spot that has great tapas, prices and spanish wine list. Arturo is the man.  The wait can be about an hour when busy but that is why Bacchus is located close by.  Give them your cell phone number and go have a glass of wine. Enjoy!
author: MEK O.

description: Best damn tapas in san francisco, definitely a hidden gem. Need I say more.
author: Raj K.

description: The staff was really nice. The wine was fabulous. The food was not great. Four of us went to eat there. We ordered just about everything on the menu! When we ordered the duck, one small thigh arrived...not good for 4 people. Some of the fried tapas plates seemed like they had been frozed and then put in oil to cook. the pork medalions also seemed a little lean cuisine-like. Sorry, but that is just my opinion.
author: Sue S.

description: Its just like in the movies.  I hop on the trolley up hyde and walk half a block to Zarzuela.  Their food and service is top notch.  This place is great for a date or a big group of friends. The only thing bad I would say is that I found out I don't like goat cheese here :]
author: Brian D.

description:
What a neighborhood find!  Great Spanish tapas in a nice atmosphere.

The oysters with Romesco sauce, octopus, and shrimp with garlic are truly wonderful.  Other items mostly great as well.  Saffron salmon was slightly over-cooked and in general the daily special fish not as nice as some of the other choices menitioned above.  A few times I have ordered the octopus as a dessert.  Dessert menu itself is ok, but not as good as the octopus!

The sangria is good and the service is always without flaw.
author: Richard P.

description: 4 star food and and good service. The only complaint was the waiting area was a bit cramped and they didn't serve you a glass of wine while you waited. Prices are very reasonable.
author: Seann G.

description:
I was really excited to try this place after seeing good Yelp reviews, however I was quickly disappointed. The best part of my dinner was probably the sangria or the bread. 

My friend and I tried 4 different dishes, only one of which we were able to finish (not because of quantity but rather quality). We had the salmon (which was much to salty), roasted peppers (didn't know you could really mess this up, it was just drenched in oil and kind of bland), prawns (got to peal them yourself, not much too them), and duck (the only fairly decent part of the meal which we finished). Basically everything was drenched in oil, which is fine if it actually gives it flavor instead of just tasting like oil. 

There are a lot of tasty restaurants in the neighborhood, this is not one of them.
author: Vera C.

description: We visited this restaurant while in San Francisco over Labor Day weekend.  It was really busy that night, but we were able to get a table withing 20 minutes.  The restaurant itself is pretty small and cramped, but they make the best of the space. By far, this is my favorite tapas restaurant.  The Sangria was delicious....I just couldn't get enough!! The paella was also fantastic!!  I will definitely return the next time I am in San Francisco.
author: Tammy D.

description: After living in Spain it is difficult to find Spanish restaurants that live up to my "senoras" home cooking.  Zarzuela is the restaurant!  The food and sangria is to die for.  I highly recommend it.
author: Kasee F.

description: Great atmosphere, friendly staff and wonderful tapas. The marinated shrimp are outstanding. The sangria is a must!!
author: A D.

description: This is a great place for either a date or with a group of friends...they don't take reservations so try to go early or late.  The staff is warm and great about making recommendations. I loved the bisque, asparagus with proscuitto, white beans, shrimp dishes, sausage, and of course, the SANGRIA.
author: L C.

description:
I had never tried Tapas cuisine, so that was on the agenda for the San Francisco trip.  We picked Zarzuela after reading some good reviews on yelp. 

We reached there at around 7:00 pm. It was a weekday, so got a table right away. Our server was a slightly plump gentleman in his forties (my guess). He was very enthusiastic. We asked him about a couple of dishes and he described them quite accurately. This was helpful because this was my first time with Tapas food and I did not know what to expect. After consulting him we ordered the Sangria, a cold tapas and a hot one, and a pasta.

The sangria was very fruity. Significant other is not a wine person, but he liked it. It was little too fruity for me. They have a lots of tapas dishes. Our choice was restricted as we don't eat meat. We ordered Rollitos de Berenjena - grilled eggplant filled with goat cheese from the cold tapas menu. We liked the subtle flavor. I would enjoyed it hot. It seemed easy - I am going to try it at home. The hot tapas was Champinones al Ajillo - mushrooms sauted in garlic sauce. It was nicely cooked but a little bland for our Indian taste buds. Next was Fideos con Almejas y Mejillones - Vermicelli tossed with clams and mussels, tomato, white wine and herbs. Both of us liked this one. This too was bit too subtle but pretty good nevertheless.

I think the Spanish food is a lot like Italian food, only with less cheese and more seafood. Next time I go to a Tapas restaurant, I am going to skip the pasta and try more Tapas dishes. There are lots of interesting ones to choose from.

As for Zarzuela restaurant, it was a very good experience. The service is excellent and the food is great. If you are looking for a simple cozy place, definitely check out this place. Check their website for timing - it seems it is closed on Sunday.
author: SoCal G.

description: The food is good but nothing spectacular. We had the Spanish ham, gambas, croquettas, mussels, paella, goat cheese and the anchovies in vinegar. The anchovies is the only dish that I thought was pretty good. The sangria was great! The staff is also very friendly, attentive and the service is quick. We celebrated a friend's birthday here and our wonderful server sang the most wonderful birthday song in Spanish. He had also asked the celebrant to go ahead and pick a dessert off the list. However, when we asked for the check, the dessert was added on our bill.
author: Katherine C.

description: This is an awesome little spot!  Invited by some family friends for a catch-up dinner while I was in town, I knew I was in for a treat because my friend always knows some of the best places to go.  Seriously, the baked goat cheese in tomato sauce was one of the best things I've ever had.  I could eat it until I floated out of the room.  The roasted peppers were also amazingly great.   I realize that some would say that roasted peppers are easy to make, but the combination here is done well.  They are both crunchy and soft, flavorful but not over done.  Also, the mushrooms with garlic and herbs were done well.  We also had the tortilla (Spanish-style omelet) and it was delicious too.  The service was quite attentive, and the place filled up while we were there--a sure sign of a great restaurant!  Dessert was delicious too--we had the Crema Catalana and a rich chocolate dish of some sort that I loved as well.  Go!
author: Joolz M.

description:
Very good tapas.

Great chill, casual atmosphere and very tasty dishes that are not too big so you can get 6 to 10 between 2 people.

Sangria is not very good though, very watered down.

If they offer a special, jamon iberico, which is $28 (compared to $10 for normal serrano), don't skip it.  It is the most flavorful, rich, marbled ham I've ever had.
author: Tommy L.

description: Our favorite local hang-out...great sangria, good tapas, and friendly service, all for a good price, at least for San Francisco standards.  Head in before 7 pm and you can usally avoid a wait, but as is always the case with Russian Hill, parking is a bear.
author: Amy M.

description: Nice little place for tapas, a hidden gem in Russian Hill.  Nice menu selection and friendly service - they are great on recommending wines to pair with your meal so take advantage of that.  If you like mussels, be sure to order one of those plates.  Roasted papas not so spectacular...I've had better at Cha Cha Cha.
author: Erin F.

description:
Wonderful tapas. The Gaspacho is the best in the city that I have tried. It used to be the best overall but then I found something better in Portland. But I digress. Its hard to go wrong with Zarzuela's tapas. Your bill can add up fast if you order too much.

Parking is the pits on weekends. You are more likely to find an STD than a parking space in this neighborhood. Go on a rainy week day or take a cab to avoid the hassle.

Tables are small and packed together so its not ideal for large groups. You can easily see how many chicken croquettas are on your neighbors dish. But the place is not really noisy. Sometimes I had to wait 30+ minutes but on week days there is barely a wait.
author: Joe L.

description:
I loved this restaurant.  The food was wonderful (we had shrimp in garlic and olive oil...the BEST; paella; goat cheese with marinara; gazpacho).  The shrimp was amazing!!!  Paella was good, but I've def had better---next time I'll try more menu items and skip the paella.  The bread was good too-- very basic, but perfect for dipping.

Service was a little slow to start, but once our waiter came up to our table, service was brisk.  

We ordered the bread pudding and flan.  I'd skip them and get dessert somewhere else...or order more tapas instead!!!
author: courtney o.

description:
If you plan to dine here, prepare for the 20 min. search for a parking spot (the one drawback to this restuarant).

We (party of four) ordered 5 tapas, and a 2 person portion of the seafood paella.  The tapas were legit, I recommend the stuffed mushrooms.  The Garlic Shrimp tapas is also scrumptious.  The highlight of our meal was definitely the paella, it was just right. Even though we ordered a 2 person portion, there was just enough for the four of us (considering that we had all just ate five tapas).  Service was great.  Go to Swensen's (diagonally across the street) for ice cream afterwards.
author: CaliforniaGrown R.

description:
I used to be a big fan, but I hadn't been in a long time because I kinda forgot about it, but ended up there again the other night with friends.  I was glad that I rediscovered the place.

Amazing food, authentic dishes, great wines, good atomosphere and service.  It's well-priced as well compared to other restaurants of this caliber in the city.

Highlights from the menu for me were the gambas al ajillo, paella, arroz con leche, manchego cheese, goat cheese in tomato sauce, chorizo, and well, pretty much everything I've eaten there.

Once many years ago, I even dined at a table next to Danny Glover.  He looked like he liked it too.  So, don't take it from me...take it from Danny Glover and go try the place out.  You'll dig it.
author: Rob S.

description: I would give it 5 stars if the parking was better.  This place serves great sangrias and the tapas are delicious.  It's one if my favorite places for tapas.  Too bad the parking sucks.
author: Yen T.

description: Excellent tapas!  The food is amazing and the service was very friendly and warm.  If you have a love for Spanish food then I highly recommend that you try this establishment.  However, be warned that parking is NEVER available - you're better off walking or taking a taxi.
author: Daria i.

description:
Went here with another couple on a Wednesday around 6:30p for my girlfriends birthday.  Been here a few times and am a big fan.  We order a variety of tapas, at least one for each person and then split a 2 person paella .  It's a lot of food and is all excellent.  Sangria is quite refresshing too, not super strong.

The other thing is that the service is fantastic.  Even on a Wednesday it was pretty full, so there was a bit of an initial wait for the waiter to take our food order (though if you're into rushing in and out, a Spanish restaurant shouldn't be part of your evening plans), but no biggie we were there to enjoy the evening.  Having said that, once we ordered the food started arriving quickly, but not too quickly, it was all well paced out.

The best part is that the waiter, just by noticing a lone birthday card on the table came out and surprised us with a piece of birthday cake and a lit candle for all of us to share.  That's the difference between the hipster, "I'm angry to be working here" type of waiter and the staff at Zarzuela who are experienced, helpful, and truly professional.
author: Peter C.

description: The absolute BEST Spanish I've had since my trip to Madrid.  OK, kinda sucks that there are no reservations, but the Sangria is so worth the wait!  Serivce is impeccable and friendly at the same time.  Don't go cuz that means shorter wait time for me!!!!
author: Lee Y.

description: This spot is wonderful.  Wonderful service, great sangria, and make sure to ask what is fresh that night.  Not overly expensive and worth every penny.  Thank you Zarzuela for a great experience.
author: Chris D.

description: Since my last review, I've been back for the paella and it is completely deserving of 5 stars. I LOVE it here! Please see my previous review for more details as it all still applies.
author: Maria Y.

description: This was my very first tapas experience.  The service was superb.  Our waiter was extremely attentive.  The food was delicious.  Parking is difficult.  They don't except reservations so get there early!!!
author: e w.

description: great place for great tapas. Pricey but worth it. Wouldn't say that it's the best palce but overall a great. Parking is usually tight and hard to get, so be prepared.
author: Neelesh V.

description: It started with a beautiful mural outside the restaurant, took a picture and it looked awesome. Several people recommended us to come early cuz there is no reservations and difficult parking. Since it was a special day, our anniversary, 20 big ones! Nothing was going to go wrong, found parking 20 feet away and our waiting time for a table was 15 minutes. Corkage was standard, but it didn't matter with the bottle I brought, Estancia, Napa. Now the tapas, Calamare, Asparagus, Croquetas, White Anchovies and Snails. I was a little suprised when we got the Calamare, thinking it was deepr fried, which I love, we got sauteed! However the squids were delicately tender and flavorful, something new! Croquetas make the grade for a tapa restaurant in my book, crunchy on the outside, perfect! Boquerones, I could eat that all day, food was well plated, wife loved it! Snails on crostini was nothing to be proud of but it was ok. We had to skip the dessert menu cuz the ice cream shop across the street could not be ignored, hehe ! Our romantic evening was a success! Good Job Z !
author: Eddie I.

description: Don't like sangrias, but theirs were fabulous. Wasn't sure what to order so our waiter just started bringing us dishes he thought we would like. EVERYTHING was delicious and totally affordable. Fantastic!
author: H. E.

description: Always reliable, as close to Barcelona as I have found in the states. Andy, the owner, is gracious and Arturo, a wiater, is the best waiter I have ever had, anywhere, in my life of world travel. Great food, great wine list and all very reasonably priced. Only negative is parking, but its on the cable car line so no worries. Great neighborhood.  All around it shouldn't be missed!!
author: Marshall J.

description: zarzuela makes a mean paella.  their fried squid, poached octopus, chorizo, snails and mussels are some of my favorites.  i would say their food is pretty authentic.  tapa style allows you to try a variety of dishes.  parking can be a challenge....
author: Paulina C.

description: i'm a big big fan of this teeny tiny tapas spot! it's cute and cozy and nestled in nob hill; serving up some scrumptious spanish fare. a girlfriend and i chose this place for a catch-up dinner, and i was concerned at first that they don't take reservations. however, we had no problems and were seated at a two-top right away. we had a carafe of sangria, the patatas bravas, gambas al ajillo, marinated mushrooms, and eggplant rolled up with goat cheese. the eggplant was my favorite; tender slices of grilled eggplant gently hugging tangy pillows of goat cheese - heaven!! the other dishes were good too, but i would highly recommend this one. and all of that food, plus tip, for under $60! i would say that this small site is better suited for couples than groups, but i'm sure they would be accommodating for large parties. nice time you're in nob hill, be sure to satisfy your tapas cravings here!
author: Kris G.

description: I highly recommend Zarzuela for birthday dinners. Not only do you get to feast on delicious food in a cozy and charming Russian Hill tapas restaurant,  but you will get serenaded by the owner, singing a traditional Spanish birthday song. I came here with my friend for her birthday tonight without reservations and we had no problem getting a table right near the window. The service was attentive, friendly, and made our dining experience all the more enjoyable (as well it should be, such a change from the attitude you sometimes get at trendy SF restaurants). Before we ordered we were presented with an assortment of olives and bread, a nice snack while we waited for our first tapas to arrive. These included the Spanish tortilla- a frittata of sorts, with egg and potato and served with sumptously sweet roasted peppers as well as a vegetable stew. And if that were not enough, the main course- paella with chicken and seafood- left us glad we wore our stretchy pants to this culinary extravaganza. We also enjoyed sangria which, not overly sweet, was a fine compliment to the meal. Our night ended with a treat- the owner brought out a huge slice of moist chocolate cake and sang for my friend. It was a special moment indeed. Oh, and the cake was absolutely pure chocolatey  bliss laced with strawberry cream and sliced mangoes. I'll be going back to Zarzuela, even if there is no birthday in sight.
author: Kate A.

description: one of  my favorite spanish restaurants, can you say authentic..hell ya
author: augusto c.

description:
i love this place.  decent sangria (cheaper sangria and just as good would be at chachacha's).

i love the shrimp bisque.  everything else is decent and high end tapas.  i love the duck and the lamb.  and the mushrooms.  we fight over the potatoes. ;)

it is a bit expensive for tapas.

the desserts are divine.  kudos to their pastry chef!  pears poached in wine.  dessert has always been perfect.

i love their waiting area that is in the middle of the restuarant, very cozy.

nice decor.  fast service.  fabulous wait staff.
author: tc h.

description: This restaurant always makes me happy! Try everything -- you can't go wrong. I've spent a fair amount of time in Spain and this makes me feel like I'm there again.
author: Linda B.

description: I've lived in the bay area for 15 years; 8 of it in the city. I have driven/walked by this cute corner spot hundreds of times and have always wanted to make my way in. 8:00 on a saturday night is not likely the best time to try a new spot---there were people lined up outside but we put our name in anyway. We were a party of two and the owner told us to come back in 20 minutes. We walked down the street to an adorable wine bar thats about the size of a small closet and had a few glasses of wine---only to look up and realize we'd been gone for almost an hour. We sheepishly walked back in, passing the waiting people still outside and we were seated immediately. The owner HELD THE TABLE for us---in spite of people waiting outside to be seated. He said, "Oh.....there you are! You're table is waiting". The food was phenomenal--the paella was delicious and the sagria was top notch. Authentic tapas with a great atmosphere....what took me so long to try out this fantastic spot?!!! I'll be back, for sure.
author: P N.

description: I love this place. They don't take reservations. The spanish salad is the best in the biz, hands down. Crab bisque is fantastic. One of my SF fav's. Arturo is the man. Great staff, great service, great food. Parking is very tough. Expec tto cruise around for 30 minutes.
author: geoff h.

description: Food was decent but not as good as some of the other Spanish/tapas places in SF.  It's actually nice that the don't take reservations as you can get in on a Saturday night on short notice (you can down the street to Bacchus wine bar for a drink while you wait after putting your name in)
author: Brenda S.

description: San Francisco is not a tapas town and I know that and you should know that.  But Zarzuela gives me hope.  I had forgotten about this place.  I had come here years before but I think the atrocious parking memories put a huge dent on the wonderful food memories, causing me to neglect the place.  So sad but I went again last night and despite the parking that is still horrible (I circled around for like 30 minutes before I found a hidden spot by Vallejo and Leavenworth), I was in gustatory heaven.  My Barcelona flashbacks came with each bite of the boquerones, the pan con tomate (where they rub the tomatoes onto the bread), the jamon serrano, the manchego, the gambas ajillo, the pulpo, and finally, the crema catalana.  Yes, J and I ordered a LOT, but we did forewarn our authentic Spanish waiter, who was super nice.  All he simply did was smile and say, it will help with finishing the sangria.  Awesome, my kind of restaurant!  Zarzuela is not at fault for the parking, so five shiny stars.
author: Pelle Y.

description: This is one of my favorite restaurants in the whole city!  My boyfriend brought me here on our first date (needless to say, we're still together after a year :)) and I continue to bring friends and family here when they're visiting.  First off, the location.  I love the quaint corner it sits on as you watch the cable cars go by along the tree lined streets.  The atmosphere is fun and friendly; a true locals spot.  Now on to the food...I've tried many, many things here and I haven't been disappointed yet.  Start with a carafe of sangria.  You won't regret it ;)  Some of my favs: grilled eggplant with goat cheese, croquetas (amazing!), sauteed shrimp in garlic and olive oil, mussels in red wine, scallops.  It's all fantastic.  I've never tried any of the rice dishes but I smell them as they go by and well, that'll have to be next time :)  Prices are very decent too so you can get as little or as much as you'd like.  If you're not looking to spend a lot or don't enjoy the obscene amounts of food that these chains feed us nowadays, this place is the way to go.  Or, by all means, order 10 dishes and you'll still be pleasantly surprised.  Excellent food, fantastic ambiance, won't break the bank...get it?  got it?  good.
author: Kelly H.

description: Came here on a Friday night at 9:30pm (an hour before closing) and we waited 15 minutes for a table.  We ordered 5 tapas (dates with prosciutto and almonds, scallops with green beans, white bean stew, chorizo and meatballs).   Husband had a glass of sangria and I had a lemonade.  Total was $53.  Everything was good but the only standouts were surprisingly the dates with prosciutto and almonds and the meatballs.  Have had better tapas in NYC.  This place was very crowded and very noisy and people linger forever.   Nice for groups, not so nice if you want to talk rather than shout.  Service was good.  I will give it another try someday.
author: Mystic C.

description: This is hands down...the loudest restaurant that I've ever been to. We had paella and stuffed mushrooms. It was a bit overpriced and you will NOT find parking. Take the trolly.
author: Rose S.

description: i have been to zarzuela a bunch of times because it is a favorite of one of my friends.  definitely bring your peeps so you can try lots of tapas - everything is so good!  i love their sangria too.  on my most recent visit, my favorite things were the stuffed eggplant, chorizo, and shrimp.  i guess the only bad thing is that they dont take reservations which always bugs me.
author: Carolyn B.

description: Wow, a great place. Cozy atmosphere, attentive staff, perfect food. Tapas tasted were quail, shrimp, mushrooms with garlic, house salad, cold zucchini/ tomato ratatoule-style, flan. Two sangrias and coffee, $51.00. A new favorite by Russian Hill. Ten minute wait to get into the small intimate slightly crowded dining room with a friendly convivial atmosphere.
author: t m.

description: This is the second dining experience with my out of town guest.  He researched this place in HKG and wanted to compare with real Spanish tapas, he had in Spain.  It's at the corner of Hyde /Union diagonal to original Swensens icecream.                                                     We ordered two cold and two hot tapas. The cold was a grilled egplant wraping goat cheese, nice flavor but maybe a bit too much cheese, less would of been better.  The next cold dish was a vegetarian mish mash and was quite good, had the bell peppers, onions, olives, and some squash, good combination, spanish salsa.  The hot dish were some roasted imported green peppers, naturally sweet with a kick of spicyness at the end.  Finally pork medallons on a skewers and a dallop of mashed potatoes, was not impressesd, but did go well when eaten with the roast peppers.  We both had a bowl of the cold vegetable soup, gespacho,  was like a fancy fresh blended V8, good and refreshing on a hot day maybe.  For entrees we both ordered small portions, mine a roasted short ribs again with mash potatoes and his sea scallops with a red pepper sauce.  Both were good and fresh but nothing too spectacular.                                  My friend commented that they were close to the real thing in Spain, except there the portions were smaller and more refined.  Kinda like how some Chinese food is here, compared to HongKong.  Americanized usually means larger portions, but less fine prep work done on the food.  The service was good, our server seemed to be the real authentic Spainard, was friendly but not too overtly so.  The sangria was nice not too fruity.  Overall if you can't make it to this region of Spain anytime soon, give it a try.
author: Michael D.

description:
zarzuela's is a great place for a light dinner and some sangria. 

the three of us ordered 3 tapas dishes, paella, and a carafe of sangria.

the tapas came out almost imemdiately, closely followed by the sangria. 
we ordered the chorizo, omelette, and croquetas.
all three tapas dishes were excellent, in presentation, texture, flavour, and portion. 

the paella was also pretty good, however a couple of my clams were sandy and had that horrific "grit crunch" when eaten. also, the rice at some parts was not thoroughly cooked. besides that, the paella was well seasoned and portioned. the vegetables were great, as was the rest of the seafood. 

the sangria was great, had a slight sweet/bitter taste that i love, and quickly disappeared. 

zarzuela is a great place for a casual date or small (less than 6 people) group outing. it's not a large place and mass conversations of large tables (we sat next to a table of 10) on top of the loud music can overpower the entire restaurant, as happened when we went. 

all in all a fun experience, i'd love to go again.
author: Maihien N.

description: Zarzuela is a great restaurant -- if you're lucky enough to find parking or are in walking distance. The staff are welcoming and the food is delicious. On the rare warm San Francisco day, the Sangria is perfectly refreshing. They have an incredible assortment of delicious food to serve both meat lovers and vegetarians (like me). The baked goat cheese and potatoes with spicy tomato sauce were delicious. My seafood loving friends enjoyed their meals as well, although you may not want to order the shrimp if you don't like having to work hard to disassemble it for eating.
author: Janel A.

description: it wasn't as good as i expected.  if you're looking for tapas try cha cha cha's in the haight or cesar's in berkeley (a good excuse to go to east bay).
author: Lindsay T.

description: Vegetarians have to work just a little bit to find things that are suitable, but luckily the wine list is so extensive, you'll be able to take your mind off of it.  The small plates are tasty, but even more charming (to me) is the neighborhood-y community feel - like the restaurant has been around forever so you, the customer, are one of many.  It's nice that the ambience says that but the wait staff doesn't - and I agree with the yelpers who say DON'T DRIVE and GO EARLY.
author: Anjali K.

description: Great tapas here.  I come here often.  It's a great place for a reasonably priced date.  Rather lively environment and a friendly staff.  The food is consistently tasty.  I always get the chicken and ham croquettes as well as the lamp chops.  The sangria here is a great substitute for wine if you're interested in spending a little less.
author: Nate B.

description: Service is superb and attentive. No reservations as it fills up quickly.  The food was wonderful tapas style of course. We had the fish (seabass?), scallops?, potatoes, calamari, pulpos (octopus), cheese platter. 4 girls with sangria = lots of talking and flowing food OK?  All I know is that the food was tasty. Bill wasn't bad either. Too bad they don't have a bar as seating can be a wait.
author: Eesayah O.

description: Good, inexpensive food with a cool atmosphere -- I'm sure I'll go back.  The corner seat by the window is really nice.  The olive dish appetizer is a good touch, but I don't understand why they even bother with the bread -- very disappointing.  The tapas here were definitely good, but I felt they are a step below what you get a Pesce.  The pork medallions, short ribs, and Spanish potatoes are worth getting.  The chorizo was just alright -- same with the chocolate mousse spongecake.  The sangria gets a solid four and a half stars.
author: Luke P.

description: I lived in Spain a few years ago and fell in love wih it. One of my fondest memories (of many) was the food. Since I have been back I have only found one other place (in San Diego) that has a TRULY authentic feel to both the food and the ambiance. This place does it right. I travel to S.F. frequently, and one of the last times I was there, a colleague was about to take 20 clients to dinner at a restaurant that I wouldn't eat in if I was starving. I asked him to wait a minute, called Zarzuela, and they got us the back room all to ourselves with 3 or 4 waitstaff handling our every need. Granted, we spent a couple thousand on food and wine, so they were happy we were there, but I didn't see anybody not smiling in the main room either. The food was VERY authentic, and they have a good (not great) selection of Rioja's and Duero wines. One comment is that I would prefer sitting in the main dining room with the windows. The back room had none, and was a bit stuffy -- but considering our last minute reservation (on a Saturday) that was unavoidable. I would & will go back.
author: Robert D.

description: I'm still searching for a place in this city where one can find decent Spanish tapas, and Zarzuela doesn't really impress me.  The decor isn't Spanish at all, although they put up some Spanish posters.  The food is good, nothing impressive: the patatas bravas were good, the boquerones were tasteful,...  The service was not personal at all, the waiter couldn't recommend any tapas.  I'll keep on looking for good Spanish tapas in this city...
author: Marijke D.

description: The food here is not worth your time, I was very disappointed. All of the tapas we ordered were lacking flavor, and I didn't have a cold at the time. Maybe we missed out on something, but I would take a pass.
author: Mountbatten M.

description: cute lil' neighborhood authentic spanish joint with tapas and paella. loved the service here and felt very at home as if i was at my uncle's home. the sangria was good, too. only four stars because of parking and the wait. for a party of 2 people, we waited for an hour. ugh. but the food was delicious!
author: Mika D.

description: great paella and tapas.  friendly waiters.  but, no reservations and parking can be tough
author: Dawn P.

description: Super food, great atmosphere, and delicious sangria made this a solid 4 star rating.  I reserve 5 stars for truly exceptional experiences, but this does not mean that Zarzuela is anything less than perfect.  I loved walking in to the restaurant and seeing romantic couples on dates in the corners and hip city families filling in the middle tables.  We came on a friend date with someone so environment was key.  I personally love when a restaurant actually contributes to being able to have fun conversation, which Zarzuela did.  Maybe it was the European guy who had a cigarette in his mouth before he even left the restaurant.  Or maybe it was the perfect timing of the service.  When you order multiple dishes it is awesome when they keep bringing them out to you over the course of the night, like a veritable feast, rather than crowd your table with 10 dishes all at once.  The food was extremely tasty.  I'd go with anything with goat cheese, and the steak and short rib specials were delicious (written with a future diner in mind).  I am sure this restaurant does not score for most creative tapas, but sometimes that's not really the point now is it.
author: Denise G.

description: Great experience, great food, nice people, good service. The wait was a bit too long - we were told 30 mins, so we headed to the Sake bar near by, and drank our drinks fast enough to make it back in 30 mins - only to have to wait in the little waiting room for another 30 mins! I wish they had told us an hour from the start, so we could have stayed in the bar and enjoyed our sakes...
author: M K.

description: Their food is nice and fresh, but it felt way too crammed in there. The tables are place too close to each other and it's too loud. Smaller parties have to wait longer. I also felt rushed with their service.
author: August S.

description: Came here with friends on the advice of the reviews on Yelp.  I've been disappointed with the Spanish tapas choices in San Francisco since our trip to Barcelona several years back.  This one has been our best experience so far.  I heeded the advice that this place gets crowded, so we got there before 6pm on a Friday night, and it was already filling up.  Table to table, even in the back by 7pm, and very little parking in the neighborhood, unless you count the nearby garage for $20.  Luckily, someone pulled out near Van Ness & Union, and we just walked up about 3 blocks.  The restaurant is in a nice setting, tall ceilings, non-pretentious, with posters of matadors on top.  We got started with a pitcher of sangria, which was simple, not too fruity, with just that right amount of brandy and triple sec...delicious.  Our strategy was to sample as much as possible, so we skipped the main courses, and went for the cold and hot tapas.  All the portions were very decently sized...not huge, but definitely not leaving you feeling cheated, and priced very reasonably.  We started with the grilled eggplant stuffed with goat cheese...tasty, but not exceptional.  Next, we had the chorizo and the shrimp in garlic sauce.  The chorizo was actually underwhelming...I expected more of a kick, but I loved the shrimp...very tender, with fragrant garlic, and they didn't skimp on the olive oil.  Really delicious!  I've always enjoyed mussels in wine sauce, and this was again one of the highlights.  In my opinion, better than at a French place like Plouf...the sauce here was slightly smokey flavored, and I couldn't help but do the "buoy" with the bread.  Our friend had a vision of Patatas Bravas as she had them back in Barcelona, with this "special sauce", but unfortunately, they didn't quite match her expectations here.  The sauce was pedestrian...basically, just tasted like potatoes to me.  My favorite dish was probably the poached octopus.  I love octopus...raw, grilled.  This one appeared to be grilled first for that smokey taste I love, but then poached so they were so tender...the best of both worlds.  I think this was the favorite dish of everyone at the table...even people who weren't particularly crazy about octopus.  We had another pitcher of Sangria, and then for desert, 4 of us shared the poached pear.  It was pretty looking, but I'm not a desert person, so I had no real opinion about it.  Service was friendly and attentive, but not intrusive, as noted by others.  All in all, we were stuffed and sated, and with tip, it came to about $135 for a party of 4, which I think was well worth it.  I'm definitely coming back for the Paella, and am really happy I took the advice of Yelpers!
author: David C.

description: i give up on hyde street. first it was "frascati" -  shockingly bad. then "zarzuela" - better, but not good. the waiter was quite sweet. service just fine. but the food was overcooked, bland - kind of like eating leftovers reheated! that's exactly what it was like, actually. sangria? again, bland and boring. atmosphere? what atmosphere? no music. weird lighting. don't bother going to find out for yourself.
author: Nathalie P.

description: I was a tapas virgin before Zarzuela, and it set a pretty high bar for future tapas restaurants.  The prices are acceptable (for a tapas place) and the food is very well-prepared.  The sangria is also wonderful -- light, refreshing, and with bits of real fruit floating about.  The wait can be nasty on weekends though and people tend to camp outside before it opens, so be sure to get there early.
author: Ana L.

description: I ate here last night.  Food was great.  Some was quite simple, but the ingredients were all high quality.  We took the suggestions of our waiter and had the Serrano Ham on toasts w/ tomatoe, chorizo, shrimp in garlic & olive oil, seafood salad, asparagus & these delicious fish/potato croquettes with aoli.  Seafood salad was amazing & every element retained it's own flavor - so often with ceviches everything gets masked by too much dressing.  Finally, we had a good bottle of Sauv. Blanc - total bill was under $80.  Unbeatable for price & quality.  Will definitely be back.
author: Alicia M.

description: Came here with some friends the other night and would definitely recommend it.  We went family style and every dish was delicious -- the goat cheese in tomato sauce, the tortilla espanola, the patatas bravas, the grilled calamari -- all definitely worth a try.  We also got a carafe of sangria and it was some of the best sangria i've ever had -- not too sweet but very flavorful.
author: Mike D.

description: Awesome all the time.  Never had a bad meal there.  Order up on the hot and cold tapas.  They're all soooooo good!  And then you have to order the seafood paella.  It's soooo good to eat.  I even hear the owner heads to Spain every year to the different regions to try new tapas ideas to bring back here.  I'm back there time and time again.  The wine selection there also is very good.  Pairs so very nicely with their menu.
author: Darin Y.

description: Solid spot.  I've never been to a Spanish Tapas restaurant before, so I wasnt sure what to expect, but everything was very good.
author: Richard C.

description: Best friend was visiting and we decided to go to our neighborhood tapas restaurant. Three people for plenty of food and a pitcher of sangria = $70. Service isn't super attentive, but who cares when you're focusing on the tortilla espagnol or empanadas of the day? Great food, value, and atmosphere. A staple of the Russian Hill neighborhood.
author: e w.

description: Charming neighborhood location in Russian Hill where you can watch the cable cars go by. Personable service. Excellent value.
author: Lawrence L.

description: There's a lot I really liked about this place.  The owners/servers were adorable and really friendly, and the crowd was jubilant and cheery, like they were all in the midst of family reunions.  Everything I had was good, although nothing was particularly memorable.  But, it was a great place for a group dinner and they were very accommodating.  Did I forget to mention that it's across the street from Swensen's?
author: P L.

description: I am not big on tapas.  I wasn't to impressed with Bocadillos, but Zarzuela changed my tune.  RUSTIC and authentic.  Great intimate experience.  I preferred the "spanish scampi"  plate, the octopus, the goat cheese in a warm tomato broth, and the paella was stellar.  THERE IS ABSOLUTELY NO WHERE TO PARK, so take the hyde street cable car and get dropped off in style.
author: igor r.

description: nice food, nice ambiance, nice server, this place is not for romantic, gd for groups, last night came here with some friends. someone has her bday  &the server was singing happy bday in spanish w/ a beautiful voice & everyone's clapping. we ate: potatoes w/ tomato sauce, eggplant w/ goat cheese inside, grilled mushroom, croquette w/ ham&chicken, pearsalad, seafood rice paella & the fried octopus. So far, the food was nice but this place is not that luxurious, very casual & good tapas. not bad.....
author: Ms C.

description: Great place!  The dishes are delectable and quite a complement to the tast buds.  I came here a few days after I broke my elbow and was drinking Pinot Noir while being looped up on Vicodin.. Therefore, I don't remember much other than the food.  Which was pretty damn good if I remember it.
author: Marko C.

description: Andy - the manager/host has got to be the rudest a*hoe I've ever encountered in the industry.  He's got the charm of a neanderthal.  Put my name on list for two.  He says will be 30min & seats everyone that comes after me without a word.  I recheck where I am on the list & he says rudely - well, your other party is not here and it hasnt been thirty minutes.  I tell him it would be nice to know that you dont seat people if there party isnt there - but that my husband was parking the car.  He says - it can take 30 min to park the car here. My reply is that it can also take 5 minutes - but what if I want to be seated and order anyways? Wow - there's plenty of great tapas restaurants in SF - and one doesnt need to patron a restaurant where the management thinks that you are lucky to be partoning their restaurant.  There's no need to be rude or inconsiderate to anyone - and it's that kind of attitude that will result in bad karma for your restaurant.
author: Jane D.

description: i ended up going back unexpectedly the next week after giving the restaurant five stars.  the manager was endearing, which is a huge plus in my book , and the food was just as good as i remembered.  however, the sangria was less than tasty-- two of us had a big headache after a glass and one thought it tasted like cheap red wine.  bringing the rating down to three stars.
author: Victory V.

description: delicious food, recommend the mushrooms especially. it is very hard to park, after circling for 30 minutes we had to pay $20 for parking in lot for 1.5 hours. also because they don't take reservations you may have to wait a while. the restaurant is small but quaint.
author: I. K.

description: i've been back to this place several times. the chrorizo is really good here. we ordered two of these plates. this is a great date place. small plates to share :) or big ones too.
author: Miss O.
